Meanwhile Passepartout, who had perched himself on the lower branches of a tree, was resolving an idea which had at first struck him like a flash, and which was now firmly lodged in his brain. The plan seemed wild, almost desperate, yet as he watched the somber preparations below, it appeared to be the only hope left. He glanced down at the shadowy forms of the fakirs and the silent, expectant crowd, their faces illuminated by the flickering torches. 

His heart thudded in his chest as he silently slid down to a lower bough, careful not to rustle the leaves. The night air was heavy with the scent of incense and hemp, and the distant beat of tambourines grew louder as dawn crept over the horizon. Passepartout’s resolve hardened; he would act, no matter the risk.

Suddenly, the doors of the pagoda swung open, and a flood of golden light spilled out. In its midst appeared Aouda, draped in white, her face pale and serene. For a fleeting moment, she seemed to awaken, her eyes searching the crowd, but the narcotic fumes soon claimed her again, and she swayed, barely conscious, in the arms of the priests.

Sir Francis Cromarty, hidden among the onlookers, felt his pulse quicken. He gripped Phileas Fogg’s hand, feeling the cold, reassuring touch of the knife concealed within his companion’s palm. The procession began to move, the chanting rising to a fevered pitch as the fakirs led Aouda toward the funeral pyre. Passepartout, muscles tensed, prepared to seize the only chance that fortune might offer the brave.

---

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: He had remembered the peculiar ceremony he had witnessed at Bombay, when the priests had carried the young woman, Aouda, to the pagoda. He recalled the strange, rigid customs of the country, and the fatalistic resignation with which the natives seemed to accept their fate. But Passepartout, with his lively French spirit, could not reconcile himself to such a cruel destiny for the unfortunate victim. He determined, at all hazards, to save her. He had heard the conversation between Sir Francis Cromarty and Mr. Fogg, and he knew that the latter was ready to risk everything for the sake of humanity. Passepartout, therefore, resolved to act without delay. He slipped down from the tree, and, gliding through the bushes, approached the place where the priests were preparing for the sacrifice. The night was dark, but the moon, now rising above the horizon, threw a pale light over the scene. Passepartout crept silently forward, his heart beating violently. He reached the edge of the clearing, and saw the priests grouped around the funeral pyre. Aouda lay motionless, apparently unconscious, on the pile of wood. The priests were chanting a monotonous hymn, and the crowd of natives stood in a circle, watching the proceedings with awe. Passepartout waited for a favorable moment to act, his eyes fixed on the unfortunate woman whom he had resolved to save at the peril of his life.

events.title: Passepartout's Specter Act Saves Aouda
detailed_summary: From a short distance, the rescuers observe the unconscious Aouda being placed on the funeral pyre beside the rajah's body.
A torch is applied, and the oil-drenched wood immediately catches fire.
Sir Francis and the guide physically restrain Phileas Fogg, who appears poised for a desperate, sacrificial rush toward the burning pyre.
Fogg forcefully pushes them aside, just as the entire scene undergoes a sudden, dramatic transformation.
A collective cry of terror arises from the crowd.
The multitude throws themselves onto the ground, paralyzed by fear.
The supposedly dead rajah appears to rise miraculously, like a phantom, from the pyre.
He lifts his wife (Aouda) into his arms and descends, his figure made more ghostly by the swirling smoke.
The terrified fakirs, soldiers, and priests remain prostrate, not daring to look at the apparent supernatural event.
The spectral figure carries the lifeless Aouda with surprising ease.
Fogg and Sir Francis stand stunned but upright; the Parsee guide bows his head, and Passepartout's reaction is assumed to be similar shock.
The figure walks towards Fogg and Sir Francis and abruptly instructs them, "Let us be off!"
The rescuer is revealed to be Passepartout himself, who had secretly climbed onto the pyre amidst the smoke and darkness.
He successfully freed Aouda by impersonating the resurrected rajah with bold audacity, navigating through the terrified crowd.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: In the semi-obscurity they saw the victim, quite senseless, stretched out beside her husband’s body.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: It was Passepartout who, playing his part with a happy audacity, had passed through the crowd amid the general terror.

events.text_segment:
In the semi-obscurity they saw the victim, quite senseless, stretched out beside her husband’s body. Then a torch was brought, and the wood, heavily soaked with oil, instantly took fire.
At this moment Sir Francis and the guide seized Phileas Fogg, who, in an instant of mad generosity, was about to rush upon the pyre. But he had quickly pushed them aside, when the whole scene suddenly changed. A cry of terror arose. The whole multitude prostrated themselves, terror-stricken, on the ground.
The old rajah was not dead, then, since he rose of a sudden, like a spectre, took up his wife in his arms, and descended from the pyre in the midst of the clouds of smoke, which only heightened his ghostly appearance.
Fakirs and soldiers and priests, seized with instant terror, lay there, with their faces on the ground, not daring to lift their eyes and behold such a prodigy.
The inanimate victim was borne along by the vigorous arms which supported her, and which she did not seem in the least to burden. Mr. Fogg and Sir Francis stood erect, the Parsee bowed his head, and Passepartout was, no doubt, scarcely less stupefied.
The resuscitated rajah approached Sir Francis and Mr. Fogg, and, in an abrupt tone, said, “Let us be off!”
It was Passepartout himself, who had slipped upon the pyre in the midst of the smoke and, profiting by the still overhanging darkness, had delivered the young woman from death! It was Passepartout who, playing his part with a happy audacity, had passed through the crowd amid the general terror.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Phileas Fogg, accompanied by Passepartout and the guide, cautiously approached the motionless form of the young woman. The flickering light of their torches revealed her delicate features, pale and drawn, her eyes closed as if in a deep, troubled sleep. Around her, the silent forest pressed in, the only sounds the distant crackle of the funeral pyre being prepared by the priests. Fogg knelt beside her, his face set with determination. "We must act quickly," he whispered. Passepartout, his heart pounding, glanced nervously at the shadowy figures moving among the trees. The guide, trembling, urged haste, for the ceremony would soon begin.

With gentle hands, Fogg and Passepartout lifted the senseless woman, careful not to disturb the shroud that covered her. The guide led the way, picking a path through the undergrowth, away from the clearing where the priests chanted their incantations. Every step was fraught with danger; a single misstep, a snapped twig, could betray their presence. But fortune favored them, and they reached the edge of the forest unobserved.

There, in the shelter of the trees, Passepartout produced a flask of water and sprinkled a few drops on the woman's face. Slowly, she stirred, her eyelids fluttering open. Confusion and fear clouded her gaze, but Fogg spoke to her in gentle tones, assuring her of their good intentions. The guide explained, in her native tongue, that she was safe. Gradually, understanding dawned, and the woman, though weak, managed a faint smile of gratitude.

events.title: Escape Under Fire
detailed_summary: Shortly after the rescue, the four companions vanish into the surrounding woods.
The elephant rapidly carries them away from the scene.
The sounds of shouting and pursuit, along with a bullet whizzing past Fogg's hat, confirm their deception has been uncovered.
The actual corpse of the rajah becomes visible on the pyre.
The priests, overcoming their fear, realize an abduction has occurred.
They lead soldiers into the forest in pursuit, firing a volley of shots at the escaping party.
However, the fugitives on the elephant quickly gain distance, soon moving beyond the effective range of the bullets and arrows.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: A moment after all four of the party had disappeared in the woods, and the elephant was bearing them away at a rapid pace.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: They hastened into the forest, followed by the soldiers, who fired a volley after the fugitives; but the latter rapidly increased the distance between them, and ere long found themselves beyond the reach of the bullets and arrows.

events.text_segment:
A moment after all four of the party had disappeared in the woods, and the elephant was bearing them away at a rapid pace. But the cries and noise, and a ball which whizzed through Phileas Fogg’s hat, apprised them that the trick had been discovered.
The old rajah’s body, indeed, now appeared upon the burning pyre; and the priests, recovered from their terror, perceived that an abduction had taken place. They hastened into the forest, followed by the soldiers, who fired a volley after the fugitives; but the latter rapidly increased the distance between them, and ere long found themselves beyond the reach of the bullets and arrows.

But the fugitives rapidly increased the distance between themselves and their pursuers; and, ere long, found themselves beyond the reach of bullets and arrows.

chapters.chapter_title: CHAPTER XIV. IN WHICH PHILEAS FOGG DESCENDS THE WHOLE LENGTH OF THE BEAUTIFUL VALLEY OF THE GANGES WITHOUT EVER THINKING OF SEEING IT

events.title: Post-Rescue Celebration and Reflection
detailed_summary: The successful rescue mission concludes, bringing relief.
Passepartout expresses great amusement over his role in the exploit.
Sir Francis congratulates Passepartout warmly.
Phileas Fogg offers rare praise, saying "Well done!"
Passepartout deflects the praise, crediting Fogg and calling his own contribution a mere "queer" idea.
He humorously reflects on his brief impersonation as the husband of a venerable rajah.
Aouda remains unconscious from the ordeal, resting in a howdah.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The rash exploit had been accomplished; and for an hour Passepartout laughed gaily at his success.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: As for the young Indian woman, she had been unconscious throughout of what was passing, and now, wrapped up in a travelling-blanket, was reposing in one of the howdahs.

events.text_segment: The rash exploit had been accomplished; and for an hour Passepartout laughed gaily at his success. Sir Francis pressed the worthy fellow’s hand, and his master said, “Well done!” which, from him, was high commendation; to which Passepartout replied that all the credit of the affair belonged to Mr. Fogg. As for him, he had only been struck with a “queer” idea; and he laughed to think that for a few moments he, Passepartout, the ex-gymnast, ex-sergeant fireman, had been the spouse of a charming woman, a venerable, embalmed rajah! As for the young Indian woman, she had been unconscious throughout of what was passing, and now, wrapped up in a travelling-blanket, was reposing in one of the howdahs.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The rash exploit had been accomplished; and for an hour Passepartout laughed gaily at his success. Sir Francis pressed the worthy fellow’s hand, and his companion received his congratulations with evident pleasure. As for Phileas Fogg, he said, “Well done!” which, in a man of so few words, did not go without its effect. To which Passepartout replied that all the credit of the affair belonged to his master, and that he himself had only had a “queer” idea or two. He added, with a laugh, that he had been for a few moments the husband of a charming woman, and that, as a widower, he was in no hurry to marry again. Aouda, who had been restored to consciousness by the fresh air as they hurried away from the scene of her intended sacrifice, was now resting in the howdah, still weak from the ordeal she had undergone. The party continued their journey, descending the beautiful valley of the Ganges, but Phileas Fogg, true to his methodical habits, did not allow himself to be distracted by the scenery, intent only on the progress of his journey.

He looked out into the darkness, trying to pierce the gloom for some sign of the pursued. The monotonous rumble of the wheels, the occasional shriek of the engine, and the swaying of the carriage lulled him into a half-dreamy state, in which hope and fear alternated by turns.

events.title: Journey Continuation and Concerns for Aouda
detailed_summary: Guided skillfully by the Parsee, the elephant travels swiftly through the dark forest and across a plain.
They halt after about an hour's travel past the pagoda.
Aouda remains deeply unconscious; the guide administers brandy and water without effect.
Sir Francis, recognizing the symptoms of hemp intoxication, reassures the others about her current state.
However, he expresses grave concern for Aouda's future safety if she stays in India.
He warns Fogg that fanatics would find her anywhere in the country, even under English police protection.
Sir Francis concludes that leaving India permanently is her only path to safety.
Phileas Fogg states he will consider the situation.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The elephant, thanks to the skilful guidance of the Parsee, was advancing rapidly through the still darksome forest, and, an hour after leaving the pagoda, had crossed a vast plain.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Phileas Fogg replied that he would reflect upon the matter.

events.text_segment:
The elephant, thanks to the skilful guidance of the Parsee, was advancing rapidly through the still darksome forest, and, an hour after leaving the pagoda, had crossed a vast plain. They made a halt at seven o’clock, the young woman being still in a state of complete prostration. The guide made her drink a little brandy and water, but the drowsiness which stupefied her could not yet be shaken off. Sir Francis, who was familiar with the effects of the intoxication produced by the fumes of hemp, reassured his companions on her account. But he was more disturbed at the prospect of her future fate. He told Phileas Fogg that, should Aouda remain in India, she would inevitably fall again into the hands of her executioners. These fanatics were scattered throughout the county, and would, despite the English police, recover their victim at Madras, Bombay, or Calcutta. She would only be safe by quitting India for ever.
Phileas Fogg replied that he would reflect upon the matter.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The elephant, thanks to the skilful guidance of the Parsee, was advancing rapidly through the still darksome forest, and, an hour after leaving the pagoda, had crossed a vast plain. They made a halt at a ruined bungalow. The young woman was still in a state of complete prostration. Her eyes were closed, and her breathing was faint and irregular. The Parsee had poured a few drops of brandy down her throat, but the stimulant produced no effect. Sir Francis, who was familiar with the effects of the intoxication produced by the inhalation of hemp, reassured his companions on her condition. But he was less tranquil as to the future safety of the unfortunate woman. He was especially anxious that she should not remain in India, as she would be certain to fall again into the hands of her persecutors. He explained this to Phileas Fogg, and added that it would be impossible to protect her, even with the help of the English authorities. "The fanatics will find her everywhere," he said. "It is only by quitting India for ever that she can escape their vengeance." Phileas Fogg replied that he would see about it.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: The great beast moved with a steady, tireless pace, its broad feet making scarcely a sound upon the soft earth. Phileas Fogg, seated upon its back, maintained his usual composure, his eyes fixed ahead, while Passepartout, perched behind, clung tightly to the howdah, marvelling at the animal’s strength and endurance. The Parsee, guiding the elephant with gentle words and a light touch, seemed perfectly at home in the wilderness, his keen eyes alert for any sign of danger. The forest gradually gave way to open country, where the first pale rays of dawn began to pierce the lingering mists. Here and there, distant villages could be glimpsed, their thatched roofs just visible above the trees. The travellers pressed on, determined to make the most of the cool morning hours before the heat of the day set in.

events.title: Arrival at Allahabad and Passepartout's Shopping Errand
detailed_summary: The group reaches the Allahabad railway station around ten o'clock.
The railway line continues from here, promising arrival in Calcutta within 24 hours.
This timing allows Fogg to catch the planned steamer to Hong Kong.
Aouda is settled in a waiting room.
Fogg tasks Passepartout with buying necessary clothing and toiletries for Aouda, giving him unlimited funds.
Passepartout ventures into Allahabad, noting its significance as the 'City of God' at the confluence of the Ganges and Jumna rivers.
He observes the city's landmarks, including its fort-turned-prison, and finds its commerce disappointing compared to London.
He eventually locates an elderly Jewish merchant selling second-hand goods.
Passepartout purchases a Scottish dress, a large mantle, and an otter-skin pelisse for seventy-five pounds.
He returns to the station, pleased with his purchases.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The station at Allahabad was reached about ten o’clock, and, the interrupted line of railway being resumed, would enable them to reach Calcutta in less than twenty-four hours.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He then returned triumphantly to the station.

events.text_segment:
The station at Allahabad was reached about ten o’clock, and, the interrupted line of railway being resumed, would enable them to reach Calcutta in less than twenty-four hours. Phileas Fogg would thus be able to arrive in time to take the steamer which left Calcutta the next day, October 25th, at noon, for Hong Kong.
The young woman was placed in one of the waiting-rooms of the station, whilst Passepartout was charged with purchasing for her various articles of toilet, a dress, shawl, and some furs; for which his master gave him unlimited credit. Passepartout started off forthwith, and found himself in the streets of Allahabad, that is, the City of God, one of the most venerated in India, being built at the junction of the two sacred rivers, Ganges and Jumna, the waters of which attract pilgrims from every part of the peninsula. The Ganges, according to the legends of the Ramayana, rises in heaven, whence, owing to Brahma’s agency, it descends to the earth.
Passepartout made it a point, as he made his purchases, to take a good look at the city. It was formerly defended by a noble fort, which has since become a state prison; its commerce has dwindled away, and Passepartout in vain looked about him for such a bazaar as he used to frequent in Regent Street. At last he came upon an elderly, crusty Jew, who sold second-hand articles, and from whom he purchased a dress of Scotch stuff, a large mantle, and a fine otter-skin pelisse, for which he did not hesitate to pay seventy-five pounds. He then returned triumphantly to the station.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
The station at Allahabad was reached about ten o’clock, and, the interrupted line of railway being resumed, would enable them to reach Calcutta in less than twenty-four hours. Phileas Fogg would thus be able to catch the steamer which left Calcutta the next day at noon for Hong Kong. He would therefore gain some hours on the prescribed time, for the arrival at Calcutta, according to the programme, was not due till the following day, the 25th, at noon.

The train stopped at the station. Passepartout jumped out first, and was followed by Mr. Fogg, who assisted his fair companion to descend. Phileas Fogg intended to remain at the station until the departure of the train for Calcutta. He did not wish to leave the young woman alone, as she was still very much agitated. The purchase of the articles of toilet, which he had promised to procure for Aouda, could only be made at Allahabad. It was necessary to find a shop, and, at the same time, to see to the purchase of some clothes for the young woman, who was entirely destitute. Passepartout was charged with this commission, and started off for the bazaars, leaving Mr. Fogg and Aouda at the station.

The worthy fellow went on his errand, enchanted to use his feet again. They had been so long kept at rest by the railway, traversing the entire length of India at a speed of twenty miles an hour, that they craved the exercise. Passepartout found himself in the streets of the "City of God," one of the most venerated in India, being built at the junction of the two sacred rivers, Ganges and Jumna—the waters of which attract pilgrims from every part of the peninsula. The curious thing was, that Passepartout seemed to be as little affected by this place as his master. He entered a shop, and bought a complete outfit of travelling clothes, such as a woman of European taste would require; and, being generous, he did not haggle over the price, but paid for the articles at once. He also bought a large mantle, a Scotch dress, and a splendid otter-skin pelisse, for which he paid seventy-five pounds. He then returned triumphantly to the station, well satisfied with his purchase.

He was disappointed in the bazaar, which he found to be less brilliant than those of Regent Street or Oxford Street in London. At last he came upon an old, crusty Jew, who sold second-hand articles, and from this merchant he purchased a dress of Scotch stuff, a large cloak, and a magnificent otter-skin pelisse, for which he paid seventy-five pounds. He then returned to the station, well satisfied with his purchase.

events.title: Aouda's Recovery, Description, and Fogg's Generosity
detailed_summary: Aouda begins to recover from the effects of the drugs administered by the priests.
Her consciousness returns, and her eyes regain their gentle expression.
The narrative includes a poetic description of an Indian queen's beauty, implying Aouda possesses similar charms in a European sense.
She is noted to be a charming woman who speaks English purely, confirming the guide's assessment of her upbringing.
As the train prepares to depart, Fogg pays the guide the exact sum agreed upon.
Passepartout is surprised, feeling Fogg owes the guide more for his devotion and the risks taken.
He reflects on the danger the guide would face if caught by the Indians.
The question of what to do with the expensive elephant, Kiouni, arises.
Fogg resolves this by offering the elephant to the Parsee guide as a gift, acknowledging his devotion beyond the paid service.
The guide is overjoyed, recognizing the gift's immense value.
Passepartout applauds the gesture and bids farewell to Kiouni with sugar lumps.
The elephant affectionately lifts Passepartout with its trunk before gently setting him down.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The influence to which the priests of Pillaji had subjected Aouda began gradually to yield, and she became more herself, so that her fine eyes resumed all their soft Indian expression.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Passepartout, not in the least alarmed, caressed the animal, which replaced him gently on the ground.

events.text_segment:
The influence to which the priests of Pillaji had subjected Aouda began gradually to yield, and she became more herself, so that her fine eyes resumed all their soft Indian expression.
When the poet-king, Ucaf Uddaul, celebrates the charms of the queen of Ahmehnagara, he speaks thus:
“Her shining tresses, divided in two parts, encircle the harmonious contour of her white and delicate cheeks, brilliant in their glow and freshness. Her ebony brows have the form and charm of the bow of Kama, the god of love, and beneath her long silken lashes the purest reflections and a celestial light swim, as in the sacred lakes of Himalaya, in the black pupils of her great clear eyes. Her teeth, fine, equal, and white, glitter between her smiling lips like dewdrops in a passion-flower’s half-enveloped breast. Her delicately formed ears, her vermilion hands, her little feet, curved and tender as the lotus-bud, glitter with the brilliancy of the loveliest pearls of Ceylon, the most dazzling diamonds of Golconda. Her narrow and supple waist, which a hand may clasp around, sets forth the outline of her rounded figure and the beauty of her bosom, where youth in its flower displays the wealth of its treasures; and beneath the silken folds of her tunic she seems to have been modelled in pure silver by the godlike hand of Vicvarcarma, the immortal sculptor.”
It is enough to say, without applying this poetical rhapsody to Aouda, that she was a charming woman, in all the European acceptation of the phrase. She spoke English with great purity, and the guide had not exaggerated in saying that the young Parsee had been transformed by her bringing up.
The train was about to start from Allahabad, and Mr. Fogg proceeded to pay the guide the price agreed upon for his service, and not a farthing more; which astonished Passepartout, who remembered all that his master owed to the guide’s devotion. He had, indeed, risked his life in the adventure at Pillaji, and, if he should be caught afterwards by the Indians, he would with difficulty escape their vengeance. Kiouni, also, must be disposed of. What should be done with the elephant, which had been so dearly purchased? Phileas Fogg had already determined this question.
“Parsee,” said he to the guide, “you have been serviceable and devoted. I have paid for your service, but not for your devotion. Would you like to have this elephant? He is yours.”
The guide’s eyes glistened.
“Your honour is giving me a fortune!” cried he.
“Take him, guide,” returned Mr. Fogg, “and I shall still be your debtor.”
“Good!” exclaimed Passepartout. “Take him, friend. Kiouni is a brave and faithful beast.” And, going up to the elephant, he gave him several lumps of sugar, saying, “Here, Kiouni, here, here.”
The elephant grunted out his satisfaction, and, clasping Passepartout around the waist with his trunk, lifted him as high as his head. Passepartout, not in the least alarmed, caressed the animal, which replaced him gently on the ground.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The influence to which the priests of Pillaji had subjected Aouda began gradually to yield, and she became more herself, so that her fine eyes resumed all their soft Indian expression. Her charming countenance was lighted up with animation; her beauty, in the European style, was remarkable. She spoke English with great purity, and the guide had not exaggerated in saying that the young Parsee lady had been transformed by education. As the train was about to start, Mr. Fogg paid the guide the price agreed upon, without haggling; moreover, he added a gratuity, which astonished Passepartout, who thought all Englishmen stingy. The Parsee, with tears in his eyes, thanked them again and again. The gift of the elephant had completely overwhelmed him. "May he serve you well!" said Phileas Fogg, as he handed him the animal's reins. "Oh, sir," replied the Parsee, "you are too generous!" "Not at all. It is justice. Farewell, Kiouni!" Passepartout, not without emotion, patted the elephant's trunk, and offered him a lump of sugar, which the animal received graciously. Then, as if he understood what was said, he lifted Passepartout with his trunk, and deposited him gently on the ground. The train started off, and soon disappeared in the direction of Benares.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text:
The influence to which the priests of Pillaji had subjected Aouda began gradually to yield, and she became more herself, so that her fine eyes resumed all their soft Indian expression. Her pallor disappeared, and her features returned to their Indian quietude and repose. It was evident that the young woman had passed through a terrible ordeal. During the day, she recounted her history to Phileas Fogg and his companions. Born in Bombay, she was the daughter of a wealthy Parsee merchant. She received an English education, and from her manners and language, it was easy to see that she had not been brought up in the woods. She was married against her will to the old rajah of Bundelcund; and, knowing the fate that awaited her, she had tried to escape, but was seized and delivered to the priests of Pillaji. They had intoxicated her with fumes of hemp and opium, and had thus been able to induce her to submit to the sacrifice from which she had been rescued by the bold devotion of Phileas Fogg.

Aouda fully understood her deliverance, and the presence of her deliverer beside her filled her with gratitude. She looked at him with the utmost trust, and her eyes expressed all the gratitude she dared not utter. The train was about to start from Allahabad. Phileas Fogg paid the Parsee guide the price agreed upon for his service, without haggling; not a farthing more nor less. Passepartout would have liked to reward the man for his devotion and the risk he had run, but the Englishman contented himself with paying the strict sum stipulated. He did not even bargain about the elephant, for which he had paid twenty times its value. As for what to do with Kiouni, this was a question which perplexed all the party. Phileas Fogg at last resolved it by saying to the guide, "He belongs to you."

The guide's eyes glistened. "Your honour is giving me a fortune!" cried he.

"Take him, friend," returned Mr. Fogg, "and I shall still be your debtor."

"Good!" exclaimed Passepartout. "Take him, friend. Kiouni is a brave and faithful beast." And going up to the elephant, he gave him several lumps of sugar, saying, "Here, Kiouni, here, here."

The elephant grunted out his satisfaction, and, clasping Passepartout around the waist with his trunk, lifted him as high as his head. Passepartout, not in the least alarmed, caressed the animal, which replaced him gently on the ground.

The influence to which the priests of Pillaji had subjected Aouda began gradually to yield, and she became more herself, so that her fine eyes resumed all their soft Indian expression. Her pallor gave way to a warm tint, and her beautiful features recovered all their charm; the feverish restlessness of her manner disappeared, and she became once more a woman—beautiful, elegant, and full of life. It was thus that the poet-king, Udaya Singh, celebrated the queen, Aouda, in a poem which is still sung in the palaces of India:

"Was it a goddess, or a mortal woman,
Who, from the blue depths of the sky,
Descended to the earth, to inspire love and adoration?
Her eyes were stars, her lips the rose,
Her hair the night, her form a vision of grace."

But the European narrator, less poetical, would simply say that Aouda was a charming woman, in the European sense of the word, and that she spoke English with great purity, which confirmed the Parsee guide’s assertion as to her education. The train was about to start. Mr. Fogg paid the guide the price agreed upon, without haggling. Passepartout would have liked to reward him further, for his devotion and the risk he had run; but the guide had been paid all that was due to him. What was to be done with the elephant, which had been so dearly purchased? Phileas Fogg had already made up his mind. "Parsee," said he to the guide, "you have been very serviceable and devoted. I have paid for your service, but not for your devotion. Would you like to have this elephant? He is yours."

The guide’s eyes sparkled. "Your honour is giving me a fortune!" cried he.

"Take him, friend," returned Mr. Fogg, "and I shall still be your debtor."

"Good!" exclaimed Passepartout. "Take him, friend. Kiouni is a brave and faithful beast." And going up to the elephant, he gave him several lumps of sugar, saying, "Here, Kiouni, here, here."

The elephant grunted out his satisfaction, and, clasping Passepartout around the waist with his trunk, lifted him as high as his head. Passepartout, not in the least alarmed, caressed the animal, which replaced him gently on the ground.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Phileas Fogg, meanwhile, watched her with a quiet, respectful interest, never intruding upon her thoughts, but always ready to offer his assistance or a word of comfort when needed. Passepartout, for his part, was delighted to see the young woman recovering her spirits. He busied himself with a thousand little attentions, bringing her tea, arranging her seat, and doing his best to make the journey as pleasant as possible.

The train sped on across the Indian plains, the landscape rolling by in a blur of green and gold. Occasionally, a herd of antelopes would be seen bounding away from the track, or a group of villagers would pause in their work to watch the iron monster thunder past. The air was warm and fragrant, filled with the scent of distant blossoms and the promise of adventure.

Aouda, now more at ease, began to converse with her companions. She spoke of her childhood, of the days before her marriage, and of the customs and traditions of her people. Her voice was low and musical, and both Fogg and Passepartout listened with interest. She expressed her gratitude for her rescue, and her admiration for the courage and resourcefulness of the two men who had saved her from a dreadful fate.

Phileas Fogg, ever the gentleman, assured her that he had only done what any man of honour would have done in his place. He spoke little, but his words were always to the point, and Aouda soon came to rely on his calm judgment and steady presence.

As the train approached the next station, Passepartout grew restless. He had not forgotten the delays they had already suffered, and he was anxious to make up for lost time. He kept a careful eye on the time, consulting his watch every few minutes and urging the conductor to maintain the schedule.

At last, the train drew up at the station, and the travellers alighted to stretch their legs. Aouda looked about her with curiosity, taking in the sights and sounds of the bustling platform. Merchants called out their wares, porters hurried to and fro with heavy loads, and the air was filled with the cries of vendors and the clatter of wheels.

Phileas Fogg, ever mindful of his wager, wasted no time in making inquiries about the next stage of their journey. He learned that the railway would soon end, and that they would have to find another means of transport to continue their progress. Undaunted, he set about making arrangements, confident that he would overcome whatever obstacles lay ahead.

Aouda, reassured by Fogg's composure, felt her spirits rise. She looked forward to the adventures that awaited them, and resolved to face the future with courage and hope. Passepartout, too, was in high spirits, certain that with such a master, nothing was impossible.

detailed_summary: Fogg, Sir Francis, Passepartout, and Aouda board the train for Benares, giving Aouda the best seat.
The eighty-mile journey is completed rapidly in two hours.
During the trip, Aouda fully regains her senses.

Her companions offer her liquor to aid her recovery.
Sir Francis explains the events of her rescue, highlighting Fogg's bravery and Passepartout's clever idea.

events.text_segment: Soon after, Phileas Fogg, Sir Francis Cromarty, and Passepartout, installed in a carriage with Aouda, who had the best seat, were whirling at full speed towards Benares. It was a run of eighty miles, and was accomplished in two hours. During the journey, the young woman fully recovered her senses. What was her astonishment to find herself in this carriage, on the railway, dressed in European habiliments, and with travellers who were quite strangers to her! Her companions first set about fully reviving her with a little liquor, and then Sir Francis narrated to her what had passed, dwelling upon the courage with which Phileas Fogg had not hesitated to risk his life to save her, and recounting the happy sequel of the venture, the result of Passepartout’s rash idea. Mr. Fogg said nothing; while Passepartout, abashed, kept repeating that “it wasn’t worth telling.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Soon after, Phileas Fogg, Sir Francis Cromarty, and Passepartout, installed in a carriage with Aouda, who had the best seat, were whirling at full speed towards Benares. The train pursued its course at full speed, passing, as it were, through the midst of the beautiful country so often described in the travel books. The eighty miles between Allahabad and Benares were accomplished in two hours, and during this time Aouda completely recovered her senses. The pallor had left her cheeks; she became animated, and her beautiful eyes resumed all their softness. Her companions gave her a few drops of liquor, which revived her. She then began to look about her with astonishment, and asked where she was. Passepartout hastened to tell her what had passed, dwelling upon his master’s courage and the devotion of his companions. He omitted, however, to speak of his own share in the rescue; but Sir Francis Cromarty put him right, and recounted the affair in all its details. Aouda thanked them with tears in her eyes. Her charming voice trembled when she spoke of Phileas Fogg, and her glance was full of gratitude. The brave Englishman, however, did not seem to understand what she said. He contented himself with bowing to her in silence. During the journey, Sir Francis Cromarty and Phileas Fogg exchanged but few words. The former was deeply impressed by the conduct of Fogg, who had risked his life to save the young woman. Passepartout, meanwhile, was thinking of the strange series of events which had brought them to this place, and of the odd chance which had made him the instrument of their deliverance. He was proud, though he said nothing about it.

events.text_segment:
Aouda pathetically thanked her deliverers, rather with tears than words; her fine eyes interpreted her gratitude better than her lips. Then, as her thoughts strayed back to the scene of the sacrifice, and recalled the dangers which still menaced her, she shuddered with terror.
Phileas Fogg understood what was passing in Aouda’s mind, and offered, in order to reassure her, to escort her to Hong Kong, where she might remain safely until the affair was hushed up—an offer which she eagerly and gratefully accepted. She had, it seems, a Parsee relation, who was one of the principal merchants of Hong Kong, which is wholly an English city, though on an island on the Chinese coast.
At half-past twelve the train stopped at Benares. The Brahmin legends assert that this city is built on the site of the ancient Casi, which, like Mahomet’s tomb, was once suspended between heaven and earth; though the Benares of to-day, which the Orientalists call the Athens of India, stands quite unpoetically on the solid earth, Passepartout caught glimpses of its brick houses and clay huts, giving an aspect of desolation to the place, as the train entered it.
Benares was Sir Francis Cromarty’s destination, the troops he was rejoining being encamped some miles northward of the city. He bade adieu to Phileas Fogg, wishing him all success, and expressing the hope that he would come that way again in a less original but more profitable fashion.

events.title: Journey through Behar, Night Travel, and Arrival in Calcutta On Schedule
detailed_summary: Leaving Benares, the train travels along the Ganges valley.
The travelers observe the diverse landscape of Behar: green mountains, fields, jungles with alligators, villages, and forests.
They see elephants bathing and groups of Indians performing religious ablutions in the Ganges despite the cold.
The narrative notes these are Brahmins, hostile to Buddhism, worshipping Vishnu, Shiva, and Brahma.
A reflection occurs on how these deities might view modern, anglicised India with its steam technology impacting the sacred river.
The scenery passes quickly, sometimes obscured by steam.
Landmarks like the fort of Chupenie, Ghazipur, Lord Cornwallis's tomb, Buxar, Patna (opium market), and Monghir (industrial town) are glimpsed or noted.
Night falls, and the train speeds through the darkness amidst the sounds of tigers, bears, and wolves.
The sights of Bengal are hidden by night.
Calcutta is reached at seven in the morning.
Fogg has five hours until the noon departure of the Hong Kong steamer.
He checks his journal and confirms his arrival on October 25th, exactly as scheduled.
He is neither early nor late, having lost the two days previously gained during the journey across India.
The narrative suggests Fogg does not regret this loss of time.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The railway, on leaving Benares, passed for a while along the valley of the Ganges.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: But it is not to be supposed that Phileas Fogg regretted them.

events.text_segment:
The railway, on leaving Benares, passed for a while along the valley of the Ganges. Through the windows of their carriage the travellers had glimpses of the diversified landscape of Behar, with its mountains clothed in verdure, its fields of barley, wheat, and corn, its jungles peopled with green alligators, its neat villages, and its still thickly-leaved forests. Elephants were bathing in the waters of the sacred river, and groups of Indians, despite the advanced season and chilly air, were performing solemnly their pious ablutions. These were fervent Brahmins, the bitterest foes of Buddhism, their deities being Vishnu, the solar god, Shiva, the divine impersonation of natural forces, and Brahma, the supreme ruler of priests and legislators. What would these divinities think of India, anglicised as it is to-day, with steamers whistling and scudding along the Ganges, frightening the gulls which float upon its surface, the turtles swarming along its banks, and the faithful dwelling upon its borders?
The panorama passed before their eyes like a flash, save when the steam concealed it fitfully from the view; the travellers could scarcely discern the fort of Chupenie, twenty miles south-westward from Benares, the ancient stronghold of the rajahs of Behar; or Ghazipur and its famous rose-water factories; or the tomb of Lord Cornwallis, rising on the left bank of the Ganges; the fortified town of Buxar, or Patna, a large manufacturing and trading-place, where is held the principal opium market of India; or Monghir, a more than European town, for it is as English as Manchester or Birmingham, with its iron foundries, edgetool factories, and high chimneys puffing clouds of black smoke heavenward.
Night came on; the train passed on at full speed, in the midst of the roaring of the tigers, bears, and wolves which fled before the locomotive; and the marvels of Bengal, Golconda ruined Gour, Murshedabad, the ancient capital, Burdwan, Hugly, and the French town of Chandernagor, where Passepartout would have been proud to see his country’s flag flying, were hidden from their view in the darkness.
Calcutta was reached at seven in the morning, and the packet left for Hong Kong at noon; so that Phileas Fogg had five hours before him.
According to his journal, he was due at Calcutta on the 25th of October, and that was the exact date of his actual arrival. He was therefore neither behind-hand nor ahead of time. The two days gained between London and Bombay had been lost, as has been seen, in the journey across India. But it is not to be supposed that Phileas Fogg regretted them.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The railway, on leaving Benares, passed for a while along the valley of the Ganges. The country that the train traversed was full of lively scenes. Passengers in their carriages could see green mountains, fields of wheat, jungles where snakes and alligators abounded, villages perched on the slopes, thick forests, and, beyond, the horizon, the silvery line of the sacred river. Elephants, sometimes half hidden by the trees, bathed in the waters, and groups of Indians, despite the morning cold, performed their religious ablutions in the Ganges. These were Brahmins, the bitterest foes of Buddhism, their deities being Vishnu, the solar god, Shiva, the divine impersonation of natural forces, and Brahma, the supreme ruler of priests and legislators. What would these divinities think of India, anglicised as it is today, with steamers whistling and trains running along the sacred river? The panorama passed before their eyes like a flash, save when a cloud of steam from the locomotive sometimes hid it from view. The travelers could just catch glimpses of the fort of Chupenie, twenty miles off to the right, the ancient stronghold of the rajahs of Behar; Ghazipur and its famous rose-water factories; the tomb of Lord Cornwallis rising on the left bank; the fort of Buxar; Patna, a large manufacturing and commercial city, where is held the principal opium market of India; Monghir, a more than European town, for it is as English as Manchester or Birmingham, with its iron foundries, edge-tool factories, and high chimneys puffing clouds of black smoke heavenward. Night came on. The train passed on at full speed, in the midst of the roaring of tigers, bears, and wolves which fled before the locomotive; and the travelers could not see the scenes so lively and so various which the daylight had disclosed to view. Mr. Fogg and his companions slept soundly. The train stopped at two or three stations, and at daybreak they reached the station of Burhampoor. Passepartout, on waking and looking out, could not realize that he was actually crossing India in a railway train. The locomotive, guided by an English engineer and fed with English coal, threw out its smoke upon cotton, coffee, nutmeg, clove, and pepper plantations, while the steam curled in spirals around groups of palm-trees. In the distance they could see the first lines of the mountains of the Himalayas, with their rugged summits; and huge forests, interspersed with villages, still slept in the mist of the morning. At seven the train entered the station at Calcutta. Phileas Fogg had accomplished the journey from Bombay in exactly the time prescribed by the itinerary. He had not gained an hour nor lost a minute. He was now in the great city of Calcutta, and had five hours before him in which to take the steamer that was to start at noon for Hong Kong. He left the train, giving his arm to Aouda; Passepartout followed, carrying the bags. Mr. Fogg made his way to the passport office, and then to a hotel, where he ordered breakfast. He then carefully noted in his journal the date of his arrival, October 25th, and the hour, seven in the morning, exactly as scheduled. He had lost the two days previously gained, but he did not seem to regret it.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The railway, on leaving Benares, passed for a while along the valley of the Ganges. The train wound its way through a landscape rich with the verdant hues of rice fields and the distant shimmer of temple spires. The river itself, broad and majestic, glimmered in the morning sun, its banks dotted with villages where the daily life of India unfolded in timeless rhythm. Herds of cattle grazed near the water’s edge, and fishermen cast their nets from slender boats, their figures silhouetted against the golden light.

Phileas Fogg, ever composed, sat by the window, his gaze fixed on the passing scenery. Passepartout, his faithful servant, could not help but marvel at the sights, his eyes wide with wonder at the unfamiliar world rushing by. He pointed out elephants bathing in the river, women in bright saris carrying water pots on their heads, and children waving as the train thundered past.

As the train advanced, the valley gradually gave way to rolling hills and dense forests. The air grew cooler, scented with the fragrance of flowering trees. Occasionally, the train would slow as it crossed narrow bridges or passed through small stations, where vendors hurried alongside the carriages, offering tea, fruit, and sweetmeats to the passengers.

At one such stop, Passepartout leaned out to purchase a cup of steaming chai, exchanging a few words with the vendor in broken English. The bustle of the platform, the cries of hawkers, and the clatter of luggage created a lively scene, but soon the whistle blew, and the train resumed its journey.

Inside the carriage, Sir Francis Cromarty, who had joined Fogg and Passepartout, engaged his companions in conversation about the customs and history of the region. He spoke of the ancient city of Allahabad, their next destination, where the sacred rivers Ganges and Jumna meet. Fogg listened attentively, his mind ever calculating the time and distance yet to be covered.

As the day wore on, the landscape changed once more. The forests thinned, and the train entered a region of rocky outcrops and scattered villages. The sun dipped lower in the sky, casting long shadows across the land. Fogg consulted his watch, noting with satisfaction that they were still on schedule.

Passepartout, meanwhile, reflected on the strangeness of his journey. Only days before, he had never imagined he would travel so far from home, witnessing such wonders. Yet, as the train pressed on towards Allahabad, he felt a growing sense of adventure, eager to see what lay ahead on their remarkable voyage around the world.

chapters.chapter_title: CHAPTER XV. IN WHICH THE BAG OF BANKNOTES DISGORGES SOME THOUSANDS OF POUNDS MORE

events.title: Arrival in Calcutta and Immediate Arrest
detailed_summary: Phileas Fogg, Aouda, and Passepartout arrive at the Calcutta train station.
Fogg intends to immediately board the Hong Kong steamer to ensure Aouda's safety.
A policeman approaches Fogg, confirms his identity and that Passepartout is his servant, and instructs them both to follow him.
Fogg displays no surprise, respecting the law, while Passepartout's attempt to question is silenced by the policeman and Fogg's signal.
Aouda is permitted to accompany them.
They are transported in a four-wheeled carriage (palkigahri) through contrasting parts of the city: the poor 'black town' and the affluent 'European town'.
No one speaks during the twenty-minute journey.
They arrive at a modest building, revealed to be a place of detention.
The policeman escorts them into a room with barred windows, informing them they will appear before Judge Obadiah soon.
The policeman leaves, locking the door behind him.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The train entered the station, and Passepartout jumping out first, was followed by Mr. Fogg, who assisted his fair companion to descend.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He then retired, and closed the door.

events.text_segment:
The train entered the station, and Passepartout jumping out first, was followed by Mr. Fogg, who assisted his fair companion to descend. Phileas Fogg intended to proceed at once to the Hong Kong steamer, in order to get Aouda comfortably settled for the voyage. He was unwilling to leave her while they were still on dangerous ground.
Just as he was leaving the station a policeman came up to him, and said, “Mr. Phileas Fogg?”
“I am he.”
“Is this man your servant?” added the policeman, pointing to Passepartout.
“Yes.”
“Be so good, both of you, as to follow me.”
Mr. Fogg betrayed no surprise whatever. The policeman was a representative of the law, and law is sacred to an Englishman. Passepartout tried to reason about the matter, but the policeman tapped him with his stick, and Mr. Fogg made him a signal to obey.
“May this young lady go with us?” asked he.
“She may,” replied the policeman.
Mr. Fogg, Aouda, and Passepartout were conducted to a palkigahri, a sort of four-wheeled carriage, drawn by two horses, in which they took their places and were driven away. No one spoke during the twenty minutes which elapsed before they reached their destination. They first passed through the “black town,” with its narrow streets, its miserable, dirty huts, and squalid population; then through the “European town,” which presented a relief in its bright brick mansions, shaded by coconut-trees and bristling with masts, where, although it was early morning, elegantly dressed horsemen and handsome equipages were passing back and forth.
The carriage stopped before a modest-looking house, which, however, did not have the appearance of a private mansion. The policeman having requested his prisoners—for so, truly, they might be called—to descend, conducted them into a room with barred windows, and said: “You will appear before Judge Obadiah at half-past eight.”
He then retired, and closed the door.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
The train entered the station, and Passepartout jumping out first, was followed by Mr. Fogg, who assisted his fair companion to descend. Mr. Fogg intended to proceed at once to the Hong Kong steamer, in order to place Aouda in safety there. He was unwilling to leave her while they were still on dangerous ground.

At the moment that Mr. Fogg, Aouda, and Passepartout were passing through the station, a policeman came up to them.

"Mr. Phileas Fogg?" asked he.

"I am he."

"And this is your servant?" added the policeman, pointing to Passepartout.

"Yes."

"Be so good, both of you, as to follow me."

Mr. Fogg made no resistance, and passed quietly along, followed by his companions. Passepartout tried to ask the policeman questions, but the latter only replied with the order to "come along," and Mr. Fogg, by a sign, advised his servant to obey.

"May this young lady go with us?" asked he.

"She may," replied the policeman.

The policeman proceeded to a palkighari, a sort of four-wheeled carriage, which awaited his party. He got in, and the others followed. The vehicle passed, at a rapid pace, through the "black town," with its narrow streets, its poor, nest-like houses, and squalid population; then through the "European town," which presented a relief in its bright brick mansions, shaded by coconut-trees, and bristling with masts, where, although it was early morning, elegantly dressed horsemen and handsome equipages were passing back and forth.

The carriage stopped before a modest-looking house, which, however, did not have the appearance of a private dwelling. The policeman, having requested his prisoners—for so, truly, they might be called—to descend, conducted them into a room with barred windows, and said:

"You will appear before Judge Obadiah at half-past eight."

He then retired and closed the door.

The station was bustling with activity, the clatter of porters and the shouts of cabmen filling the air. Passepartout, ever attentive, hurried to secure a conveyance, while Mr. Fogg, with his customary composure, offered his arm to Aouda. She accepted it gratefully, her eyes reflecting both fatigue and trust in her companions. The trio made their way through the throng, their progress watched with curiosity by the local onlookers, who noted the distinguished Englishman, the elegant lady in foreign dress, and the lively Frenchman.

Having procured a cab, Passepartout opened the door with a flourish, and Mr. Fogg assisted Aouda inside before taking his own seat. Passepartout climbed up beside the driver, eager to observe the city as they made their way to the hotel. The cab rattled through the streets, past shops and markets, the sights and sounds of the new city swirling around them. Aouda gazed out the window, marveling at the unfamiliar architecture and the vibrant life of the place, while Mr. Fogg consulted his watch, ever mindful of the relentless march of time.

Upon arrival at the hotel, Passepartout leapt down and helped the others alight. Mr. Fogg requested rooms and ensured that Aouda would have every comfort. Passepartout, meanwhile, busied himself with the luggage, his cheerful energy undiminished by the long journey. Once settled, Mr. Fogg inquired about the next leg of their journey, determined that no delay should hinder their progress. Aouda, grateful for the care and attention she received, expressed her thanks to both gentlemen. Passepartout, with a twinkle in his eye, assured her that nothing would prevent them from reaching their destination. Thus, the travelers prepared for the next stage of their remarkable adventure, their spirits buoyed by the successful completion of another leg of their journey.

events.title: Reactions to Imprisonment and Fogg's Resolve
detailed_summary: Passepartout exclaims in dismay that they are prisoners.
Aouda, emotional but trying to hide it, tells Fogg he should abandon her, blaming herself for his predicament.
Fogg calmly dismisses her suggestion as impossible, stating he wouldn't be arrested for preventing a suttee and that there must be a mistake.
He reaffirms his commitment to escorting Aouda to Hong Kong.
Passepartout nervously points out the steamer departs at noon.
Fogg confidently assures him they will be on board by noon.
His certainty impresses Passepartout, who mutters agreement, though he remains deeply uneasy.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Why, we are prisoners!” exclaimed Passepartout, falling into a chair.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: But he was by no means reassured.

events.text_segment:
“Why, we are prisoners!” exclaimed Passepartout, falling into a chair.
Aouda, with an emotion she tried to conceal, said to Mr. Fogg: “Sir, you must leave me to my fate! It is on my account that you receive this treatment, it is for having saved me!”
Phileas Fogg contented himself with saying that it was impossible. It was quite unlikely that he should be arrested for preventing a suttee. The complainants would not dare present themselves with such a charge. There was some mistake. Moreover, he would not, in any event, abandon Aouda, but would escort her to Hong Kong.
“But the steamer leaves at noon!” observed Passepartout, nervously.
“We shall be on board by noon,” replied his master, placidly.
It was said so positively that Passepartout could not help muttering to himself, “Parbleu that’s certain! Before noon we shall be on board.” But he was by no means reassured.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
“Why, we are prisoners!” exclaimed Passepartout, falling into a chair.

Aouda, with an emotion she tried to conceal, said to Mr. Fogg: “Sir, you must leave me to my fate! It is on my account that you are arrested. It is for having saved me!”

Phileas Fogg contented himself with saying that this could not be. That he was not arrested for having saved Aouda, but by a mistake, and that he would soon be set at liberty.

Aouda pressed his hand, and her eyes filled with tears. Passepartout was as if struck dumb. He saw plainly that the matter was very serious, and he could not understand how a simple act of humanity could have brought them into such trouble.

The hours passed. The steamer was to leave at noon, and it was already half-past eight. Passepartout, seeing that they did not come to set them at liberty, became impatient. He could not help muttering:

“Mon Dieu! Monsieur Fogg, will they not let us go?”

“I will go and see,” replied Mr. Fogg quietly.

He sat down again, and began to play patience.

Time passed. The clock struck ten. The noise outside was increased by the arrival of a carriage. Soon after, footsteps were heard in the corridor. The door opened, and the policeman appeared, accompanied by a clerk, who said:

“Mr. Phileas Fogg?”

“I am here,” replied Mr. Fogg.

“Is this your servant?”

“Yes.”

“Come this way.”

Mr. Fogg rose, and, followed by Passepartout and Aouda, left the room. They passed through the court, and found themselves in a carriage, which was rapidly driven to the courthouse. During the ride, neither Mr. Fogg nor his companions spoke a word.

events.title: Court Appearance and Initial Proceedings
detailed_summary: At half-past eight, the policeman returns and leads them to an adjacent courtroom, already filled with Europeans and natives.
Fogg, Aouda, and Passepartout sit on a bench opposite the magistrate's and clerk's desks.
Judge Obadiah, a portly man, enters with his clerk, Oysterpuff.
The judge mistakenly puts on the clerk's wig before realizing his error.
He questions how a judge can deliver a wise sentence in a clerk's wig, and they exchange headpieces.
Passepartout grows increasingly anxious as he watches the clock.
The judge calls the first case, and Oysterpuff confirms the presence of Phileas Fogg and Passepartout.
The judge mentions they have been sought for two days.
Passepartout impatiently asks about the charges.
Fogg asserts his rights as an English subject.
The judge confirms they haven't been mistreated and orders the complainants to be brought in.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: At half-past eight the door opened, the policeman appeared, and, requesting them to follow him, led the way to an adjoining hall.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Very well; let the complainants come in.”

events.text_segment:
At half-past eight the door opened, the policeman appeared, and, requesting them to follow him, led the way to an adjoining hall. It was evidently a court-room, and a crowd of Europeans and natives already occupied the rear of the apartment.
Mr. Fogg and his two companions took their places on a bench opposite the desks of the magistrate and his clerk. Immediately after, Judge Obadiah, a fat, round man, followed by the clerk, entered. He proceeded to take down a wig which was hanging on a nail, and put it hurriedly on his head.
“The first case,” said he. Then, putting his hand to his head, he exclaimed, “Heh! This is not my wig!”
“No, your worship,” returned the clerk, “it is mine.”
“My dear Mr. Oysterpuff, how can a judge give a wise sentence in a clerk’s wig?”
The wigs were exchanged.
Passepartout was getting nervous, for the hands on the face of the big clock over the judge seemed to go around with terrible rapidity.
“The first case,” repeated Judge Obadiah.
“Phileas Fogg?” demanded Oysterpuff.
“I am here,” replied Mr. Fogg.
“Passepartout?”
“Present,” responded Passepartout.
“Good,” said the judge. “You have been looked for, prisoners, for two days on the trains from Bombay.”
“But of what are we accused?” asked Passepartout, impatiently.
“You are about to be informed.”
“I am an English subject, sir,” said Mr. Fogg, “and I have the right—”
“Have you been ill-treated?”
“Not at all.”
“Very well; let the complainants come in.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: At half-past eight the door opened, the policeman appeared, and, requesting them to follow him, led the way to an adjoining hall. He proceeded to take his seat, but, seeing that the clerk had brought him his own wig instead of his, he called out, "Oysterpuff!" "Your worship!" "You have put on my wig!" "So I have, your worship," returned the clerk, hastily exchanging the wig. "Now, gentlemen," said the judge, "are you the persons whose names are Phileas Fogg and Passepartout?" "We are." "Very well. You have been looked for these two days on the arrival of the Rangoon." "But what are we accused of?" asked Passepartout impatiently. "You shall be informed in due time," replied the judge. "You are English subjects?" "We are," answered Mr. Fogg. "Very well; you have not been ill-treated?" "Not at all." "Very good. Let the complainants be brought in."

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text:
At half-past eight the door opened, the policeman appeared, and, requesting them to follow him, led the way to an adjoining hall. It was evidently a court-room, and a crowd of Europeans and natives already occupied the rear of the apartment. Mr. Fogg, Aouda, and Passepartout took their places on a bench opposite the desk of the magistrate and his clerk. Immediately after, Judge Obadiah, a fat, round man, followed by the clerk, entered. Judge Obadiah proceeded to take his seat, but, seeing that the clerk had brought him his own wig instead of his, he called out, "Oysterpuff!" "Your worship?" "You have put on my wig." "So I have, your worship," returned the clerk, hastily exchanging the wig. The judge, now properly accoutred, took up a large sheet of paper and called out, "The first case!" Then, putting his hand to his head, he exclaimed, "Why, this is not my wig!" "No, your worship, it is mine," replied Oysterpuff. "Dear me! So it is. We have made a mistake in the wigs."

So saying, the two functionaries set about rectifying the error. Passepartout was getting nervous, for the hands of the clock seemed to move with terrible rapidity. "The first case!" repeated Judge Obadiah. "Phileas Fogg?" demanded Oysterpuff. "I am here," replied Mr. Fogg. "Passepartout?" "Present," responded Passepartout. "Good," said the judge. "You have been looked for these two days on the trains from Bombay." "But what do you want with us?" cried Passepartout, impatiently. "Silence!" said the judge. "I am about to render judgment."

He then turned to the policeman, and ordered, "Let the complainants be brought in."

There, a magistrate was seated behind a high desk, his face grave and impassive. The clerk of the court, pen in hand, sat ready to record the proceedings. Fix, the detective, stood to one side, his eyes never leaving Phileas Fogg and his companions. The little group entered quietly, Aouda glancing anxiously at Fogg, who maintained his usual composure, and Passepartout, whose face betrayed his agitation.

The magistrate, after a brief glance at the papers before him, addressed the accused. "You are charged with having caused a disturbance yesterday at the Suez mosque, and with having violated the sanctity of the place. What have you to say in your defence?"

Phileas Fogg replied in a calm, measured tone, "I was not aware that my servant had entered the mosque with his shoes on. I regret the incident, and am prepared to make any reparation required by the law."

Passepartout, abashed, stammered an apology, explaining that he had acted in ignorance of the customs of the country. The magistrate listened without comment, then turned to Fix, who gave his testimony with an air of impartiality, though his satisfaction was evident to those who watched him closely.

After a brief consultation with the clerk, the magistrate pronounced judgment. "The court fines the accused a sum of one hundred pounds each. Payment must be made at once, or you will be detained."

Phileas Fogg, without hesitation, drew a roll of banknotes from his pocket and paid the fine for himself and Passepartout.

events.text_segment:
A door was swung open by order of the judge, and three Indian priests entered.
“That’s it,” muttered Passepartout; “these are the rogues who were going to burn our young lady.”
The priests took their places in front of the judge, and the clerk proceeded to read in a loud voice a complaint of sacrilege against Phileas Fogg and his servant, who were accused of having violated a place held consecrated by the Brahmin religion.
“You hear the charge?” asked the judge.
“Yes, sir,” replied Mr. Fogg, consulting his watch, “and I admit it.”
“You admit it?”
“I admit it, and I wish to hear these priests admit, in their turn, what they were going to do at the pagoda of Pillaji.”
The priests looked at each other; they did not seem to understand what was said.
“Yes,” cried Passepartout, warmly; “at the pagoda of Pillaji, where they were on the point of burning their victim.”
The judge stared with astonishment, and the priests were stupefied.
“What victim?” said Judge Obadiah. “Burn whom? In Bombay itself?”
“Bombay?” cried Passepartout.
“Certainly. We are not talking of the pagoda of Pillaji, but of the pagoda of Malabar Hill, at Bombay.”
“And as a proof,” added the clerk, “here are the desecrator’s very shoes, which he left behind him.”
Whereupon he placed a pair of shoes on his desk.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
A door was swung open by order of the judge, and three Indian priests entered. 

These priests were just as impassible as ever, and neither in their faces nor in their attitude was there any trace of the resentment which the acts of the Englishmen might have aroused. The clerk, Oysterpuff, called out their names in a loud voice, and the priests took their places in front of the judge. 

Passepartout, who was looking at them with a very uneasy air, muttered to himself, "These are the rascals who were going to burn our young lady."

The judge now addressed the accused, and asked them if they understood the charge brought against them. 

"We do," replied Mr. Fogg, consulting his watch, "and I admit it."

"You admit it?" returned the judge.

"I admit it, and I wish to add that your priests were on the point of sacrificing their victim in the Pillaji pagoda, when I rescued her."

The priests looked at each other; they evidently did not understand the English language.

Passepartout made a sign that he wished to speak. "You are not in the Pillaji pagoda, but in the pagoda of Malabar Hill, at Bombay."

"That is true," said the judge; "the charge is not of having violated the pagoda of Pillaji, but that of Malabar Hill, at Bombay."

"And as proof," added the clerk, "here are the shoes which the desecrator left behind him." And he placed a pair of shoes on the desk.

They were draped in long, flowing robes of saffron and white, their foreheads marked with sacred ash and vermilion. Their eyes, dark and solemn, swept over the assembled crowd before coming to rest on the prisoner. The murmurs in the courtroom subsided into a tense silence as the priests approached the bench, their bare feet making no sound on the stone floor. The judge, a portly Englishman with a stern countenance, regarded them with a mixture of curiosity and respect.

The priest recounted, in calm and precise tones, the events that had transpired: the arrival of the foreigner, the disturbance at the sacred site, and the subsequent confusion. As he spoke, the other two priests nodded in agreement, occasionally adding a word or gesture to corroborate his account.

Phileas Fogg, standing beside his servant Passepartout, listened intently, his expression inscrutable. The testimony of the priests was crucial; it could determine the outcome of the trial and the fate of their journey around the world.

events.text_segment:
“My shoes!” cried Passepartout, in his surprise permitting this imprudent exclamation to escape him.
The confusion of master and man, who had quite forgotten the affair at Bombay, for which they were now detained at Calcutta, may be imagined.
Fix the detective, had foreseen the advantage which Passepartout’s escapade gave him, and, delaying his departure for twelve hours, had consulted the priests of Malabar Hill. Knowing that the English authorities dealt very severely with this kind of misdemeanour, he promised them a goodly sum in damages, and sent them forward to Calcutta by the next train. Owing to the delay caused by the rescue of the young widow, Fix and the priests reached the Indian capital before Mr. Fogg and his servant, the magistrates having been already warned by a dispatch to arrest them should they arrive. Fix’s disappointment when he learned that Phileas Fogg had not made his appearance in Calcutta may be imagined. He made up his mind that the robber had stopped somewhere on the route and taken refuge in the southern provinces. For twenty-four hours Fix watched the station with feverish anxiety; at last he was rewarded by seeing Mr. Fogg and Passepartout arrive, accompanied by a young woman, whose presence he was wholly at a loss to explain. He hastened for a policeman; and this was how the party came to be arrested and brought before Judge Obadiah.

At last, Fogg, Passepartout, and the mysterious Aouda appeared, weary from their journey. Fix, who had quietly followed, was delighted to find his man. He had made up his mind to let Passepartout go on, but the latter’s exclamation betrayed him. The detective at once resolved to profit by the opportunity. Approaching Passepartout, he said, with a smile:

"You are in a great hurry, then?"

"I am indeed!" replied Passepartout. "I must get back to my master, Monsieur Fogg."

"But you have lost your shoes."

"Ah, so I have!" cried Passepartout, looking down at his feet, which were indeed without shoes. "I left them in the temple!"

Passepartout, quite out of breath, related his adventure in a few words to his master, who listened without a word, and then they all proceeded on board the steamer.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Had Passepartout been a little less preoccupied, he would have espied the detective ensconced in a corner of the court-room, watching the proceedings with an interest easily understood; for the warrant had failed to reach him at Calcutta, as it had done at Bombay and Suez.

events.text_segment:
Had Passepartout been a little less preoccupied, he would have espied the detective ensconced in a corner of the court-room, watching the proceedings with an interest easily understood; for the warrant had failed to reach him at Calcutta, as it had done at Bombay and Suez.
Judge Obadiah had unfortunately caught Passepartout’s rash exclamation, which the poor fellow would have given the world to recall.
“The facts are admitted?” asked the judge.
“Admitted,” replied Mr. Fogg, coldly.
“Inasmuch,” resumed the judge, “as the English law protects equally and sternly the religions of the Indian people, and as the man Passepartout has admitted that he violated the sacred pagoda of Malabar Hill, at Bombay, on the 20th of October, I condemn the said Passepartout to imprisonment for fifteen days and a fine of three hundred pounds.”
“Three hundred pounds!” cried Passepartout, startled at the largeness of the sum.
“Silence!” shouted the constable.
“And inasmuch,” continued the judge, “as it is not proved that the act was not done by the connivance of the master with the servant, and as the master in any case must be held responsible for the acts of his paid servant, I condemn Phileas Fogg to a week’s imprisonment and a fine of one hundred and fifty pounds.”
Fix rubbed his hands softly with satisfaction; if Phileas Fogg could be detained in Calcutta a week, it would be more than time for the warrant to arrive. Passepartout was stupefied. This sentence ruined his master. A wager of twenty thousand pounds lost, because he, like a precious fool, had gone into that abominable pagoda!
Phileas Fogg, as self-composed as if the judgment did not in the least concern him, did not even lift his eyebrows while it was being pronounced. Just as the clerk was calling the next case, he rose, and said, “I offer bail.”
“You have that right,” returned the judge.
Fix’s blood ran cold, but he resumed his composure when he heard the judge announce that the bail required for each prisoner would be one thousand pounds.
“I will pay it at once,” said Mr. Fogg, taking a roll of bank-bills from the carpet-bag, which Passepartout had by him, and placing them on the clerk’s desk.
“This sum will be restored to you upon your release from prison,” said the judge. “Meanwhile, you are liberated on bail.”
“Come!” said Phileas Fogg to his servant.
“But let them at least give me back my shoes!” cried Passepartout angrily.
“Ah, these are pretty dear shoes!” he muttered, as they were handed to him. “More than a thousand pounds apiece; besides, they pinch my feet.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Had Passepartout been a little less preoccupied, he would have espied the detective ensconced in a corner of the court-room, watching the proceedings with an interest easily understood; for the warrant had failed to reach him at Calcutta, as it had done at Bombay and Suez.

Judge Obadiah, having taken his seat, carefully scanned the accused, and proceeded to read, in a voice made husky by the use of gin, the complaint of sacrilege committed by Passepartout and his master against the religion of the Malabar Hill pagoda. He then asked Passepartout if he admitted the fact.

"Yes, your worship," replied Passepartout, who could not help muttering, "but in my country we do not put a man in prison for such a thing."

"The fact is admitted," said the judge. "But," he added, "if the law of England were applied here, the culprit would be condemned to hard labour for life. As it is, I sentence Passepartout to fifteen days' imprisonment and a fine of three hundred pounds."

"Three hundred pounds!" cried Passepartout, startled at the largeness of the sum.

"Silence!" shouted the constable.

"And you, Mr. Fogg," continued the judge, "you have not been found accomplice in the sacrilege, but you are responsible for the acts of your servant, and are therefore sentenced to a week's imprisonment and a fine of one hundred and fifty pounds."

Fix rubbed his hands softly with satisfaction; if Fogg could be detained in Calcutta a week, it would be more than time for the warrant to arrive.

Passepartout was stupefied. This sentence ruined his master. A wager of twenty thousand pounds lost, because he, like a precious fool, had gone into that abominable pagoda!

Phileas Fogg, as tranquil as if the judgment did not in the least concern him, did not even lift his eyebrows while it was being pronounced.

"Just as the clerk was calling the next case, Mr. Fogg rose, and said, "I offer bail."

"You have that right," returned the judge.

Fix's blood ran cold, but he resumed his composure when he heard the judge fix the amount of bail at one thousand pounds per head.

"I will pay it at once," said Mr. Fogg, taking a roll of banknotes from the carpet-bag, which Passepartout had by him, and placing them on the clerk's desk.

"This sum will be restored to you upon your release from prison," said the judge. "Meanwhile, you are liberated on bail."

"Come," said Phileas Fogg to his servant.

"But let them at least give me back my shoes!" cried Passepartout angrily. "They cost more than a thousand pounds apiece, with all the fine they have cost me."

And, relapsing into his old humour, he muttered as he followed Mr. Fogg out of the court-room, "That judge must be a regular bandit!"
