LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Phileas Fogg pronounced these words with the utmost calm, as if he were merely stating the price of a modest dinner, not the sum total of his entire fortune. The members of the Reform Club, gathered around the green baize table, exchanged glances of incredulity. For a moment, the only sound in the room was the gentle ticking of the clock on the mantelpiece, marking the inexorable passage of time—time that, for Mr. Fogg, was about to become the most precious commodity of all.

"Twenty thousand pounds!" repeated Stuart, the banker, his voice tinged with both admiration and disbelief. "You are prepared to risk such a sum on the mere possibility of circumnavigating the globe in eighty days?"

"I am not risking it on a possibility," replied Fogg, his gaze unwavering. "I am staking it on a certainty. The calculations are clear. The new railway in India, the improved steamers, the Suez Canal—all these have shortened the journey. It is not only possible, it is inevitable."

Flanagan, the engineer, leaned forward, his brow furrowed. "But, Fogg, you must allow for unforeseen delays—bad weather, accidents, political unrest. The world is not a clockwork mechanism."

Fogg inclined his head slightly, as if acknowledging the point, but remained unperturbed. "I have allowed for all reasonable contingencies. The schedule is tight, but not impossible."

Ralph, the club's resident skeptic, could not suppress a chuckle. "And if you fail?"

"Then I shall lose twenty thousand pounds," Fogg replied simply. "But I do not intend to fail."

A silence fell over the group, broken only by the clink of a spoon against a teacup. The challenge hung in the air, as tangible as the fog outside the club's windows.

"Very well," said Stuart at last, his eyes alight with the thrill of the wager. "We accept. Twenty thousand pounds that you cannot travel around the world in eighty days. The journey to begin at once?"

"At once," Fogg agreed. "Today is Wednesday, the 2nd of October. I shall return to this very room, at this very hour, on Saturday, the 21st of December, or forfeit the wager."

The terms were set. The gentlemen shook hands, sealing the bet with the solemnity of a contract. Fogg rose, adjusted his waistcoat, and with a polite bow, excused himself. There was no time to lose.

Outside, the city bustled with its usual indifference to the affairs of the Reform Club. Fogg hailed a cab and returned to his residence in Saville Row, where his new valet, Passepartout, awaited him. The Frenchman, still unfamiliar with his employer's habits, was startled by the sudden command to pack at once for a journey around the world.

"But, monsieur—" Passepartout began, only to be cut off by Fogg's implacable calm.

"We leave in ten minutes. There is not a moment to spare."

And so, with the wager set and the clock ticking, Phileas Fogg embarked upon the most extraordinary adventure of his life, his every action measured against the relentless march of time and the promise of twenty thousand pounds.

events.text_segment:
“What nonsense!” cried Passepartout, striking the table with his fist. “My master is the most honourable of men!”
“How can you tell? You know scarcely anything about him. You went into his service the day he came away; and he came away on a foolish pretext, without trunks, and carrying a large amount in banknotes. And yet you are bold enough to assert that he is an honest man!”
“Yes, yes,” repeated the poor fellow, mechanically.
“Would you like to be arrested as his accomplice?”
Passepartout, overcome by what he had heard, held his head between his hands, and did not dare to look at the detective. Phileas Fogg, the saviour of Aouda, that brave and generous man, a robber! And yet how many presumptions there were against him! Passepartout essayed to reject the suspicions which forced themselves upon his mind; he did not wish to believe that his master was guilty.
“Well, what do you want of me?” said he, at last, with an effort.
“See here,” replied Fix; “I have tracked Mr. Fogg to this place, but as yet I have failed to receive the warrant of arrest for which I sent to London. You must help me to keep him here in Hong Kong—”
“I! But I—”
“I will share with you the two thousand pounds reward offered by the Bank of England.”
“Never!” replied Passepartout, who tried to rise, but fell back, exhausted in mind and body.
“Mr. Fix,” he stammered, “even should what you say be true—if my master is really the robber you are seeking for—which I deny—I have been, am, in his service; I have seen his generosity and goodness; and I will never betray him—not for all the gold in the world. I come from a village where they don’t eat that kind of bread!”
“You refuse?”
“I refuse.”
“Consider that I’ve said nothing,” said Fix; “and let us drink.”
“Yes; let us drink!”
Passepartout felt himself yielding more and more to the effects of the liquor. Fix, seeing that he must, at all hazards, be separated from his master, wished to entirely overcome him. Some pipes full of opium lay upon the table. Fix slipped one into Passepartout’s hand. He took it, put it between his lips, lit it, drew several puffs, and his head, becoming heavy under the influence of the narcotic, fell upon the table.
“At last!” said Fix, seeing Passepartout unconscious. “Mr. Fogg will not be informed of the ‘Carnatic’s’ departure; and, if he is, he will have to go without this cursed Frenchman!”
And, after paying his bill, Fix left the tavern.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
“What nonsense!” cried Passepartout, striking the table with his fist. “My master is the most honourable of men!”

“How do you know?” replied Fix. “You know scarcely anything of him. You went into his service the day he left London, and he left in a great hurry, with no other baggage than a carpet-bag, and with a large sum in bank-notes. And yet you are bold enough to assert that he is an honest man!”

“Yes, yes,” repeated the poor fellow, mechanically.

“You see, then!” resumed Fix; “but will you listen to me?”

“If you will not betray my master,” replied Passepartout, in a choking voice.

“Betray him! Never! I mean to serve him, on the contrary. But I must detain him in Hong Kong, until I receive a warrant from London.”

“You will not dare to arrest Mr. Fogg as a robber?”

“I have no right to do so. But, as a detective, I am bound to keep my eyes on him. Help me, and I will do as much for you.”

Passepartout recoiled, and looked Fix steadily in the face. “You propose to me to betray my master!” he cried, with an energy that made the agent recoil in his turn. “You propose to me to betray Mr. Fogg!—never! Never!”

Fix, seeing that he could not get anything out of Passepartout, poured him a glass of brandy. “Let us drink, then!”

Passepartout drank, but he was evidently agitated, and Fix, observing that he was becoming excited and talkative, resolved to take advantage of his state. He offered him a pipe, which Passepartout accepted, and soon the narcotic effect of the opium, joined to the fumes of the alcohol, made his head heavy, and he fell into a deep sleep.

Fix, satisfied with his success, paid the bill, and left the opium den. "Now," he muttered, "Mr. Fogg will not be warned of the Carnatic's departure, and if he leaves Hong Kong, it will be without this faithful fellow."

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text:
“What nonsense!” cried Passepartout, striking the table with his fist. “I!—suspect my master! Why, he is the most honourable of men!”

“Humph!” said Fix, “but you forget; how did you happen to enter his service?”

The effect of the detective’s question was evidently to disturb Passepartout, for he replied, “I did not enter his service by chance. I was recommended to him.”

“And you have been with him—?”

“Since the very day of our departure. That is to say, for three weeks.”

“You know him, then?”

“Why, no; not at all; I have only seen him.”

“So you admit that you know nothing positive about him. You have only had to deal with him as a master, and, as such, you have found him honest and generous?”

“Yes, but that’s not all. I know what people say about him, and I won’t believe a word of it. I have seen him handle large sums of money, and he has always been as exact as a clock. I would stake my life on his honesty!”

“Still, you must admit that, since you know nothing of him—”

“That’s true—absolutely true. But I am not a spy, Mr. Fix!”

Fix hesitated for a moment, then resumed: “You are not a spy, perhaps; but you are an accomplice. You refuse to help me, and I shall be forced to arrest you.”

Passepartout seized his head with both hands. He was evidently shaken by the detective’s accusations. He remembered the mysterious departure from London, the large sum carried off, the strange journey, the sudden purchases, the odd companions, and the singular punctuality of his master. He was troubled, shaken, but his faith in Mr. Fogg remained unshaken.

At last he raised his head and said, “What do you want of me?”

“See here,” replied Fix, “I have traced Mr. Fogg to this place, but as yet I have no warrant for his arrest. You must help me to detain him in Hong Kong—”

“Detain him!—me!—never!”

“Listen. You can help me without betraying your master. I have a warrant coming from England. In the meantime, help me to keep him here for a few days. I will give you a share of the reward—two thousand pounds from the Bank of England.”

“Two thousand pounds!” cried Passepartout, pushing back his chair. “Never! Even if what you say were true—if my master were the thief, which I deny—I have seen him kind and generous, and I will never betray him—not for all the gold in the world! I am a poor man, sir, but an honest one, though I was born in a garret. You may arrest me if you like, but you shall never have my help!”

“Is that your final answer?”

“It is.”

“Very well, let us say no more about it. Let us drink.”

Passepartout, whose mind was in a state of confusion, accepted the glass which Fix filled for him. He drank one glass, then another, and soon his head grew heavy. Fix, seeing this, quietly slipped an opium pipe into his hand. Passepartout took it mechanically, lighted it, and soon the narcotic took effect. His head fell upon the table, and he slept heavily.

Fix, seeing that his companion was completely insensible, paid the bill and left the place. “At last,” he said, “Mr. Fogg will not be warned of the Carnatic’s departure, and if he leaves Hong Kong, it will be without this good fellow.”

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
“What nonsense!” cried Passepartout, striking the table with his fist. “With your permission, sir, I think I may be allowed to doubt your calculations. The world is large, and though the trains and steamers go fast, there are always delays, accidents, and unforeseen events. Eighty days! Why, it would take that time to get to India alone!”

Phileas Fogg turned his calm gaze upon his servant. “The calculations are correct, Passepartout. The journey is possible, provided one adheres strictly to the timetable. The world has grown smaller, thanks to the progress of science and industry. The railway across India is now complete, and the steamers run with regularity. The Suez Canal has shortened the passage to the East. There is nothing to prevent a man, with sufficient means and determination, from circumnavigating the globe in eighty days.”

Passepartout, still incredulous, shook his head. “But, sir, what of storms at sea, or breakdowns on the railway? What if a ship is delayed, or a train derailed? What if—”

Fogg interrupted him with a slight gesture. “We must allow for the unexpected, certainly. But the margin is sufficient. The journey is mapped out to the hour. If we leave London by the Dover-Calais train at 8:45 this evening, we shall reach Suez in seven days, Bombay in less than three weeks, Yokohama in thirty days, San Francisco in fifty-two, and New York in seventy-six. That leaves four days for contingencies.”

Passepartout’s eyes widened. “You are serious, sir?”

“Perfectly serious. I have wagered twenty thousand pounds on the result. We must be ready to leave at once.”

Passepartout, overwhelmed by the suddenness of the decision, stood speechless for a moment. Then, recovering himself, he bowed. “Very well, sir. I will pack at once.”

Fogg nodded. “You have twenty minutes. Take only what is necessary. We shall purchase anything else we require along the way.”

Passepartout hurried from the room, his mind in a whirl. Was his master mad, or was he truly capable of such a feat? The calm assurance of Mr. Fogg left no room for doubt. Passepartout resolved to do his utmost to aid his master in this extraordinary enterprise.

Meanwhile, Fogg consulted his watch, then drew out a small notebook and began to make notes. Every detail was to be considered, every minute accounted for. The wager was not merely a matter of money, but of honour and precision. The world would soon see whether Phileas Fogg could indeed travel around it in eighty days.

events.title: Fogg Assists Aouda While Passepartout is Missing
detailed_summary: Unaware of Passepartout's situation, Mr. Fogg assists Aouda with shopping for their journey.
He justifies the purchases to a grateful Aouda as being essential to his travel plan.
After shopping, they return to their hotel and dine.
Aouda retires for the night after thanking Fogg.
Mr. Fogg spends the evening reading newspapers, seemingly unperturbed.

events.text_segment:
While these events were passing at the opium-house, Mr. Fogg, unconscious of the danger he was in of losing the steamer, was quietly escorting Aouda about the streets of the English quarter, making the necessary purchases for the long voyage before them. It was all very well for an Englishman like Mr. Fogg to make the tour of the world with a carpet-bag; a lady could not be expected to travel comfortably under such conditions. He acquitted his task with characteristic serenity, and invariably replied to the remonstrances of his fair companion, who was confused by his patience and generosity:
“It is in the interest of my journey—a part of my programme.”
The purchases made, they returned to the hotel, where they dined at a sumptuously served table-d’hôte; after which Aouda, shaking hands with her protector after the English fashion, retired to her room for rest. Mr. Fogg absorbed himself throughout the evening in the perusal of the Times and Illustrated London News.

She felt herself so much more secure under his protection. Mr. Fogg made the purchases, which he deemed necessary, and they returned to the hotel, where they dined at a modest table d’hôte. After dinner, Aouda, somewhat fatigued, retired to her room after thanking her companion, who, as usual, made no reply. Fogg, left alone, took up a newspaper and read quietly, as if he had nothing else to occupy his mind.

It was only proper that a European woman should not set out on such a journey without some precautions as to her dress. Mr. Fogg took the shortest cut through the shops, and Aouda, smiling, could not but acknowledge his delicacy of taste. It was also very evident that, having resolved to make the tour of the world, he was not going to be turned from his purpose by the fate of a single man—were he even his own servant. Having provided for Aouda everything which her modesty could require, they returned to the hotel, where they dined. At the table d’hôte, which was moderately full, Mr. Fogg observed that Aouda was much affected by the noise and bustle of the crowd. He did not try to comfort her, but, when she thanked him for all he had done, he simply replied that all that he had done had been necessary to enable him to carry out his programme. After dinner, Aouda retired to her room, and Mr. Fogg, for his part, began to read the Times and the Illustrated London News.

events.title: Discovery of the Missed Steamer and Passepartout's Absence
detailed_summary: Mr. Fogg notes Passepartout's absence at bedtime but remains untroubled, knowing the steamer departs the next morning.
When Passepartout fails to appear the following morning, Fogg proceeds without visible annoyance.
He summons Aouda and arranges for a palanquin to take them to the harbour.
They arrive at the quay half an hour before the scheduled departure time (9:30 AM).
Fogg learns the "Carnatic" had actually departed the previous evening.
Facing the loss of both his transport and his servant, Fogg displays remarkable composure, calling it merely an accident to Aouda.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He had expected to find not only the steamer, but his domestic, and was forced to give up both; but no sign of disappointment appeared on his face, and he merely remarked to Aouda, “It is an accident, madam; nothing more.”

events.text_segment:
Had he been capable of being astonished at anything, it would have been not to see his servant return at bedtime. But, knowing that the steamer was not to leave for Yokohama until the next morning, he did not disturb himself about the matter. When Passepartout did not appear the next morning to answer his master’s bell, Mr. Fogg, not betraying the least vexation, contented himself with taking his carpet-bag, calling Aouda, and sending for a palanquin.
It was then eight o’clock; at half-past nine, it being then high tide, the “Carnatic” would leave the harbour. Mr. Fogg and Aouda got into the palanquin, their luggage being brought after on a wheelbarrow, and half an hour later stepped upon the quay whence they were to embark. Mr. Fogg then learned that the “Carnatic” had sailed the evening before. He had expected to find not only the steamer, but his domestic, and was forced to give up both; but no sign of disappointment appeared on his face, and he merely remarked to Aouda, “It is an accident, madam; nothing more.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Had he been capable of being astonished at anything, it would have been not to see his servant return at bedtime. Knowing that the steamer for Yokohama was not to leave until the next morning, Mr. Fogg did not disturb himself about the matter. He slept quietly, and when he rose Passepartout was not yet returned. It was not unusual for the worthy fellow to be absent for a night, as he was fond of wandering about the city; but, as he did not appear in the morning, Mr. Fogg, after waiting some time, was forced to give up any hope of seeing him before the time fixed for the departure of the steamer.

Fix, who had been waiting for him on the quay, had not seen him either. Aouda was ready, and Mr. Fogg had her conveyed in a palanquin to the quay. Half an hour before the time appointed for the departure, Mr. Fogg was there with his companion. But the "Carnatic" had left the evening before!

Mr. Fogg, who was expected on board, was not there; and the steamer, after having waited an hour for him, had set sail without him.

He was now, indeed, forced to find some other means of reaching Yokohama. At this moment Fix approached, and, looking at Mr. Fogg, said:

"Are you not going to board the steamer?"

"No," replied Fogg, coldly.

"But the steamer is going to leave!"

"I have missed it."

"Ah!" said Fix, "I am really sorry for you."

Mr. Fogg, with his habitual calmness, simply replied that it was an accident, and then turned to Aouda, who showed signs of uneasiness. "It is nothing, madam," he said; "it is an accident. We will go to the consulate and see if there is any means of leaving Hong Kong."

Aouda, with her usual trust in Mr. Fogg, made no remark. They set out at once.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: But he was not astonished; for he knew that Fix, the detective, must have detained Passepartout, and that the latter, in his simplicity, had allowed himself to be drawn into some snare. He was not uneasy, but he resolved to be on his guard. He dined at the usual hour, and, after dinner, went to his room. He did not go to bed, however, but sat in an arm-chair, and waited. As midnight struck, and Passepartout had not appeared, he rang for the bell. A servant entered. Phileas Fogg asked if his servant had returned. The man replied that he had not. Fogg dismissed him, and began to walk up and down the room. He was a man who could not be easily disturbed, but the absence of Passepartout, under such circumstances, might well have troubled him. Nevertheless, he showed no sign of anxiety, and, at half-past twelve, he lay down on the sofa, and soon fell asleep.

events.title: Fix Informs Fogg of the Early Departure and Delay
detailed_summary: Detective Fix, who had been watching, approaches Mr. Fogg.
Fix identifies himself as a fellow passenger from the "Rangoon".
He feigns surprise when asking about Fogg's servant, Passepartout.
Aouda expresses worry about Passepartout's disappearance since the previous day and asks if he might have boarded the "Carnatic".
Fix confirms Fogg and Aouda intended to take the "Carnatic".
He informs them the ship left twelve hours early due to completed repairs, necessitating a week's wait for the next steamer.
Fix internally celebrates this delay, hoping it provides time for the arrest warrant to arrive.
His hope is dashed when Fogg calmly suggests seeking alternative vessels in the harbour.

events.text_segment:
At this moment a man who had been observing him attentively approached. It was Fix, who, bowing, addressed Mr. Fogg: “Were you not, like me, sir, a passenger by the ‘Rangoon,’ which arrived yesterday?”
“I was, sir,” replied Mr. Fogg coldly. “But I have not the honour—”
“Pardon me; I thought I should find your servant here.”
“Do you know where he is, sir?” asked Aouda anxiously.
“What!” responded Fix, feigning surprise. “Is he not with you?”
“No,” said Aouda. “He has not made his appearance since yesterday. Could he have gone on board the ‘Carnatic’ without us?”
“Without you, madam?” answered the detective. “Excuse me, did you intend to sail in the ‘Carnatic’?”
“Yes, sir.”
“So did I, madam, and I am excessively disappointed. The ‘Carnatic’, its repairs being completed, left Hong Kong twelve hours before the stated time, without any notice being given; and we must now wait a week for another steamer.”
As he said “a week” Fix felt his heart leap for joy. Fogg detained at Hong Kong for a week! There would be time for the warrant to arrive, and fortune at last favoured the representative of the law. His horror may be imagined when he heard Mr. Fogg say, in his placid voice, “But there are other vessels besides the ‘Carnatic,’ it seems to me, in the harbour of Hong Kong.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
At this moment a man who had been observing him attentively approached. It was Fix, who, bowing, addressed him: "You are Mr. Phileas Fogg, are you not?"

"I am."

"And this lady—?"

"She is Miss Aouda," said Mr. Fogg.

"Aouda bowed in acknowledgment."

"I have just arrived by the Rangoon," continued Fix, "and I see that you, too, intended to embark on the Carnatic."

"Yes, sir," replied Mr. Fogg. "But we have missed her."

"I am very sorry to hear that," said Fix. "It is most unfortunate. But perhaps," he added, feigning surprise, "your servant—did he not go with you?"

Aouda, whose anxiety had not abated, said quickly, "We have not seen him since yesterday. He disappeared, and we do not know what has become of him."

"Could he have gone on board the Carnatic without you?" asked Fix.

"It is possible," said Mr. Fogg. "We will inquire."

Fix, who was delighted at the delay, said, "The Carnatic left twelve hours before the appointed time, owing to the completion of her repairs. The next steamer does not leave for a week."

A week! Mr. Fogg's brow contracted slightly, but he said, "We must look for some other means of leaving Hong Kong."

Fix, inwardly exulting, thought, "Now the warrant will arrive in time!" But he was soon disconcerted by Mr. Fogg's calmness and prompt decision to seek another vessel in the harbor.

"Yes, sir; but we have unfortunately missed her."

"I am extremely sorry," returned Fix. "I was just going to ask you if you had seen your servant."

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: It was Detective Fix, who had been following Phileas Fogg since his arrival in Suez. Fix, a shrewd and persistent officer, had received information from London about the recent robbery at the Bank of England, and the description of the suspect matched Fogg’s appearance. Fix had been watching Fogg’s every move, convinced that he was the elusive thief. As he drew near, Fix addressed Fogg politely, introducing himself as a police inspector attached to the Suez station. Fogg, ever composed, greeted him with his usual calm courtesy, betraying no sign of unease or guilt. Fix, seeking to probe further, asked Fogg about his journey and his reasons for traveling so hastily around the world. Fogg replied with measured words, explaining that he had made a wager and was determined to complete the journey in eighty days. Fix listened intently, noting every detail, but Fogg’s answers were so precise and unflappable that Fix found it difficult to catch him in any contradiction. Meanwhile, Passepartout, Fogg’s loyal servant, hovered nearby, curious about the conversation but unaware of Fix’s suspicions. The detective resolved to keep a close watch on Fogg, determined not to let him slip away. Thus began the subtle game of pursuit and evasion that would continue across continents and oceans.

events.title: Fogg's Determined Search for Alternative Transport
detailed_summary: Fogg escorts Aouda towards the docks to find another ship immediately.
A bewildered Fix follows, feeling compelled to stay close to Fogg.
Despite Fogg's previous good fortune, finding a suitable vessel proves difficult.
For three hours, Fogg searches the docks, considering chartering a vessel if needed.
He only finds ships currently loading or unloading, unable to depart promptly.
This temporary setback gives Fix a renewed sense of hope that Fogg will be delayed.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: And, offering his arm to Aouda, he directed his steps toward the docks in search of some craft about to start.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Fix began to hope again.

events.text_segment: And, offering his arm to Aouda, he directed his steps toward the docks in search of some craft about to start. Fix, stupefied, followed; it seemed as if he were attached to Mr. Fogg by an invisible thread. Chance, however, appeared really to have abandoned the man it had hitherto served so well. For three hours Phileas Fogg wandered about the docks, with the determination, if necessary, to charter a vessel to carry him to Yokohama; but he could only find vessels which were loading or unloading, and which could not therefore set sail. Fix began to hope again.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
And, offering his arm to Aouda, he directed his steps toward the docks in search of some craft about to start. Fix, who had kept close to Mr. Fogg, followed him, without being himself perceived. They descended the quay, but found no vessel at anchor. The ships which were loading or unloading, or waiting for repairs, could not leave for several days. Fix began to hope again.

Fogg and Aouda walked along the wharves, examining the various ships, but none were ready to put to sea. Fogg, determined not to lose an hour, resolved to charter a vessel, if possible, for Yokohama; but he could find none, even for ready money. Fix, meanwhile, kept a watchful eye on the proceedings, his hopes rising as the minutes passed and no solution presented itself to Fogg.

For three hours, Fogg searched the docks, inquiring at every shipping office, but always receiving the same discouraging reply. The delay, though temporary, was enough to give Fix renewed confidence that the journey would be interrupted, and that he would have time to secure the necessary warrant for Fogg's arrest.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: The night was dark, and a thin mist hung over the river, blurring the outlines of the vessels moored along the quay. Fogg, with his usual composure, moved forward, his keen eyes scanning the names and flags of the ships. Aouda, trusting in his resourcefulness, walked silently at his side. Passepartout, eager and alert, hurried a few paces ahead, questioning sailors and dockhands. Time pressed; every moment was precious if they were to continue their extraordinary journey.

events.title: Negotiating Passage on the Pilot Boat 'Tankadere'
detailed_summary: Undeterred, Fogg continues his search and is approached by a sailor offering a pilot boat, No. 43.
The sailor, John Bunsby, confirms the boat is ready and fast.
Fogg asks if Bunsby will take him to Yokohama to catch the San Francisco steamer by the 14th.
Bunsby is incredulous, stating the voyage is too long and risky at that time of year.
Fogg offers £100 per day plus a £200 bonus for timely arrival.
Bunsby hesitates, torn between the large payment and the danger.
Fix waits anxiously during the negotiation.
Fogg reassures Aouda, who affirms her lack of fear when with him.
Bunsby declines the Yokohama trip but suggests an alternative: sailing to Shanghai, only 800 miles away.
He explains the San Francisco steamer actually starts in Shanghai, stopping at Nagasaki and Yokohama later.
The Shanghai steamer departs on the 11th at 7 PM, leaving four days for the journey.
Bunsby believes they can reach Shanghai in time with favorable conditions.
Fogg agrees to the Shanghai trip and confirms Bunsby is the master of the boat, the "Tankadere".
Fogg pays £200 upfront and offers a place on the boat to Fix.
Fix accepts Fogg's offer.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: But Mr. Fogg, far from being discouraged, was continuing his search, resolved not to stop if he had to resort to Macao, when he was accosted by a sailor on one of the wharves.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Thanks, sir; I was about to ask the favour.”

events.text_segment:
But Mr. Fogg, far from being discouraged, was continuing his search, resolved not to stop if he had to resort to Macao, when he was accosted by a sailor on one of the wharves.
“Is your honour looking for a boat?”
“Have you a boat ready to sail?”
“Yes, your honour; a pilot-boat—No. 43—the best in the harbour.”
“Does she go fast?”
“Between eight and nine knots the hour. Will you look at her?”
“Yes.”
“Your honour will be satisfied with her. Is it for a sea excursion?”
“No; for a voyage.”
“A voyage?”
“Yes, will you agree to take me to Yokohama?”
The sailor leaned on the railing, opened his eyes wide, and said, “Is your honour joking?”
“No. I have missed the ‘Carnatic,’ and I must get to Yokohama by the 14th at the latest, to take the boat for San Francisco.”
“I am sorry,” said the sailor; “but it is impossible.”
“I offer you a hundred pounds per day, and an additional reward of two hundred pounds if I reach Yokohama in time.”
“Are you in earnest?”
“Very much so.”
The pilot walked away a little distance, and gazed out to sea, evidently struggling between the anxiety to gain a large sum and the fear of venturing so far. Fix was in mortal suspense.
Mr. Fogg turned to Aouda and asked her, “You would not be afraid, would you, madam?”
“Not with you, Mr. Fogg,” was her answer.
The pilot now returned, shuffling his hat in his hands.
“Well, pilot?” said Mr. Fogg.
“Well, your honour,” replied he, “I could not risk myself, my men, or my little boat of scarcely twenty tons on so long a voyage at this time of year. Besides, we could not reach Yokohama in time, for it is sixteen hundred and sixty miles from Hong Kong.”
“Only sixteen hundred,” said Mr. Fogg.
“It’s the same thing.”
Fix breathed more freely.
“But,” added the pilot, “it might be arranged another way.”
Fix ceased to breathe at all.
“How?” asked Mr. Fogg.
“By going to Nagasaki, at the extreme south of Japan, or even to Shanghai, which is only eight hundred miles from here. In going to Shanghai we should not be forced to sail wide of the Chinese coast, which would be a great advantage, as the currents run northward, and would aid us.”
“Pilot,” said Mr. Fogg, “I must take the American steamer at Yokohama, and not at Shanghai or Nagasaki.”
“Why not?” returned the pilot. “The San Francisco steamer does not start from Yokohama. It puts in at Yokohama and Nagasaki, but it starts from Shanghai.”
“You are sure of that?”
“Perfectly.”
“And when does the boat leave Shanghai?”
“On the 11th, at seven in the evening. We have, therefore, four days before us, that is ninety-six hours; and in that time, if we had good luck and a south-west wind, and the sea was calm, we could make those eight hundred miles to Shanghai.”
“And you could go—”
“In an hour; as soon as provisions could be got aboard and the sails put up.”
“It is a bargain. Are you the master of the boat?”
“Yes; John Bunsby, master of the ‘Tankadere.’”
“Would you like some earnest-money?”
“If it would not put your honour out—”
“Here are two hundred pounds on account sir,” added Phileas Fogg, turning to Fix, “if you would like to take advantage—”
“Thanks, sir; I was about to ask the favour.”

"Between eight and nine knots the hour. Will you look at her?"

"Yes."

"Your honour will be satisfied with her. Is it for a sea excursion?"

"No; for a voyage."

"A voyage?"

"Yes; will you engage to take me to Yokohama?"

The sailor leaned on the railing, opened his eyes wide, and said, "Is your honour joking?"

"No. I have missed the Carnatic, and I must get to Yokohama by the 14th, at the latest, to take the boat for San Francisco."

"I am sorry," said the pilot; "but it is impossible."

"I offer you a hundred pounds per day, and an additional two hundred pounds if I reach Yokohama in time."

The pilot seemed tempted by the large sum, but he replied, "No! I couldn't risk my men, nor myself. The distance is too great."

"Well," said Mr. Fogg, "if you cannot take me to Yokohama, can you take me to Shanghai?"

"Shanghai! That's different. Shanghai is only eight hundred miles from here, and the steamer for San Francisco starts from there. It passes by Yokohama, but if you miss it here, you can catch it at Shanghai."

"And when does the steamer leave Shanghai?"

"On the 11th, at seven in the evening. You have four days in which to get there. It's possible, if the wind holds."

"And if I pay you two hundred pounds?"

"I'll try, sir."

"You are the master of the boat?"

"Yes; John Bunsby, master of the Tankadere."

"Will you take me and these two persons to Shanghai?"

"Yes, if you pay me two hundred pounds in advance."

"Here are the two hundred pounds," said Mr. Fogg, handing the money to the pilot. "And here are three places engaged."

"Are you going to Shanghai too?" asked the pilot of Fix, who had quietly followed Mr. Fogg.

"Yes, yes," replied Fix, "I'll go with you."

"Good!" exclaimed Mr. Fogg. "The Tankadere is ready. Let us go on board."

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
This sailor, a rough-looking fellow with a weather-beaten face and a shrewd glint in his eye, approached Mr. Fogg with a certain air of familiarity. He touched his cap and said, "Beg pardon, sir, but are you the gentleman as is looking for a passage to Yokohama?"

Mr. Fogg regarded the man with his usual composure. "I am," he replied. "Do you know of a vessel bound for that port?"

"Well, sir," said the sailor, "there's the Tankadere, a small craft, but she's fast and her captain, John Bunsby, is a man as knows these waters as well as any. She'll be ready to sail with the tide, if the price is right."

Passepartout, who had been anxiously scanning the horizon, turned eagerly to his master. "Monsieur, perhaps this is our chance!"

Mr. Fogg nodded. "Take me to your captain," he said to the sailor.

The man led them along the bustling wharf, past piles of cargo and groups of Chinese laborers, until they reached a trim little schooner moored at the end of the pier. The Tankadere, though not large, looked seaworthy and well-kept. On her deck stood a stout, sunburnt man with a keen, intelligent face—Captain John Bunsby himself.

"Captain Bunsby?" inquired Mr. Fogg.

"Aye, sir. What can I do for you?"

"I wish to charter your vessel to take myself and two companions to Yokohama. Can you undertake the voyage?"

Captain Bunsby scratched his head. "It's a long run, sir, and the sea can be rough this time of year. But the Tankadere is fast, and if the wind holds, we might make it."

"What is your price?" asked Mr. Fogg, without hesitation.

The captain named a sum, which, though considerable, did not cause Mr. Fogg to flinch. "Agreed," he said. "When can you be ready to sail?"

"With the tide, sir. In less than an hour."

"Very well. We will be on board."

Passepartout, overjoyed at this unexpected turn of events, hurried off to fetch Aouda and their modest luggage. Within the hour, the three travelers were aboard the Tankadere, which soon cast off her moorings and glided out into the harbor, her sails billowing in the freshening breeze.

As the schooner sped eastward, Mr. Fogg stood on deck, his gaze fixed on the horizon. He betrayed no sign of anxiety, though the success of his journey now depended on the caprices of wind and sea. Passepartout, meanwhile, busied himself with the tasks assigned by the crew, eager to be of service and to distract himself from his worries.

Aouda, grateful for the calm assurance of her companions, watched the receding shore with mixed feelings—relief at their escape from peril, and apprehension at the uncertain future. Yet she drew comfort from Mr. Fogg's unshakable composure.

Thus, the Tankadere sailed on, bearing her passengers toward the distant coast of Japan, and Mr. Fogg, undaunted by obstacles, pressed forward in his race against time, determined to fulfill his extraordinary wager.

The boat is described as a well-maintained, fast, twenty-ton vessel with two masts, skippered by the capable John Bunsby.

events.text_segment:
Very well. In half an hour we shall go on board.”
“But poor Passepartout?” urged Aouda, who was much disturbed by the servant’s disappearance.
“I shall do all I can to find him,” replied Phileas Fogg.
While Fix, in a feverish, nervous state, repaired to the pilot-boat, the others directed their course to the police-station at Hong Kong. Phileas Fogg there gave Passepartout’s description, and left a sum of money to be spent in the search for him. The same formalities having been gone through at the French consulate, and the palanquin having stopped at the hotel for the luggage, which had been sent back there, they returned to the wharf.
It was now three o’clock; and pilot-boat No. 43, with its crew on board, and its provisions stored away, was ready for departure.
The “Tankadere” was a neat little craft of twenty tons, as gracefully built as if she were a racing yacht. Her shining copper sheathing, her galvanised iron-work, her deck, white as ivory, betrayed the pride taken by John Bunsby in making her presentable. Her two masts leaned a trifle backward; she carried brigantine, foresail, storm-jib, and standing-jib, and was well rigged for running before the wind; and she seemed capable of brisk speed, which, indeed, she had already proved by gaining several prizes in pilot-boat races. The crew of the “Tankadere” was composed of John Bunsby, the master, and four hardy mariners, who were familiar with the Chinese seas. John Bunsby, himself, a man of forty-five or thereabouts, vigorous, sunburnt, with a sprightly expression of the eye, and energetic and self-reliant countenance, would have inspired confidence in the most timid.
Phileas Fogg and Aouda went on board, where they found Fix already installed. Below deck was a square cabin, of which the walls bulged out in the form of cots, above a circular divan; in the centre was a table provided with a swinging lamp. The accommodation was confined, but neat.
“I am sorry to have nothing better to offer you,” said Mr. Fogg to Fix, who bowed without responding.
The detective had a feeling akin to humiliation in profiting by the kindness of Mr. Fogg.
“It’s certain,” thought he, “though rascal as he is, he is a polite one!”
The sails and the English flag were hoisted at ten minutes past three. Mr. Fogg and Aouda, who were seated on deck, cast a last glance at the quay, in the hope of espying Passepartout. Fix was not without his fears lest chance should direct the steps of the unfortunate servant, whom he had so badly treated, in this direction; in which case an explanation the reverse of satisfactory to the detective must have ensued. But the Frenchman did not appear, and, without doubt, was still lying under the stupefying influence of the opium.
John Bunsby, master, at length gave the order to start, and the “Tankadere,” taking the wind under her brigantine, foresail, and standing-jib, bounded briskly forward over the waves.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Very well. In half an hour we shall go on board.”

It was now half-past two, and the pilot-boat, with her crew, was ready for departure. Fix was on board before Mr. Fogg and Aouda arrived. The latter, after having inquired for Passepartout in vain, was quite uneasy; but Mr. Fogg did not betray the least disquietude. He knew that the time had come to leave Hong Kong, and that it was necessary to make every possible effort to find his servant. He went to the police station, gave a description of Passepartout, and left a sum of money to be used in the search. The same proceedings were repeated at the French consulate, and, after a brief visit to the hotel to collect their luggage, Mr. Fogg and Aouda returned to the wharf.

The "Tankadere" was a neat little craft of twenty tons, well rigged, with two masts, and a crew of four men, including John Bunsby, the master, a man of forty-five or thereabouts, of robust build and resolute countenance. The accommodations, though cramped, were clean and well kept. Mr. Fogg, after apologizing to Fix for the limited comfort, invited him to make himself at home. Fix, who was still haunted by suspicions, could not but feel humbled by the courtesy of the man he believed to be a criminal.

At ten minutes past three, the sails were hoisted, the English flag ran up to the masthead, and the "Tankadere" stood out to sea. Mr. Fogg and Aouda, standing on the deck, cast a last look at the quay in hopes of seeing Passepartout, but the poor fellow did not appear. Fix, meanwhile, inwardly congratulated himself that the Frenchman was not there, as his presence would have complicated matters. In reality, Passepartout, still under the influence of opium, was probably sleeping off his intoxication in some den of the city.

John Bunsby gave the word, and the "Tankadere," under full sail, headed for Shanghai.

Very well. In half an hour we shall go on board.”

It was now half-past two. The steamer to Yokohama was to leave at three. Fix, evidently very nervous, separated himself from the others, and proceeded to the pilot-boat, where he was to await the party. Mr. Fogg, Aouda, and the worthy John Bunsby repaired to the police station at once. Mr. Fogg gave Passepartout’s description, and left a sum of money to be employed in the search. The same formalities were gone through at the French consulate, and, after having vainly searched through the streets, Mr. Fogg and Aouda returned to the wharf.

It was now three o’clock; the pilot-boat, with all her crew on board, and her provisions stowed away, was ready for departure. John Bunsby was proud of his craft, which was a very fast sailer, and had a neat deck of well-scrubbed planks. She was built entirely of wood, and measured twenty tons. She was rigged as a schooner, and carried two masts. Her crew consisted of four men, all well seasoned to the sea. John Bunsby himself, a man of about forty-five, with a ruddy face, energetic and self-reliant, was as good a pilot as could be found.

Mr. Fogg and Aouda went on board, where they found Fix already installed. Below deck was a small cabin, with a divan, a table, and a swinging lamp. The accommodation was necessarily limited, but it was clean and neat. John Bunsby, proud of his boat, did the honours with a sailor’s frankness. Mr. Fogg apologized to Fix for offering him such a modest place. Fix, who had secretly hoped to avoid this journey, was forced to accept, and felt humiliated by the courtesy of the man whom he still suspected.

At ten minutes past three, the sails were hoisted, the English flag ran up to the masthead, and the "Tankadere" stood out to sea. Mr. Fogg and Aouda, standing on deck, cast a last look at the quay in hopes of seeing Passepartout. Fix, not without a certain inward emotion, scanned the wharf with a beating heart. But Passepartout did not appear; it was probable that, still under the stupefying influence of the opium, he was yet asleep in some den of the city.

At length John Bunsby gave the word, and the "Tankadere," under full sail, left the port of Hong Kong.

Passepartout heard this sentence with a beating heart, for it seemed to him that the moment of departure was at hand. He hurried to make the final arrangements, checking once more that all the trunks and bags were properly packed and labeled. The bustling activity of the port, with its shouts of sailors and the clatter of carts, filled the air as the hour of embarkation approached.

Phileas Fogg, as calm and composed as ever, stood by the quay, his eyes fixed on the steamer that would carry them on the next leg of their journey. Aouda, though anxious, trusted in Fogg’s unflappable demeanor, drawing comfort from his quiet confidence. Passepartout, meanwhile, darted back and forth, ensuring that nothing was left behind and that all was in readiness.

At the appointed time, Fogg led his companions up the gangway and onto the deck. The captain greeted them with a polite nod, and the crew set about preparing for departure. The whistle of the steamer sounded, echoing across the harbor, and the ropes were cast off. Slowly, the vessel began to move, gliding away from the dock and out into open water.

Passepartout stood at the rail, watching the receding shoreline with a mixture of excitement and apprehension. He could scarcely believe how far they had come, and how much farther they had yet to go. The world seemed at once vast and small, as if the boundaries of time and space could be traversed by the will of a determined man.

Fogg, ever attentive to the schedule, consulted his watch and the ship’s timetable. He calculated the hours to their next destination, allowing for every possible delay. His mind was a clockwork of precision, each thought and action measured against the inexorable march of time.

Aouda, grateful for the kindness and protection of her companions, gazed out at the sea, her thoughts drifting to the uncertain future. She wondered what awaited them at the next port, and whether their journey would end in triumph or disappointment.

As the steamer pressed on, the passengers settled into the routine of shipboard life. Meals were taken in the saloon, conversations held on the deck, and the days passed in a steady rhythm. Fogg remained focused on his goal, rarely indulging in idle talk, while Passepartout found himself drawn into the camaraderie of the crew, sharing stories and laughter to pass the time.

Yet beneath the surface, a sense of urgency persisted. The wager that had set them on this extraordinary journey weighed heavily on Fogg’s mind. Every hour counted, every delay was a potential disaster. But for now, as the ship cut through the waves and the sun dipped below the horizon, there was nothing to do but wait and hope that fortune would favor the bold.

Thus, with hearts full of hope and trepidation, the travelers pressed onward, their eyes fixed on the distant shore and the promise of adventure that lay ahead.

chapters.chapter_title: CHAPTER XXI. IN WHICH THE MASTER OF THE “TANKADERE” RUNS GREAT RISK OF LOSING A REWARD OF TWO HUNDRED POUNDS

events.title: Perilous Voyage Begins and Fix's Contemplation
detailed_summary: The journey from Hong Kong to Shanghai is presented as extremely dangerous due to the small size of the vessel, the 'Tankadere', and the volatile November weather in the Chinese seas, known for gales and equinoctial storms.
Despite the risks, the pilot, John Bunsby, trusts his boat's seaworthiness, even though proceeding to Yokohama would have been more profitable but far too dangerous.
The 'Tankadere' successfully navigates Hong Kong's channels and sails well in favourable winds upon reaching open water.
Phileas Fogg instructs the pilot to maximize speed, expressing confidence in the pilot's expertise.
Fogg stands steadily on deck observing the sea, unaffected by the motion.
Aouda, seated aft, feels overwhelmed looking at the vast, darkening ocean, perceiving the sails like large wings carrying the frail boat.
As night falls and the moon provides limited light, clouds gather, and the pilot activates the boat's lights for safety in the busy shipping lanes.
Fix remains isolated in the bow, reflecting on his situation. He avoids interaction with Fogg due to Fogg's reserved nature and Fix's discomfort at accepting Fogg's generosity.
Fix speculates that Fogg intends to proceed directly to San Francisco from Yokohama, using the vastness of America to escape justice with the stolen bank money.
He reaffirms his commitment to pursuing Fogg until extradition is secured, feeling it's his duty.
Fix finds solace in Passepartout's absence, realizing the importance of preventing any conversation between the servant (to whom he revealed much) and his master.

events.text_segment:
This voyage of eight hundred miles was a perilous venture on a craft of twenty tons, and at that season of the year. The Chinese seas are usually boisterous, subject to terrible gales of wind, and especially during the equinoxes; and it was now early November.
It would clearly have been to the master’s advantage to carry his passengers to Yokohama, since he was paid a certain sum per day; but he would have been rash to attempt such a voyage, and it was imprudent even to attempt to reach Shanghai. But John Bunsby believed in the “Tankadere,” which rode on the waves like a seagull; and perhaps he was not wrong.
Late in the day they passed through the capricious channels of Hong Kong, and the “Tankadere,” impelled by favourable winds, conducted herself admirably.
“I do not need, pilot,” said Phileas Fogg, when they got into the open sea, “to advise you to use all possible speed.”
“Trust me, your honour. We are carrying all the sail the wind will let us. The poles would add nothing, and are only used when we are going into port.”
“It’s your trade, not mine, pilot, and I confide in you.”
Phileas Fogg, with body erect and legs wide apart, standing like a sailor, gazed without staggering at the swelling waters. The young woman, who was seated aft, was profoundly affected as she looked out upon the ocean, darkening now with the twilight, on which she had ventured in so frail a vessel. Above her head rustled the white sails, which seemed like great white wings. The boat, carried forward by the wind, seemed to be flying in the air.
Night came. The moon was entering her first quarter, and her insufficient light would soon die out in the mist on the horizon. Clouds were rising from the east, and already overcast a part of the heavens.
The pilot had hung out his lights, which was very necessary in these seas crowded with vessels bound landward; for collisions are not uncommon occurrences, and, at the speed she was going, the least shock would shatter the gallant little craft.
Fix, seated in the bow, gave himself up to meditation. He kept apart from his fellow-travellers, knowing Mr. Fogg’s taciturn tastes; besides, he did not quite like to talk to the man whose favours he had accepted. He was thinking, too, of the future. It seemed certain that Fogg would not stop at Yokohama, but would at once take the boat for San Francisco; and the vast extent of America would ensure him impunity and safety. Fogg’s plan appeared to him the simplest in the world. Instead of sailing directly from England to the United States, like a common villain, he had traversed three quarters of the globe, so as to gain the American continent more surely; and there, after throwing the police off his track, he would quietly enjoy himself with the fortune stolen from the bank. But, once in the United States, what should he, Fix, do? Should he abandon this man? No, a hundred times no! Until he had secured his extradition, he would not lose sight of him for an hour. It was his duty, and he would fulfil it to the end. At all events, there was one thing to be thankful for; Passepartout was not with his master; and it was above all important, after the confidences Fix had imparted to him, that the servant should never have speech with his master.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
This voyage of eight hundred miles was a perilous venture on a craft of twenty tons, and at that season of the year. The Chinese seas are usually boisterous, subject to terrible gales of wind, especially during the equinoxes; and it was now early November. It would clearly have been to the pilot’s advantage to carry his passengers to Yokohama, since he was paid a certain sum per day; but he was obliged to go where the Tankadere could safely go, and no farther. John Bunsby, therefore, though he knew the value of time to the passengers, did not attempt imprudently to brave the perils of the sea. He was a bold mariner, but prudent, and he had a thorough confidence in his little craft.

The Tankadere, it is true, was a small vessel, but she was built for speed, and she had proved herself on many occasions. The channels of Hong Kong were soon left behind, and she was running on the open sea. The wind was favourable, the sails were set, and the vessel bounded forward on the waves. Phileas Fogg stood on the deck, calm and steady, watching the blue expanse of the ocean. He was not one to be discomposed by the motion of the vessel. Aouda, less accustomed to the sea, sat aft, her eyes fixed upon the dark horizon, her mind filled with vague apprehensions. The sails, like great white wings, seemed to bear the frail boat into the immensity of space.

Night came. The moon was hidden behind the clouds, but the sea was illuminated by the phosphorescent gleam of the waves. John Bunsby, standing at the helm, watched the lights of the vessels which passed to and fro in the distance. He had hoisted the side-lights, and the Tankadere, under her double-reefed sails, flew swiftly on her course.

Fix, seated in the bow, remained silent. He kept apart from his companions, not wishing to speak to Mr. Fogg, whose reserve he had not been able to break, nor to Aouda, to whom he could not explain his position without betraying his secret. He was, indeed, in a most embarrassing situation. He had received Fogg’s money, but he felt that he had not earned it, and he did not know how to return it. He was, moreover, determined to follow Fogg to the end of the world if necessary, but he was not without anxiety as to the result of the adventure. He thought that Fogg, after reaching Yokohama, would go straight on to San Francisco, and that once in the vast territory of the United States, it would be very difficult to arrest him. The thought that he had let Passepartout escape him, and that the latter might, at any moment, warn his master, tormented him. He resolved, therefore, to keep a close watch upon the servant, and to prevent any communication between him and his master.

He was a bold mariner, but prudent, and he had a thorough confidence in his little craft.

The Tankadere, it is true, was a small vessel, but she was built for speed, and she had proved herself on many occasions. The channels of Hong Kong were soon left behind, and she was running on the open sea. The wind was favourable, the sails were set, and the vessel bounded forward on the waves. Phileas Fogg stood on the deck, calm and steady, watching the blue expanse of the ocean. He was not one to be discomposed by the motion of the vessel. Aouda, less accustomed to the sea, sat aft, her eyes fixed upon the dark horizon, her mind filled with vague apprehensions. The sails, like great white wings, seemed to bear the frail boat into the immensity of space.

Night came. The moon was hidden behind the clouds, but the sea was illuminated by the phosphorescent gleam of the waves. John Bunsby, standing at the helm, watched the lights of the vessels which passed to and fro in the distance. He had hoisted the side-lights, and the Tankadere, under her double-reefed sails, flew swiftly on her course.

Fix, seated in the bow, remained silent. He kept apart from his companions, not wishing to speak to Mr. Fogg, whose reserve he had not been able to break, nor to Aouda, to whom he could not explain his position without betraying his secret. He was, indeed, in a most embarrassing situation. He had received Fogg’s money, but he felt that he had not earned it, and he did not know how to return it. He was, moreover, determined to follow Fogg to the end of the world if necessary, but he was not without anxiety as to the result of the adventure. He thought that Fogg, after reaching Yokohama, would go straight on to San Francisco, and that once in the vast territory of the United States, it would be very difficult to arrest him. The thought that he had let Passepartout escape him, and that the latter might, at any moment, warn his master, tormented him. He resolved, therefore, to keep a close watch upon the servant, and to prevent any communication between him and his master.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text:
This voyage of eight hundred miles was a perilous venture on a craft of twenty tons, and at that season of the year. The Chinese seas are usually boisterous, subject to terrible gales of wind, especially during the equinoxes; and it was now early November. It would clearly have been to the pilot’s advantage to carry his passengers to Yokohama, since he was paid a certain sum per day; but, he would have been rash to attempt such a voyage in so frail a vessel at this time of the year. John Bunsby, therefore, though he knew the value of time to the gentleman, did not attempt imprudently to brave the perils of the sea. He thought, however, that the journey from Hong Kong to Shanghai might be accomplished in a few days, and that the Tankadere, well built, well rigged, and well manned, would stand the voyage.

Phileas Fogg, with his usual calmness, had gone on board, paid the pilot and crew their wages in advance, and ordered the pilot to proceed at full speed. The crew, composed of four men, including the pilot, John Bunsby, were English, and knew their business. The Tankadere was a little schooner of twenty tons, as trim as a racing yacht, and with a foot of sail that would have done credit to a clipper.

The weather was fine, and the wind, which was blowing from the south-west, filled the sails, and the vessel bounded forward on the waves. The passengers were accommodated as comfortably as possible in a very narrow cabin. At eight o’clock the little schooner passed through the harbour, and entered the straits of Hong Kong. The Tankadere, impelled by favourable winds, cut through the waves with great rapidity; and if nothing occurred to break her speed, she would reach Shanghai in the time required.

Phileas Fogg stood on the deck, with legs wide apart, as if braced against the rolling of the vessel. He was as calm as ever, and showed no sign of uneasiness. Aouda, seated aft, looked with deep emotion upon the ocean, darkening now with the twilight, on which she had ventured in so frail a vessel. Above her head fluttered the white sails, which seemed like great wings bearing the boat onward with the wind.

Night came. The moon was entering her first quarter, and her light, as yet faint, was soon lost in the clouds which scudded across the sky. The pilot had hung out his lights, which was very necessary in these seas, crowded with vessels bound landward; for collisions are not uncommon occurrences, and, at the speed she was going, the least shock would shatter the gallant little craft.

Fix, seated in the bows, was absorbed in the contemplation of the ocean. He did not care to talk to his companions, and, for an additional reason, avoided conversation with Mr. Fogg, to whom he had not yet ventured to return the money received as a bribe. He was thinking, too, of the future. It seemed certain that Fogg would not stop at Yokohama, but would at once take the American steamer for San Francisco, and the vast expanse of the Pacific would secure him from pursuit. Fix’s conviction was confirmed by the manner in which the voyage was being made, and he resolved to stick to the gentleman until he reached England, but at the same time to prevent, if possible, any communication between Passepartout and his master, for he had confessed to the servant, and the latter would certainly warn his master of his true character, if they met.

1. MAJOR STRUCTURAL ISSUES:

3. INACCURATE ELEMENTS:

- The completion misattributes certain actions and thoughts to John Bunsby and Fix, introducing invented motivations and concerns not present in the original.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The weather, which had hitherto been fine, began to change. The wind, though still favorable, was capricious, and the sky, overcast with threatening clouds, gave warning of a coming storm. The little tankadere, with her slender hull and light rigging, was ill-fitted to withstand the violence of the elements, and her captain, John Bunsby, cast many an anxious glance at the horizon, where the clouds gathered in ominous masses. Nevertheless, the brave sailor, confident in his seamanship, pressed on, keeping the vessel as close to the wind as her sails would permit.

Phileas Fogg, calm as ever, stood on the deck, his eyes fixed on the compass, while Passepartout, though somewhat uneasy, busied himself with the duties assigned him by the crew. Aouda, wrapped in a thick cloak, sat near the cabin, her face pale but resolute, trusting implicitly in the courage and resourcefulness of her companions.

As night fell, the wind freshened, and the tankadere began to pitch and roll in the rising sea. The waves, lashed by the gale, broke over the bows, drenching the deck and making it difficult to keep one's footing. Bunsby, with a firm hand on the tiller, shouted orders to his men, who reefed the sails and secured the rigging. The little vessel, though tossed about like a cork, held her course bravely, heading eastward towards the mouth of the Hooghly.

Hour after hour passed in anxious suspense. The storm increased in violence, and it seemed at times as if the tankadere must founder. But Bunsby, with the skill of a veteran sailor, steered her through the tumultuous waters, avoiding the shoals and sandbanks that threatened to wreck her at every turn. Phileas Fogg, unmoved by the danger, maintained his usual composure, encouraging his companions by his calm demeanor.

At length, towards morning, the wind abated, and the sea grew calmer. The clouds broke, and the first rays of dawn illuminated the distant shore. The tankadere, battered but unscathed, glided into the mouth of the river, and Bunsby, with a sigh of relief, guided her towards the port of Calcutta.

The voyage, though perilous, had been accomplished in safety, and Phileas Fogg, ever mindful of his schedule, lost no time in making arrangements for the next stage of his journey. Passepartout, overjoyed at their escape, thanked Bunsby and his crew for their courage and skill, while Aouda expressed her gratitude in words that brought a flush of pleasure to the weather-beaten faces of the sailors.

Thus, after a night of danger and suspense, the travelers found themselves once more on solid ground, ready to continue their adventurous journey around the world. The perils of the sea had been overcome, but new challenges awaited them on the road to Calcutta, where fate and fortune would once again test their courage and resolve.

events.title: Concerns for Passepartout and Night Sailing
detailed_summary: Phileas Fogg contemplates Passepartout's sudden disappearance, considering it possible that his servant mistakenly boarded the 'Carnatic' at the last minute.
Aouda shares this view, expressing sadness over the loss of Passepartout, to whom she feels indebted.
They entertain the hope of finding Passepartout in Yokohama by checking the 'Carnatic's' passenger list.
Around ten o'clock, a strong breeze develops, but the pilot decides against reducing sail after assessing the sky, confident in the 'Tankadere's' stability.
At midnight, Fogg and Aouda retire to the cabin, where Fix is already resting, leaving the pilot and crew on deck overnight.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Phileas Fogg was also thinking of Passepartout, who had so strangely disappeared.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The pilot and crew remained on deck all night.

events.text_segment:
Phileas Fogg was also thinking of Passepartout, who had so strangely disappeared. Looking at the matter from every point of view, it did not seem to him impossible that, by some mistake, the man might have embarked on the “Carnatic” at the last moment; and this was also Aouda’s opinion, who regretted very much the loss of the worthy fellow to whom she owed so much. They might then find him at Yokohama; for, if the “Carnatic” was carrying him thither, it would be easy to ascertain if he had been on board.
A brisk breeze arose about ten o’clock; but, though it might have been prudent to take in a reef, the pilot, after carefully examining the heavens, let the craft remain rigged as before. The “Tankadere” bore sail admirably, as she drew a great deal of water, and everything was prepared for high speed in case of a gale.
Mr. Fogg and Aouda descended into the cabin at midnight, having been already preceded by Fix, who had lain down on one of the cots. The pilot and crew remained on deck all night.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Phileas Fogg was also thinking of Passepartout, who had so strangely disappeared. Looking at the matter from every point of view, it seemed to him that his honest and faithful servant had not quitted Hong Kong voluntarily, but that, caught unawares, he had been separated from them by some accident, or perhaps by a misunderstanding of orders. This was also the opinion of Aouda, who regretted the loss of the worthy fellow to whom she owed so much. They might possibly find him at Yokohama, for, if the Carnatic was carrying him thither, it would be easy to ascertain if he had taken passage on board her. A conversation ensued on this subject, but it was soon interrupted by the appearance of the pilot, who came to inform them that a fresh breeze was blowing from the west, and that the sails were in a fair way to carry them rapidly on their course.

Mr. Fogg and Aouda at once went on deck. The night was clear, and the moon shone brightly. The Tankadere, under all her sail, was running swiftly before the wind. The crew, consisting of the master, a mate, and four hands from the pilot-boat, were grouped on the forecastle. John Bunsby, standing aft, was steering with a steady hand. The pilot took a rapid survey of the horizon, and, satisfied with the prospect, returned to his post. The passengers remained on deck for some time, enjoying the fresh sea-breeze, which seemed to restore them to new life. Fix, who was not as much at ease as his companions, did not join them, but lay stretched on a bench in the forepart of the vessel. They talked of the chances of reaching Shanghai in time, and of the probability of finding Passepartout at Yokohama. The night advanced, and the passengers retired to the small cabin, where they found Fix already asleep. The pilot and his crew remained on deck all night.

events.title: Good Progress and Fix's Awkward Offer
detailed_summary: By sunrise on November 8th, the boat has covered over a hundred miles, averaging eight to nine miles per hour.
The 'Tankadere' continues at maximum speed under full sail, indicating favourable prospects if the wind persists.
The boat stays close to the coast to benefit from favourable currents, keeping the irregular shoreline within about five miles.
The sea remains relatively calm due to the offshore wind, advantageous for the small vessel.
The wind briefly weakens around noon, prompting the pilot to raise poles, but they are soon lowered as the wind strengthens again.
Fogg and Aouda handle the sea well and eat heartily.
Fix is invited to join their meal but accepts with resentment, disliking being dependent on Fogg.
After eating, Fix privately approaches Fogg, expressing discomfort and offering to pay his share for the passage.
Fogg firmly refuses, stating the cost is part of his overall travel expenses, leaving no room for argument.
Feeling rebuffed and stifled, Fix retreats to the bow and remains silent for the rest of the day.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: At sunrise the next day, which was 8th November, the boat had made more than one hundred miles.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Fix, as he bowed, had a stifled feeling, and, going forward, where he ensconced himself, did not open his mouth for the rest of the day.

events.text_segment:
At sunrise the next day, which was 8th November, the boat had made more than one hundred miles. The log indicated a mean speed of between eight and nine miles. The “Tankadere” still carried all sail, and was accomplishing her greatest capacity of speed. If the wind held as it was, the chances would be in her favour. During the day she kept along the coast, where the currents were favourable; the coast, irregular in profile, and visible sometimes across the clearings, was at most five miles distant. The sea was less boisterous, since the wind came off land—a fortunate circumstance for the boat, which would suffer, owing to its small tonnage, by a heavy surge on the sea.
The breeze subsided a little towards noon, and set in from the south-west. The pilot put up his poles, but took them down again within two hours, as the wind freshened up anew.
Mr. Fogg and Aouda, happily unaffected by the roughness of the sea, ate with a good appetite, Fix being invited to share their repast, which he accepted with secret chagrin. To travel at this man’s expense and live upon his provisions was not palatable to him. Still, he was obliged to eat, and so he ate.
When the meal was over, he took Mr. Fogg apart, and said, “sir”—this “sir” scorched his lips, and he had to control himself to avoid collaring this “gentleman”—“sir, you have been very kind to give me a passage on this boat. But, though my means will not admit of my expending them as freely as you, I must ask to pay my share—”
“Let us not speak of that, sir,” replied Mr. Fogg.
“But, if I insist—”
“No, sir,” repeated Mr. Fogg, in a tone which did not admit of a reply. “This enters into my general expenses.”
Fix, as he bowed, had a stifled feeling, and, going forward, where he ensconced himself, did not open his mouth for the rest of the day.

John Bunsby was obliged to hug the coast, and carefully watch the irregularities of the shore, which he was obliged to follow. The wind, which had thus far been favourable, was becoming capricious, and showed signs of shifting. The breeze, however, freshened again at noon, and the boat made good progress. LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The weather was clear, and the wind, having shifted to the southeast, blew briskly, propelling the General Grant swiftly along the coast of China. Phileas Fogg, ever punctual and composed, was on deck at dawn, his eyes fixed on the horizon, calculating the distance yet to be covered. Passepartout, his faithful servant, bustled about, ensuring that his master’s needs were met and that nothing was amiss with their luggage. The other passengers, some still groggy from sleep, emerged gradually, drawn by the promise of a fine day at sea.

The steamer’s engines throbbed steadily, and the crew moved with practiced efficiency. Mr. Fix, the detective, kept a discreet watch on Fogg, still convinced that the unflappable Englishman was the bank robber he sought. Yet, as the hours passed, even Fix could not help but admire Fogg’s calm demeanor and precise habits.

Breakfast was served in the saloon, where the travelers exchanged news and speculated about their arrival in Yokohama. The captain assured them that, barring unforeseen delays, they would reach their destination on schedule. Fogg, consulting his ever-present itinerary, nodded in satisfaction. Every hour gained was precious, for the wager he had staked his fortune upon allowed no margin for error.

Passepartout, meanwhile, found himself drawn into conversation with a group of merchants, who regaled him with tales of their adventures in the Far East. He listened with wide-eyed wonder, marveling at the diversity of the world and the ingenuity of those who traversed it. Yet, beneath his cheerful exterior, he worried about the obstacles that might yet arise.

As the sun climbed higher, the General Grant continued her voyage, slicing through the waves with purpose. The day promised fair weather and smooth sailing, but all aboard knew that the journey was far from over. Each mile brought them closer to their goal—and to the unknown challenges that awaited them on the road around the world.

events.title: Rapid Progress Meets Rising Storm
detailed_summary: The 'Tankadere' makes excellent progress, fueling John Bunsby's optimism about reaching Shanghai on time, which Fogg calmly acknowledges.
The crew works diligently, motivated by the promised reward, ensuring every sail is perfectly set and the steering is precise.
By evening, they have traveled 220 miles from Hong Kong, bolstering Fogg's hope of reaching Yokohama without further delays impacting his schedule.
During the night, the boat enters the rough Straits of Fo-Kien, encountering challenging eddies and choppy waves that make standing difficult.
At daybreak, the wind intensifies, and the sky signals an impending gale, confirmed by erratic barometer readings and large swells from the south-east.
The previous sunset had been ominous, occurring amidst a red mist and phosphorescent ocean.
John Bunsby observes the worsening weather with concern and informs Fogg that a squall is approaching.
Fogg calmly inquires about the wind direction.
Bunsby confirms it's a southern wind, warning of an oncoming typhoon.
Fogg pragmatically notes that a southerly typhoon will actually help push them forward.
Bunsby, taken aback by Fogg's perspective, accepts his view, though his own meteorological knowledge indicates a violent winter typhoon is likely.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Meanwhile they were progressing famously, and John Bunsby was in high hope.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: At a less advanced season of the year the typhoon, according to a famous meteorologist, would have passed away like a luminous cascade of electric flame; but in the winter equinox it was to be feared that it would burst upon them with great violence.

events.text_segment:
Meanwhile they were progressing famously, and John Bunsby was in high hope. He several times assured Mr. Fogg that they would reach Shanghai in time; to which that gentleman responded that he counted upon it. The crew set to work in good earnest, inspired by the reward to be gained. There was not a sheet which was not tightened, not a sail which was not vigorously hoisted; not a lurch could be charged to the man at the helm. They worked as desperately as if they were contesting in a Royal yacht regatta.
By evening, the log showed that two hundred and twenty miles had been accomplished from Hong Kong, and Mr. Fogg might hope that he would be able to reach Yokohama without recording any delay in his journal; in which case, the many misadventures which had overtaken him since he left London would not seriously affect his journey.
The “Tankadere” entered the Straits of Fo-Kien, which separate the island of Formosa from the Chinese coast, in the small hours of the night, and crossed the Tropic of Cancer. The sea was very rough in the straits, full of eddies formed by the counter-currents, and the chopping waves broke her course, whilst it became very difficult to stand on deck.
At daybreak the wind began to blow hard again, and the heavens seemed to predict a gale. The barometer announced a speedy change, the mercury rising and falling capriciously; the sea also, in the south-east, raised long surges which indicated a tempest. The sun had set the evening before in a red mist, in the midst of the phosphorescent scintillations of the ocean.
John Bunsby long examined the threatening aspect of the heavens, muttering indistinctly between his teeth. At last he said in a low voice to Mr. Fogg, “Shall I speak out to your honour?”
“Of course.”
“Well, we are going to have a squall.”
“Is the wind north or south?” asked Mr. Fogg quietly.
“South. Look! a typhoon is coming up.”
“Glad it’s a typhoon from the south, for it will carry us forward.”
“Oh, if you take it that way,” said John Bunsby, “I’ve nothing more to say.” John Bunsby’s suspicions were confirmed. At a less advanced season of the year the typhoon, according to a famous meteorologist, would have passed away like a luminous cascade of electric flame; but in the winter equinox it was to be feared that it would burst upon them with great violence.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Meanwhile they were progressing famously, and John Bunsby was in high hope. He took a pleasure in seeing the good craft cleaving the waves like a real English boat, and the crew were working with a will, inspired by the reward to be gained. The sails, well set, were distending in the wind, and the vessel sped forward as if she had wings. Phileas Fogg, seated aft, was as calm and taciturn as ever; he had not changed by so much as a hair’s breadth since the departure from Hong Kong. He was still the impassible man, and yet, to a keen observer, a slight gleam of satisfaction might have been detected in his eyes.

At noon the Tankadere had passed the cape of Lamock, and was forty-five miles from land. They had still one hundred and sixty miles to traverse before reaching Yokohama, and the wind was favourable; the little craft would have carried a full sail, but the captain prudently carried but two, so as not to press her unduly. John Bunsby was anxious to get in before night, for he had no confidence in the weather, and he was right. During the night the Tankadere entered the Straits of Fo-Kien, which separate the coast of China from the island of Formosa. The sea was very rough in these narrow straits, and the Tankadere was pitched about by the waves. The wind increased, and it was becoming very difficult to stand on the deck.

At daybreak the wind grew stronger. The sky was covered with thick clouds, and the barometer indicated a rapid fall. John Bunsby examined the threatening aspect of the heavens with a sailor’s care, and muttered between his teeth:

"Another squall!"

Phileas Fogg, who had been quietly watching the sky, said to the pilot:

"Is the wind coming from the south?"

"Yes, your honour," replied John Bunsby, "and it’s a typhoon coming up."

"Will it blow from the south?"

"No, from the south-west; but it will pass to the north-west, and may drive us out to sea."

"We must risk it," said Fogg. "Let us carry all sail."

The crew obeyed, and the Tankadere continued her course. The sea became very rough, and the little vessel was tossed about in every direction. Night came on, and the tempest increased in violence. John Bunsby saw the reward of two hundred pounds slipping from his grasp. He muttered, "If I can keep her afloat, I’ll be lucky!"
