He was still the impassible man, and yet, to a keen observer, a slight gleam of satisfaction might have been detected in his eyes.

At noon the Tankadere had passed the cape of Lamock, and was forty-five miles from land. They had still one hundred and sixty miles to traverse before reaching Yokohama, and the wind was favourable; the little craft would have carried a full sail, but the captain prudently carried but two, so as not to press her unduly. John Bunsby was anxious to get in before night, for he had no confidence in the weather, and he was right. During the night the Tankadere entered the Straits of Fo-Kien, which separate the coast of China from the island of Formosa. The sea was very rough in these narrow straits, and the Tankadere was pitched about by the waves. The wind increased, and it was becoming very difficult to stand on the deck.

At daybreak the wind grew stronger. The sky was covered with thick clouds, and the barometer indicated a rapid fall. John Bunsby examined the threatening aspect of the heavens with a sailor’s care, and muttered between his teeth:

"Another squall!"

Phileas Fogg, who had been quietly watching the sky, said to the pilot:

"Is the wind coming from the south?"

"Yes, your honour," replied John Bunsby, "and it’s a typhoon coming up."

"Will it blow from the south?"

"No, from the south-west; but it will pass to the north-west, and may drive us out to sea."

"We must risk it," said Fogg. "Let us carry all sail."

The crew obeyed, and the Tankadere continued her course. The sea became very rough, and the little vessel was tossed about in every direction. Night came on, and the tempest increased in violence. John Bunsby saw the reward of two hundred pounds slipping from his grasp. He muttered, "If I can keep her afloat, I’ll be lucky!"

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text: Meanwhile they were progressing famously, and John Bunsby was in high hope. He took a pleasure in seeing the good craft cleaving the waves like a real English boat, and the crew worked with a will, for they were paid for extra exertion. The promised reward acted as a stimulant, and every one was doing his best. The sails, tautened to the utmost, bore all the pressure of the wind, and the Tankadere flew forward as if she were a race-horse. By evening the log showed that two hundred and twenty miles had been accomplished from Hong Kong, and Phileas Fogg might hope that he would be able to reach Yokohama without further delay, and so gain an advance on the prescribed time. That evening, the yacht entered the Straits of Fo-Kien, which separate the coast of China from Formosa. The sea was very rough in these narrow straits, and the Tankadere was pitched about by the billows. The wind had freshened, and it was difficult to stand on the deck. At daybreak the wind blew hard, the sky was overcast, and the sea covered with foam. The barometer indicated a probable fall in the weather, and the sun rose in a hazy, red mist, through which the phosphorescent ocean shone with an ominous light. John Bunsby examined the threatening aspect of the heavens, muttering indistinctly between his teeth. When he had finished his observations, he went and stood by Mr. Fogg, and said, "Sir, I think there’s a squall ahead." "Is the wind for or against us?" asked Mr. Fogg quietly. "For us. It is blowing from the south; but it is likely to change before long." "And if it does?" "We’ll try to keep ahead of it, sir. If we can’t, we must stop, and we’ll be blown back." "Then we must do our best, John," replied Mr. Fogg. "And I will reward you." "Never fear, sir," said John Bunsby. "I’ll do what a man can do. But I tell you there’s a typhoon coming on." "Let it come," said Fogg. "It will carry us forward faster." John Bunsby could not help admiring the coolness of his passenger, who was not only not afraid, but seemed to hope for a tempest. The pilot did not know, however, that Fogg owed to the famous meteorologist, Fitzjames Stephen, the knowledge that in the winter the typhoon, or cyclone, is always from the south, and that it is the best wind that could blow them to Yokohama.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The weather was fair, the wind steady, and the little tankadère cut through the waves with remarkable speed. Phileas Fogg, ever calm and composed, stood on the deck, his eyes fixed on the horizon, while Passepartout, unable to contain his excitement, moved about the vessel, occasionally exchanging a few words with the worthy skipper. Aouda, though still somewhat anxious, had gained confidence from the resolute demeanor of her companions and the evident skill of John Bunsby and his crew.

As the hours passed, the coast of China gradually faded from view, replaced by the endless expanse of the South China Sea. The tankadère, though small, proved herself a seaworthy craft, and Bunsby, with his years of experience, handled her with a master’s touch. The sails were trimmed to catch every breath of wind, and the vessel heeled gracefully, making the most of the favorable conditions.

Passepartout, ever the optimist, could not help but express his admiration. “Monsieur Fogg, we shall arrive in Hong Kong ahead of schedule, I am sure of it!” he exclaimed, his face beaming with hope.

Fogg merely nodded, consulting his watch and the nautical chart spread out before him. “We must maintain this speed,” he replied, “and hope that the wind does not shift.”

John Bunsby, overhearing the conversation, chimed in with a confident grin. “No fear, sir! The wind’s with us, and barring any unforeseen squalls, we’ll make Hong Kong in good time.”

The day wore on, and the sun began its descent toward the western horizon, painting the sky with hues of orange and gold. The crew, though few in number, worked diligently, adjusting the rigging and keeping a sharp lookout for any signs of danger. The sea, for the moment, remained calm, and the tankadère sped onward, her bow cutting cleanly through the gentle swells.

As night fell, the stars emerged, guiding the little vessel on her course. Fogg, ever methodical, calculated their position and estimated the time of arrival. Passepartout, wrapped in his coat, gazed up at the constellations, marveling at the adventure that had brought him so far from home.

Thus, with hope in their hearts and the wind at their backs, the travelers pressed on toward Hong Kong, each hour bringing them closer to their goal—and to the next stage of their extraordinary journey around the world.

events.title: Battling the Typhoon's Fury
detailed_summary: The pilot takes immediate storm precautions: reefing sails, removing poles, and positioning the crew at the bows.
A small, strong triangular storm-jib is hoisted to maintain some control.
Bunsby advises passengers to go below, but Fogg, Fix, and Aouda refuse, disliking the confinement and preferring to stay on deck despite the danger.
Around 8 o'clock, the storm hits with intense rain and wind, tossing the 'Tankadere' like a feather at incredible speed.
The boat is driven northward all day by monstrous waves, managing to keep pace with them.
It narrowly avoids being swamped multiple times due to the pilot's skillful maneuvering.
The passengers are frequently soaked by spray but endure it; Fix is inwardly frustrated, Aouda observes Fogg's calmness with admiration, and Fogg remains unfazed, treating the typhoon as expected.
Towards evening, the wind shifts to the north-west, causing the boat to roll violently in the wave troughs.
As darkness falls, the storm intensifies further, filling Bunsby with dread.
After consulting his crew, Bunsby suggests to Fogg that they should seek shelter in a coastal port.
Fogg agrees with the idea of heading to a port.
When Bunsby asks which port, Fogg calmly and resolutely insists on continuing towards their original destination: Shanghai.
The pilot is initially stunned by Fogg's determination but ultimately agrees, directing the 'Tankadere' back onto its northward course despite the severe conditions.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The pilot took his precautions in advance.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: So the “Tankadere” kept steadily on her northward track.

events.text_segment:
The pilot took his precautions in advance. He reefed all sail, the pole-masts were dispensed with; all hands went forward to the bows. A single triangular sail, of strong canvas, was hoisted as a storm-jib, so as to hold the wind from behind. Then they waited.
John Bunsby had requested his passengers to go below; but this imprisonment in so narrow a space, with little air, and the boat bouncing in the gale, was far from pleasant. Neither Mr. Fogg, Fix, nor Aouda consented to leave the deck.
The storm of rain and wind descended upon them towards eight o’clock. With but its bit of sail, the “Tankadere” was lifted like a feather by a wind, an idea of whose violence can scarcely be given. To compare her speed to four times that of a locomotive going on full steam would be below the truth.
The boat scudded thus northward during the whole day, borne on by monstrous waves, preserving always, fortunately, a speed equal to theirs. Twenty times she seemed almost to be submerged by these mountains of water which rose behind her; but the adroit management of the pilot saved her. The passengers were often bathed in spray, but they submitted to it philosophically. Fix cursed it, no doubt; but Aouda, with her eyes fastened upon her protector, whose coolness amazed her, showed herself worthy of him, and bravely weathered the storm. As for Phileas Fogg, it seemed just as if the typhoon were a part of his programme.
Up to this time the “Tankadere” had always held her course to the north; but towards evening the wind, veering three quarters, bore down from the north-west. The boat, now lying in the trough of the waves, shook and rolled terribly; the sea struck her with fearful violence. At night the tempest increased in violence. John Bunsby saw the approach of darkness and the rising of the storm with dark misgivings. He thought awhile, and then asked his crew if it was not time to slacken speed. After a consultation he approached Mr. Fogg, and said, “I think, your honour, that we should do well to make for one of the ports on the coast.”
“I think so too.”
“Ah!” said the pilot. “But which one?”
“I know of but one,” returned Mr. Fogg tranquilly.
“And that is—”
“Shanghai.”
The pilot, at first, did not seem to comprehend; he could scarcely realise so much determination and tenacity. Then he cried, “Well—yes! Your honour is right. To Shanghai!”
So the “Tankadere” kept steadily on her northward track.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
The pilot took his precautions in advance. He reefed the sails, removed the poles, had the crew take their places at the bows. A small, but very strong, triangular sail, a storm-jib, was hoisted in its place, to hold the wind from astern, and the Tankadere was as much as possible put in condition to brave the tempest. John Bunsby advised that the passengers go below, but this was not to the taste of either Mr. Fogg, Fix, or Aouda. The confinement in so small a cabin, with the boat pitching and rolling fearfully, was far from inviting. They preferred to remain on deck, watching the tempest, which was then at its height.

The rain fell in torrents, and the wind blew with tremendous violence. The Tankadere, under her reduced sail, was lifted like a feather by the wind, and flew off at a speed of twelve to thirteen knots. The waves foamed and crested around her, and she seemed almost to mount them. The mariners' hands never left the ropes, and their eyes were fixed on the rigging and the sails, lest the least accident should imperil the vessel. The passengers were often drenched by the spray, but they did not complain. Fix gnawed his lips with rage; the delay, so contrary to his hopes, filled him with despair. Aouda, with her eyes fixed upon her companion, beheld him calm and unmoved, as if the storm were a part of his programme, and he were foreordained to brave it, if not to conquer it. As for Phileas Fogg, he was as calm as ever, and showed neither impatience nor anxiety. He was not one to be disconcerted by a storm.

Towards eight o'clock the wind veered to the north-west. The boat now rolled heavily, and the sea struck her with great violence. The night was dark, and the tempest increased in fury. John Bunsby began to feel anxious. He consulted his crew, who agreed with him that it would be prudent to make for one of the ports on the coast. He approached Mr. Fogg, and said, "I think, sir, we ought to make for a port."

"It will be time enough to do so, if we cannot reach Shanghai," was Mr. Fogg's tranquil answer.

"But the wind is on the point of changing again, and it will soon be impossible to keep the boat to the north."

"We will see which way the wind blows. To-morrow, at dawn, we shall know."

John Bunsby could say no more. He went back to his post. The passengers remained silent, and the Tankadere flew on amidst the roaring of the sea and wind. Towards dawn the tempest abated a little, but the sea was still very high. The Tankadere had not been seriously damaged, and held her course towards Shanghai.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text:
The pilot took his precautions in advance. He reefed the sails, removed the poles, had the crew take their places at the bows. A small, but very strong, triangular sail, a storm-jib, was hoisted in its place, to hold the wind from astern, and the Tankadere was as much as possible put in condition to brave the tempest. John Bunsby advised that the passengers go below, but this was not to the taste of either Mr. Fogg, Fix, or Aouda. The confinement in so small a cabin, with the boat pitching and rolling, was far from inviting. They preferred to remain on deck, watching the tempest, which was then at its height.

The rain fell in torrents, and the wind blew with tremendous violence. The Tankadere, under her reduced sail, was lifted like a feather by the wind, and flew off to the north at the speed of a locomotive. The sea was monstrous, and the boat would have been swamped a dozen times but for the skill of the pilot in managing her. The passengers were often drenched by the spray, but they submitted to it philosophically. Fix cursed it inwardly, while Aouda, her eyes fixed upon her companion, whose coolness amazed her, showed herself worthy of him, and braved the storm at his side. As for Phileas Fogg, it seemed just as if the typhoon were a part of his programme, and he was not even behind time.

By midnight, however, the wind had abated somewhat, and the storm was less violent. The Tankadere still kept up headway, and John Bunsby hoped that she might reach the Shanghai roads in time. But at daybreak, the wind began to freshen again, and soon blew hard from the northwest. The boat, now rolling heavily, could no longer keep her course to the north. John Bunsby consulted his crew, and after a short discussion, approached Mr. Fogg, and said, "I think, sir, we had better put in to one of the ports on the coast."

"I think so too," said Fogg.

"Ah!" said the pilot. "But which?"

"To Shanghai," replied Mr. Fogg.

The pilot at first did not seem to understand; he could scarcely realize so much determination and tenacity. Then he cried, "Well—yes! Your honour is right. To Shanghai!"

simple_agent_extraction_refined_2.text:
The pilot took his precautions in advance. He reefed the sails, removed the poles, had the crew take their places at the bows. A small, but very strong, triangular sail, a storm-jib, was hoisted in its place, to hold the wind from astern, and the Tankadere was as much as possible put in condition to brave the tempest. John Bunsby advised that the passengers go below, but this was not to the taste of either Mr. Fogg, Fix, or Aouda. The confinement in so small a cabin, with the boat pitching and rolling, was far from inviting. They preferred to remain on deck, watching the tempest, which was then at its height.

About eight o’clock the storm burst upon them with great violence. The wind blew a perfect hurricane, and the Tankadere was tossed about like a feather. She was driven northward with incredible speed, and the waves rose to a height of twenty feet above her deck. She would have been swamped a dozen times but for the skill of the pilot in managing her. The passengers were often drenched by the spray, but they submitted to it philosophically. Fix cursed it inwardly, while Aouda, her eyes fixed upon her companion, whose coolness amazed her, showed herself worthy of him, and braved the storm at his side. As for Phileas Fogg, it seemed just as if the typhoon were a part of his programme, and he was not even behind time.

Towards evening the wind veered to the north-west, and the boat, instead of keeping headway, now lay in the trough of the waves. The sea struck her with fearful violence. The night came on dark and threatening. The poor little craft seemed to be at the mercy of the dreadful elements. At times the pilot’s heart failed him. He consulted his crew, who were of his opinion. John Bunsby approached Mr. Fogg, and said, “I think, sir, we ought to make for one of the ports on the coast.”

“I think so too,” said Fogg.

“Ah!” said the pilot. “But which?”

“To Shanghai,” replied Mr. Fogg.

The pilot at first did not seem to understand; he could scarcely realize so much determination and tenacity. Then he cried, “Well—yes! Your honour is right. To Shanghai!”

And the Tankadere kept steadily on her northward course through the frightful storm.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
He carefully examined the condition of the craft, making sure that every rope was secure and every sail properly trimmed. The wind, which had been blowing steadily from the west, showed signs of shifting, and the sky was streaked with long, thin clouds that presaged a change in the weather. The pilot, a man of experience and prudence, did not wish to be caught unprepared by a sudden squall or a treacherous gust. He checked the barometer, noted the pressure, and consulted his compass, all the while keeping a wary eye on the horizon.

Phileas Fogg, who had been observing these preparations with his usual calm, approached the pilot and inquired as to the prospects for the next leg of their journey. The pilot replied that, if the wind held, they could expect to make good time, but he warned that the weather was unpredictable in these latitudes, and that they must be ready for any eventuality. Fogg nodded, satisfied that all was being done that could be done, and returned to his seat, where he resumed his silent contemplation of the landscape slipping by.

Passepartout, meanwhile, was bustling about the deck, his natural curiosity piqued by the unfamiliar rigging and the strange machinery of the vessel. He asked questions of the crew, who answered him with good-natured amusement, and even attempted to lend a hand with the sails, though his efforts were more enthusiastic than effective. Aouda, wrapped in a warm shawl against the chill wind, watched the proceedings with a mixture of anxiety and admiration for the composure of her companions.

As the day wore on, the wind began to freshen, and the sea grew rougher. The pilot ordered the sails reefed, and the crew sprang to their tasks with practiced efficiency. The vessel heeled over, cutting through the waves with a speed that delighted Passepartout and caused Aouda to cling more tightly to the rail. Fogg remained impassive, his eyes fixed on the chronometer, calculating the minutes gained or lost with each change in the wind.

Night fell, and the sky cleared, revealing a multitude of stars. The pilot, satisfied that all was well, allowed himself a brief respite, but he remained vigilant, ready to act at the first sign of danger. Thus, with every precaution taken and every man at his post, the little vessel pressed on through the darkness, bearing its passengers ever closer to their goal.

events.title: Surviving the Night and Storm Abates
detailed_summary: The night is horrific, and the boat survives only through the crew's constant vigilance and near-miraculous escapes from foundering.
Aouda is exhausted but remains stoic, receiving protection from Fogg against the waves multiple times.
Daylight reveals the tempest continuing unabated, but the wind shifts back to the south-east, which is advantageous.
The 'Tankadere' resumes its rapid progress, though battered by crossing waves.
They spot the coast occasionally through mist but see no other ships.
Around noon, the storm begins to show signs of calming, which become more apparent as the sun sets.
The intense but brief storm passes, allowing the exhausted passengers to eat and rest.
The night becomes relatively calm, allowing more sails to be hoisted, increasing the boat's speed.
By the next morning's dawn, they sight the coast, and Bunsby estimates they are less than 100 miles from Shanghai.
They have only one day left to cover the remaining distance to catch the Yokohama steamer that evening.
The time lost during the storm means they are further behind schedule than they would have been.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The night was really terrible; it would be a miracle if the craft did not founder.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Had there been no storm, during which several hours were lost, they would be at this moment within thirty miles of their destination.

events.text_segment:
The night was really terrible; it would be a miracle if the craft did not founder. Twice it could have been all over with her if the crew had not been constantly on the watch. Aouda was exhausted, but did not utter a complaint. More than once Mr. Fogg rushed to protect her from the violence of the waves.
Day reappeared. The tempest still raged with undiminished fury; but the wind now returned to the south-east. It was a favourable change, and the “Tankadere” again bounded forward on this mountainous sea, though the waves crossed each other, and imparted shocks and counter-shocks which would have crushed a craft less solidly built. From time to time the coast was visible through the broken mist, but no vessel was in sight. The “Tankadere” was alone upon the sea.
There were some signs of a calm at noon, and these became more distinct as the sun descended toward the horizon. The tempest had been as brief as terrific. The passengers, thoroughly exhausted, could now eat a little, and take some repose.
The night was comparatively quiet. Some of the sails were again hoisted, and the speed of the boat was very good. The next morning at dawn they espied the coast, and John Bunsby was able to assert that they were not one hundred miles from Shanghai. A hundred miles, and only one day to traverse them! That very evening Mr. Fogg was due at Shanghai, if he did not wish to miss the steamer to Yokohama. Had there been no storm, during which several hours were lost, they would be at this moment within thirty miles of their destination.

More than once, Mr. Fogg threw over her his cloak to protect her from the waves. Daylight appeared; the tempest had not abated, but the wind now returned to the south-east. It was a favorable change, and the Tankadere again resumed her rapid course. The sea was still very high, and it was difficult to make out the coast through the thick mist. Nothing was to be seen but the wild waves. The crew, with Bunsby at their head, redoubled their efforts. The little craft, battered by the cross seas, kept bravely on her way. About noon, the storm began to moderate, and the signs of a calm became more distinct as the sun went down. The short but terrible tempest had passed, and the passengers, completely exhausted, were able to eat a little and take some rest. The night was comparatively quiet. The sails were again hoisted, and the boat sped forward on the waves. At dawn, they sighted the coast, and Bunsby declared that they were less than a hundred miles from Shanghai. But they had only one day left to reach that port, in order to catch the steamer for Yokohama, which was to leave that very evening. The time lost during the storm had been greater than they had supposed, and they were now further behind than they would have been if the weather had remained moderate.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The wind howled with a ferocity that seemed to tear at the very seams of the little craft, and the waves rose higher and higher, crashing over the deck and threatening to sweep away anything not firmly lashed down. Phileas Fogg stood at the prow, his face impassive, but his eyes keenly watching the horizon, searching for any sign of a break in the storm. Passepartout clung to the rigging, his knuckles white, muttering prayers in French and vowing never again to set foot on the sea. The captain, a grizzled old sailor with nerves of steel, barked orders to the crew, who scrambled to obey, their oilskins gleaming in the spray.

All through the night, the tempest raged. The little vessel was tossed about like a toy, but she held together, her timbers groaning under the strain. The passengers huddled below deck, listening to the roar of the wind and the crash of the waves, each hour seeming longer than the last. Fogg, however, remained calm, his mind fixed on the goal ahead. He knew that every minute lost could mean failure, but he also knew that panic would serve no purpose.

As dawn broke, the storm began to abate. The wind lessened, and the waves grew smaller, though the sea was still rough. The crew emerged, exhausted but relieved, and the captain allowed himself a rare smile. They had survived the night. Passepartout, pale but unhurt, climbed shakily onto the deck and gazed at the gray horizon. Fogg checked his watch, calculating their position and the time lost. The journey was not over, but hope returned with the morning light.

events.title: Race Against Time and Last-Minute Signal
detailed_summary: The wind progressively weakens, and the sea calms down.
All available sails are hoisted to maximize speed.
By noon, they are 45 miles from Shanghai with only six hours remaining.
Concern grows among everyone (except Fogg) about whether they can make it in time, as an average speed of nine miles per hour is needed while the wind continues to drop.
The breeze becomes light and inconsistent, coming from the coast.
Despite the weak wind, the lightweight 'Tankadere' with its large sails manages to catch the gusts effectively, aided by currents.
By 6 o'clock, Bunsby finds they are only ten miles from the river mouth, but Shanghai itself is another twelve miles upstream.
At 7 o'clock, they are still three miles short of Shanghai.
The pilot expresses frustration, fearing he will lose the substantial reward.
He observes Fogg, who remains completely calm despite his entire fortune being at risk.
Just then, the smoke plume of the American steamer bound for Yokohama is seen departing on schedule.
Bunsby reacts with despair, but Fogg calmly orders him to signal the ship.
A small cannon used for fog signals is prepared.
Before firing, Fogg instructs them to hoist their flag at half-mast as a distress signal, hoping the steamer will alter course to assist.
Fogg then commands them to fire the cannon.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The wind grew decidedly calmer, and happily the sea fell with it.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: And the booming of the little cannon resounded in the air.

events.text_segment:
The wind grew decidedly calmer, and happily the sea fell with it. All sails were now hoisted, and at noon the “Tankadere” was within forty-five miles of Shanghai. There remained yet six hours in which to accomplish that distance. All on board feared that it could not be done, and every one—Phileas Fogg, no doubt, excepted—felt his heart beat with impatience. The boat must keep up an average of nine miles an hour, and the wind was becoming calmer every moment! It was a capricious breeze, coming from the coast, and after it passed the sea became smooth. Still, the “Tankadere” was so light, and her fine sails caught the fickle zephyrs so well, that, with the aid of the currents John Bunsby found himself at six o’clock not more than ten miles from the mouth of Shanghai River. Shanghai itself is situated at least twelve miles up the stream. At seven they were still three miles from Shanghai. The pilot swore an angry oath; the reward of two hundred pounds was evidently on the point of escaping him. He looked at Mr. Fogg. Mr. Fogg was perfectly tranquil; and yet his whole fortune was at this moment at stake.
At this moment, also, a long black funnel, crowned with wreaths of smoke, appeared on the edge of the waters. It was the American steamer, leaving for Yokohama at the appointed time.
“Confound her!” cried John Bunsby, pushing back the rudder with a desperate jerk.
“Signal her!” said Phileas Fogg quietly.
A small brass cannon stood on the forward deck of the “Tankadere,” for making signals in the fogs. It was loaded to the muzzle; but just as the pilot was about to apply a red-hot coal to the touchhole, Mr. Fogg said, “Hoist your flag!”
The flag was run up at half-mast, and, this being the signal of distress, it was hoped that the American steamer, perceiving it, would change her course a little, so as to succour the pilot-boat.
“Fire!” said Mr. Fogg. And the booming of the little cannon resounded in the air.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
The wind grew decidedly calmer, and happily the sea fell with it. All sails that could be kept up were hoisted, and the Tankadere passed as rapidly as possible between the banks of the narrow channel. Still, the yacht’s progress was checked by the capricious little breezes, which now and then came from the land, and died away as soon as they reached her. Aouda, who was anxious, though she said nothing, saw the crew continually changing their tack to take advantage of the least puff of wind. John Bunsby was at the helm, and his eyes were fixed upon the horizon. His only thought was to keep the Tankadere at as steady a speed as possible. Fix was still on board, and he, too, was watching the progress of the yacht with anxiety, for the steamer for Yokohama would not wait for the arrival of the party, and if they missed it, the whole journey round the world would be compromised.

By noon the Tankadere was still forty-five miles from Shanghai, and it was necessary to reach that port, if possible, before nightfall. Phileas Fogg calculated that they must average at least nine miles an hour, and the wind was becoming every moment less steady. The breeze, which had been fresh in the morning, now fell away, and it was feared that they would not reach their destination in time. The current, however, was favorable, and Bunsby did his best to make the most of it. Still, the yacht advanced but slowly, and at six o’clock in the evening, they were only ten miles from the mouth of the river. Shanghai itself was still twelve miles farther on.

The pilot swore under his breath, for he saw his reward of two hundred pounds slipping from him. Fogg, who had not yet exhibited any sign of impatience, remained as cool as ever. He was, indeed, risking his fortune, and perhaps his life, but he showed no emotion. Aouda was pale, but she did not utter a word. Fix gnawed his lips, and his heart beat with violence.

At this moment, John Bunsby, who was scanning the horizon, cried out: "There’s the steamer!"

A black smoke, rising in the distance, indicated the steamer’s position. She was leaving the port, on her way to Yokohama.

"Confound her!" cried Bunsby, pushing back his cap. "Signal her!" said Fogg quietly.

A small brass cannon stood on the forward deck. It was used for making signals in foggy weather. The powder was ready, and the gun was loaded. Bunsby was about to apply a light to the fuse, when Fogg stopped him, and said: "Hoist the flag at half-mast."

It was a signal of distress, and, if the steamer perceived it, she would, no doubt, come to the yacht’s assistance.

The flag was run up at half-mast, and, while the crew fired off a gun, Fogg remained motionless, with his arms crossed, and his eyes fixed upon the steamer, which was rapidly moving away.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The wind grew decidedly calmer, and happily the sea fell with it. The waves, which had threatened to engulf the vessel, now subsided into long, rolling swells, and the Henrietta, though still laboring under her reduced rig, made better headway. The sky, which had been overcast for so many days, began to clear, and a pale sun shone through the thinning clouds, casting a silvery sheen over the vast expanse of water. The crew, who had been working tirelessly to keep the ship afloat and on course, allowed themselves a moment of relief, exchanging hopeful glances as they went about their duties.

Phileas Fogg, ever composed, stood at the bow, his gaze fixed on the horizon. He had calculated the time lost during the storm and knew that every hour of fair weather was precious. Passepartout, his faithful servant, emerged from below deck, his face brightening at the sight of the calmer sea. "Monsieur," he said, approaching Fogg, "it seems the worst is behind us."

"Let us hope so, Passepartout," replied Fogg, his voice steady. "But we must not relax our vigilance. The journey is not yet over."

Captain Speedy, who had been overseeing the repairs to the rigging, joined them. "We’ve lost some time, Mr. Fogg, but with this wind, we can make up a bit of it. If it holds, we’ll sight land by tomorrow."

Fogg nodded, his expression inscrutable. He knew that every minute counted if he was to win his wager. The passengers and crew settled into a routine, their spirits lifted by the improved conditions. Passepartout busied himself with small tasks, ever watchful for any opportunity to assist his master.

As night fell, the Henrietta sailed steadily onward, her course set for the American coast. The stars emerged, twinkling above the calm sea, and a sense of quiet determination settled over all aboard. Phileas Fogg, standing alone on deck, allowed himself a rare moment of reflection, contemplating the challenges overcome and those yet to come. The journey was not yet finished, but hope had returned with the calming of the wind and sea.

chapters.chapter_title: CHAPTER XXII. IN WHICH PASSEPARTOUT FINDS OUT THAT, EVEN AT THE ANTIPODES, IT IS CONVENIENT TO HAVE SOME MONEY IN ONE’S POCKET

events.title: Passepartout Awakens Alone on the Carnatic
detailed_summary: The steamship 'Carnatic' leaves Hong Kong for Japan precisely on schedule, carrying cargo and passengers, but Phileas Fogg's reserved cabins remain empty.
The following day, Passepartout appears on deck looking dazed, unsteady, and dishevelled.
A flashback explains that after Fix departed the opium den, waiters carried the unconscious Passepartout to a bed designated for smokers.
Three hours later, haunted by his duty, Passepartout managed to wake up, fighting the lingering effects of the drug.
Driven by the need to fulfill his responsibilities, he left the opium den.
He stumbled through the streets, relying on walls for support, repeatedly falling and getting up, instinctively calling out the name of the ship, 'Carnatic'.
Reaching the quay just as the steamer was about to leave, Passepartout rushed onto the plank and collapsed unconscious on the deck.
Sailors, apparently familiar with such incidents, carried him down to the second cabin.
Passepartout did not fully awaken until the ship was 150 miles away from the Chinese coast.
Finding himself on the deck the next morning, he breathes in the refreshing sea air.
The clean air helps to clear his mind, allowing him to slowly piece together the previous evening's events: Fix's confession and his time in the opium den.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The “Carnatic,” setting sail from Hong Kong at half-past six on the 7th of November, directed her course at full steam towards Japan.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The opium-house.

events.text_segment:
The “Carnatic,” setting sail from Hong Kong at half-past six on the 7th of November, directed her course at full steam towards Japan. She carried a large cargo and a well-filled cabin of passengers. Two state-rooms in the rear were, however, unoccupied—those which had been engaged by Phileas Fogg.
The next day a passenger with a half-stupefied eye, staggering gait, and disordered hair, was seen to emerge from the second cabin, and to totter to a seat on deck.
It was Passepartout; and what had happened to him was as follows: Shortly after Fix left the opium den, two waiters had lifted the unconscious Passepartout, and had carried him to the bed reserved for the smokers. Three hours later, pursued even in his dreams by a fixed idea, the poor fellow awoke, and struggled against the stupefying influence of the narcotic. The thought of a duty unfulfilled shook off his torpor, and he hurried from the abode of drunkenness. Staggering and holding himself up by keeping against the walls, falling down and creeping up again, and irresistibly impelled by a kind of instinct, he kept crying out, “The ‘Carnatic!’ the ‘Carnatic!’”
The steamer lay puffing alongside the quay, on the point of starting. Passepartout had but few steps to go; and, rushing upon the plank, he crossed it, and fell unconscious on the deck, just as the “Carnatic” was moving off. Several sailors, who were evidently accustomed to this sort of scene, carried the poor Frenchman down into the second cabin, and Passepartout did not wake until they were one hundred and fifty miles away from China. Thus he found himself the next morning on the deck of the “Carnatic,” and eagerly inhaling the exhilarating sea-breeze. The pure air sobered him. He began to collect his sense, which he found a difficult task; but at last he recalled the events of the evening before, Fix’s revelation, and the opium-house.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
The “Carnatic,” setting sail from Hong Kong at half-past six on the 7th of November, directed her course at full steam towards Japan. She carried a large cargo and a well-filled cabin of passengers. Two state-rooms in the rear were, however, unoccupied—those which had been engaged by Phileas Fogg. 

The next day a passenger, with half-stupefied eyes, staggering gait, and disordered hair, appeared upon the deck. It was Passepartout; and what had happened to him was as follows:

Shortly after Fix left the opium den, two waiters had lifted the unconscious Passepartout, and had carried him to the bed reserved for the smokers. Three hours later, pursued even in his dreams by a fixed idea, the thought of duty, he awoke, struggled against the stupefying influence of the narcotic, and managed to drag himself from the bed. The thought of the steamer, which was to start at once, drove him to his feet. He tottered through the streets, reeling like a drunken man, and, finding himself, as he passed along the docks, called out mechanically the name of the vessel, “Carnatic! Carnatic!”

The steamer was on the point of starting. Passepartout had but just time to rush on board, and, as soon as he had set foot on the deck, fell senseless among the package of ropes. The sailors, who were evidently accustomed to this sort of scene, carried him down into the second cabin, and Passepartout did not wake up till they were one hundred and fifty miles away from China.

Thus he found himself the next morning on the deck of the “Carnatic,” and eagerly inhaled the invigorating sea air. The pure breeze soon completely cleared his brain; he remembered the events of the evening before, Fix’s revelation, and the opium den.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: Phileas Fogg was on board, but Fix had been left behind. The detective, after his fruitless search for Passepartout, had arrived at the wharf only to see the Carnatic's smoke on the horizon. He was furious, for he had missed his man by a matter of minutes. Meanwhile, Passepartout, after a night of confusion and misadventure, had finally found his way to the dock, only to discover that the Carnatic had already departed. He wandered the streets of Hong Kong, offering his services as a valet, but with little success. At last, he encountered a troupe of acrobats who were in need of an extra performer. Passepartout, recalling his youthful training in gymnastics, offered his services and was accepted. He spent the next few days rehearsing with the troupe, performing feats of agility and strength that astonished the local populace. Meanwhile, Phileas Fogg, unaware of Passepartout's predicament, maintained his usual composure. He spent his time on the Carnatic in quiet contemplation, confident that his servant would rejoin him in Yokohama. The voyage was uneventful, and the ship made good time across the China Sea. As the Carnatic approached the Japanese coast, Fogg prepared for the next stage of his journey, determined to maintain his schedule and win the wager that had set him on this extraordinary adventure.

events.title: Realization of Fogg's Absence and Fix's Treachery
detailed_summary: Passepartout berates himself for getting drunk and worries about his master's potential reaction.
He comforts himself with the thought that at least he didn't miss the ship, viewing this as paramount.
His thoughts turn to Fix; he hopes the detective is not on board and hasn't followed them as threatened.
He reaffirms his belief in Mr. Fogg's innocence regarding the bank robbery charge.
He considers whether he should reveal Fix's true purpose to Mr. Fogg.
He contemplates waiting until they return to London to share the information about the pursuing detective, perhaps turning it into a humorous anecdote.
He decides his immediate priority is to find Mr. Fogg and apologize for his state the previous night.
Passepartout gets up and searches the after-deck but doesn't find his master or Aouda.
He assumes Aouda is still resting and that Fogg might be playing cards.
He descends to the saloon, but Fogg isn't there either.
Passepartout asks the purser for the location of Mr. Fogg's cabin.
The purser states there is no passenger registered under the name Fogg.
Passepartout insists, describing his master and mentioning the young lady.
The purser firmly denies any young lady being on board and presents the passenger list as proof.
Passepartout examines the list and confirms his master's name is absent.
A sudden thought makes him ask if he is truly on the 'Carnatic' heading to Yokohama, which the purser confirms.

He collapses onto a seat, suddenly understanding everything.
He recalls the crucial detail about the earlier departure time, which he failed to relay to Fogg.

He fully grasps the detective's ploy and its consequences: Mr. Fogg is likely ruined, his wager lost, and he might even face arrest.
Distraught at this thought, Passepartout feels immense anger towards Fix and anticipates a future confrontation.

events.text_segment:
“It is evident,” said he to himself, “that I have been abominably drunk! What will Mr. Fogg say? At least I have not missed the steamer, which is the most important thing.”
Then, as Fix occurred to him: “As for that rascal, I hope we are well rid of him, and that he has not dared, as he proposed, to follow us on board the “Carnatic.” A detective on the track of Mr. Fogg, accused of robbing the Bank of England! Pshaw! Mr. Fogg is no more a robber than I am a murderer.”
Should he divulge Fix’s real errand to his master? Would it do to tell the part the detective was playing? Would it not be better to wait until Mr. Fogg reached London again, and then impart to him that an agent of the metropolitan police had been following him round the world, and have a good laugh over it? No doubt; at least, it was worth considering. The first thing to do was to find Mr. Fogg, and apologise for his singular behaviour.
Passepartout got up and proceeded, as well as he could with the rolling of the steamer, to the after-deck. He saw no one who resembled either his master or Aouda. “Good!” muttered he; “Aouda has not got up yet, and Mr. Fogg has probably found some partners at whist.”
He descended to the saloon. Mr. Fogg was not there. Passepartout had only, however, to ask the purser the number of his master’s state-room. The purser replied that he did not know any passenger by the name of Fogg.
“I beg your pardon,” said Passepartout persistently. “He is a tall gentleman, quiet, and not very talkative, and has with him a young lady—”
“There is no young lady on board,” interrupted the purser. “Here is a list of the passengers; you may see for yourself.”
Passepartout scanned the list, but his master’s name was not upon it. All at once an idea struck him.
“Ah! am I on the ‘Carnatic?’”
“Yes.”
“On the way to Yokohama?”
“Certainly.”
Passepartout had for an instant feared that he was on the wrong boat; but, though he was really on the “Carnatic,” his master was not there.
He fell thunderstruck on a seat. He saw it all now. He remembered that the time of sailing had been changed, that he should have informed his master of that fact, and that he had not done so. It was his fault, then, that Mr. Fogg and Aouda had missed the steamer. Yes, but it was still more the fault of the traitor who, in order to separate him from his master, and detain the latter at Hong Kong, had inveigled him into getting drunk! He now saw the detective’s trick; and at this moment Mr. Fogg was certainly ruined, his bet was lost, and he himself perhaps arrested and imprisoned! At this thought Passepartout tore his hair. Ah, if Fix ever came within his reach, what a settling of accounts there would be!

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
“It is evident,” said he to himself, “that I have been abominably drunk! What will Mr. Fogg say? At least I haven’t missed the steamer, which is the most important thing.”

Then his thoughts turned to Fix. “Is it possible that that rascal is on board? He promised to follow us, and here he is, no doubt, dogging our steps. But, after all, Mr. Fogg is not a robber, and I must not let myself be taken in by appearances. Should I tell my master? No, not yet; when we get back to London, I’ll tell him everything, and we’ll have a good laugh over it.”

Passepartout, feeling somewhat reassured, resolved to find Mr. Fogg and apologize for his escapade of the previous night. He got up and went on deck. Mr. Fogg was not there. Aouda was not there either. “They are probably still asleep,” he thought. He went below to the saloon; neither was there. He asked the purser for the number of Mr. Fogg’s cabin. The purser replied that there was no passenger of that name on board. Passepartout insisted, describing his master and the young lady. The purser was positive; no such persons were on the passenger list. He showed it to Passepartout, who scanned it eagerly, but in vain. His master’s name was not there.

A sudden thought struck him. “Am I on the Carnatic?”

“Yes,” replied the purser.

“Bound for Yokohama?”

“Certainly.”

Passepartout had a sinking sensation. He sat down heavily, and at last understood it all. He remembered the change in the hour of departure, which he had not communicated to his master. He was the cause of their separation! He, who had so faithfully followed his master everywhere, was now separated from him—perhaps forever! All through the fault of that cursed Fix, who had made him drunk! Fix, who had separated him from his master, and who was, no doubt, rejoicing over his success! But what would become of Mr. Fogg? Ruined, lost! His wager gone! And perhaps arrested and imprisoned! At this thought, Passepartout was seized with a violent fit of rage. He would have liked to find Fix and strangle him! He wept bitterly.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
“It is evident,” said he to himself, “that I have been abominably drunk! I have been dreaming of railways, steamers, and all sorts of impossible things. Eighty days round the world! What nonsense! Why, I have not even left my club.”

He looked about him. The familiar walls of the Reform Club’s reading-room met his gaze. The heavy curtains, the deep armchairs, the ticking of the great clock in the corner—all were as they had been. The fire burned low in the grate, and the gas-lamps cast a mellow glow over the polished tables. Phileas Fogg, for it was he, sat upright and tried to collect his thoughts. Had he really wagered half his fortune on a madcap journey? Had he really traversed continents and oceans, braved storms and delays, all for the sake of a bet? It seemed incredible.

He rose and walked to the window. The fog of London pressed against the glass, thick and impenetrable. The city’s muffled sounds drifted in, reassuring in their familiarity. Fogg pressed his hand to his brow. The events of the past weeks—if they were not a dream—crowded upon him: the frantic dash to catch the train at Suez, the wild ride on the elephant through the jungles of India, the rescue of Aouda from the flames, the endless days at sea, the pursuit by Detective Fix, the snowbound rails in America, the final desperate sprint across England. Could all this have been the product of an overactive imagination, inflamed by too much brandy and the heat of the club’s fire?

He turned as the door opened and Passepartout entered, his face alight with excitement. “Monsieur! Monsieur Fogg! It is done! We have arrived!”

Fogg stared at his servant. “Arrived? Where?”

“Why, in London, monsieur! At the very hour! The wager is won!”

Fogg shook his head. “Nonsense, Passepartout. I have not stirred from this room. I have been dreaming, nothing more.”

“But, monsieur, the journey—the trains, the ships, the adventures—Aouda—”

Fogg’s heart gave a sudden leap. Aouda! Was she, too, a figment of his imagination? Or had he truly met her, saved her, and brought her to England?

At that moment, Aouda herself appeared in the doorway, her eyes shining. “Mr. Fogg, you are here! I feared you had gone.”

Fogg looked from Aouda to Passepartout, and back again. The weight of reality pressed upon him. If this was a dream, it was the most vivid he had ever known. But as Aouda took his hand, and Passepartout beamed with pride, Fogg realized that the impossible had become possible. He had, indeed, gone around the world in eighty days. The wager was won, but more than that, he had found love and friendship on the journey.

He smiled, a rare expression for the precise and reserved Englishman. “It seems, my friends, that the world is not so large after all.”

events.title: Facing Dire Straits Alone
detailed_summary: Following his initial shock and anger, Passepartout calms down and evaluates his predicament.
He acknowledges his unenviable position: alone, en route to Japan, with no money.
His passage is already paid, which grants him five or six days to determine his course of action.
He decides to eat heartily during the voyage, consuming meals with vigor, as if eating for Fogg and Aouda too, anticipating potential food scarcity upon arrival.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: After his first depression, Passepartout became calmer, and began to study his situation.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He helped himself as generously as if Japan were a desert, where nothing to eat was to be looked for.

events.text_segment: After his first depression, Passepartout became calmer, and began to study his situation. It was certainly not an enviable one. He found himself on the way to Japan, and what should he do when he got there? His pocket was empty; he had not a solitary shilling, not so much as a penny. His passage had fortunately been paid for in advance; and he had five or six days in which to decide upon his future course. He fell to at meals with an appetite, and ate for Mr. Fogg, Aouda, and himself. He helped himself as generously as if Japan were a desert, where nothing to eat was to be looked for.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: After his first depression, Passepartout became calmer, and began to study his situation. It seemed to him that he had been separated from his master, and that he was alone upon the earth. Yet, after all, he found himself on the way to Japan, and, as his passage had been paid as far as Yokohama, he had five or six days before him. Passepartout was, it is true, separated from the noble and generous Fogg, as well as from the dear Aouda; but he was not in the least cast down. He was naturally sanguine, and the prospect of a new country, the strange sights, the novel experiences, all contributed to revive his spirits. He resolved to eat as much as possible, since he might have to fast upon reaching Yokohama. He therefore ate for himself, for Mr. Fogg, and for Aouda, and, as if Japan were a desert, he determined to lay in a stock of nourishment for the future. In this wise, the days passed on board the Carnatic.

events.title: Arrival in Yokohama and Exploring the European Quarter
detailed_summary: On November 13th at dawn, the 'Carnatic' reaches the port of Yokohama.
Yokohama is identified as a key Pacific port near Yeddo (Tokyo), the former residence of the Tycoon.
The ship anchors at the quay among many international vessels.
Passepartout cautiously steps ashore onto the unfamiliar Japanese land.
Lacking a plan, he wanders aimlessly through Yokohama's streets.
He first finds himself in a district with European-style architecture, featuring low-fronted houses with verandas.
This area, situated between the 'promontory of the Treaty' and the river, includes streets, squares, docks, and warehouses.
He observes a diverse crowd similar to Hong Kong and Calcutta, comprising Americans, English, Chinese, and Dutch merchants.
Despite the bustling international presence, Passepartout feels utterly isolated.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: At dawn on the 13th the “Carnatic” entered the port of Yokohama.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The Frenchman felt himself as much alone among them as if he had dropped down in the midst of Hottentots.

events.text_segment:
At dawn on the 13th the “Carnatic” entered the port of Yokohama. This is an important port of call in the Pacific, where all the mail-steamers, and those carrying travellers between North America, China, Japan, and the Oriental islands put in. It is situated in the bay of Yeddo, and at but a short distance from that second capital of the Japanese Empire, and the residence of the Tycoon, the civil Emperor, before the Mikado, the spiritual Emperor, absorbed his office in his own. The “Carnatic” anchored at the quay near the custom-house, in the midst of a crowd of ships bearing the flags of all nations.
Passepartout went timidly ashore on this so curious territory of the Sons of the Sun. He had nothing better to do than, taking chance for his guide, to wander aimlessly through the streets of Yokohama. He found himself at first in a thoroughly European quarter, the houses having low fronts, and being adorned with verandas, beneath which he caught glimpses of neat peristyles. This quarter occupied, with its streets, squares, docks, and warehouses, all the space between the “promontory of the Treaty” and the river. Here, as at Hong Kong and Calcutta, were mixed crowds of all races, Americans and English, Chinamen and Dutchmen, mostly merchants ready to buy or sell anything. The Frenchman felt himself as much alone among them as if he had dropped down in the midst of Hottentots.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The city, situated on the western coast of the great bay of Yeddo, was already stirring with the activity of early morning. The quays were alive with the bustle of porters, merchants, and travelers, all eager to begin the day’s business. The “Carnatic,” after a swift and uneventful passage from Hong Kong, glided smoothly to her berth, her decks crowded with passengers anxious to disembark and set foot on Japanese soil.

Phileas Fogg, ever punctual and composed, was among the first to leave the vessel. He was accompanied by Aouda, whose eyes sparkled with curiosity at the unfamiliar sights and sounds of the bustling port. Passepartout, though weary from his recent adventures, was filled with relief and hope, for he had feared that his master’s journey might be delayed by the mishaps in Hong Kong.

The trio made their way through the throng, seeking a hotel where they could rest and refresh themselves before continuing their journey. Fogg, with his usual efficiency, quickly secured rooms at a reputable establishment, and soon they were settled in comfortable quarters. After a brief respite, Fogg began to make inquiries about the next steamer to San Francisco, for he was determined to lose no time in resuming his race against the clock.

Yokohama, with its blend of Eastern tradition and Western influence, offered many distractions, but Fogg’s mind remained fixed on his goal: to circumnavigate the globe in eighty days.

events.title: Venturing into Native Yokohama (Benten)
detailed_summary: Passepartout considers seeking aid from the French and English consuls but is reluctant to reveal his story, intertwined as it is with his master's situation.
He resolves to try other avenues first and moves from the European quarter into the native Japanese section.
He enters the Japanese quarter known as Benten, named for a sea goddess worshipped locally.
He takes in the distinctive sights: beautiful fir and cedar groves, unique sacred gates, picturesque bridges among bamboo, shaded temples, and Buddhist/Confucian retreats.
He observes the lively streets filled with children resembling figures from Japanese art, playing amidst small poodles and cats.

The streets are crowded with various people: priests in procession with tambourines, distinctively dressed police and customs officers carrying two sabres, soldiers in blue cotton uniforms, the Mikado's guards in silk and mail, and numerous military figures, reflecting the high status of the military in Japan compared to China.
He also sees begging friars, pilgrims, and ordinary civilians with characteristic Japanese physical features (hair, head shape, stature, complexion) that differentiate them from the Chinese.
He notes the unique local transportation methods like carriages, palanquins, barrows with sails, and bamboo litters.

He observes the local women, whom he doesn't find particularly attractive, noting their gait, footwear (canvas shoes, straw sandals, clogs), blackened teeth, flat chests, and kimonos tied with large knots at the back, drawing a parallel to contemporary Parisian fashion.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: He had, at least, one resource,—to call on the French and English consuls at Yokohama for assistance.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: An ornament which the modern Parisian ladies seem to have borrowed from the dames of Japan.

events.text_segment:
He had, at least, one resource,—to call on the French and English consuls at Yokohama for assistance. But he shrank from telling the story of his adventures, intimately connected as it was with that of his master; and, before doing so, he determined to exhaust all other means of aid. As chance did not favour him in the European quarter, he penetrated that inhabited by the native Japanese, determined, if necessary, to push on to Yeddo.
The Japanese quarter of Yokohama is called Benten, after the goddess of the sea, who is worshipped on the islands round about. There Passepartout beheld beautiful fir and cedar groves, sacred gates of a singular architecture, bridges half hid in the midst of bamboos and reeds, temples shaded by immense cedar-trees, holy retreats where were sheltered Buddhist priests and sectaries of Confucius, and interminable streets, where a perfect harvest of rose-tinted and red-cheeked children, who looked as if they had been cut out of Japanese screens, and who were playing in the midst of short-legged poodles and yellowish cats, might have been gathered.
The streets were crowded with people. Priests were passing in processions, beating their dreary tambourines; police and custom-house officers with pointed hats encrusted with lac and carrying two sabres hung to their waists; soldiers, clad in blue cotton with white stripes, and bearing guns; the Mikado’s guards, enveloped in silken doubles, hauberks and coats of mail; and numbers of military folk of all ranks—for the military profession is as much respected in Japan as it is despised in China—went hither and thither in groups and pairs. Passepartout saw, too, begging friars, long-robed pilgrims, and simple civilians, with their warped and jet-black hair, big heads, long busts, slender legs, short stature, and complexions varying from copper-colour to a dead white, but never yellow, like the Chinese, from whom the Japanese widely differ. He did not fail to observe the curious equipages—carriages and palanquins, barrows supplied with sails, and litters made of bamboo; nor the women—whom he thought not especially handsome—who took little steps with their little feet, whereon they wore canvas shoes, straw sandals, and clogs of worked wood, and who displayed tight-looking eyes, flat chests, teeth fashionably blackened, and gowns crossed with silken scarfs, tied in an enormous knot behind an ornament which the modern Parisian ladies seem to have borrowed from the dames of Japan.

---

**Simulated Output:**

He had, at least, one resource,—to call on the French and English consuls at Yokohama for assistance. Yet Passepartout hesitated, unwilling to expose the tangled circumstances that bound him to his master’s fate. Pride and discretion urged him to seek another way. With a determined air, he left the European quarter behind and ventured into the heart of native Yokohama, toward the district known as Benten, named for the sea goddess revered by the local people.

The scene before him was a vivid tapestry of Japanese life. Graceful firs and stately cedars shaded winding paths, while vermilion torii gates marked the entrances to tranquil temples nestled among groves of bamboo. Picturesque bridges arched over quiet streams, and the air was filled with the distant chime of temple bells and the murmur of prayer.

Children, as lively and delicate as the figures painted on lacquered screens, played in the streets, their laughter mingling with the yelps of small poodles and the soft mewing of cats. The thoroughfares bustled with a colorful throng: priests in solemn procession, their tambourines jingling; police and customs officers, each bearing two sabres and dressed in distinctive garb; soldiers in blue cotton uniforms, and the Mikado’s guards resplendent in silk and mail, their presence a testament to the military’s high esteem in Japan.

Passepartout’s observant eye took in the multitude—begging friars, devout pilgrims, and townsfolk whose features, from their hair and head shape to their stature and complexion, set them apart from the Chinese he had seen in Hong Kong. He marveled at the ingenious conveyances: carriages and palanquins, barrows fitted with sails, and litters of bamboo, all moving with a peculiar grace through the crowded streets.

As he passed, he could not help but notice the women of Yokohama. Their gait was measured, their feet clad in canvas shoes, straw sandals, or wooden clogs. Their teeth, blackened by custom, and their flat chests gave them an appearance Passepartout found less than charming, though he noted with amusement the large knots of their sashes tied at the back—a fashion, he mused, not unlike that of certain Parisian ladies.

---

**End of simulated literary segment.**

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
He had, at least, one resource,—to call on the French and English consuls at Yokohama for assistance. This thought gave him a little hope, and he resolved to act upon it without delay. He knew that the consuls were always ready to help their countrymen in distress, and he trusted that they would be able to extricate him from his present difficulty. He therefore set out at once for the consulate, and, after a short walk through the busy streets of Yokohama, he arrived at the building where the French consul resided.

He entered, and was received by a polite official, to whom he explained his situation. The consul listened attentively, and, after making a few inquiries, promised to do all in his power to assist him. He wrote a note to the English consul, requesting his cooperation, and gave Passepartout a letter of introduction. Passepartout thanked him warmly, and, with renewed confidence, proceeded to the English consulate.

There, he was received with equal kindness, and the consul, after reading the French consul's note, assured Passepartout that he would do his utmost to help him. He made inquiries about the Carnatic, and learned that the steamer had indeed sailed, but that another vessel, the General Grant, would leave for San Francisco on the following day. The consul advised Passepartout to secure a passage on this ship, and even offered to advance him the necessary funds, should he be in need.

Passepartout, overjoyed at this unexpected good fortune, thanked the consul profusely, and hurried off to the office of the General Grant. There, he found that a few places were still available, and he at once engaged a berth. He then returned to the consulate to inform the consul of his success, and to express his gratitude for the assistance he had received.

Thus, thanks to the kindness of the French and English consuls, Passepartout was able to continue his journey, and he resolved to be more careful in the future, so as not to be separated again from his master. He spent the rest of the day in making preparations for his departure, and, when evening came, he retired to his lodgings, feeling much more hopeful than he had been in the morning.

events.title: Hunger, Countryside Exploration, and Nightfall
detailed_summary: Passepartout continues his wandering for hours, observing various establishments: shops with curious goods, jewelry stores, decorated restaurants, tea-houses serving sake alongside tea, and smoking lounges offering fine tobacco instead of opium.
His walk leads him out into the countryside, surrounded by expansive rice fields.
He admires vibrant camellias blooming on trees, along with cherry, plum, and apple trees cultivated primarily for their flowers, guarded by oddly shaped scarecrows.

He observes the local wildlife: eagles on cedars, herons standing solemnly in willows, and numerous crows, ducks, hawks, wild birds, and cranes, learning the latter are considered sacred symbols of longevity and prosperity.
He spots some violets but discovers they lack fragrance, disappointing his hope for finding something edible.
Despite having eaten a substantial breakfast before leaving the ship, his day of walking makes him increasingly hungry.
He notices the absence of mutton, goat, or pork at butcher stalls and recalls that cattle are sacred and used only for farming, concluding meat is scarce.
He yearns for game or fish, common Japanese staples alongside rice, but realizes he must endure his hunger until the next day.
As night arrives, Passepartout returns to the native quarter.
He wanders through streets illuminated by colorful lanterns, watching dancers perform skillful steps and astrologers working outdoors with telescopes.
He reaches the harbor area, lit by the resin torches of fishermen in their boats.
Eventually, the streets grow quiet, and the bustling crowds are replaced by patrols.
He observes the patrols, noting the officers' splendid costumes and entourages, finding their formality amusing and likening each passing group to a departing European embassy.

events.text_segment:
Passepartout wandered for several hours in the midst of this motley crowd, looking in at the windows of the rich and curious shops, the jewellery establishments glittering with quaint Japanese ornaments, the restaurants decked with streamers and banners, the tea-houses, where the odorous beverage was being drunk with “saki,” a liquor concocted from the fermentation of rice, and the comfortable smoking-houses, where they were puffing, not opium, which is almost unknown in Japan, but a very fine, stringy tobacco. He went on till he found himself in the fields, in the midst of vast rice plantations. There he saw dazzling camellias expanding themselves, with flowers which were giving forth their last colours and perfumes, not on bushes, but on trees, and within bamboo enclosures, cherry, plum, and apple trees, which the Japanese cultivate rather for their blossoms than their fruit, and which queerly-fashioned, grinning scarecrows protected from the sparrows, pigeons, ravens, and other voracious birds. On the branches of the cedars were perched large eagles; amid the foliage of the weeping willows were herons, solemnly standing on one leg; and on every hand were crows, ducks, hawks, wild birds, and a multitude of cranes, which the Japanese consider sacred, and which to their minds symbolise long life and prosperity.
As he was strolling along, Passepartout espied some violets among the shrubs.
“Good!” said he; “I’ll have some supper.”
But, on smelling them, he found that they were odourless.
“No chance there,” thought he.
The worthy fellow had certainly taken good care to eat as hearty a breakfast as possible before leaving the “Carnatic;” but, as he had been walking about all day, the demands of hunger were becoming importunate. He observed that the butchers stalls contained neither mutton, goat, nor pork; and, knowing also that it is a sacrilege to kill cattle, which are preserved solely for farming, he made up his mind that meat was far from plentiful in Yokohama—nor was he mistaken; and, in default of butcher’s meat, he could have wished for a quarter of wild boar or deer, a partridge, or some quails, some game or fish, which, with rice, the Japanese eat almost exclusively. But he found it necessary to keep up a stout heart, and to postpone the meal he craved till the following morning. Night came, and Passepartout re-entered the native quarter, where he wandered through the streets, lit by vari-coloured lanterns, looking on at the dancers, who were executing skilful steps and boundings, and the astrologers who stood in the open air with their telescopes. Then he came to the harbour, which was lit up by the resin torches of the fishermen, who were fishing from their boats.
The streets at last became quiet, and the patrol, the officers of which, in their splendid costumes, and surrounded by their suites, Passepartout thought seemed like ambassadors, succeeded the bustling crowd. Each time a company passed, Passepartout chuckled, and said to himself: “Good! another Japanese embassy departing for Europe!”

Passepartout wandered for several hours in the midst of this motley crowd, looking in at the windows of the rich and curious shops, the jewellery establishments glittering with quaint Japanese ornaments, the restaurants decked with streamers and banners, the tea-houses, where the odorous beverage was being drunk with “saki,” a liquor concocted from the fermentation of rice, and the comfortable smoking-houses, where they were puffing, not opium, which is almost unknown in Japan, but a very fine, stringy tobacco. 

His steps, guided as much by curiosity as by leisure, soon led him beyond the bustling thoroughfares and into the tranquil countryside. Here, vast rice fields stretched out beneath a pale sky, their emerald blades swaying gently in the breeze. Passepartout paused to admire the camellias, their blossoms vivid against the dark foliage, and the cherry, plum, and apple trees, cultivated not for fruit but for the delicate beauty of their flowers. Oddly shaped scarecrows, more whimsical than menacing, stood sentinel among the rows.

Birds abounded: eagles perched solemnly atop ancient cedars, herons stood motionless in the willows, and flocks of crows, ducks, and wild cranes filled the air with their calls. Passepartout learned from a passing villager that the cranes were sacred, emblems of longevity and prosperity in this distant land.

He stooped to gather a handful of violets, hoping for a fragrant reward, but found them scentless and inedible. Despite the hearty breakfast he had enjoyed aboard the steamer, the hours of walking had sharpened his appetite. Yet, as he passed the butcher stalls, he noted the absence of mutton, goat, or pork, and recalled that cattle in Japan were revered and used only for labor. Meat, it seemed, was a rare luxury.

His thoughts turned to the prospect of game or fish, staples of the Japanese table, but he resigned himself to waiting until the morrow for a proper meal. As dusk fell, Passepartout retraced his steps to the native quarter, where the streets glowed with the light of countless lanterns. Dancers performed intricate steps to the music of flutes and drums, while astrologers, their telescopes pointed skyward, read the fortunes of passersby.

Drawn by the flicker of resin torches, Passepartout wandered to the harbor, where fishermen prepared their boats for the night’s work. Gradually, the lively crowds dispersed, replaced by the measured tread of patrols. The officers, resplendent in their ceremonial garb and attended by small retinues, amused Passepartout with their gravity, each group reminding him of a miniature European embassy setting out on a diplomatic mission.

---

**End of simulated output.**

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
He strolled along the narrow streets, his eyes wide with wonder at the unfamiliar sights and sounds. The air was filled with the mingled scents of incense, tea, and the subtle aroma of the tobacco, while the chatter of the crowd, the clatter of wooden sandals on the pavement, and the occasional tinkling of a samisen created a lively, almost festive atmosphere. Passepartout paused now and then to admire the delicate porcelain displayed in shop windows, the lacquered boxes and fans painted with scenes of cherry blossoms and Mount Fuji, and the silks of every hue, shimmering in the sunlight.

He was particularly struck by the neatness and cleanliness of the city. The streets were swept, the houses freshly painted, and the people themselves, in their bright kimonos, seemed to take pride in their appearance. Children played in the doorways, their laughter ringing out as they chased each other, while vendors called out their wares in musical voices. At one corner, Passepartout stopped to watch a group of men engaged in a game of go, their faces intent as they placed the black and white stones on the board.

As he wandered, Passepartout could not help but compare the bustling streets of Yokohama to those of his native Paris. There was a certain orderliness here, a sense of harmony, that contrasted with the noisy chaos of the boulevards he knew so well. Yet, for all its strangeness, the city felt welcoming, and Passepartout found himself smiling at the passersby, who returned his greetings with polite bows.

After some time, hunger began to make itself felt, and Passepartout entered a small restaurant, where he was served a meal of rice, fish, and pickled vegetables, accompanied by a cup of steaming tea. The flavors were new to him, but he ate with relish, grateful for the sustenance after his long walk. Refreshed, he resumed his exploration, determined to see as much of the city as possible before returning to his master.

As the afternoon wore on, Passepartout found himself drawn to the harbor, where ships from all over the world lay at anchor. He watched as sailors unloaded crates and barrels, their shouts mingling with the cries of the seagulls overhead. The sight reminded him of the journey still ahead, and he resolved to return to the hotel before nightfall, lest he lose his way in the labyrinthine streets of Yokohama.

chapters.chapter_title: CHAPTER XXIII. IN WHICH PASSEPARTOUT’S NOSE BECOMES OUTRAGEOUSLY LONG

events.title: Passepartout's Desperate Morning: Exchanging Clothes for Survival
detailed_summary: Waking up exhausted and starving, Passepartout resolved to find food immediately.
He considered selling his watch but dismissed the idea, deciding instead to use his singing voice, hoping the Japanese appreciate music.
Realizing it was too early for a performance and his attire was too fine for a street artist, he decided to wait.
The idea struck him to exchange his European clothes for Japanese ones, which would both suit his planned performance and provide immediate funds for food.
After searching, he found a dealer of old clothes.
The dealer accepted the exchange, liking the European outfit.
Passepartout emerged dressed in old Japanese garments, including a coat and faded turban, with a small amount of money acquired from the transaction.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The next morning poor, jaded, famished Passepartout said to himself that he must get something to eat at all hazards, and the sooner he did so the better.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: A few small pieces of silver, moreover, jingled in his pocket.

events.text_segment:
The next morning poor, jaded, famished Passepartout said to himself that he must get something to eat at all hazards, and the sooner he did so the better. He might, indeed, sell his watch; but he would have starved first. Now or never he must use the strong, if not melodious voice which nature had bestowed upon him. He knew several French and English songs, and resolved to try them upon the Japanese, who must be lovers of music, since they were for ever pounding on their cymbals, tam-tams, and tambourines, and could not but appreciate European talent.
It was, perhaps, rather early in the morning to get up a concert, and the audience prematurely aroused from their slumbers, might not possibly pay their entertainer with coin bearing the Mikado’s features. Passepartout therefore decided to wait several hours; and, as he was sauntering along, it occurred to him that he would seem rather too well dressed for a wandering artist. The idea struck him to change his garments for clothes more in harmony with his project; by which he might also get a little money to satisfy the immediate cravings of hunger. The resolution taken, it remained to carry it out.
It was only after a long search that Passepartout discovered a native dealer in old clothes, to whom he applied for an exchange. The man liked the European costume, and ere long Passepartout issued from his shop accoutred in an old Japanese coat, and a sort of one-sided turban, faded with long use. A few small pieces of silver, moreover, jingled in his pocket.

The idea struck him to change his garments for clothes more in harmony with his project; by which he might also get a little money to satisfy the immediate cravings of hunger.

Acting upon this idea, he took his course towards the docks, where he hoped to find some sailors who would be glad to purchase his European clothes. It chanced to be a Japanese dealer in old clothes, to whom he applied.
