LLM_completions.prefix-probing: He found himself still in the Japanese theatre, where he had passed the night. The performances, it is true, had ceased, but the actors were still in the house, lounging about and conversing in low tones. The gas was being extinguished, and the dim light added to the fantastic aspect of the place. Shadows flitted to and fro, like actual spectres, and Passepartout, famished and exhausted, felt himself becoming quite ghostly in the midst of these strange scenes. He had not eaten since the previous day, and his stomach reminded him of its emptiness with every step he took. He resolved to go out at once and try to find some food, no matter at what cost. He left the theatre and wandered through the streets of Yokohama, which were just beginning to be animated by the first stirrings of the day. Shops were opening, and the air was filled with the cries of vendors and the clatter of carts. Passepartout, with his last few coins, managed to purchase a little rice, which he devoured greedily. This meagre meal revived him somewhat, and he began to consider what he should do next. He had not a penny left, and was alone in a strange country, without friends or resources. He thought of his master, Mr. Fogg, and wondered anxiously what had become of him, and whether he would ever be able to rejoin him.

events.title: Seeking Passage and Discovering an Opportunity
detailed_summary: Pleased with the outcome of the clothes exchange, Passepartout momentarily embraced his new guise, comparing it to being at Carnival.
His first action was to find a modest tea-house.
He ate a small meal of bird and rice, aware that his next meal was uncertain.
After eating, he focused on his predicament: needing to leave Japan quickly, as he couldn't resell his current costume and held no fond memories of the country.
He considered seeking work as a cook or servant on a steamer bound for America to pay for his passage.
He acknowledged the immense distance across the Pacific to San Francisco.
Determined, he headed towards the docks.
As he approached, doubts surfaced about the feasibility of his plan: his appearance might arouse suspicion, and he lacked references.
While contemplating, he noticed a large placard carried by a clown.
The placard advertised the final Japanese performances of an acrobatic troupe owned by William Batulcar, before their departure to the United States.
Reading about the troupe's destination, Passepartout immediately saw it as his opportunity.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Good!” thought he.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “The United States!” said Passepartout; “that’s just what I want!”

events.text_segment:
“Good!” thought he. “I will imagine I am at the Carnival!”
His first care, after being thus “Japanesed,” was to enter a tea-house of modest appearance, and, upon half a bird and a little rice, to breakfast like a man for whom dinner was as yet a problem to be solved.
“Now,” thought he, when he had eaten heartily, “I mustn’t lose my head. I can’t sell this costume again for one still more Japanese. I must consider how to leave this country of the Sun, of which I shall not retain the most delightful of memories, as quickly as possible.”
It occurred to him to visit the steamers which were about to leave for America. He would offer himself as a cook or servant, in payment of his passage and meals. Once at San Francisco, he would find some means of going on. The difficulty was, how to traverse the four thousand seven hundred miles of the Pacific which lay between Japan and the New World.
Passepartout was not the man to let an idea go begging, and directed his steps towards the docks. But, as he approached them, his project, which at first had seemed so simple, began to grow more and more formidable to his mind. What need would they have of a cook or servant on an American steamer, and what confidence would they put in him, dressed as he was? What references could he give?
As he was reflecting in this wise, his eyes fell upon an immense placard which a sort of clown was carrying through the streets. This placard, which was in English, read as follows:
ACROBATIC JAPANESE TROUPE,
HONOURABLE WILLIAM BATULCAR, PROPRIETOR,
LAST REPRESENTATIONS,
PRIOR TO THEIR DEPARTURE TO THE UNITED STATES,
OF THE
LONG NOSES! LONG NOSES!
UNDER THE DIRECT PATRONAGE OF THE GOD TINGOU!
GREAT ATTRACTION!
“The United States!” said Passepartout; “that’s just what I want!”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
“Good!” thought he. “If the costume of an acrobat suits me, perhaps I shall find a place as a cook or servant on board some steamer. What’s more, I am not so very far from the American continent, which I must reach at all hazards.”

He at once set out towards the docks, but as he walked along, he was struck by a sudden thought. “After all,” said he to himself, “I have no money, and my appearance is not likely to recommend me. Who would employ a clown as a cook or servant? Pshaw! I must try, anyhow.”

But as he was reflecting thus, his eyes fell upon a large placard, which a sort of clown was carrying through the streets. This placard, which was in English, read as follows:

LAST REPRESENTATIONS,
OF THE
JAPANESE TROUPE,
OF
WILLIAM BATULCAR,
THE CELEBRATED ACROBAT,
AND HIS
TROUPE OF JAPANESE ARTISTS,
LAST PERFORMANCE,
TO TAKE PLACE
BEFORE THEIR DEPARTURE TO THE UNITED STATES,
OF THE
LONG NOSES! LONG NOSES!
UNDER THE DIRECT PATRONAGE OF THE GOD TINGOU!
GREAT ATTRACTION!

"That’s just what I want," thought Passepartout. "I’ll offer myself to the manager. I’ll be accepted, no doubt, as a clown. I’ll have a chance to get to San Francisco!"

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
“Good!” thought he. "If the Aouda affair is settled, I shall have nothing to do but to pay my passage to Yokohama. If not, I shall be compelled to stop at Bombay, and so lose the benefit of the steamer. But I must see to Aouda first."

He left the station, and, without losing a moment, made his way to the house of the Parsee merchant, where he had left the young woman. Fix followed him, and, as usual, Passepartout brought up the rear. The Parsee received them with his customary politeness, and, in answer to Fogg’s inquiries, assured him that Aouda was resting quietly, and that she had suffered no ill effects from her recent adventure.

Phileas Fogg was relieved. He requested that Aouda be informed of his presence, and, in a few moments, she appeared, calm and composed, though her eyes still bore traces of the anxiety she had endured. Fogg bowed gravely, and, in a few words, explained the situation: they were to leave for Calcutta by the next train, and he invited her to accompany them, assuring her that she would be under his protection until she could be safely restored to her family or friends.

Aouda, deeply moved by the kindness and delicacy of her deliverer, accepted the offer with gratitude. Passepartout, who had conceived a profound admiration for the young woman, was delighted at this arrangement, and busied himself with preparations for the journey.

Fix, meanwhile, was in a state of perplexity. The presence of Aouda complicated his plans. He had hoped to arrest Fogg at Bombay, but the addition of a lady to the party made such a step more difficult. He resolved, however, to follow them to Calcutta, and to watch for a more favorable opportunity.

Thus, all being arranged, the little party set out for the railway station, where the train for Calcutta awaited them. The journey was to be long and full of perils, but Phileas Fogg, calm and imperturbable as ever, was prepared to face whatever might befall.

events.title: Joining Batulcar's Acrobatic Troupe
detailed_summary: Passepartout followed the placard-bearer back into the Japanese district.
He arrived at a large cabin decorated with streamers and painted depictions of jugglers, identifying it as Batulcar's establishment.
He learned Batulcar was the director of a diverse troupe of performers giving final shows before heading to the U.S.
Passepartout entered and requested to see Mr. Batulcar, who appeared.
Batulcar initially mistook Passepartout for a native Japanese person.
Passepartout inquired about a servant position.
Batulcar rejected the offer, stating he already had two perfectly capable 'servants' – his own arms.
Passepartout expressed his strong desire to travel to the Pacific with the troupe.
Batulcar recognized Passepartout was not Japanese and questioned his attire.
Passepartout identified himself as a Parisian.
Batulcar, associating French nationality with making faces, asked if Passepartout could grimace.
Passepartout affirmed, slightly annoyed, adding Americans were equally adept.
Batulcar offered Passepartout a position as a clown instead of a servant, noting the international appeal of French clowns.
He confirmed Passepartout's physical strength and singing ability (even in acrobatic positions).
Satisfied with Passepartout's recalled skills from his youth, Batulcar hired him on the spot.
Passepartout secured employment with the Japanese troupe.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: He followed the clown, and soon found himself once more in the Japanese quarter.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He was engaged to act in the celebrated Japanese troupe.

events.text_segment:
He followed the clown, and soon found himself once more in the Japanese quarter. A quarter of an hour later he stopped before a large cabin, adorned with several clusters of streamers, the exterior walls of which were designed to represent, in violent colours and without perspective, a company of jugglers.
This was the Honourable William Batulcar’s establishment. That gentleman was a sort of Barnum, the director of a troupe of mountebanks, jugglers, clowns, acrobats, equilibrists, and gymnasts, who, according to the placard, was giving his last performances before leaving the Empire of the Sun for the States of the Union.
Passepartout entered and asked for Mr. Batulcar, who straightway appeared in person.
“What do you want?” said he to Passepartout, whom he at first took for a native.
“Would you like a servant, sir?” asked Passepartout.
“A servant!” cried Mr. Batulcar, caressing the thick grey beard which hung from his chin. “I already have two who are obedient and faithful, have never left me, and serve me for their nourishment and here they are,” added he, holding out his two robust arms, furrowed with veins as large as the strings of a bass-viol.
“So I can be of no use to you?”
“None.”
“The devil! I should so like to cross the Pacific with you!”
“Ah!” said the Honourable Mr. Batulcar. “You are no more a Japanese than I am a monkey! Who are you dressed up in that way?”
“A man dresses as he can.”
“That’s true. You are a Frenchman, aren’t you?”
“Yes; a Parisian of Paris.”
“Then you ought to know how to make grimaces?”
“Why,” replied Passepartout, a little vexed that his nationality should cause this question, “we Frenchmen know how to make grimaces, it is true but not any better than the Americans do.”
“True. Well, if I can’t take you as a servant, I can as a clown. You see, my friend, in France they exhibit foreign clowns, and in foreign parts French clowns.”
“Ah!”
“You are pretty strong, eh?”
“Especially after a good meal.”
“And you can sing?”
“Yes,” returned Passepartout, who had formerly been wont to sing in the streets.
“But can you sing standing on your head, with a top spinning on your left foot, and a sabre balanced on your right?”
“Humph! I think so,” replied Passepartout, recalling the exercises of his younger days.
“Well, that’s enough,” said the Honourable William Batulcar.
The engagement was concluded there and then.
Passepartout had at last found something to do. He was engaged to act in the celebrated Japanese troupe.

**Generated Literary Segment:**

He followed the clown, and soon found himself once more in the Japanese quarter. The narrow streets bustled with color and noise, banners fluttering above the heads of passersby, and the air thick with the scent of incense and fried delicacies. Passepartout, still in his borrowed Japanese garb, trailed the placard-bearer until they reached a large, gaudily decorated cabin. Painted panels depicted jugglers and acrobats in mid-leap, and a sign above the entrance proclaimed: "Batulcar’s Troupe—Final Performances Before Departure for America!"

Curious and hopeful, Passepartout entered and asked to see Mr. Batulcar. The director himself soon appeared—a stout, energetic man with a bristling mustache and a shrewd eye. At first, Batulcar regarded Passepartout as a native, but a few words in rapid French quickly dispelled the illusion.

"You are not Japanese?" Batulcar exclaimed, eyeing Passepartout’s costume with surprise.

"No, monsieur," Passepartout replied, "I am a Parisian, and I seek employment—perhaps as a servant for your journey across the Pacific."

Batulcar laughed heartily. "A servant? I have two excellent ones—my own arms! But a Parisian, you say? Can you make faces? Grimace, like all your countrymen?"

Passepartout, a little piqued, assured him that he could, and that Americans were no less skilled in such arts. Batulcar, delighted, proposed instead that Passepartout join the troupe as a clown, for French clowns, he declared, were always in demand.

"Are you strong? Can you sing—perhaps even while standing on your head?" Batulcar inquired.

Passepartout, recalling his youthful days in the circus, answered in the affirmative. Satisfied, Batulcar clapped him on the back and declared him hired. Thus, Passepartout found himself engaged as a performer, ready to cross the Pacific in the company of Batulcar’s remarkable troupe.

---

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
He followed the clown, and soon found himself once more in the Japanese quarter. The narrow streets were alive with the bustle of evening, lanterns glowing softly above the heads of passersby, and the air was thick with the mingled scents of incense and roasted chestnuts. Fogg moved with purpose, his eyes scanning the crowd for any sign of Passepartout. The clown, nimble and sure-footed, led him through a maze of alleys, past shops adorned with paper fans and silk kimonos, until they reached a small theatre tucked between two teahouses.

Inside, the sound of laughter and applause drifted out into the street. The clown gestured for Fogg to wait, then slipped inside. Moments later, he returned, beckoning Fogg to follow. The Englishman entered the theatre, his heart beating a little faster. On the stage, a troupe of acrobats performed, their costumes shimmering in the lamplight. But Fogg’s attention was fixed on a figure at the side of the stage, dressed in the outlandish garb of a clown, his face painted white with a red nose and exaggerated eyebrows. It was Passepartout.

Passepartout, unaware of his master’s presence, was preparing for his act. He juggled wooden balls, his movements deft and practiced, though his eyes betrayed a certain sadness. Fogg watched as his faithful servant took the stage, eliciting laughter and cheers from the audience with his antics. When the act was over, Fogg made his way backstage, where the clown who had guided him introduced him to the manager.

A few words in English and French sufficed to explain the situation. The manager, understanding that Passepartout was not a professional clown but a traveler in distress, agreed to release him from his engagement. Passepartout, upon seeing Fogg, could scarcely believe his eyes. He rushed forward, embracing his master with tears of relief and gratitude.

“Ah, monsieur!” he cried. “I thought I should never see you again!”

Fogg, with his customary composure, merely nodded. “Come, Passepartout. We have no time to lose.”

Together, they left the theatre and made their way back through the winding streets to the port, where the steamer for Yokohama was preparing to depart. Passepartout, though weary from his ordeal, was filled with renewed hope. He vowed never again to let himself be separated from his master, and as they boarded the ship, he looked back at the city with a mixture of relief and wonder, grateful for the strange adventure that had, at last, brought him safely back to Mr. Fogg’s side.

events.title: The Acrobatic Spectacle Begins
detailed_summary: Passepartout accepted the less-than-dignified role, focused on reaching San Francisco within the week.
The performance, heavily advertised by Batulcar, was set for three o'clock, heralded by loud Japanese instruments.
Without rehearsal, Passepartout was assigned to use his strength in the 'human pyramid' finale featuring the 'Long Noses of the god Tingou'.
Before the start time, the venue filled with a diverse audience of Europeans, natives, Chinese, and Japanese.
Musicians positioned themselves inside, playing various traditional instruments energetically.
The show commenced with typical acrobatic displays, showcasing the exceptional skills of Japanese equilibrists.
Acts included manipulating paper butterflies with a fan, creating smoke calligraphy, juggling lit candles extinguished and relit with the mouth, and complex spinning top tricks.
The tops performed incredible feats, moving across various surfaces and objects, demonstrating apparent autonomy and creating musical sounds.
Jugglers interacted with the spinning tops in complex ways.
The general acrobatic and gymnastic feats involving ladders, poles, and balls were performed with remarkable precision.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: It was not a very dignified position, but within a week he would be on his way to San Francisco.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The turning on ladders, poles, balls, barrels, &c., was executed with wonderful precision.

events.text_segment:
It was not a very dignified position, but within a week he would be on his way to San Francisco.
The performance, so noisily announced by the Honourable Mr. Batulcar, was to commence at three o’clock, and soon the deafening instruments of a Japanese orchestra resounded at the door. Passepartout, though he had not been able to study or rehearse a part, was designated to lend the aid of his sturdy shoulders in the great exhibition of the “human pyramid,” executed by the Long Noses of the god Tingou. This “great attraction” was to close the performance.
Before three o’clock the large shed was invaded by the spectators, comprising Europeans and natives, Chinese and Japanese, men, women and children, who precipitated themselves upon the narrow benches and into the boxes opposite the stage. The musicians took up a position inside, and were vigorously performing on their gongs, tam-tams, flutes, bones, tambourines, and immense drums.
The performance was much like all acrobatic displays; but it must be confessed that the Japanese are the first equilibrists in the world.
One, with a fan and some bits of paper, performed the graceful trick of the butterflies and the flowers; another traced in the air, with the odorous smoke of his pipe, a series of blue words, which composed a compliment to the audience; while a third juggled with some lighted candles, which he extinguished successively as they passed his lips, and relit again without interrupting for an instant his juggling. Another reproduced the most singular combinations with a spinning-top; in his hands the revolving tops seemed to be animated with a life of their own in their interminable whirling; they ran over pipe-stems, the edges of sabres, wires and even hairs stretched across the stage; they turned around on the edges of large glasses, crossed bamboo ladders, dispersed into all the corners, and produced strange musical effects by the combination of their various pitches of tone. The jugglers tossed them in the air, threw them like shuttlecocks with wooden battledores, and yet they kept on spinning; they put them into their pockets, and took them out still whirling as before.
It is useless to describe the astonishing performances of the acrobats and gymnasts. The turning on ladders, poles, balls, barrels, &c., was executed with wonderful precision.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
It was not a very dignified position, but within a week he would be on his way to San Francisco. Passepartout was not even certain that he would get there at all. The contract which he had signed with William Batulcar obliged him to appear in the last act of the Japanese troupe’s performance, and this act was to take place at three o’clock, before a large audience, which had been attracted by the posters and the loud music of the Japanese instruments. Without any rehearsal, Passepartout was to take part in the grand finale, the “human pyramid,” in which fifty long-nosed acrobats, representing the god Tingou, were to form a pyramid by mounting one upon another, and Passepartout was to be the base of the edifice, supporting all the others on his broad shoulders. This was not an easy task, especially as the performers were to wear enormous noses, which, according to the legend, had been given to them by the god Tingou as a punishment for their misdeeds.

The performance was to begin at three o’clock, and before that hour the theatre was filled with a curious and motley crowd—Europeans, natives, Chinese, and Japanese, all eager to witness the wonderful feats of the acrobats. The musicians took their places inside, and the performance began with the usual displays of skill and agility. The Japanese equilibrists, with their paper butterflies, which they kept flying in the air with the aid of fans; the jugglers, who made lighted candles appear and disappear in their mouths; the smoke artists, who traced mysterious characters in the air with the smoke of their pipes; the top-spinners, who sent their tops whirling over the floor, up the walls, across the ceiling, and even on the points of swords; the jugglers, who caught the tops on little sticks, and made them perform the most incredible evolutions; the gymnasts, who performed on ladders, poles, and balls—all these wonderful feats were executed with a precision and dexterity which excited the admiration of the spectators.

It was not a very dignified position, but within a week he would be on his way to San Francisco. Passepartout was not even certain that he would get there at all. The contract which he had signed with William Batulcar obliged him to appear in the last act of the Japanese troupe’s performance, and this act was to take place at three o’clock, before a large audience, which had been attracted by the posters and the loud music of the Japanese instruments. Without any rehearsal, Passepartout was to take part in the grand finale, the “human pyramid,” in which fifty long-nosed acrobats, representing the god Tingou, were to form a pyramid by mounting one upon another, and Passepartout was to be the base of the edifice, supporting all the others on his broad shoulders. This was not an easy task, especially as the performers were to wear enormous noses, which, according to the legend, had been given to them by the god Tingou as a punishment for their misdeeds.

The performance was to begin at three o’clock, and before that hour the theatre was filled with a curious and motley crowd—Europeans, natives, Chinese, and Japanese, all eager to witness the wonderful feats of the acrobats. The musicians took their places inside, and the performance began with the usual displays of skill and agility. The Japanese equilibrists, with their paper butterflies, which they kept flying in the air with the aid of fans; the jugglers, who made lighted candles appear and disappear in their mouths; the smoke artists, who traced mysterious characters in the air with the smoke of their pipes; the top-spinners, who sent their tops whirling over the floor, up the walls, across the ceiling, and even on the points of swords; the jugglers, who caught the tops on little sticks, and made them perform the most incredible evolutions; the gymnasts, who performed on ladders, poles, and balls—all these wonderful feats were executed with a precision and dexterity which excited the admiration of the spectators.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
He had, in fact, no time to lose. The steamer for Yokohama was to leave in a few hours, and Passepartout, though somewhat bruised and disheveled from his recent adventures, was determined not to let his master down. He hurried through the bustling streets of Hong Kong, dodging rickshaws and porters, his mind fixed on the single goal of reaching the steamer before it sailed. 

Meanwhile, Phileas Fogg, ever composed and methodical, had already made his arrangements. He had secured the necessary tickets, checked the departure time, and ensured that Aouda was comfortably settled. The prospect of missing the steamer, and thus failing in his wager, was not to be entertained. Fogg’s calm exterior belied the urgency of the situation, but his every action was calculated to save precious minutes.

Passepartout arrived at the quay just as the last passengers were boarding. He waved frantically, catching sight of his master on the deck. Fogg, recognizing his faithful servant, signaled to the crew to lower the gangplank once more. With a final burst of energy, Passepartout scrambled aboard, breathless but triumphant. The steamer’s whistle sounded, and the vessel began to move away from the dock, bound for Yokohama.

As the city receded into the distance, Fogg turned to Passepartout. “You have done well,” he said quietly. Passepartout, still panting, managed a grateful smile. Aouda, observing the exchange, felt a renewed sense of admiration for both men. The journey had tested them in ways none could have foreseen, yet their resolve remained unshaken.

The days at sea passed in a routine of quiet anticipation. Fogg spent his time consulting timetables and making notes in his ever-present notebook. Passepartout, ever resourceful, made friends among the crew and passengers, gathering information about the next leg of their journey. Aouda, grateful for her rescue and the company of her companions, found solace in their shared purpose.

At last, the coast of Japan appeared on the horizon. The travelers prepared to disembark, each aware that the most challenging part of their journey still lay ahead. But for now, they had triumphed over adversity, and the promise of San Francisco beckoned them onward, ever closer to the completion of their remarkable voyage.

events.title: The Human Pyramid and Unexpected Recognition
detailed_summary: The main event featured the 'Long Noses,' performers associated with the god Tingou, unknown in Europe.
They wore medieval-style costumes with wings and distinctively long bamboo noses (five to ten feet) attached to their faces.
These noses, varying in shape and decoration, were used for gymnastic exercises.
Performers lay on their backs while others balanced and performed acrobatics on their elongated noses.
The finale was advertised as a 'human pyramid' representing the Car of Juggernaut, formed not on shoulders, but on the noses.
The usual base performer had left the troupe.
Passepartout, possessing the needed strength and dexterity, was chosen as the new base.
Reluctantly donning the costume with wings and a six-foot false nose, Passepartout felt a twinge of melancholy recalling his youth, but consoled himself that it earned him food.
He took his position on stage with others forming the pyramid's base, lying down with noses pointed upward.
Successive tiers of performers balanced on the noses below them, constructing a human monument reaching the theatre's ceiling.
Amid loud applause and orchestral music, the pyramid suddenly became unstable.
The balance was lost as one of the base noses (Passepartout's) disappeared.
The entire structure collapsed dramatically.
Passepartout was responsible; abandoning his post, he leaped over the footlights and scrambled into the right-hand gallery.
He landed at the feet of a spectator, exclaiming in recognition.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Ah, my master! my master!”

events.text_segment:
But the principal attraction was the exhibition of the Long Noses, a show to which Europe is as yet a stranger.
The Long Noses form a peculiar company, under the direct patronage of the god Tingou. Attired after the fashion of the Middle Ages, they bore upon their shoulders a splendid pair of wings; but what especially distinguished them was the long noses which were fastened to their faces, and the uses which they made of them. These noses were made of bamboo, and were five, six, and even ten feet long, some straight, others curved, some ribboned, and some having imitation warts upon them. It was upon these appendages, fixed tightly on their real noses, that they performed their gymnastic exercises. A dozen of these sectaries of Tingou lay flat upon their backs, while others, dressed to represent lightning-rods, came and frolicked on their noses, jumping from one to another, and performing the most skilful leapings and somersaults.
As a last scene, a “human pyramid” had been announced, in which fifty Long Noses were to represent the Car of Juggernaut. But, instead of forming a pyramid by mounting each other’s shoulders, the artists were to group themselves on top of the noses. It happened that the performer who had hitherto formed the base of the Car had quitted the troupe, and as, to fill this part, only strength and adroitness were necessary, Passepartout had been chosen to take his place.
The poor fellow really felt sad when—melancholy reminiscence of his youth!—he donned his costume, adorned with vari-coloured wings, and fastened to his natural feature a false nose six feet long. But he cheered up when he thought that this nose was winning him something to eat.
He went upon the stage, and took his place beside the rest who were to compose the base of the Car of Juggernaut. They all stretched themselves on the floor, their noses pointing to the ceiling. A second group of artists disposed themselves on these long appendages, then a third above these, then a fourth, until a human monument reaching to the very cornices of the theatre soon arose on top of the noses. This elicited loud applause, in the midst of which the orchestra was just striking up a deafening air, when the pyramid tottered, the balance was lost, one of the lower noses vanished from the pyramid, and the human monument was shattered like a castle built of cards!
It was Passepartout’s fault. Abandoning his position, clearing the footlights without the aid of his wings, and, clambering up to the right-hand gallery, he fell at the feet of one of the spectators, crying, “Ah, my master! my master!”

But the principal attraction was the exhibition of the Long Noses, a show to which Europe is as yet a stranger. These noses, painted and festooned with ribbons, served not merely as ornament, but as the very apparatus for their astonishing feats.

The troupe began their display by lying supine upon the stage, their noses pointing skyward like the masts of some bizarre fleet. With a flourish, other acrobats mounted these flexible bridges, balancing with practiced ease, and soon the stage was alive with a spectacle of tumblers and contortionists, each supported by the improbable strength of a comrade’s nose.

The climax of the performance was announced as the formation of the Car of Juggernaut—a human pyramid, not built upon shoulders, but upon these extraordinary nasal supports. Yet, on this evening, the usual base performer was absent, and the task fell to Passepartout, whose agility and strength had not gone unnoticed. With a sigh, he donned the winged tunic and the six-foot nose, feeling a pang of nostalgia for his days as a gymnast, but consoled by the thought that at least he would earn his supper.

Taking his place among the base, Passepartout lay down, nose aloft, as the pyramid began to rise above him, tier upon tier, until the human edifice nearly touched the theatre’s ceiling. The audience erupted in applause, the orchestra struck up a triumphant march—when suddenly, disaster struck. The pyramid wavered, teetered, and, with a crash, collapsed in a tangle of limbs and noses.

The cause was soon apparent: Passepartout, abandoning his post, had vanished from beneath the structure. In a flash, he had leapt over the footlights, scrambled into the right-hand gallery, and landed breathless at the feet of a startled spectator. Looking up, he recognized the face before him and cried out in astonishment.

---

**End of Segment**

But the principal attraction was the exhibition of the Long Noses, a show to which Europe is as yet a stranger. These singular performers, worshippers of the god Tingou, appeared in fantastic medieval garb, their shoulders adorned with wings, and, most notably, each wore a prodigious bamboo nose—some five, others ten feet in length—fastened to their faces and decorated with colored paper, tinsel, and fluttering streamers. The noses, some straight, others curved or twisted, gleamed under the gaslight, their surfaces lacquered and festooned with tiny bells and rosettes.

The performance began with the Long Noses lying flat upon their backs, their noses raised like the prows of ships. At a signal, a second group of acrobats climbed atop these noses, balancing with astonishing dexterity. Then a third group mounted the second, and so on, until, as announced by the master of ceremonies, a pyramid of forty performers was formed—not upon shoulders, but upon noses, the whole structure swaying perilously as it rose toward the theatre’s ceiling.

It was at this moment that the audience was informed the usual base performer had left the troupe, and that a replacement had been found in the person of Passepartout, whose strength and agility had recommended him for the role. Passepartout, though he donned the winged tunic and six-foot nose with a sigh, could not help but recall his youthful days as a gymnast in Paris, mingling nostalgia with the melancholy of his present circumstances. Still, he consoled himself that the performance would at least provide him with a meal.

He took his place among the base, lying down with his nose pointed skyward, as the pyramid was constructed above him, tier by tier, each level more precarious than the last. The orchestra struck up a lively march, and the audience burst into applause as the human monument trembled at its full height. Suddenly, at the very climax, a commotion arose: one of the noses at the base—Passepartout’s—had vanished! The pyramid wavered, then collapsed in a spectacular heap, amid shrieks and laughter.

In the confusion, Passepartout was seen springing over the footlights, bounding into the right-hand gallery, and landing at the feet of a gentleman seated in the front row. Breathless, his false nose askew, Passepartout looked up, recognized the face before him, and cried out, with irrepressible emotion:

“Ah! Monsieur Fogg!”

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
These Long Noses form a peculiar caste among the natives of Japan, and are so called from their snub noses, which are at least three inches long. Some of these noses are painted red, others green, or blue, or black; but all are of a most extraordinary shape. The Long Noses are held in great veneration. Old legends assert that they are descended from the ancient Tengu, supernatural beings who were half man, half bird, and who, according to the Japanese mythology, once inhabited the mountains of the island. The Tengu were supposed to possess prodigious powers, and to be able to fly through the air, to change their shape at will, and to cause tempests and earthquakes. The Long Noses, their descendants, are believed to have inherited some of these marvellous faculties, and to be able, by a mere motion of their noses, to bring good or evil fortune upon those who consult them. Hence the respect in which they are held, and the crowds which flock to their exhibitions.

Aouda, Phileas Fogg, and Passepartout found themselves in the midst of a curious assemblage, composed of men, women, and children, all intent upon the spectacle. The Long Noses, dressed in fantastic costumes, performed a variety of singular evolutions, twisting and turning their noses in every conceivable way, and executing grotesque dances, to the great delight of the spectators. Some of them balanced themselves on bamboo poles, others leaped through hoops, or performed feats of agility and strength, all the while keeping up a running fire of jokes and repartees, which, though unintelligible to the foreigners, were received with shouts of laughter by the natives.

The exhibition lasted for more than an hour, and was followed by a procession, in which the Long Noses marched in solemn state, preceded by musicians playing on strange instruments, and followed by a crowd of admirers. Phileas Fogg, who had never before witnessed anything of the kind, regarded the spectacle with his usual imperturbable calm, while Passepartout, who was always ready to be amused, laughed heartily at the antics of the performers. Aouda, though somewhat astonished at the singularity of the exhibition, could not help joining in the general merriment.

After the procession had passed, the crowd gradually dispersed, and our travellers, having satisfied their curiosity, prepared to continue their walk through the streets of Yokohama. They had seen one of the most curious sights of Japan, and Passepartout, in particular, was loud in his praises of the Long Noses, declaring that he had never beheld anything so extraordinary in all his travels.

events.title: Reunion, Resolution, and Departure for America
detailed_summary: Phileas Fogg recognized Passepartout despite his outlandish costume.
Passepartout confirmed his identity.
Fogg immediately instructed him to come to the steamer.
Fogg, Aouda, and Passepartout exited the theatre through the lobby.
Outside, they were confronted by a furious William Batulcar.
Batulcar demanded compensation for the collapsed pyramid.
Phileas Fogg placated him by giving him a handful of banknotes.
Precisely at the scheduled departure time of 6:30 PM, Fogg and Aouda boarded the American steamer.
Passepartout followed them, still wearing his wings and the six-foot nose in his haste.

events.text_segment:
“You here?”
“Myself.”
“Very well; then let us go to the steamer, young man!”
Mr. Fogg, Aouda, and Passepartout passed through the lobby of the theatre to the outside, where they encountered the Honourable Mr. Batulcar, furious with rage. He demanded damages for the “breakage” of the pyramid; and Phileas Fogg appeased him by giving him a handful of banknotes.
At half-past six, the very hour of departure, Mr. Fogg and Aouda, followed by Passepartout, who in his hurry had retained his wings, and nose six feet long, stepped upon the American steamer.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
"You here?"

"Myself!" responded Passepartout, whose voice betrayed a lively emotion; and, rushing to his master, he warmly embraced him.

"Well, then, let us go to the steamer, young man!" cried Fogg.

Mr. Fogg, Aouda, and Passepartout passed through the lobby of the theatre to the street. Passepartout was evidently much moved. He had found his master again. It was as if he had found his family.

But William Batulcar, who had followed them out, was furious. His money and his show were gone! He demanded damages for the "pyramid" having fallen to pieces. Phileas Fogg, without a word, drew from his pocket a handful of banknotes, which he handed to the manager, who grasped them and counted them with a grimace of satisfaction.

At half-past six, the hour of departure, Mr. Fogg, followed by Aouda and Passepartout, who still wore his wings and nose, boarded the American steamer. Passepartout, in his haste, had not even taken time to remove his theatrical costume, and thus, with his enormous nose six feet long, he followed his master and mistress on board the vessel that was to bear them to Yokohama.

Its signals were observed by the captain of the Yokohama-bound steamer.
Seeing the flag flown at half-mast, the steamer altered its course to approach the smaller vessel.
Phileas Fogg settled his payment with John Busby, the pilot-boat's captain.
Fogg gave Busby a substantial reward of five hundred and fifty pounds beyond the agreed price.
Fogg, along with Aouda and Fix, boarded the larger steamer.
The steamer immediately departed for its destinations, Nagasaki and Yokohama.

The signals made by the “Tankadere” had been seen by the captain of the Yokohama steamer, who, espying the flag at half-mast, had directed his course towards the little craft. Phileas Fogg, after paying the stipulated price of his passage to John Busby, and rewarding that worthy with the additional sum of five hundred and fifty pounds, ascended the steamer with Aouda and Fix; and they started at once for Nagasaki and Yokohama.

events.title: Reaching Yokohama and Locating Passepartout

The steamer to San Francisco was scheduled to leave the same evening.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: They reached their destination on the morning of the 14th of November.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He could not help starting, which so changed the position of his nose as to bring the “pyramid” pell-mell upon the stage.

events.text_segment:
They reached their destination on the morning of the 14th of November. Phileas Fogg lost no time in going on board the “Carnatic,” where he learned, to Aouda’s great delight—and perhaps to his own, though he betrayed no emotion—that Passepartout, a Frenchman, had really arrived on her the day before.
The San Francisco steamer was announced to leave that very evening, and it became necessary to find Passepartout, if possible, without delay. Mr. Fogg applied in vain to the French and English consuls, and, after wandering through the streets a long time, began to despair of finding his missing servant. Chance, or perhaps a kind of presentiment, at last led him into the Honourable Mr. Batulcar’s theatre. He certainly would not have recognised Passepartout in the eccentric mountebank’s costume; but the latter, lying on his back, perceived his master in the gallery. He could not help starting, which so changed the position of his nose as to bring the “pyramid” pell-mell upon the stage.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
They reached their destination on the morning of the 14th of November. Phileas Fogg was only twenty-four hours behind time. Passepartout, the involuntary cause of this delay, was, it is true, almost as much affected as his master; and, to his credit, he had not uttered a single word of complaint. Aouda was also deeply concerned; but she did not speak.

As soon as they landed, Fogg inquired if the Carnatic had left. It was due to sail that very evening for San Francisco. He at once went on board, and learned, to his great satisfaction, that Passepartout, a Frenchman, had arrived the day before. This information delighted Aouda, and, perhaps, Fogg himself, though he betrayed no emotion.

At the consulate, Fogg could obtain no further intelligence. He then made the round of the city, searching for his servant in every possible place, but all in vain. Time pressed; the steamer would soon depart. At last, as if by a sudden inspiration, he entered the theatre of the Honourable Mr. Batulcar, where a Japanese troupe was performing.

Fogg would never have recognized his servant in the strange costume he wore, but Passepartout, lying on his back in the midst of a human pyramid, perceived his master in the gallery. An involuntary movement, at this discovery, caused the pyramid to totter, and, with a crash, all the performers came down together, amid the most unseasonable laughter and applause of the audience. Passepartout, extricating himself as quickly as possible from the confusion of the actors and the fragments of scenery, rushed towards his master, his nose no longer adorned with its artificial appendage, and grasped him warmly by the hand.

events.title: Passepartout's Explanation and Reintegration
detailed_summary: Aouda informed Passepartout about their journey from Hong Kong to Shanghai aboard the 'Tankadere', including Fix's presence.
Passepartout showed no outward reaction upon hearing Fix's name.
He decided it wasn't the right moment to reveal his interactions with the detective to Fogg.
When explaining his absence, he attributed it solely to being overcome by opium intoxication at a Hong Kong tavern.
Mr. Fogg listened to the explanation impassively, without comment.
He then gave Passepartout money to buy clothes suitable for his role.
In less than an hour, Passepartout had removed his costume components (nose and wings) and no longer resembled the performer.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: All this Passepartout learned from Aouda, who recounted to him what had taken place on the voyage from Hong Kong to Shanghai on the “Tankadere,” in company with one Mr. Fix.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Within an hour the Frenchman had cut off his nose and parted with his wings, and retained nothing about him which recalled the sectary of the god Tingou.

events.text_segment:
All this Passepartout learned from Aouda, who recounted to him what had taken place on the voyage from Hong Kong to Shanghai on the “Tankadere,” in company with one Mr. Fix.
Passepartout did not change countenance on hearing this name. He thought that the time had not yet arrived to divulge to his master what had taken place between the detective and himself; and, in the account he gave of his absence, he simply excused himself for having been overtaken by drunkenness, in smoking opium at a tavern in Hong Kong.
Mr. Fogg heard this narrative coldly, without a word; and then furnished his man with funds necessary to obtain clothing more in harmony with his position. Within an hour the Frenchman had cut off his nose and parted with his wings, and retained nothing about him which recalled the sectary of the god Tingou.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: All this Passepartout learned from Aouda, who recounted to him what had taken place on the voyage from Hong Kong to Shanghai on the “Tankadere,” in company with one Mr. Fix. Passepartout did not betray, by the slightest sign, that he knew the detective had followed them on board the steamer; he listened to Aouda’s narrative as if it were all new to him. He did not, however, think it advisable to tell Mr. Fogg what had happened; he was too well aware that, if he had been less stupefied by opium, he would never have let Fix outwit him. He contented himself with telling his master that he had been overtaken by a sort of intoxication at a tavern in Hong Kong. Mr. Fogg heard this explanation without a word, and merely gave his servant money to purchase another pair of shoes. It was only after a long search that Passepartout succeeded in finding suitable clothing, for he had, as it were, to replace his whole wardrobe. He soon got rid of his nose and wings, and no longer resembled a second-rate tragedian.

events.title: Departure on the 'General Grant' for San Francisco
detailed_summary: The vessel for the Yokohama to San Francisco leg was the 'General Grant', operated by the Pacific Mail Steamship Company.
It was described as a large, 2,500-ton paddle-wheel steamer, well-appointed and fast.
Details of its engine mechanism, including the walking-beam, piston-rod, and connecting-rod driving the paddles, were noted.
The ship had three masts and substantial sail capacity to supplement its steam engine.
With a speed of twelve miles per hour, it was expected to complete the Pacific crossing in twenty-one days.
This schedule gave Phileas Fogg confidence in reaching San Francisco by December 2nd, New York by December 11th, and London by December 20th.
This timeline potentially offered a buffer of several hours before his December 21st deadline.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The steamer which was about to depart from Yokohama to San Francisco belonged to the Pacific Mail Steamship Company, and was named the “General Grant.”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Phileas Fogg was therefore justified in hoping that he would reach San Francisco by the 2nd of December, New York by the 11th, and London on the 20th—thus gaining several hours on the fatal date of the 21st of December.

events.text_segment: The steamer which was about to depart from Yokohama to San Francisco belonged to the Pacific Mail Steamship Company, and was named the “General Grant.” She was a large paddle-wheel steamer of two thousand five hundred tons; well equipped and very fast. The massive walking-beam rose and fell above the deck; at one end a piston-rod worked up and down; and at the other was a connecting-rod which, in changing the rectilinear motion to a circular one, was directly connected with the shaft of the paddles. The “General Grant” was rigged with three masts, giving a large capacity for sails, and thus materially aiding the steam power. By making twelve miles an hour, she would cross the ocean in twenty-one days. Phileas Fogg was therefore justified in hoping that he would reach San Francisco by the 2nd of December, New York by the 11th, and London on the 20th—thus gaining several hours on the fatal date of the 21st of December.

The General Grant offered to the passengers a superior comfort, with spacious cabins and a well-appointed saloon. The engine, of the walking-beam type, with its enormous piston-rod and connecting-rod, drove the paddle-wheels with great regularity. The vessel was rigged with three masts, and could, whenever the wind was favorable, make use of her sails, thus increasing her speed. Under steam and sail, the General Grant was able to maintain an average speed of twelve miles an hour, and it was expected that the voyage across the Pacific would be accomplished in twenty-one days. This would enable Phileas Fogg to reach San Francisco by the 2nd of December, New York by the 11th, and London by the 20th; thus gaining several hours on the fatal date of the 21st of December.

The weather was favorable, and the “General Grant” steamed out of the harbor, her prow turned towards the vast Pacific, bearing the little party onward in their adventurous journey around the world.

events.title: Smooth Pacific Crossing and Developing Relationships
detailed_summary: The 'General Grant' carried a diverse group of passengers, including British, American, Chinese laborers heading to California, and East Indian officers on a world tour.
The voyage across the Pacific was uneventful.
The large paddle steamer remained stable, experiencing little rolling, living up to the ocean's peaceful reputation.
Mr. Fogg maintained his usual calm and reserved demeanor.
Aouda found her feelings for Fogg deepening beyond simple gratitude.
His quiet generosity made a strong impression on her, leading to developing emotions she acted upon almost unconsciously, which seemed unnoticed by him.
Aouda became deeply invested in Fogg's travel plans, growing anxious about any potential delays.
She frequently conversed with Passepartout.
Passepartout recognized Aouda's growing affection for Fogg.
As a loyal servant, he consistently praised Fogg's positive qualities: integrity, generosity, and dedication.
He actively sought to alleviate Aouda's anxieties about the journey's success, assuring her the hardest parts were over.
He expressed confidence that crossing America by train and the Atlantic by steamer would ensure they met the deadline.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: There was a full complement of passengers on board, among them English, many Americans, a large number of coolies on their way to California, and several East Indian officers, who were spending their vacation in making the tour of the world.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: A railway train from San Francisco to New York, and a transatlantic steamer from New York to Liverpool, would doubtless bring them to the end of this impossible journey round the world within the period agreed upon.

events.text_segment:
There was a full complement of passengers on board, among them English, many Americans, a large number of coolies on their way to California, and several East Indian officers, who were spending their vacation in making the tour of the world. Nothing of moment happened on the voyage; the steamer, sustained on its large paddles, rolled but little, and the “Pacific” almost justified its name. Mr. Fogg was as calm and taciturn as ever. His young companion felt herself more and more attached to him by other ties than gratitude; his silent but generous nature impressed her more than she thought; and it was almost unconsciously that she yielded to emotions which did not seem to have the least effect upon her protector. Aouda took the keenest interest in his plans, and became impatient at any incident which seemed likely to retard his journey.
She often chatted with Passepartout, who did not fail to perceive the state of the lady’s heart; and, being the most faithful of domestics, he never exhausted his eulogies of Phileas Fogg’s honesty, generosity, and devotion. He took pains to calm Aouda’s doubts of a successful termination of the journey, telling her that the most difficult part of it had passed, that now they were beyond the fantastic countries of Japan and China, and were fairly on their way to civilised places again. A railway train from San Francisco to New York, and a transatlantic steamer from New York to Liverpool, would doubtless bring them to the end of this impossible journey round the world within the period agreed upon.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: There was a full complement of passengers on board, among them English, many Americans, a large number of coolies on their way to California, and several East Indian officers, who were spending their vacation in making the tour of the world. The "General Grant" was a large paddle-wheel steamer, of great tonnage, well equipped and very fast. She was as comfortable as a steamer could be. With her broad paddle-wheels, she made little motion on the sea, and the Pacific justified its name, for it was as calm as an inland lake. The days passed monotonously, with little incident. Mr. Fogg was as calm and impassible as ever. He was not one to be disturbed by the monotony of the voyage, nor by the conversations of his fellow-passengers, which he rarely joined. Aouda, however, felt her gratitude to Mr. Fogg deepening into a warmer sentiment. She was unconscious of the extent of her feelings, but the quiet generosity and devotion of her companion made a profound impression upon her. She became more and more interested in the success of his journey, and grew anxious at the least delay. She often conversed with Passepartout, who, with his usual good nature, did his best to reassure her. He praised Mr. Fogg's energy and honesty, his devotion and generosity, and declared that the hardest part of the journey was over, that they had only to cross America by train, and the Atlantic by steamer, and that they would arrive in London in time. Passepartout, with the instinct of a devoted servant, had noticed Aouda's growing attachment to his master, and he was delighted at the prospect of their happiness.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The steamer, the General Grant, was a fine vessel, with spacious cabins and broad decks, and she ploughed the waters of the Pacific with a steady, powerful motion. The passengers, drawn from so many different nations, presented a curious spectacle as they mingled on deck or in the saloon. The English, with their habitual reserve, kept somewhat apart, forming little groups and discussing the news from home or the progress of the voyage. The Americans, more demonstrative, were eager to make acquaintances, and their lively conversation and laughter enlivened the long hours at sea. The coolies, huddled together in a corner of the lower deck, looked with wonder at the vast expanse of ocean, their faces betraying both excitement and apprehension at the unknown world to which they were bound. The East Indian officers, in their smart uniforms, strolled about with an air of easy confidence, occasionally joining in the games or conversations of their fellow travelers.

Phileas Fogg, as usual, remained calm and self-possessed, spending much of his time pacing the deck or reading in a quiet corner. Passepartout, delighted with the novelty of the voyage, made friends with everyone, his good humor and curiosity making him a favorite among the crew and passengers alike. Aouda, grateful for the kindness shown her, enjoyed the fresh sea air and the ever-changing panorama of sky and water.

events.title: Mid-Ocean Calculation and Passepartout's Watch 'Triumph'
detailed_summary: Nine days out from Yokohama, Fogg had crossed half the planet's longitude.
On November 23rd, the 'General Grant' crossed the 180th meridian, the point directly opposite London.
Fogg noted that 52 of his allotted 80 days had passed, leaving only 28.
Although halfway by meridian, he had actually completed over two-thirds of the total travel distance (17,500 out of approx. 26,000 miles).

This discrepancy was due to the necessary detours taken earlier in the journey (London-Aden-Bombay-Calcutta-Singapore-Yokohama) compared to a direct route along London's latitude (approx. 12,000 miles).
The path forward was now direct, and Fix was presumed absent, removing a source of obstacles.
On the same day, November 23rd, Passepartout made what he considered a delightful discovery.
He had stubbornly kept his watch set to London time throughout the journey, dismissing local times.
He found that his watch now perfectly matched the ship's chronometers without any adjustment.
He was ecstatic, wishing Fix were present to witness this 'vindication'.
Passepartout mockingly recalled Fix's explanations about time zones, meridians, the sun, and the moon, dismissing them as nonsense.
He triumphantly declared his certainty that the sun would eventually align with his watch.

The narrative clarifies Passepartout's ignorance: if his watch had a 24-hour dial, it would show 9 PM (21:00), matching the time difference from London at the 180th meridian, thus revealing the true situation, not vindicating his London time.
It's noted that even if Fix could explain this, Passepartout likely wouldn't understand or accept it.
Furthermore, had Fix been present, Passepartout's confrontation would have been about different matters entirely.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: On the ninth day after leaving Yokohama, Phileas Fogg had traversed exactly one half of the terrestrial globe.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Moreover, if the detective had been on board at that moment, Passepartout would have joined issue with him on a quite different subject, and in an entirely different manner.

events.text_segment:
On the ninth day after leaving Yokohama, Phileas Fogg had traversed exactly one half of the terrestrial globe. The “General Grant” passed, on the 23rd of November, the one hundred and eightieth meridian, and was at the very antipodes of London. Mr. Fogg had, it is true, exhausted fifty-two of the eighty days in which he was to complete the tour, and there were only twenty-eight left. But, though he was only half-way by the difference of meridians, he had really gone over two-thirds of the whole journey; for he had been obliged to make long circuits from London to Aden, from Aden to Bombay, from Calcutta to Singapore, and from Singapore to Yokohama. Could he have followed without deviation the fiftieth parallel, which is that of London, the whole distance would only have been about twelve thousand miles; whereas he would be forced, by the irregular methods of locomotion, to traverse twenty-six thousand, of which he had, on the 23rd of November, accomplished seventeen thousand five hundred. And now the course was a straight one, and Fix was no longer there to put obstacles in their way!
It happened also, on the 23rd of November, that Passepartout made a joyful discovery. It will be remembered that the obstinate fellow had insisted on keeping his famous family watch at London time, and on regarding that of the countries he had passed through as quite false and unreliable. Now, on this day, though he had not changed the hands, he found that his watch exactly agreed with the ship’s chronometers. His triumph was hilarious. He would have liked to know what Fix would say if he were aboard!
“The rogue told me a lot of stories,” repeated Passepartout, “about the meridians, the sun, and the moon! Moon, indeed! moonshine more likely! If one listened to that sort of people, a pretty sort of time one would keep! I was sure that the sun would some day regulate itself by my watch!”
Passepartout was ignorant that, if the face of his watch had been divided into twenty-four hours, like the Italian clocks, he would have no reason for exultation; for the hands of his watch would then, instead of as now indicating nine o’clock in the morning, indicate nine o’clock in the evening, that is, the twenty-first hour after midnight precisely the difference between London time and that of the one hundred and eightieth meridian. But if Fix had been able to explain this purely physical effect, Passepartout would not have admitted, even if he had comprehended it. Moreover, if the detective had been on board at that moment, Passepartout would have joined issue with him on a quite different subject, and in an entirely different manner.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
On the ninth day after leaving Yokohama, Phileas Fogg had traversed exactly one half of the terrestrial globe. The General Grant, on which he was travelling, was crossing the Pacific from Japan to San Francisco. Mr. Fogg might have been expected to be somewhat anxious, for the time was passing rapidly, and he had only twenty-eight days in which to complete the journey to London. The distance he still had to traverse was at least seven thousand miles.

But the General Grant made excellent time, and Phileas Fogg, who was as calm and methodical as ever, noted that, on the 23rd of November, the vessel crossed the 180th meridian, the line exactly opposite the meridian of London. Of the eighty days allotted for his journey, fifty-two had now passed; he had, therefore, twenty-eight days left. Though he had only reached the halfway point in longitude, he had already accomplished more than two-thirds of the whole journey, in actual distance, by the circuitous route he had taken—London to Aden, Aden to Bombay, Bombay to Calcutta, Calcutta to Singapore, Singapore to Yokohama, and Yokohama to San Francisco. The distance from London to Yokohama, going eastward, is about seventeen thousand five hundred miles, while by the direct route, by way of the 50th parallel, it is only about twelve thousand miles. But Phileas Fogg had been obliged to make the detours named, and the General Grant, instead of going directly to San Francisco, was obliged to touch at several points on the way. But now the route was a straight one, and Fix, who had so persistently followed Mr. Fogg, and who was now, as it seemed, left behind, was no longer to be feared.

On this 23rd of November, Passepartout made a joyful discovery. It will be remembered that he had stubbornly kept his famous family watch at London time, and had refused to change the hands, though all the clocks in the various countries he had visited had been set according to the sun. Now, on this day, though he had not touched his watch, he found that it agreed exactly with the ship's chronometers. His triumph was hilarious. He would have liked to know what Fix would say if he were aboard! "The rogue told me a lot of stories about the meridians, the sun, and the moon! Moon, indeed! If one listened to that sort of thing, one would have to believe that every country has its own time, as if the sun were not the same everywhere! I’m sure that if he were here, he would not dare to maintain the contrary!"

It is certain that Fix would not have dared to maintain the contrary, for he would not have been able to convince Passepartout. Passepartout was, besides, quite incapable of reasoning. If the watch had been set at a twenty-four hour dial, like the chronometers of the ship, it would have shown nine o’clock in the evening, the exact hour at which the vessel was crossing the 180th meridian. The difference between London time and the 180th meridian is exactly twelve hours; but if Fix had been there, Passepartout would have had other things to say to him than about the meridians.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
He was now in the heart of the United States, and the train was speeding across the vast prairies of Nebraska, bound for Omaha. The journey from San Francisco had been accomplished without any notable incident. The Pacific Railroad, completed only a few years before, had opened up the continent, and the iron rails stretched in a straight line across the immense plains, linking the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans.

Phileas Fogg, as was his custom, spent most of his time in the carriage, reading newspapers or quietly gazing out the window at the endless expanse of grassland. Passepartout, his faithful servant, was more restless. He marveled at the herds of buffalo that sometimes delayed the train, the distant silhouettes of Native American encampments, and the occasional sight of a solitary horseman galloping across the horizon. The Frenchman was filled with wonder at the scale and novelty of the American landscape, so different from the cities and countryside of Europe and Asia through which they had already passed.

Aouda, the young Parsee woman whom Fogg had rescued in India, was also a passenger in their compartment. She was grateful for the Englishman’s protection and had come to admire his calm determination. The three companions had formed a close bond during their travels, united by the shared goal of reaching London within the prescribed eighty days.

The train made brief stops at small stations, where the passengers could stretch their legs and observe the bustling activity of the frontier towns. At one such stop, Passepartout struck up a conversation with a local, who regaled him with tales of the gold rush and the dangers of the wild West. The Frenchman listened with wide-eyed fascination, his imagination fired by stories of outlaws and pioneers.

As the train pressed on, the landscape began to change. The flat prairies gave way to rolling hills and wooded valleys. The air grew colder, and the sky was often overcast. Fogg consulted his watch frequently, calculating the time gained or lost at each stop. He was ever mindful of the wager he had made at the Reform Club, and the fortune that depended on his punctual arrival in London.

One evening, as the sun set in a blaze of orange and purple, the train crossed a long wooden bridge over a rushing river. The passengers gathered at the windows to admire the view, and Passepartout exclaimed at the engineering marvels that made such a journey possible. Fogg, however, remained impassive, his thoughts fixed on the road ahead.

Thus, with half the world behind them and half still to traverse, Phileas Fogg and his companions pressed onward, undaunted by the challenges that lay before them, determined to complete their extraordinary journey around the world in eighty days.

events.title: Fix's Pursuit Strategy Revealed
detailed_summary: The narrative poses the question of Fix's location.
It reveals that Fix was, in fact, aboard the 'General Grant'.
Upon arriving in Yokohama, Fix had gone directly to the English consulate, separating temporarily from Fogg.
There, he finally received the arrest warrant, which had trailed him from Bombay via the 'Carnatic'.
Fix was greatly disappointed, realizing the warrant was ineffective now that Fogg was no longer on British soil (Yokohama).
Extradition would now be required.
After a moment of frustration, Fix reasoned that the warrant would be valid again once Fogg reached England.
He concluded Fogg intended to return home, believing he had evaded the police.
Fix resolved to follow Fogg across the Atlantic.
He worried about the dwindling reward money, noting Fogg had already spent over £5,000 on various expenses, but took comfort in the Bank's wealth.
Having decided his course, Fix boarded the 'General Grant'.
He was present when Fogg and Aouda arrived.
To his shock, he recognized Passepartout despite his theatrical costume.
Fix quickly hid in his cabin to prevent a confrontation and relied on the crowded ship to remain unseen by Passepartout.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Where was Fix at that moment?
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He quickly concealed himself in his cabin, to avoid an awkward explanation, and hoped—thanks to the number of passengers—to remain unperceived by Mr. Fogg’s servant.

events.text_segment:
Where was Fix at that moment?
He was actually on board the “General Grant.”
On reaching Yokohama, the detective, leaving Mr. Fogg, whom he expected to meet again during the day, had repaired at once to the English consulate, where he at last found the warrant of arrest. It had followed him from Bombay, and had come by the “Carnatic,” on which steamer he himself was supposed to be. Fix’s disappointment may be imagined when he reflected that the warrant was now useless. Mr. Fogg had left English ground, and it was now necessary to procure his extradition!
“Well,” thought Fix, after a moment of anger, “my warrant is not good here, but it will be in England. The rogue evidently intends to return to his own country, thinking he has thrown the police off his track. Good! I will follow him across the Atlantic. As for the money, heaven grant there may be some left! But the fellow has already spent in travelling, rewards, trials, bail, elephants, and all sorts of charges, more than five thousand pounds. Yet, after all, the Bank is rich!”
His course decided on, he went on board the “General Grant,” and was there when Mr. Fogg and Aouda arrived. To his utter amazement, he recognised Passepartout, despite his theatrical disguise. He quickly concealed himself in his cabin, to avoid an awkward explanation, and hoped—thanks to the number of passengers—to remain unperceived by Mr. Fogg’s servant.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Where was Fix at that moment? He was actually on board the General Grant. On reaching Yokohama, Fix, leaving Mr. Fogg, whom he expected to meet again during the day, had repaired at once to the English consulate, where he at last found the warrant of arrest. It had followed him from Bombay, and had come by the Carnatic, on which steamer he himself was supposed to be. Fix's disappointment may be imagined when he reflected that the warrant was now useless unless Mr. Fogg should return to English ground. In effect, this warrant could only be executed in Great Britain. As soon as Fix realized this, he was overwhelmed with anger. He wished to detain Fogg at Yokohama, and had failed! He considered himself beaten. But, after a moment's reflection, he saw that Fogg was inevitably returning to England, and so would be at the mercy of the warrant. Fix, therefore, resolved to follow the journey round the world. He would not lose sight of Fogg until he had set foot on English soil, where the warrant would be effective. In any case, the detective's business was to follow him, and it was clear that Fogg was not aware of the presence of the warrant, and believed himself safe from pursuit. Fix, therefore, took passage on the General Grant. He was on board when Mr. Fogg and Aouda arrived. To his extreme surprise, he recognized Passepartout, despite his theatrical costume. He quickly concealed himself in his cabin, to avoid an explanation with the servant, and hoped that the crowd on board would prevent Passepartout from seeing him.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: At that moment, Detective Fix was in the bustling port city of Suez, Egypt. He had arrived there ahead of the Mongolia, the steamer carrying Phileas Fogg and his companions, having received word from London about the audacious robbery at the Bank of England. Fix’s orders were clear: to keep a close watch on any suspicious Englishmen passing through the major ports along the route to India, as it was believed the thief would attempt to escape the country by heading east. Fix, diligent and methodical, spent his days at the consulate and the telegraph office, anxiously awaiting further instructions and the arrival of the suspect. He was determined to apprehend the culprit and claim the reward, but he was also frustrated by the lack of a proper warrant, which would allow him to make an arrest. As the Mongolia steamed into the harbor, Fix’s anticipation grew. He scrutinized the passengers disembarking, searching for any sign of nervousness or haste. When he finally laid eyes on Phileas Fogg—a man of calm demeanor and precise habits—Fix’s suspicions were aroused. Fogg’s reserved manner and the unusual nature of his journey seemed to fit the profile of the bank robber. Fix resolved to shadow Fogg closely, hoping to gather enough evidence to justify an arrest. Thus, at that moment, Fix was in Suez, poised at the threshold of a pursuit that would take him around the world, driven by duty and the hope of solving the great mystery.

events.title: Confrontation and Uneasy Alliance Between Passepartout and Fix
detailed_summary: Despite Fix's efforts, he encountered Passepartout directly on the deck later that same day.
Without saying anything, Passepartout immediately attacked Fix.
He grabbed Fix by the throat and delivered a series of punches.
A group of American passengers watched with amusement, placing bets on the fight.
The assault demonstrated the superiority of French boxing technique.
After venting his anger, Passepartout felt relieved.
Fix, somewhat disheveled, stood up and coolly asked Passepartout if he was finished.
Passepartout confirmed he was done for the moment.
Fix requested a private conversation, stating it was in Fogg's interest.
Passepartout, seemingly swayed by Fix's composure, followed him to a secluded spot.
Fix acknowledged the beating, stating he had anticipated it.
He declared a shift in his strategy: previously Fogg's adversary, he was now supporting Fogg's journey.
Passepartout questioned if Fix now believed Fogg was innocent.
Fix coldly stated he still considered Fogg a criminal, urging Passepartout to listen.
He explained his past actions (using priests, intoxicating Passepartout, causing delays) were aimed at detaining Fogg on British territory until the warrant arrived.
Passepartout listened intently, fists clenched.
Fix continued, explaining that since Fogg seemed headed back to England, Fix's interest now lay in facilitating Fogg's return.
He argued their interests aligned, as only in England could Passepartout learn the truth about his master.
Passepartout carefully considered Fix's words and believed he was being sincere.
Fix proposed friendship.
Passepartout rejected friendship but agreed to an alliance, warning Fix against any betrayal.
Fix calmly accepted the terms.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: On that very day, however, he met Passepartout face to face on the forward deck.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Agreed,” said the detective quietly.

events.text_segment:
On that very day, however, he met Passepartout face to face on the forward deck. The latter, without a word, made a rush for him, grasped him by the throat, and, much to the amusement of a group of Americans, who immediately began to bet on him, administered to the detective a perfect volley of blows, which proved the great superiority of French over English pugilistic skill.
When Passepartout had finished, he found himself relieved and comforted. Fix got up in a somewhat rumpled condition, and, looking at his adversary, coldly said, “Have you done?”
“For this time—yes.”
“Then let me have a word with you.”
“But I—”
“In your master’s interests.”
Passepartout seemed to be vanquished by Fix’s coolness, for he quietly followed him, and they sat down aside from the rest of the passengers.
“You have given me a thrashing,” said Fix. “Good, I expected it. Now, listen to me. Up to this time I have been Mr. Fogg’s adversary. I am now in his game.”
“Aha!” cried Passepartout; “you are convinced he is an honest man?”
“No,” replied Fix coldly, “I think him a rascal. Sh! don’t budge, and let me speak. As long as Mr. Fogg was on English ground, it was for my interest to detain him there until my warrant of arrest arrived. I did everything I could to keep him back. I sent the Bombay priests after him, I got you intoxicated at Hong Kong, I separated you from him, and I made him miss the Yokohama steamer.”
Passepartout listened, with closed fists.
“Now,” resumed Fix, “Mr. Fogg seems to be going back to England. Well, I will follow him there. But hereafter I will do as much to keep obstacles out of his way as I have done up to this time to put them in his path. I’ve changed my game, you see, and simply because it was for my interest to change it. Your interest is the same as mine; for it is only in England that you will ascertain whether you are in the service of a criminal or an honest man.”
Passepartout listened very attentively to Fix, and was convinced that he spoke with entire good faith.
“Are we friends?” asked the detective.
“Friends?—no,” replied Passepartout; “but allies, perhaps. At the least sign of treason, however, I’ll twist your neck for you.”
“Agreed,” said the detective quietly.
