events.title: Buffalo Herd Causes Major Delay
detailed_summary: Around 9:00 AM, the train crossed into Nevada via the Carson Valley, continuing its northeast trajectory.
At noon, it arrived in Reno, pausing for a twenty-minute breakfast stop.
From Reno, the railway followed the Humboldt River north for some distance before turning eastward, staying near the river until reaching the Humboldt Range at Nevada's eastern edge.
After breakfast, Mr. Fogg and his companions returned to their seats, observing the changing scenery of prairies, distant mountains, and streams.
Occasionally, immense herds of buffalo appeared in the distance like moving barriers.
These vast herds frequently posed significant obstacles to trains, sometimes halting them for hours as thousands of animals crossed the tracks in dense formations.
Around midday, the train encountered such an obstacle: a massive herd of ten to twelve thousand buffalo blocking the way.
The locomotive reduced speed and attempted to nudge the animals aside with its cow-catcher, but the sheer number of buffalo made this impossible.
The animals proceeded calmly, occasionally letting out loud bellows, their movement seemingly unstoppable like a 'torrent of living flesh'.
Passengers observed this unusual sight from the train's platforms.
Phileas Fogg, despite having the most pressing schedule, remained seated, calmly and philosophically awaiting the herd's passage.
Passepartout grew increasingly agitated by the delay, expressing a desire to use his revolvers on the animals.
He exclaimed about the absurdity of mere cattle halting trains and wondered aloud if Fogg had factored such an event into his plans.
He also criticized the train's engineer for not attempting to force a passage through the herd.

The engineer, however, acted prudently by not confronting the buffalo, understanding that while the initial impact might clear some animals, the locomotive would quickly be overwhelmed, leading to derailment and immobilization.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The train entered the State of Nevada through the Carson Valley about nine o’clock, going always northeasterly; and at midday reached Reno, where there was a delay of twenty minutes for breakfast.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He would have crushed the first buffaloes, no doubt, with the cow-catcher; but the locomotive, however powerful, would soon have been checked, the train would inevitably have been thrown off the track, and would then have been helpless.

events.text_segment:
The train entered the State of Nevada through the Carson Valley about nine o’clock, going always northeasterly; and at midday reached Reno, where there was a delay of twenty minutes for breakfast.
From this point the road, running along Humboldt River, passed northward for several miles by its banks; then it turned eastward, and kept by the river until it reached the Humboldt Range, nearly at the extreme eastern limit of Nevada.
Having breakfasted, Mr. Fogg and his companions resumed their places in the car, and observed the varied landscape which unfolded itself as they passed along the vast prairies, the mountains lining the horizon, and the creeks, with their frothy, foaming streams. Sometimes a great herd of buffaloes, massing together in the distance, seemed like a moveable dam. These innumerable multitudes of ruminating beasts often form an insurmountable obstacle to the passage of the trains; thousands of them have been seen passing over the track for hours together, in compact ranks. The locomotive is then forced to stop and wait till the road is once more clear.
This happened, indeed, to the train in which Mr. Fogg was travelling. About twelve o’clock a troop of ten or twelve thousand head of buffalo encumbered the track. The locomotive, slackening its speed, tried to clear the way with its cow-catcher; but the mass of animals was too great. The buffaloes marched along with a tranquil gait, uttering now and then deafening bellowings. There was no use of interrupting them, for, having taken a particular direction, nothing can moderate and change their course; it is a torrent of living flesh which no dam could contain.
The travellers gazed on this curious spectacle from the platforms; but Phileas Fogg, who had the most reason of all to be in a hurry, remained in his seat, and waited philosophically until it should please the buffaloes to get out of the way.
Passepartout was furious at the delay they occasioned, and longed to discharge his arsenal of revolvers upon them.
“What a country!” cried he. “Mere cattle stop the trains, and go by in a procession, just as if they were not impeding travel! Parbleu! I should like to know if Mr. Fogg foresaw this mishap in his programme! And here’s an engineer who doesn’t dare to run the locomotive into this herd of beasts!”
The engineer did not try to overcome the obstacle, and he was wise. He would have crushed the first buffaloes, no doubt, with the cow-catcher; but the locomotive, however powerful, would soon have been checked, the train would inevitably have been thrown off the track, and would then have been helpless.

It was a torrent of living flesh which no human force could arrest.

The travelers gazed on this curious spectacle from the platforms. Phileas Fogg, who had the most reason of all to be in a hurry, remained quietly seated, waiting philosophically until it should please these formidable travelers to get out of the way. Passepartout was furious at the delay they occasioned, and longed to discharge his arsenal of revolvers upon them. "What a country!" he cried. "Mere cattle stop the trains, and go by, no one knows how long! Pshaw! I should like to know if Mr. Fogg foresaw this mishap in his programme. And here's an engineer who doesn't dare to run the locomotive into this herd of beasts!"

The engineer did not attempt to force a passage through, and he was wise. He would have crushed the first buffaloes, no doubt, with the cow-catcher; but the locomotive, however powerful, would soon have been checked, the train would have been thrown off the track, and would then have been helpless.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
During this halt, the passengers alighted to stretch their legs and partake of a hasty meal at the station restaurant. Phileas Fogg, ever punctual and methodical, made use of the time to procure a cup of tea and a few slices of toast, while Passepartout, his faithful servant, eagerly sampled the local fare, his curiosity piqued by the unfamiliar dishes. Fix, the detective, kept a watchful eye on the pair, still determined to apprehend Fogg at the earliest opportunity.

The town of Reno, though small, bustled with activity, its streets alive with miners, traders, and travelers bound for the goldfields or the Pacific coast. The air was crisp, and the distant mountains shimmered under the midday sun. The train’s whistle soon summoned the passengers back, and with a final clang of the bell, the locomotive resumed its journey, steaming eastward across the arid plains.

As the train sped on, the landscape changed gradually. The fertile valleys gave way to stretches of sagebrush and rocky outcrops, the vastness of the American West unfolding before the travelers’ eyes. Passepartout, gazing out the window, marveled at the endless horizon and the occasional herds of wild mustangs galloping in the distance. He remarked to his master on the immensity of the country, to which Fogg replied with his usual composure, noting the efficiency of the American railways and the importance of maintaining their schedule.

The afternoon passed uneventfully, save for the occasional stop at remote stations where a few passengers disembarked or boarded. At one such stop, a group of Native Americans could be seen observing the train from a distance, their presence a reminder of the untamed nature of the land through which they traveled. The conductor, making his rounds, assured the passengers that the journey through Nevada was generally safe, though tales of train robberies and attacks were not uncommon in these parts.

As evening approached, the train neared the border of Utah, the sun casting long shadows across the desert. The passengers settled in for the night, some conversing quietly, others lost in thought or lulled to sleep by the rhythmic clatter of the wheels. Fogg, ever vigilant, consulted his itinerary and calculated their progress, satisfied that, barring unforeseen delays, they remained on course to complete their journey around the world in eighty days.

events.title: Resuming the Journey into Utah
detailed_summary: The most sensible approach was to wait for the obstruction to clear and then make up the lost time by increasing the train's speed.
The buffalo procession continued for three full hours.
The railway track was finally clear as night began to fall.
The last of the buffalo herd crossed the rails just as the front ranks disappeared over the southern horizon.
At 8:00 PM, the train navigated through the narrow passages of the Humboldt Range.
By 9:30 PM, it had entered the territory of Utah, noted as the area of the Great Salt Lake and the distinctive Mormon settlement.

chapters.chapter_title: CHAPTER XXVII. IN WHICH PASSEPARTOUT UNDERGOES, AT A SPEED OF TWENTY MILES AN HOUR, A COURSE OF MORMON HISTORY

events.title: Passepartout Encounters a Mormon Missionary
detailed_summary: The train altered course, heading towards the Great Salt Lake.
Around 9 AM, Passepartout went onto the platform for fresh air, noting the cold, grey weather and the sun appearing as a large golden ring through the mist.
He was distracted from estimating the sun's value by the appearance of a peculiar man.
This man, who boarded at Elko, was tall, dark, and dressed entirely in black, resembling a clergyman.
He moved through the train, posting handwritten notices on each car door.
Passepartout read a notice announcing a lecture on Mormonism by Elder William Hitch in car No. 117.
The notice invited those interested in learning about the 'Latter Day Saints' to attend.
Intrigued and knowing little about Mormonism beyond polygamy, Passepartout decided he would go.

events.text_segment:
During the night of the 5th of December, the train ran south-easterly for about fifty miles; then rose an equal distance in a north-easterly direction, towards the Great Salt Lake.
Passepartout, about nine o’clock, went out upon the platform to take the air. The weather was cold, the heavens grey, but it was not snowing. The sun’s disc, enlarged by the mist, seemed an enormous ring of gold, and Passepartout was amusing himself by calculating its value in pounds sterling, when he was diverted from this interesting study by a strange-looking personage who made his appearance on the platform.
This personage, who had taken the train at Elko, was tall and dark, with black moustache, black stockings, a black silk hat, a black waistcoat, black trousers, a white cravat, and dogskin gloves. He might have been taken for a clergyman. He went from one end of the train to the other, and affixed to the door of each car a notice written in manuscript.
Passepartout approached and read one of these notices, which stated that Elder William Hitch, Mormon missionary, taking advantage of his presence on train No. 48, would deliver a lecture on Mormonism in car No. 117, from eleven to twelve o’clock; and that he invited all who were desirous of being instructed concerning the mysteries of the religion of the “Latter Day Saints” to attend.
“I’ll go,” said Passepartout to himself. He knew nothing of Mormonism except the custom of polygamy, which is its foundation.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
During the night of the 5th of December, the train ran south-easterly for about fifty miles; then rose an equal distance in a north-easterly direction, towards the Great Salt Lake. From time to time, passengers could catch glimpses of the vast, white expanse of the desert, broken here and there by clusters of dark pines, and the train, as it sped along, seemed to fly over a sea of snow, with the mountains in the distance looming like spectral islands. At nine o’clock in the morning, Passepartout, braving the cold, stepped out upon the platform to breathe the fresh air. The weather was cold and grey; great clouds, like masses of smoke, hung low in the sky, and through the mist the sun appeared as a large golden ring. Passepartout, whose wits were always active, was just then calculating what this sun, which he saw for the first time on American territory, might be worth, when his attention was drawn to a rather singular personage who had just made his appearance on the platform.

This person, who had come on board at Elko, was tall, dark, with black moustache, black stockings, black hat, black coat, black cravat, and white cravat pin; in short, he was dressed in black from head to foot, and looked like a clergyman. He moved from one car to another, affixing to the doors a notice written in manuscript. Passepartout approached and read one of these notices. It ran as follows:

"ELDER WILLIAM HITCH, Mormon missionary, will deliver a lecture on Mormonism, in car No. 117, from eleven to twelve o’clock. All who are desirous of being instructed concerning the mysteries of the Latter Day Saints are invited to attend."

"I’ll go," said Passepartout to himself. He knew nothing of Mormonism but the custom of polygamy, which is its foundation. The news of the lecture, therefore, interested him greatly.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text:
During the night of the 5th of December, the train ran south-easterly for about fifty miles; then rose an equal distance in a north-easterly direction, towards the Great Salt Lake. At seven o’clock in the morning, the travellers got out to observe the picturesque beauties of the Great Salt Lake, the vastest lake in the United States, after Superior. Salt Lake, about seventy miles long and thirty-five wide, is situated three miles eight hundred feet above the sea. Quite different from Lake Superior, whose fresh waters make it the largest in the world, Salt Lake contains considerable salt, and its specific gravity is such that a man cannot sink in it. The surrounding country is of a wild, desolate aspect. Huge blocks of rock, piled one upon another, lie on the banks, and the mountains, covered with snow, rise grandly from the midst of the waters to an immense height. The air was pure, and the sun, which was now shining brightly, brought out the singular character of the scenery, and the travellers gazed with admiration upon the strange spectacle presented by this American Dead Sea.

Passepartout, on the platform, found the weather cold, but not snowy. The sun’s disk, enlarged by the mist, seemed an enormous ring of gold, and Passepartout was amusing himself by calculating its value in pounds sterling, when he was diverted from this interesting study by a strange-looking person who made his appearance on the platform. This person, who had taken the train at Elko, was tall and dark, with black moustache, black stockings, black silk hat, black waistcoat, black trousers, white cravat, and dogskin gloves. He might have been taken for a clergyman. He went from one end of the train to the other, and affixed to the doors of the cars some notices written with a large hand.

Passepartout approached and read one of these notices. It stated that a meeting would be held that day, at eleven o’clock, in car No. 48, under the auspices of the Elder William Hitch, missionary, who would deliver a lecture on Mormonism, and invite all who were desirous of being instructed in the mysteries of the religion of the "Latter Day Saints" to attend. Passepartout, who only knew of the Mormons as a sect who practised polygamy, was curious to learn more. He decided to go.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: During the night of the 5th of December, the train ran south-easterly for about fifty miles; then rose an equal distance in a north-easterly direction, towards the Great Salt Lake. At Ogden, the branch line for Salt Lake City stopped, and the cars, attached to the main train, continued their journey eastward over the Union Pacific road. From this point, the road passed through a country of remarkable character. The Great Salt Lake, about which so many marvellous legends have been told, spread out its vast sheet of water, sparkling in the sun, and surrounded by picturesque mountains. The train skirted the lake for several miles, and Passepartout could see, on its banks, the scattered dwellings of the Mormons, who, in spite of the world’s ridicule, have founded a flourishing city in this desolate region. The train entered the territory of Utah, the land of the Mormons, and soon reached Ogden, where a halt of twenty minutes was made. Passepartout, curious to see the celebrated city, left the train, and strolled through the streets. He saw the temple, the tabernacle, and the houses of the Mormon dignitaries, but he did not meet any of the prophet’s wives, who, it was said, numbered more than two hundred. He returned to the station, and the train resumed its journey across the vast plains of the Far West.

events.title: Elder Hitch's Fiery Lecture Begins
detailed_summary: Word of the lecture circulated among the train's approximately 100 passengers.
About thirty passengers gathered in car No. 117 for the lecture.
Passepartout secured a seat near the front.
Mr. Fogg and Fix chose not to attend the lecture.
Elder William Hitch began speaking at the scheduled time, his voice immediately irritated.
He proclaimed Joe and Hiram Smith as martyrs and suggested Brigham Young would also become one due to government persecution, challenging anyone to disagree.
No one contradicted him; his agitated tone seemed unusual for his calm appearance, likely stemming from the Mormons' recent struggles with the US government.

The narrative explains the government's recent subjugation of Utah and imprisonment of Brigham Young, leading to increased verbal resistance from Mormons like Elder Hitch, who sought converts on trains.

Using a loud voice and animated gestures, the Elder recounted Mormon history, starting from biblical times and the supposed discovery and translation of ancient religious texts by Joseph Smith, Jr. in 1825.
He described a divine messenger appearing to Smith in a forest with the sacred annals.
Some audience members lost interest and departed during this historical account.

Undeterred, Elder Hitch continued, describing the founding of the church, its international growth, the establishment of a colony and temple in Ohio, and Smith's venture into banking, including acquiring an ancient papyrus.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The news quickly spread through the train, which contained about one hundred passengers, thirty of whom, at most, attracted by the notice, ensconced themselves in car No. 117.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Several of the audience, not being much interested in the missionary’s narrative, here left the car; but Elder Hitch, continuing his lecture, related how Smith, junior, with his father, two brothers, and a few disciples, founded the church of the “Latter Day Saints,” which, adopted not only in America, but in England, Norway and Sweden, and Germany, counts many artisans, as well as men engaged in the liberal professions, among its members; how a colony was established in Ohio, a temple erected there at a cost of two hundred thousand dollars, and a town built at Kirkland; how Smith became an enterprising banker, and received from a simple mummy showman a papyrus scroll written by Abraham and several famous Egyptians.

events.text_segment:
The news quickly spread through the train, which contained about one hundred passengers, thirty of whom, at most, attracted by the notice, ensconced themselves in car No. 117. Passepartout took one of the front seats. Neither Mr. Fogg nor Fix cared to attend.
At the appointed hour Elder William Hitch rose, and, in an irritated voice, as if he had already been contradicted, said, “I tell you that Joe Smith is a martyr, that his brother Hiram is a martyr, and that the persecutions of the United States Government against the prophets will also make a martyr of Brigham Young. Who dares to say the contrary?”
No one ventured to gainsay the missionary, whose excited tone contrasted curiously with his naturally calm visage. No doubt his anger arose from the hardships to which the Mormons were actually subjected. The government had just succeeded, with some difficulty, in reducing these independent fanatics to its rule. It had made itself master of Utah, and subjected that territory to the laws of the Union, after imprisoning Brigham Young on a charge of rebellion and polygamy. The disciples of the prophet had since redoubled their efforts, and resisted, by words at least, the authority of Congress. Elder Hitch, as is seen, was trying to make proselytes on the very railway trains.
Then, emphasising his words with his loud voice and frequent gestures, he related the history of the Mormons from Biblical times: how that, in Israel, a Mormon prophet of the tribe of Joseph published the annals of the new religion, and bequeathed them to his son Mormon; how, many centuries later, a translation of this precious book, which was written in Egyptian, was made by Joseph Smith, junior, a Vermont farmer, who revealed himself as a mystical prophet in 1825; and how, in short, the celestial messenger appeared to him in an illuminated forest, and gave him the annals of the Lord.
Several of the audience, not being much interested in the missionary’s narrative, here left the car; but Elder Hitch, continuing his lecture, related how Smith, junior, with his father, two brothers, and a few disciples, founded the church of the “Latter Day Saints,” which, adopted not only in America, but in England, Norway and Sweden, and Germany, counts many artisans, as well as men engaged in the liberal professions, among its members; how a colony was established in Ohio, a temple erected there at a cost of two hundred thousand dollars, and a town built at Kirkland; how Smith became an enterprising banker, and received from a simple mummy showman a papyrus scroll written by Abraham and several famous Egyptians.

**Generated Literary Segment:**

The news quickly spread through the train, which contained about one hundred passengers, thirty of whom, at most, attracted by the notice, ensconced themselves in car No. 117. Passepartout, ever curious, managed to secure a seat near the front, his eyes wide with anticipation. Mr. Fogg and Detective Fix, less interested in religious discourses, remained in their compartment, leaving Passepartout to his own devices.

At the appointed hour, Elder William Hitch, a tall, thin man with a calm countenance but a voice that betrayed a certain irritation, rose to address the assembly. He began by extolling the virtues and sufferings of the Mormon prophets, declaring with fervor that Joseph and Hiram Smith had died as martyrs, and that Brigham Young, now imprisoned by the government, would likely share their fate. His words, delivered with a challenging glance, seemed to invite contradiction, but none was forthcoming; the passengers, perhaps out of politeness or indifference, remained silent.

The Elder’s agitation, so at odds with his serene appearance, was perhaps a reflection of the recent troubles that had befallen the Mormon community. The government’s heavy hand had subdued Utah, and Brigham Young’s incarceration had only served to inflame the zeal of his followers. Elder Hitch, seizing the opportunity, sought to win converts even here, on the iron road that spanned the continent.

With a voice that rose above the clatter of the wheels, he launched into a history of the faith, tracing its origins to biblical times. He recounted how, in 1825, Joseph Smith, Jr., guided by a divine messenger in a secluded forest, had discovered the sacred annals inscribed on golden plates. Some listeners, their curiosity waning, slipped quietly from the car as the narrative grew more elaborate.

Undeterred, Elder Hitch pressed on, describing the founding of the church, its rapid spread across continents, the establishment of a colony and a magnificent temple in Ohio, and the ill-fated banking venture that followed. He spoke, too, of the mysterious papyrus acquired by Smith, his gestures growing ever more animated as he sought to hold the attention of his dwindling audience.

---

**End of Segment**

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The car was a long, well-lighted vehicle, furnished with comfortable seats and provided with the usual arrangements for heating. The passengers, curious and expectant, took their places, some with newspapers in hand, others chatting in low tones about the singular event that had just been announced. The conductor, a tall man with a grave face, passed through the car, glancing at the tickets and making sure that all was in order. 

Among the group was a variety of people: a few businessmen, a family with two children, a pair of elderly ladies, and several young men who seemed to be traveling for pleasure. The air was filled with a subdued excitement, for it was not every day that such an incident occurred on the Pacific Railroad. 

At the appointed hour, a man entered the car. He was of medium height, with a calm and resolute expression, and he carried himself with an air of quiet authority. This was Mr. Phileas Fogg, the English gentleman whose wager had set in motion the extraordinary journey around the world. He was accompanied by his faithful servant, Passepartout, who looked about him with a mixture of curiosity and apprehension. 

Mr. Fogg took a seat near the center of the car, while Passepartout settled himself beside him, glancing nervously at the other passengers. The conductor, after a brief consultation with the engineer, addressed the assembly. 

"Ladies and gentlemen," he began, "you have been invited here to witness a most unusual occurrence. As you are aware, the train is about to cross a bridge of somewhat doubtful solidity. It is the opinion of the engineers that the bridge will not bear the weight of the train if it passes over at the usual speed. However, it has been decided to attempt the crossing at full speed, in the hope that the momentum will carry us safely to the other side."

A murmur ran through the car. Some of the passengers exchanged anxious glances, while others tried to appear unconcerned. Mr. Fogg remained impassive, his gaze fixed on the window. Passepartout, however, could not conceal his uneasiness.

The conductor continued, "I must ask you all to remain seated and to keep calm. The crossing will be made in a few moments."

The train began to accelerate, the wheels clattering more rapidly over the rails. The passengers held their breath as the engine thundered onto the bridge, the car swaying and vibrating with the speed. For a few seconds, it seemed as if the whole structure would give way beneath them. Then, with a final jolt, the train reached solid ground on the other side. A cheer broke out among the passengers, and even Mr. Fogg allowed himself a faint smile.

events.title: Lecture Audience Dwindles as Smith's Story Continues
detailed_summary: The lecture grew tedious, causing the audience to shrink to twenty people.
The Elder, unaffected by the departures, recounted Joseph Smith's bankruptcy in 1837 and subsequent tarring and feathering by creditors.
He described Smith's comeback years later, leading a large community in Independence, Missouri, before being driven out and heading west.
The audience dwindled further to only ten listeners, including Passepartout, who remained attentive.
Passepartout learned about Smith's later life: his return after persecutions, founding the large Nauvoo community in Illinois in 1839 where he held multiple leadership roles.
He heard about Smith's 1843 presidential candidacy.
Finally, the Elder recounted Smith's capture in Carthage, imprisonment, and assassination by masked attackers.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The Elder’s story became somewhat wearisome, and his audience grew gradually less, until it was reduced to twenty passengers.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Thus he learned that, after long persecutions, Smith reappeared in Illinois, and in 1839 founded a community at Nauvoo, on the Mississippi, numbering twenty-five thousand souls, of which he became mayor, chief justice, and general-in-chief; that he announced himself, in 1843, as a candidate for the Presidency of the United States; and that finally, being drawn into ambuscade at Carthage, he was thrown into prison, and assassinated by a band of men disguised in masks.

events.text_segment:
The Elder’s story became somewhat wearisome, and his audience grew gradually less, until it was reduced to twenty passengers. But this did not disconcert the enthusiast, who proceeded with the story of Joseph Smith’s bankruptcy in 1837, and how his ruined creditors gave him a coat of tar and feathers; his reappearance some years afterwards, more honourable and honoured than ever, at Independence, Missouri, the chief of a flourishing colony of three thousand disciples, and his pursuit thence by outraged Gentiles, and retirement into the Far West.
Ten hearers only were now left, among them honest Passepartout, who was listening with all his ears. Thus he learned that, after long persecutions, Smith reappeared in Illinois, and in 1839 founded a community at Nauvoo, on the Mississippi, numbering twenty-five thousand souls, of which he became mayor, chief justice, and general-in-chief; that he announced himself, in 1843, as a candidate for the Presidency of the United States; and that finally, being drawn into ambuscade at Carthage, he was thrown into prison, and assassinated by a band of men disguised in masks.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
The Elder’s story became somewhat wearisome, and his audience grew gradually less, until it was reduced to twenty passengers. But this did not disconcert the worthy apostle, who proceeded with the history of Mormonism, recounting with his usual ardour that, after a bankruptcy in 1837, the prophet Joseph Smith, a bankrupt, was tarred and feathered in Ohio by his creditors. He became, however, a man of influence, and, as a visionary, founded a sect of which he was both the head and the pontiff.

His disciples, after increasing to the number of three thousand, were obliged to leave Missouri, whither they had gone, on account of their religious ideas. Then, after long persecutions, Smith reappeared in Illinois, and, in 1839, founded a community at Nauvoo, on the Mississippi, numbering twenty-five thousand souls, of which he became mayor, chief justice, and general-in-chief. He was, besides, the founder of a sect, and a candidate for the presidency of the United States.

But, in 1844, he was drawn into ambuscade at Carthage, betrayed by his followers, and fell under the blows of masked assassins. It was then that his brother, the inspired Brigham Young, became his successor and, after a long period of persecution, led the Mormons to the valley of the Great Salt Lake, where, in the midst of that fertile region, they founded the city of Salt Lake, the capital of Utah.

events.title: Passepartout Alone Hears Lecture's End and Refuses Conversion
detailed_summary: Eventually, only Passepartout remained in the audience.
The Elder addressed Passepartout directly, shifting focus to Brigham Young's succession after Smith's death.
He described Young leading the Mormons from Nauvoo to the Great Salt Lake.
He highlighted the colony's success in that fertile region along the emigrant trail, attributing its growth to the practice of polygamy.
The Elder passionately denounced the US government's actions against them, citing congressional jealousy, military intervention in Utah, and the imprisonment of Brigham Young as unjust.
He declared the Mormons would never yield to force, having been driven from multiple states, and would find a new independent territory.
Fixing his gaze upon Passepartout, the Elder directly asked if he, 'my brother,' would join them under their flag.
Passepartout bravely answered 'No!' and promptly left the car, leaving the Elder alone.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Passepartout was now the only person left in the car, and the Elder, looking him full in the face, reminded him that, two years after the assassination of Joseph Smith, the inspired prophet, Brigham Young, his successor, left Nauvoo for the banks of the Great Salt Lake, where, in the midst of that fertile region, directly on the route of the emigrants who crossed Utah on their way to California, the new colony, thanks to the polygamy practised by the Mormons, had flourished beyond expectations.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “No!” replied Passepartout courageously, in his turn retiring from the car, and leaving the Elder to preach to vacancy.

events.text_segment:
Passepartout was now the only person left in the car, and the Elder, looking him full in the face, reminded him that, two years after the assassination of Joseph Smith, the inspired prophet, Brigham Young, his successor, left Nauvoo for the banks of the Great Salt Lake, where, in the midst of that fertile region, directly on the route of the emigrants who crossed Utah on their way to California, the new colony, thanks to the polygamy practised by the Mormons, had flourished beyond expectations.
“And this,” added Elder William Hitch, “this is why the jealousy of Congress has been aroused against us! Why have the soldiers of the Union invaded the soil of Utah? Why has Brigham Young, our chief, been imprisoned, in contempt of all justice? Shall we yield to force? Never! Driven from Vermont, driven from Illinois, driven from Ohio, driven from Missouri, driven from Utah, we shall yet find some independent territory on which to plant our tents. And you, my brother,” continued the Elder, fixing his angry eyes upon his single auditor, “will you not plant yours there, too, under the shadow of our flag?”
“No!” replied Passepartout courageously, in his turn retiring from the car, and leaving the Elder to preach to vacancy.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: He added that the Congress of the United States had not dared to pass laws to check the advance of this bold sect; that the soldiers of the Union had in vain tried to reduce the faithful to obedience. He related how, after a long succession of injustices and persecutions, the Mormons had finally been obliged to fly from Illinois, to seek a refuge on the borders of the desert. He dwelt upon the courage with which Brigham Young, the new Moses, had led his people across the deserts to the Promised Land, and how, under the prophet's inspired guidance, they had founded, upon the banks of the Great Salt Lake, a city and a State, which had flourished in spite of the most extraordinary difficulties. He declared that, in spite of the army sent against them by the government, their prophet had not hesitated to resist, even to the point of imprisonment, and that the Mormons, driven from Vermont, from New York, from Ohio, from Missouri, from Illinois, would never yield to force; that they would only yield to justice, and that they claimed their independence. These words, pronounced with a vehemence which could not be mistaken, excited a very lively emotion in Passepartout, who could not refrain from asking if such a story was true. "All true," replied the Elder; "and the proof is in this train, which is taking you to the land of the Saints. Will you, my brother, enter into the bosom of our Church?" "No!" replied Passepartout courageously, in his turn retiring from the car, and leaving the Elder to preach to vacancy.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text:
Passepartout was now the only person left in the car, and the Elder, looking him full in the face, reminded him that, two years after the assassination of Joseph Smith, the inspired prophet, Brigham Young, his successor, left Nauvoo for the banks of the Great Salt Lake, where, in the midst of that fertile region, directly on the route of the emigrants who crossed Utah on their way to California, the new colony, thanks to the polygamy practised by the Mormons, had flourished beyond expectations. 

He dwelt upon the number of the adherents, and the zeal with which they defended, themselves, the audacity with which they had braved the American government, and the terrible war which had resulted. He explained how Congress had not as yet dared to pass laws against polygamy, and how the Mormon colony had spread in spite of the United States army, and the jealousy of the Congress. He related the incidents of the war, and the unjust imprisonment of Brigham Young, exposing the pretended crimes of which he was accused. He added that the Mormons, after being driven from Vermont, from New York, from Ohio, from Missouri, from Illinois, had at last found a refuge on the shores of the Great Salt Lake, and that, if they were again driven out, they would yet find an independent territory to plant their tent in. 

Then, with his fiery eyes fixed on his single auditor, and raising his voice, as if to seek a recruit, he said: "And you, sir, will you not plant yours under the shadow of our flag?" "No!" replied Passepartout, courageously, in his turn retiring from the car, and leaving the Elder to preach to vacancy.

events.title: Arrival at Great Salt Lake and Description of Region
detailed_summary: While the lecture occurred, the train continued its journey.
Around 12:30 PM, the train arrived at the edge of the Great Salt Lake.
Passengers could view the large inland sea, also known as the Dead Sea, fed by an 'American Jordan'.
The lake was described as picturesque, surrounded by salt-encrusted cliffs, having shrunk over time, increasing its depth.
Specific details about the lake's dimensions (70 miles long, 35 wide) and high elevation (3,800 feet) were provided.
Its high salt content (specific weight 1,170) was noted, making it inhospitable to fish, unlike Lake Asphaltite.
The surrounding land was described as well-cultivated by Mormon farmers, anticipating features like ranches, crop fields, prairies, and various plants that would be visible in warmer months.
Currently, however, a light layer of snow covered the ground.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: During the lecture the train had been making good progress, and towards half-past twelve it reached the northwest border of the Great Salt Lake.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Now the ground was covered with a thin powdering of snow.

events.text_segment:
During the lecture the train had been making good progress, and towards half-past twelve it reached the northwest border of the Great Salt Lake. Thence the passengers could observe the vast extent of this interior sea, which is also called the Dead Sea, and into which flows an American Jordan. It is a picturesque expanse, framed in lofty crags in large strata, encrusted with white salt—a superb sheet of water, which was formerly of larger extent than now, its shores having encroached with the lapse of time, and thus at once reduced its breadth and increased its depth.
The Salt Lake, seventy miles long and thirty-five wide, is situated three miles eight hundred feet above the sea. Quite different from Lake Asphaltite, whose depression is twelve hundred feet below the sea, it contains considerable salt, and one quarter of the weight of its water is solid matter, its specific weight being 1,170, and, after being distilled, 1,000. Fishes are, of course, unable to live in it, and those which descend through the Jordan, the Weber, and other streams soon perish.
The country around the lake was well cultivated, for the Mormons are mostly farmers; while ranches and pens for domesticated animals, fields of wheat, corn, and other cereals, luxuriant prairies, hedges of wild rose, clumps of acacias and milk-wort, would have been seen six months later. Now the ground was covered with a thin powdering of snow.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: During the lecture the train had been making good progress, and towards half-past twelve it reached the northwest border of the Great Salt Lake. From this point the railway left the territory of Utah, and entered that of the State of Nevada. The track followed for a little distance the windings of the lake, on the northern shore. The passengers could see from the windows the vast extent of this inland sea, which is also called the Dead Sea, and into which flows an American Jordan. It is a picturesque sheet of water, framed in lofty crags, encrusted with white salt, a superb lake, which formerly occupied a much larger space; but, having receded from its old borders, has now a length of seventy miles, with an average width of thirty-five. Its surface is situated 3,800 feet above the level of the sea. Very different from Lake Asphaltite, whose depression is 1,200 feet below the sea, it contains considerable salt, and its specific weight is 1,170, water being 1,000. Fish cannot live in it. The surrounding country is well cultivated, for the Mormons are mostly farmers, while ranches, pens for domesticated animals, fields of wheat, corn, and other cereals, luxuriant prairies, orchards, and forests succeed each other as far as the eye can reach. But the scene was then white with snow, and the train passed on at full speed, without stopping at Ogden, where it arrived at two o'clock.

Its banks are well cultivated, for the Mormons are mostly farmers; there were fields of wheat, corn, and other cereals, and, in the spring, hedges of wild rose, clumps of acacias, and milk-wort would have been seen; but the ground was then covered with a thin layer of snow.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_2.text: During the lecture the train had been making good progress, and towards half-past twelve it reached the northwest border of the Great Salt Lake. From this point could be seen the vast extent of the lake, the Dead Sea of the Americans, into which flows an American Jordan. It is a picturesque sheet of water, framed in lofty crags, encrusted with white salt, a superb lake, which formerly occupied a much larger space; but its shores have encroached, and it has grown narrower and deeper. Its length is now about seventy miles, with an average breadth of thirty-five. Its surface is three thousand eight hundred feet above the level of the sea. Its waters contain more salt than the sea; one quarter of the weight of the water is solid matter. Its specific weight is 1,170, and after being distilled, one thousand parts of this water leave one hundred and seventy parts of residue. Fish are not found in this lake. Those which descend through the Jordan, the Weber, and other streams perish as soon as they touch its waters. Around the lake the country is well cultivated, for the Mormons are mostly farmers; luxuriant prairies, fields of wheat, maize, and other cereals, hedges of wild rose, clumps of acacias and milk-wort would have been seen six months later, but then the ground was covered with a thin layer of snow.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The vast expanse of water stretched out to the left of the train, its surface shimmering under the midday sun. The passengers, many of whom had never seen such a spectacle, pressed their faces to the windows, eager to catch a glimpse of the famous lake. Phileas Fogg, however, remained as composed as ever, his gaze fixed on the pages of his guidebook. Passepartout, on the other hand, could not contain his excitement. He darted from one side of the carriage to the other, exclaiming at the changing scenery and pointing out the distant mountains that framed the horizon.

The train skirted the edge of the lake, its iron wheels clattering rhythmically over the rails. Occasionally, the engineer sounded the whistle, sending flocks of waterfowl into the air. The landscape was stark and beautiful, with salt-encrusted shores gleaming white against the blue water. The air was dry and crisp, carrying with it the faint tang of salt.

As they continued their journey, the passengers fell into conversation about the wonders of the American West. Stories were exchanged of pioneers and prospectors, of the hardships endured and the fortunes made. Even Mr. Fogg looked up from his book to listen, his interest piqued by the tales of adventure and discovery that had shaped this vast and untamed land.

events.title: Excursion to Salt Lake City
detailed_summary: The train arrived at Ogden at 2 PM for a six-hour stop.
Mr. Fogg, Passepartout, and Fix took a branch line to visit Salt Lake City for two hours.
The city was characterized as typically American in its grid-like layout, invoking Victor Hugo's description of right-angled sobriety.
The narrator commented on the Anglo-Saxon preference for symmetry evident in the city's design.
At 3 PM, the travelers walked through the town, located between the Jordan River and the Wahsatch Mountains.
They observed few churches but noted significant buildings like the prophet's mansion, courthouse, and arsenal.
Houses were described as blue-brick with verandas and gardens, enclosed by a clay/pebble wall from 1853.
The main street featured a market and hotels.
The city felt sparsely populated, with deserted streets except near the temple area, which was enclosed by palisades.
A large number of women were present, attributed to the Mormon practice of polygamy.
The text clarified that not all Mormons practice polygamy, but Mormon women are particularly keen to marry due to religious beliefs about salvation.
The women observed did not appear particularly prosperous or content; their clothing varied from modest black silk dresses to attire resembling Native American fashion.

events.text_segment:
The train reached Ogden at two o’clock, where it rested for six hours, Mr. Fogg and his party had time to pay a visit to Salt Lake City, connected with Ogden by a branch road; and they spent two hours in this strikingly American town, built on the pattern of other cities of the Union, like a checker-board, “with the sombre sadness of right-angles,” as Victor Hugo expresses it. The founder of the City of the Saints could not escape from the taste for symmetry which distinguishes the Anglo-Saxons. In this strange country, where the people are certainly not up to the level of their institutions, everything is done “squarely”—cities, houses, and follies.
The travellers, then, were promenading, at three o’clock, about the streets of the town built between the banks of the Jordan and the spurs of the Wahsatch Range. They saw few or no churches, but the prophet’s mansion, the court-house, and the arsenal, blue-brick houses with verandas and porches, surrounded by gardens bordered with acacias, palms, and locusts. A clay and pebble wall, built in 1853, surrounded the town; and in the principal street were the market and several hotels adorned with pavilions. The place did not seem thickly populated. The streets were almost deserted, except in the vicinity of the temple, which they only reached after having traversed several quarters surrounded by palisades. There were many women, which was easily accounted for by the “peculiar institution” of the Mormons; but it must not be supposed that all the Mormons are polygamists. They are free to marry or not, as they please; but it is worth noting that it is mainly the female citizens of Utah who are anxious to marry, as, according to the Mormon religion, maiden ladies are not admitted to the possession of its highest joys. These poor creatures seemed to be neither well off nor happy. Some—the more well-to-do, no doubt—wore short, open, black silk dresses, under a hood or modest shawl; others were habited in Indian fashion.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
The train reached Ogden at two o’clock, where it rested for six hours. Mr. Fogg and his party had time to pay a visit to Salt Lake City, connected with Ogden by a branch road; and they spent two hours in this strikingly American town, built on the pattern of other cities of the Union, like a checker-board, “with the sombre sadness of right-angles,” as Victor Hugo expresses it. It was in this the stronghold of Mormonism, that Passepartout beheld for the first time the curious land of the Latter Day Saints, whose history is so extraordinary. The founder of the sect, Joseph Smith, was a Vermont farmer, who, in 1825, announced that he had received a divine revelation, and published, as the result of it, the “Book of Mormon,” a sort of Bible, written in an ancient and unknown language. Smith, at the head of his disciples, settled in Ohio, and, moving from there to Missouri and Illinois, founded, in 1839, the city of Nauvoo, on the Mississippi. Persecuted by the Gentiles, they were obliged to leave, and, under the leadership of the prophet’s successor, Brigham Young, they emigrated to the far West. The journey across the plains was long and painful, but the Mormons, poor and weary as they were, found, in the midst of the mountains, a country fertile and well-watered, where, on the shores of the Great Salt Lake, they stopped, in 1847, to found the city of Salt Lake, the capital of the State of Utah.

This singular city, laid out with great regularity, and whose wide streets are lined with trees, numbers about twenty-five thousand inhabitants. A stream, called the Jordan, after the biblical river, flows into the Great Salt Lake. Salt Lake City is built between this river and the range of the Wahsatch Mountains, and its aspect is rather severe. The principal buildings are the temple, dedicated to the worship of the Latter Day Saints, the court-house, and the arsenal; the prophet’s mansion is a sort of fortress, guarded by sentinels. At three o’clock, as the travellers were promenading through the streets, they saw many women, who seemed to be looking at them with an air of curiosity. These women were not, however, particularly handsome, nor did they appear to be very happy. Passepartout could not help remarking their somewhat odd costume, which was neither exactly American nor European. Some wore black silk dresses, others were clothed in Indian fashion. Passepartout was not surprised at all to learn that the number of husbands is far from being as great as that of wives in Utah. It must be observed that polygamy is not a matter of course, and that the Mormons are free to marry or not, as they please; but it is worth noting that all the women aspire to marriage, because, according to the religion of the country, a woman cannot enter the celestial beatitude unless she is married. These poor creatures seemed to Passepartout to be neither well off nor happy. Some, the more well-to-do, wore black silk dresses; others, the majority, were clothed in Indian fashion.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: The streets, wide and straight, crossed each other at right angles, and the houses, with their verandas, gardens, and small orchards, were scattered along them with a certain regularity. The town was clean, the air pure, and everything bespoke order and comfort. The fort, the courthouse, the arsenal, the tabernacle, the schoolhouses, and the houses of the prophets and elders, were all visited in turn. A half-hour sufficed to see these curiosities. Salt Lake City was founded in 1847 by a colony of Mormons, under the leadership of the prophet Brigham Young, who left Nauvoo, Illinois, in order to seek, on the shores of the Great Salt Lake, a shelter from the persecutions which they had endured. The system of polygamy, which is still practised, was, until 1862, tolerated by the United States government, but has since been made illegal. The population of the city numbers about twenty-five thousand, and the country around is cultivated by the Mormons, who are mostly English, Danish, and Swedish. They are a sober, industrious people, and the city has a thriving appearance. Mr. Fogg and his companions did not see the prophet, who was engaged in a religious ceremony, but they heard much of him. After a short walk through the streets, they returned to the station, and resumed their journey at eight o’clock, in the evening, after a hearty meal at the railway restaurant. The train sped on across the plains, and the travellers, wrapped in their cloaks, slept soundly until morning.

events.title: Passepartout Reflects on Polygamy and Departs
detailed_summary: Passepartout felt a sense of fear observing the groups of women assigned to make one Mormon man happy.
His common sense led him to pity the husband most of all.
He considered the task of managing numerous wives through life and leading them collectively to the Mormon afterlife, alongside Joseph Smith, to be daunting.
The entire concept repelled him strongly.
He imagined, perhaps incorrectly, that some of the women in Salt Lake City were looking at him in an alarming way.
Fortunately for his peace of mind, their visit to the city was short.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Passepartout could not behold without a certain fright these women, charged, in groups, with conferring happiness on a single Mormon.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Happily, his stay there was but brief.

events.text_segment: Passepartout could not behold without a certain fright these women, charged, in groups, with conferring happiness on a single Mormon. His common sense pitied, above all, the husband. It seemed to him a terrible thing to have to guide so many wives at once across the vicissitudes of life, and to conduct them, as it were, in a body to the Mormon paradise with the prospect of seeing them in the company of the glorious Smith, who doubtless was the chief ornament of that delightful place, to all eternity. He felt decidedly repelled from such a vocation, and he imagined—perhaps he was mistaken—that the fair ones of Salt Lake City cast rather alarming glances on his person. Happily, his stay there was but brief.

He felt decidedly repelled by the whole business, and he fancied, perhaps wrongly, that the fair inhabitants of Salt Lake City cast rather alarming glances in his direction. Happily, his stay there was but brief; at half-past twelve the travellers were again on board the train, and they soon left the town behind them.

There were women of all ages, from the young girl to the old crone, all united by the same bond, and forming a singular contrast to the European customs Passepartout was accustomed to. He could not help reflecting on the strangeness of such a society.

events.title: A Belated Passenger and a Surprising Revelation
detailed_summary: By 4 PM, the group was back at the Ogden station and boarded the train.
As the train began to move, shouts of 'Stop!' were heard.
A Mormon man, clearly late, was seen running breathlessly.
Since the station lacked barriers, he ran along the track, managed to jump onto the rear platform, and collapsed into a seat, exhausted.
Passepartout had watched the man's frantic effort with keen interest.
He approached the man and learned that he had fled his home after a domestic argument.
Once the man regained his composure, Passepartout politely inquired about the number of wives he had, speculating it might be twenty given his desperate escape.
The Mormon, looking towards the sky, replied he had only one wife, emphatically stating that one was sufficient trouble.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: At four the party found themselves again at the station, took their places in the train, and the whistle sounded for starting.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “One, sir,” replied the Mormon, raising his arms heavenward —“one, and that was enough!”

events.text_segment:
At four the party found themselves again at the station, took their places in the train, and the whistle sounded for starting. Just at the moment, however, that the locomotive wheels began to move, cries of “Stop! stop!” were heard.
Trains, like time and tide, stop for no one. The gentleman who uttered the cries was evidently a belated Mormon. He was breathless with running. Happily for him, the station had neither gates nor barriers. He rushed along the track, jumped on the rear platform of the train, and fell, exhausted, into one of the seats.
Passepartout, who had been anxiously watching this amateur gymnast, approached him with lively interest, and learned that he had taken flight after an unpleasant domestic scene.
When the Mormon had recovered his breath, Passepartout ventured to ask him politely how many wives he had; for, from the manner in which he had decamped, it might be thought that he had twenty at least.
“One, sir,” replied the Mormon, raising his arms heavenward —“one, and that was enough!”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: At four the party found themselves again at the station, took their places in the train, and the whistle sounded for starting. Just as the locomotive was about to move off, cries of "Stop! stop!" were heard. A young man, a Mormon, much out of breath, rushed towards the train; he carried a carpet-bag in one hand and a large bundle in the other. He threw them upon the platform of the car, ran after the train, jumped on the rear step, and fell, panting, into one of the seats. Passepartout, who had been anxiously watching this scene, approached the man, and politely inquired if he was much hurt. "No," replied the Mormon, picking up his bag, "but I would not run for such a thing again, if you killed me." "Why, what was the matter, then?" "I wanted to get away from my wife," replied the Mormon. "Indeed!" said Passepartout. "She quarrelled with me, and I ran off." "You are lucky to have only one wife!" said Passepartout, with a sigh of sympathy. "My faith, it isn't much!" replied the Mormon, with a grimace. "One is more than enough for me, thank you!"

chapters.chapter_title: CHAPTER XXVIII. IN WHICH PASSEPARTOUT DOES NOT SUCCEED IN MAKING ANYBODY LISTEN TO REASON

events.title: Traversing the Mountainous West
detailed_summary: The train journey proceeds north from Ogden before turning east into the challenging Wahsatch Mountains.
This section of the track presented significant engineering obstacles, warranting a much higher government subsidy compared to the plains.
Engineers prioritized navigating around natural barriers rather than blasting through them, requiring only one substantial tunnel to reach the great basin.
The railway line had peaked in elevation at Great Salt Lake and subsequently descended and ascended again towards the continental divide.
The mountainous terrain featured numerous creeks, necessitating the construction of culverts for crossings.
Passepartout's impatience mounted during this leg of the journey.
Fix shared a sense of urgency, eager to leave the difficult terrain behind and reach England without delays, his anxiety seemingly surpassing even Fogg's.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The train, on leaving Great Salt Lake at Ogden, passed northward for an hour as far as Weber River, having completed nearly nine hundred miles from San Francisco.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Passepartout grew more and more impatient as they went on, while Fix longed to get out of this difficult region, and was more anxious than Phileas Fogg himself to be beyond the danger of delays and accidents, and set foot on English soil.

events.text_segment:
The train, on leaving Great Salt Lake at Ogden, passed northward for an hour as far as Weber River, having completed nearly nine hundred miles from San Francisco. From this point it took an easterly direction towards the jagged Wahsatch Mountains. It was in the section included between this range and the Rocky Mountains that the American engineers found the most formidable difficulties in laying the road, and that the government granted a subsidy of forty-eight thousand dollars per mile, instead of sixteen thousand allowed for the work done on the plains. But the engineers, instead of violating nature, avoided its difficulties by winding around, instead of penetrating the rocks. One tunnel only, fourteen thousand feet in length, was pierced in order to arrive at the great basin.
The track up to this time had reached its highest elevation at the Great Salt Lake. From this point it described a long curve, descending towards Bitter Creek Valley, to rise again to the dividing ridge of the waters between the Atlantic and the Pacific. There were many creeks in this mountainous region, and it was necessary to cross Muddy Creek, Green Creek, and others, upon culverts.
Passepartout grew more and more impatient as they went on, while Fix longed to get out of this difficult region, and was more anxious than Phileas Fogg himself to be beyond the danger of delays and accidents, and set foot on English soil.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
The train, on leaving Great Salt Lake at Ogden, passed northward for an hour as far as Weber River, having completed nearly nine hundred miles from San Francisco. From this point it turned eastward, and kept by the side of the river, as far as the mouth of the pass of Wahsatch. The tracks here left the valley and entered the mountain gorge. For the engineers had, from prudence, not attempted to overcome the obstacles by straightening the line, but had wound it in curves, so as to avoid the abrupt angles of the rocks. One tunnel only, of about nine hundred yards in length, was pierced through the mountains, and the train emerged from this into the basin of the Great Salt Lake, which is situated at an elevation of four thousand feet above the level of the sea.

The country between Ogden and the Wahsatch Mountains is covered with immense beds of snow, and the train was forced to proceed with great caution, so as not to be stopped by avalanches or snowdrifts. The passengers had to be patient, and even the most impatient, like Passepartout, found it necessary to resign themselves to the delays. Fix, who was as anxious as any one to reach England, was even more agitated than Fogg himself, and could not conceal his uneasiness.

The line, after having reached its highest point at the Great Salt Lake, descended again towards the basin, and then, after crossing several creeks by means of culverts, began to climb towards the divide of the continent. The scenery was wild and picturesque, but neither Fogg nor his companions paid much attention to it. Passepartout, especially, was in a fever of impatience, and tried in vain to make the conductor understand the necessity of hurrying on. But the latter could not, or would not, listen to reason, and the train continued its slow progress through the mountains.

events.title: Aouda Spots Colonel Proctor
detailed_summary: The train made stops at Fort Bridger and later Green River station in Wyoming Territory.
Snowfall mixed with rain had occurred but didn't impede the train's progress.
Passepartout worried about the potential impact of worsening weather on Fogg's schedule, questioning the wisdom of winter travel.
While Passepartout focused on the weather, Aouda experienced anxiety from a different source.
During the stop at Green River, Aouda saw Colonel Stamp Proctor, the man who had insulted Fogg in San Francisco, among the passengers on the platform.
Deeply alarmed, she quickly moved away from the window to avoid recognition.
Her strong feelings for Fogg, characterized by his unwavering, albeit undemonstrative, devotion, intensified her fear.
She internally grappled with the nature of her feelings for Fogg, recognizing them potentially transcending gratitude.
The sight of Proctor, whom Fogg intended to confront eventually, caused her great distress.
She understood Proctor's presence was accidental but posed a grave threat if Fogg were to see him.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: At ten o’clock at night the train stopped at Fort Bridger station, and twenty minutes later entered Wyoming Territory, following the valley of Bitter Creek throughout.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Chance alone, it was clear, had brought Colonel Proctor on this train; but there he was, and it was necessary, at all hazards, that Phileas Fogg should not perceive his adversary.

events.text_segment:
At ten o’clock at night the train stopped at Fort Bridger station, and twenty minutes later entered Wyoming Territory, following the valley of Bitter Creek throughout. The next day, 7th December, they stopped for a quarter of an hour at Green River station. Snow had fallen abundantly during the night, but, being mixed with rain, it had half melted, and did not interrupt their progress. The bad weather, however, annoyed Passepartout; for the accumulation of snow, by blocking the wheels of the cars, would certainly have been fatal to Mr. Fogg’s tour.
“What an idea!” he said to himself. “Why did my master make this journey in winter? Couldn’t he have waited for the good season to increase his chances?”
While the worthy Frenchman was absorbed in the state of the sky and the depression of the temperature, Aouda was experiencing fears from a totally different cause.
Several passengers had got off at Green River, and were walking up and down the platforms; and among these Aouda recognised Colonel Stamp Proctor, the same who had so grossly insulted Phileas Fogg at the San Francisco meeting. Not wishing to be recognised, the young woman drew back from the window, feeling much alarm at her discovery. She was attached to the man who, however coldly, gave her daily evidences of the most absolute devotion. She did not comprehend, perhaps, the depth of the sentiment with which her protector inspired her, which she called gratitude, but which, though she was unconscious of it, was really more than that. Her heart sank within her when she recognised the man whom Mr. Fogg desired, sooner or later, to call to account for his conduct. Chance alone, it was clear, had brought Colonel Proctor on this train; but there he was, and it was necessary, at all hazards, that Phileas Fogg should not perceive his adversary.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
At ten o’clock at night the train stopped at Fort Bridger station, and twenty minutes later entered Wyoming Territory, following the valley of Bitter Creek throughout. The whole region was still sprinkled with snow, which had partially melted, but as the weather was not severe, the progress of the train was not hindered. It was a country of vast extent, with few or no inhabitants, except a few bands of Indians, scattered here and there, and some trappers, who found their living in the pursuit of fur-bearing animals.

Passepartout, on waking and looking out, could not see any towns or villages. The train passed on at full speed, and did not stop at any of the stations of the Bitter Creek valley. The wind, which blew from the south, increased the feeling of cold, and the sky was overcast. Passepartout, whose keen sense of the practical made him more uneasy than his master, could not help thinking that the weather might become worse, and seriously affect the journey. He had seen snow fall in the mountains, and knew what it was to be blocked up by drifts. He asked himself if it was prudent to undertake a journey at this season, and if it would not have been better to have waited till the spring to attempt the tour of the world. But then, as he reflected, what would become of the wager? Besides, it was now too late to draw back.

At eight o’clock in the morning the train stopped at Green River station. Aouda, who had been awake for some time, looked out of the window, but suddenly drew back with a movement of terror. Passepartout, who was beside her, asked what was the matter.

"I saw him," she replied, in a low voice.

"Him? Whom?"

"That man who wanted to insult Mr. Fogg at San Francisco."

She pointed to a passenger who was walking on the platform. Passepartout recognized Colonel Stamp Proctor, who, with a party of friends, seemed to be making preparations for departure. Passepartout understood at once the cause of Aouda’s alarm. The presence of this man might lead to a quarrel, and it was necessary, at all hazards, to prevent Mr. Fogg from seeing his adversary.

Aouda, deeply agitated, withdrew from the window. Her heart beat violently. She had, in the course of the journey, become attached to the reserved and imperturbable gentleman who had saved her life. She felt that her gratitude was becoming something more than a sentiment, and that she would be unhappy if anything happened to him. The thought that a meeting with Colonel Proctor might lead to a fatal result filled her with terror.

Passepartout tried to reassure her, and promised to keep a close watch on Mr. Fogg. But, as usual, nobody would listen to reason. Mr. Fogg, who was walking up and down the platform, did not notice Colonel Proctor, and the train soon resumed its journey.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: The night was cold and clear, and the moon, rising above the snowy summits of the Rocky Mountains, bathed the wild landscape in a pale, mysterious light. The train, with its long line of carriages, wound like a serpent through the narrow defiles, the engine’s headlamp throwing a bright circle ahead, and the rhythmic clatter of the wheels echoing against the rocky walls. Inside the Pullman car, Phileas Fogg sat quietly, his calm face betraying no sign of fatigue or anxiety. He was absorbed in his usual game of whist with Passepartout, Colonel Proctor, and Fix, the detective, who had joined the party at Omaha. The game proceeded in silence, broken only by the occasional call of the score or the shuffle of the cards. Passepartout, though usually lively, was subdued, his thoughts wandering to the adventures and dangers they had already encountered on their journey. He glanced from time to time at his master, whose composure reassured him, and at Aouda, who sat near the window, gazing out at the moonlit wilderness. The train sped on, crossing wooden bridges over icy streams, and passing through small, sleeping settlements where only the distant howl of a wolf or the barking of a dog disturbed the stillness. The passengers, lulled by the motion of the train, gradually fell asleep, leaving the whist players and a few night owls awake. As the hours passed, the train climbed steadily, approaching the highest point of the route, where the air grew thinner and colder. Yet, inside the car, the warmth and light created a sense of security, and the travelers, each absorbed in their own thoughts, awaited the dawn and the next stage of their remarkable journey.

events.title: Conspiracy to Prevent a Confrontation
detailed_summary: Taking advantage of Fogg's nap, Aouda informed Fix and Passepartout about Colonel Proctor's presence on the train.
Fix reacted vehemently, declaring that Proctor would have to contend with him before settling matters with Fogg, as Fix felt more insulted.
Passepartout also volunteered to confront the colonel himself.
Aouda firmly stated that Fogg would insist on handling the matter personally and intended to seek Proctor out upon returning to America.
She emphasized the absolute necessity of keeping Fogg unaware of Proctor's presence to avert a potentially disastrous encounter.
Fix concurred, acknowledging that any confrontation, win or lose, would cause delays harmful to Fogg's tight schedule.
Passepartout pointed out that such a delay would directly benefit Fogg's opponents at the Reform Club.

They collectively decided that the best course of action was to ensure Fogg remained inside their train car for the next four days until reaching New York, thereby minimizing the chance of an encounter.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Aouda seized a moment when Mr. Fogg was asleep to tell Fix and Passepartout whom she had seen.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: We must, if possible, prevent his stirring out of it.”

events.text_segment:
Aouda seized a moment when Mr. Fogg was asleep to tell Fix and Passepartout whom she had seen.
“That Proctor on this train!” cried Fix. “Well, reassure yourself, madam; before he settles with Mr. Fogg; he has got to deal with me! It seems to me that I was the more insulted of the two.”
“And, besides,” added Passepartout, “I’ll take charge of him, colonel as he is.”
“Mr. Fix,” resumed Aouda, “Mr. Fogg will allow no one to avenge him. He said that he would come back to America to find this man. Should he perceive Colonel Proctor, we could not prevent a collision which might have terrible results. He must not see him.”
“You are right, madam,” replied Fix; “a meeting between them might ruin all. Whether he were victorious or beaten, Mr. Fogg would be delayed, and—”
“And,” added Passepartout, “that would play the game of the gentlemen of the Reform Club. In four days we shall be in New York. Well, if my master does not leave this car during those four days, we may hope that chance will not bring him face to face with this confounded American. We must, if possible, prevent his stirring out of it.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Aouda seized a moment when Mr. Fogg was asleep to tell Fix and Passepartout whom she had seen. That gentleman, she said, who had so grossly insulted Mr. Fogg at the San Francisco meeting, was on the train. Fix started at this news, and, addressing Passepartout, said, "If this is the case, we must be on our guard. He will try to provoke Mr. Fogg, and if he succeeds, we are lost."

"He must not see Mr. Fogg," replied Passepartout. "If he does, there will be a quarrel."

"Aouda," said Fix, "you are right. We must prevent a meeting at all hazards."

"I will watch," said Passepartout. "If I see the gentleman approach, I will warn Mr. Fogg."

"But," said Aouda, "Mr. Fogg will not allow himself to be insulted. He will demand satisfaction."

"He will," replied Fix, "and if he fights, he will lose precious time."

"Yes," said Passepartout, "and that would suit the gentlemen of the Reform Club."

"We must keep Mr. Fogg in his compartment for the next four days," said Fix. "If he leaves it, we are lost."

They all agreed to this plan, and resolved to watch over Mr. Fogg with the utmost vigilance.

She spoke in a low, urgent whisper, her eyes wide with concern. "I am certain," she said, "that the man I glimpsed in the crowd was none other than the priest who presided over my supposed sacrifice. The detective, ever cautious, asked, "Are you sure, madam? Could it not be a trick of the light, or a resemblance?" But Aouda shook her head. "I could not mistake him. His face is burned into my memory. We must be careful."

The three agreed to say nothing to Fogg for now, lest he be troubled or distracted from their journey. Outside, the city bustled on, unaware of the danger lurking nearby.

events.title: The Whist Game Diversion
detailed_summary: Their discussion ceased as Fogg awoke and glanced out the window.
Passepartout quietly asked Fix if his offer to fight for Fogg was genuine.
Fix responded with determination, stating he would do whatever it took to get Fogg back to Europe alive, which slightly unnerved Passepartout, though his loyalty to Fogg didn't waver.
The challenge became finding a way to keep Fogg, who was naturally disinclined to move about, confined to the car.
Fix devised a plan, suggesting a game of whist to occupy Fogg, reminding him of his pastime on ships.
Fogg lamented the lack of cards and fellow players.
Fix countered that cards were readily available on American trains and proposed Aouda might join.
Aouda affirmed her knowledge of whist as part of a standard English upbringing.
Fix offered himself as the third player, completing the table with a theoretical fourth player (dummy).
Fogg happily accepted, glad for the chance to play his preferred game.
Passepartout procured cards, scoring materials, and a playing surface.
The game commenced; Aouda played proficiently, earning Fogg's praise, while Fix demonstrated considerable skill, proving a worthy opponent.
Passepartout felt relief, believing Fogg was now safely engrossed and unlikely to leave the compartment.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The conversation dropped.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Now,” thought Passepartout, “we’ve got him. He won’t budge.”

events.text_segment:
The conversation dropped. Mr. Fogg had just woke up, and was looking out of the window. Soon after Passepartout, without being heard by his master or Aouda, whispered to the detective, “Would you really fight for him?”
“I would do anything,” replied Fix, in a tone which betrayed determined will, “to get him back living to Europe!”
Passepartout felt something like a shudder shoot through his frame, but his confidence in his master remained unbroken.
Was there any means of detaining Mr. Fogg in the car, to avoid a meeting between him and the colonel? It ought not to be a difficult task, since that gentleman was naturally sedentary and little curious. The detective, at least, seemed to have found a way; for, after a few moments, he said to Mr. Fogg, “These are long and slow hours, sir, that we are passing on the railway.”
“Yes,” replied Mr. Fogg; “but they pass.”
“You were in the habit of playing whist,” resumed Fix, “on the steamers.”
“Yes; but it would be difficult to do so here. I have neither cards nor partners.”
“Oh, but we can easily buy some cards, for they are sold on all the American trains. And as for partners, if madam plays—”
“Certainly, sir,” Aouda quickly replied; “I understand whist. It is part of an English education.”
“I myself have some pretensions to playing a good game. Well, here are three of us, and a dummy—”
“As you please, sir,” replied Phileas Fogg, heartily glad to resume his favourite pastime even on the railway.
Passepartout was dispatched in search of the steward, and soon returned with two packs of cards, some pins, counters, and a shelf covered with cloth.
The game commenced. Aouda understood whist sufficiently well, and even received some compliments on her playing from Mr. Fogg. As for the detective, he was simply an adept, and worthy of being matched against his present opponent.
“Now,” thought Passepartout, “we’ve got him. He won’t budge.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
The conversation dropped. Mr. Fogg had just awakened, and was looking out of the window. Soon, Passepartout, who had been reflecting, quietly approached Fix, and, in a low voice, asked: "You have really made up your mind to save Mr. Fogg?"

"Yes," replied Fix, through his set teeth. "I will do everything to get him back to Europe alive."

Passepartout felt something like a shudder at these words, but his confidence in his master remained unshaken.

The difficulty was, how to prevent Mr. Fogg from leaving the car, and thus exposing himself to the chances of a meeting with the unfortunate Colonel Proctor.

Fix, after a moment's thought, said: "We must induce Mr. Fogg to remain in the car, and not stir out."

"But what can we do to amuse him?" asked Passepartout.

Fix was inspired. "Whist!" he exclaimed. "We will play whist, as you used to do on the steamers."

"It is a good idea," said Passepartout. "He loves the game."

"But there are no cards nor partners."

"Oh, we shall find cards and three of us will make up the game."

Aouda had learned whist in England, and was quite ready to play. Fix, too, was a good player, and now the game was arranged. Passepartout went in search of a pack of cards, a score-book, counters, and a table, and soon the party was seated in the corner of the car, deeply absorbed in the game.

Mr. Fogg found Aouda a very skilful player, and Fix proved himself a worthy adversary. As for Passepartout, he was delighted to have his master thus occupied, and felt sure that he would not stir as long as the game lasted.
