LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
They found a suitable spot in the baggage car, where the noise of the wheels and the clatter of the train would mask the sounds of their preparations. The seconds, with grave faces, measured out the paces, while the conductor kept a wary eye on the proceedings, anxious that the duel should not disturb the other passengers or cause any damage to the railway’s property. 

Phileas Fogg, calm and collected as ever, stood at one end of the makeshift field, his pistol in hand. Colonel Proctor, his face set in a determined scowl, took his place at the other. The seconds handed each man a loaded pistol, and the conductor, acting as referee, explained the rules: at the signal, the two would advance, firing at will, until one was hit or the ammunition was spent.

The tension in the car was palpable. Passepartout, Fogg’s loyal servant, watched anxiously from the doorway, wringing his hands and muttering prayers for his master’s safety. The seconds stepped back, and the conductor raised his hand. “Gentlemen, are you ready?” he asked. Both nodded. “Fire!”

At the word, the two men advanced, their eyes locked. Proctor fired first, the shot ringing out above the roar of the train, but the bullet embedded itself harmlessly in a crate. Fogg, unflinching, took careful aim and squeezed the trigger. His shot grazed Proctor’s arm, drawing a thin line of blood. The seconds rushed forward, declaring the duel over, as honor had been satisfied.

Proctor, nursing his wound, bowed stiffly to Fogg. “Sir, you are a worthy opponent.” Fogg returned the bow with equal formality. The conductor, relieved that the affair had ended without serious injury, ushered the party back to their seats, and the train sped on toward its destination, the matter settled and the journey resumed.

events.title: Desperate Defense and Passepartout's Gamble
detailed_summary: The armed Sioux exchanged fire with the passengers, most of whom were also armed.
Indians attacked the engine crew, stunning the engineer and stoker.
A Sioux chief tried to stop the train but, unfamiliar with the controls, accidentally opened the steam valve fully, causing the locomotive to accelerate violently.
Simultaneously, Sioux fighters swarmed the cars, climbing over roofs, forcing doors, and engaging in close combat with passengers.
They looted the baggage car, throwing luggage off the speeding train.
Amidst continuous cries and gunfire, the travelers fought back bravely.
Some cars were barricaded, becoming mobile forts enduring the siege at high speed.
Aouda displayed remarkable courage, using a revolver effectively against attackers appearing at broken windows.
The battle resulted in casualties on both sides: twenty Sioux fell dead, some crushed by the wheels, while several passengers lay wounded.
After ten minutes, it became clear the Sioux would win if the train wasn't stopped soon.
Fort Kearney station and its garrison were close, but if passed, the train would be entirely vulnerable.
The conductor, fighting near Fogg, was shot and fell, warning they had only five minutes to stop the train or be lost.
Fogg prepared to take action himself.
Passepartout intervened, declaring he would go.
Before Fogg could stop him, Passepartout slipped out a door unnoticed by the attackers and got under the train.
Leveraging his past acrobatic skills, he navigated the dangerous space beneath the cars amidst the ongoing firefight, moving towards the engine.
Reaching the front, hanging between the tender and the baggage car, he managed to loosen the safety chains.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The Sioux were armed with guns, from which came the reports, to which the passengers, who were almost all armed, responded by revolver-shots.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: There, suspended by one hand between the baggage-car and the tender, with the other he loosened the safety chains; but, owing to the traction, he would never have succeeded in unscrewing the yoking-bar, had not a violent concussion jolted this bar out.

events.text_segment:
The Sioux were armed with guns, from which came the reports, to which the passengers, who were almost all armed, responded by revolver-shots.
The Indians had first mounted the engine, and half stunned the engineer and stoker with blows from their muskets. A Sioux chief, wishing to stop the train, but not knowing how to work the regulator, had opened wide instead of closing the steam-valve, and the locomotive was plunging forward with terrific velocity.
The Sioux had at the same time invaded the cars, skipping like enraged monkeys over the roofs, thrusting open the doors, and fighting hand to hand with the passengers. Penetrating the baggage-car, they pillaged it, throwing the trunks out of the train. The cries and shots were constant. The travellers defended themselves bravely; some of the cars were barricaded, and sustained a siege, like moving forts, carried along at a speed of a hundred miles an hour.
Aouda behaved courageously from the first. She defended herself like a true heroine with a revolver, which she shot through the broken windows whenever a savage made his appearance. Twenty Sioux had fallen mortally wounded to the ground, and the wheels crushed those who fell upon the rails as if they had been worms. Several passengers, shot or stunned, lay on the seats.
It was necessary to put an end to the struggle, which had lasted for ten minutes, and which would result in the triumph of the Sioux if the train was not stopped. Fort Kearney station, where there was a garrison, was only two miles distant; but, that once passed, the Sioux would be masters of the train between Fort Kearney and the station beyond.
The conductor was fighting beside Mr. Fogg, when he was shot and fell. At the same moment he cried, “Unless the train is stopped in five minutes, we are lost!”
“It shall be stopped,” said Phileas Fogg, preparing to rush from the car.
“Stay, monsieur,” cried Passepartout; “I will go.”
Mr. Fogg had not time to stop the brave fellow, who, opening a door unperceived by the Indians, succeeded in slipping under the car; and while the struggle continued and the balls whizzed across each other over his head, he made use of his old acrobatic experience, and with amazing agility worked his way under the cars, holding on to the chains, aiding himself by the brakes and edges of the sashes, creeping from one car to another with marvellous skill, and thus gaining the forward end of the train.
There, suspended by one hand between the baggage-car and the tender, with the other he loosened the safety chains; but, owing to the traction, he would never have succeeded in unscrewing the yoking-bar, had not a violent concussion jolted this bar out.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The Sioux were armed with guns, from which came the reports, to which the passengers, who were almost all armed, responded by revolver-shots. The Indians had first mounted the engine, and half stunned the engineer and stoker with blows from their muskets. A chief, grasping the engine driver’s lever, reversed the steam, and the train was at once stopped. Meanwhile, the Sioux had invaded the cars, passing from one to another, and fighting hand to hand with the passengers. Some of the cars were barricaded, and sustained a regular siege, like moving forts carried along at the speed of the train. They fought bravely, aided by the travelers, whose courage was sustained by the presence of the lady. Aouda defended herself with a revolver, with the energy of a true heroine. The bullets whistled, and the cries of the wounded and the combatants mingled with the noise of the train, which was now moving at full speed. The chief, who had stopped the train, not knowing how to manage the engine, had opened the regulator instead of closing it, and the locomotive, under a full head of steam, dashed forward with frightful rapidity. The Indians had not expected this, and, being carried off, they clung to the handrails, to the brakes, and to the roofs of the cars. Some were thrown off, and fell under the wheels. Twenty Sioux, mortally wounded, lay on the railway track, and a dozen passengers, severely hurt, were left behind. The train, which the chief had not been able to stop, continued its course, but at the end of ten minutes it became evident that the Sioux would win the day if the train was not stopped. Near Fort Kearney was a garrison, but if the train passed it, the travelers would be entirely at the mercy of the savages. The conductor, wounded in the arm, and fighting bravely by Mr. Fogg’s side, was shot and fell, exclaiming, “We are lost if the train is not stopped within five minutes!” “It shall be stopped,” said Phileas Fogg, preparing to rush from the car. “Stay, monsieur,” cried Passepartout; “this is my business.” He had slipped through the door, and, not being perceived by the Indians, was soon under the car. The next instant he was hanging on to the chains, aiding himself with his acrobatic skill, and, with incredible agility, making his way to the front of the train, while the shots continued to be fired from the windows. The Sioux had not noticed him; he reached the engine, and, in a few moments, had loosened the safety chains and the coupling of the engine from the train.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The Sioux were armed with guns, from which came the reports, to which the passengers, who were almost all armed, responded by revolver-shots. The combat became general along the train. The Sioux had first mounted the engine and half of them had forced their way into the cars, fighting hand to hand with the passengers. The panic was terrible; women cried, children screamed, and the shots were fired indiscriminately. Some of the travelers, less courageous than the others, had hidden themselves under the seats. Others, determined to sell their lives dearly, fought with desperation. The conductors and engineers, armed with their revolvers, defended themselves bravely, barricading the doors and windows as best they could. The struggle lasted for several minutes, and the train, which had not stopped, continued to run at full speed, the engineer having opened the throttle to the utmost.

Suddenly, three sharp whistles were heard. The train slackened its speed, and soon stopped altogether. The Sioux, profiting by this halt, redoubled their efforts. They attempted to force the doors of the cars, but the passengers resisted with energy. The struggle was at its height when a cry was heard: "The bridge! The bridge!" The train had reached Medicine Bow, and before it was a bridge of a hundred feet span, which the engineers had hastily repaired, but which was very unsafe. The train could not pass over it at full speed, and it was necessary to stop.

The Sioux, seeing the train stop, made a last effort to carry the cars by assault, but they were repulsed by the passengers, who fought with the courage of despair. At this moment, Phileas Fogg, who had not ceased to watch the combat with coolness, said to the conductor, "We must uncouple the engine from the train."

"It is impossible," replied the conductor.

"I will show you how," said Mr. Fogg.

A few moments later, amidst a shower of bullets, Mr. Fogg, accompanied by the engineer and Passepartout, succeeded in uncoupling the engine, which, with a loud whistle, darted forward over the bridge, carrying with it the engineer, Mr. Fogg, and Passepartout. The Sioux, stupefied at this bold maneuver, remained motionless. The train, left behind, was soon surrounded by the Indians, who, after a short struggle, overpowered the passengers and took possession of the cars.

Meanwhile, the engine, having passed the bridge, stopped on the other side. Mr. Fogg and his companions, leaving the engine, hastened to a place of safety, whence they could see the train in the power of the Sioux. They were safe, but what would become of the passengers left behind? Mr. Fogg resolved to return and rescue them, whatever the risk.

events.title: Engine Detached, Train Saved, Hero Missing
detailed_summary: A sudden jolt dislodged the coupling bar, separating the engine from the train cars.
The locomotive sped off, while the detached cars continued moving forward due to momentum.
The brakes were applied, bringing the train cars to a halt less than a hundred feet from Kearney station.
Soldiers from the fort, alerted by the gunfire, approached rapidly.
Caught by surprise at the soldiers' arrival, the Sioux warriors fled before the train came to a complete stop.
As the passengers gathered on the station platform, a headcount revealed several missing individuals.
Among the missing was Passepartout, the courageous Frenchman whose actions had resulted in their rescue.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The train, now detached from the engine, remained a little behind, whilst the locomotive rushed forward with increased speed.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: But when the passengers counted each other on the station platform several were found missing; among others the courageous Frenchman, whose devotion had just saved them.

events.text_segment:
The train, now detached from the engine, remained a little behind, whilst the locomotive rushed forward with increased speed.
Carried on by the force already acquired, the train still moved for several minutes; but the brakes were worked and at last they stopped, less than a hundred feet from Kearney station.
The soldiers of the fort, attracted by the shots, hurried up; the Sioux had not expected them, and decamped in a body before the train entirely stopped.
But when the passengers counted each other on the station platform several were found missing; among others the courageous Frenchman, whose devotion had just saved them.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The train, now detached from the engine, remained a little behind, whilst the locomotive rushed forward with increased speed. It might, perhaps, be able to reach Kearney station. The conductor was full of hope, and, as he looked at the train, he saw that the cars were still moving, and that they would reach the station in a few moments. The passengers had all got out, and were standing on the platform. The soldiers, who had been drawn up in line, quickly surrounded the train. The Sioux, seeing the soldiers, had not dared to continue their attack, and had fled into the prairie. But, as the passengers were being counted, it was found that several were missing, and among them was the brave Frenchman, whose devotion had saved them all.

chapters.chapter_title: CHAPTER XXX. IN WHICH PHILEAS FOGG SIMPLY DOES HIS DUTY

events.title: Aftermath of the Sioux Attack and Fogg's Resolve
detailed_summary: Three individuals, including Passepartout, were unaccounted for following the Sioux attack, their fate unknown.
Numerous passengers were wounded, with Colonel Proctor suffering a serious injury after fighting valiantly.
The injured were transported to the station for medical care.
Aouda remained unharmed, and Phileas Fogg, despite being in the center of the conflict, was unscathed. Fix had a minor arm wound.
Passepartout's absence deeply distressed Aouda.
Passengers exited the blood-stained train, witnessing gruesome remnants of the battle and observing the retreating Sioux in the distance.
Phileas Fogg stood silently, contemplating a significant choice.
Aouda observed him wordlessly, conveying her unspoken plea for Passepartout's rescue.
Fogg understood her concern regarding his imprisoned servant and the necessity of risking everything for him.
He firmly declared to Aouda his intention to find Passepartout, whether alive or deceased.
Aouda emotionally expressed her gratitude, clutching his hands.
Fogg emphasized the urgency, stating they must act immediately to find Passepartout alive.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Three passengers including Passepartout had disappeared.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Living,” added Mr. Fogg, “if we do not lose a moment.”

events.text_segment:
Three passengers including Passepartout had disappeared. Had they been killed in the struggle? Were they taken prisoners by the Sioux? It was impossible to tell.
There were many wounded, but none mortally. Colonel Proctor was one of the most seriously hurt; he had fought bravely, and a ball had entered his groin. He was carried into the station with the other wounded passengers, to receive such attention as could be of avail.
Aouda was safe; and Phileas Fogg, who had been in the thickest of the fight, had not received a scratch. Fix was slightly wounded in the arm. But Passepartout was not to be found, and tears coursed down Aouda’s cheeks.
All the passengers had got out of the train, the wheels of which were stained with blood. From the tyres and spokes hung ragged pieces of flesh. As far as the eye could reach on the white plain behind, red trails were visible. The last Sioux were disappearing in the south, along the banks of Republican River.
Mr. Fogg, with folded arms, remained motionless. He had a serious decision to make. Aouda, standing near him, looked at him without speaking, and he understood her look. If his servant was a prisoner, ought he not to risk everything to rescue him from the Indians? “I will find him, living or dead,” said he quietly to Aouda.
“Ah, Mr.—Mr. Fogg!” cried she, clasping his hands and covering them with tears.
“Living,” added Mr. Fogg, “if we do not lose a moment.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Three passengers including Passepartout had disappeared. Had they been killed in the struggle? Were they taken prisoners by the Sioux? It was impossible to know.

There were many wounded, but none mortally. Colonel Proctor was one of the most seriously hurt; he had fought bravely, and a ball had entered his groin. He was carried into the station with the other wounded to receive such attention as could be given them.

Aouda was safe; and Phileas Fogg, who had been in the thickest of the fight, had not received a scratch. Fix was slightly wounded in the arm. But Passepartout was not to be found, and Aouda, in the midst of her gratitude for her deliverance, could not help but be filled with the deepest anxiety.

The passengers left the train, the rails of which were stained with blood. The carriages were shattered, and the ground was strewn with the dead and wounded. The Sioux, vanquished, had retreated into the distance, and silence reigned once more.

Phileas Fogg stood motionless, his face betraying no emotion. He was evidently making a serious decision. Aouda looked at him with an expression of the most profound supplication. Her eyes seemed to say, "You will not abandon him?"

Fogg understood her. He had already made up his mind.

"I will go," said he.

"To find Passepartout?" cried Aouda, seizing his hand and pressing it to her heart.

"Yes; but it is not to be attempted with so few men as we have. I will go."

"Alone?" asked Fix, who had come up.

"Alone. No, sir," said the detective, "you shall not go alone."

Fogg smiled, and on that smile there was something heroic. He pressed Aouda's hand, and then, with a calm voice, said, "We must lose no time. Passepartout is a prisoner; he may be dead. We must find him, at all hazards. Come!"

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Phileas Fogg, who had been so calm and collected throughout the journey, now felt a pang of anxiety. The train had stopped unexpectedly in the middle of the vast Indian jungle, and the absence of Passepartout and the two other passengers was immediately noticed. Mr. Fogg, accompanied by the ever-faithful Aouda and the resourceful Detective Fix, began to search the carriages and the surrounding area, calling out for the missing men. The dense foliage and the unfamiliar sounds of the jungle heightened their sense of urgency.

A railway official explained that the missing passengers had last been seen near the rear of the train, possibly stepping out during a brief halt. Fogg, determined not to lose precious time, organized a search party. The group moved cautiously, wary of wild animals and the possibility of hostile locals. As they pressed deeper into the undergrowth, they found signs of a struggle: a torn piece of Passepartout’s distinctive blue turban and footprints leading away from the tracks.

Aouda, concerned for Passepartout’s safety, urged Fogg to continue the search. Fix, though still intent on his own mission, assisted with genuine concern. After a tense hour, distant shouts were heard. The party followed the sounds and soon discovered Passepartout and the two other passengers, who had been waylaid by a group of curious villagers. With some negotiation and the offer of a few coins, Fogg secured their release. Relieved, the group hurried back to the train, determined to make up for lost time on their journey around the world.

events.title: Organizing the Rescue Mission
detailed_summary: Fogg's decision to rescue Passepartout meant sacrificing his journey and likely losing his wager due to the unavoidable delay.
Despite the personal cost, Fogg felt it was his duty and did not waver.
The commander of Fort Kearney was present with a hundred soldiers prepared to defend the station.
Fogg informed the captain about the three missing passengers, unsure if they were dead or captured.
He asked if the captain planned to pursue the Sioux.
The captain hesitated, citing the risk of the Sioux retreating far beyond reach and the need to protect the fort.
Fogg pressed the issue, emphasizing the importance of the three missing lives.
The captain questioned the wisdom of risking fifty soldiers to save three.
Fogg countered that while he couldn't dictate the captain's decision, he believed it was the right thing to do.
The captain asserted his authority, stating no one could tell him his duty.
Fogg coolly declared he would pursue the Sioux alone.
Fix, surprised, questioned Fogg's intention to go alone.
Fogg argued he couldn't abandon Passepartout, to whom everyone owed their lives.
Moved by Fogg's bravery, the captain changed his mind and called for thirty volunteers.
The entire company stepped forward, and the captain selected thirty men led by an old sergeant.
Fogg thanked the captain.
Fix asked to join the rescue party.
Fogg permitted him but requested, as a favor, that Fix stay with Aouda in case anything happened to him.
The detective turned pale at the thought of being separated from Fogg and leaving him to venture into the wilderness.
Fix observed Fogg closely and, despite his internal conflict and suspicions, felt compelled by Fogg's calm demeanor to agree.
He promised to stay.
Fogg briefly took Aouda's hand, entrusted his valuable carpet-bag to her, and departed with the sergeant and soldiers.
Before leaving, he offered the soldiers a $5,000 reward if the prisoners were saved.
The rescue party departed shortly after midday.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Phileas Fogg, by this resolution, inevitably sacrificed himself; he pronounced his own doom.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: It was then a little past noon.

events.text_segment:
Phileas Fogg, by this resolution, inevitably sacrificed himself; he pronounced his own doom. The delay of a single day would make him lose the steamer at New York, and his bet would be certainly lost. But as he thought, “It is my duty,” he did not hesitate.
The commanding officer of Fort Kearney was there. A hundred of his soldiers had placed themselves in a position to defend the station, should the Sioux attack it.
“Sir,” said Mr. Fogg to the captain, “three passengers have disappeared.”
“Dead?” asked the captain.
“Dead or prisoners; that is the uncertainty which must be solved. Do you propose to pursue the Sioux?”
“That’s a serious thing to do, sir,” returned the captain. “These Indians may retreat beyond the Arkansas, and I cannot leave the fort unprotected.”
“The lives of three men are in question, sir,” said Phileas Fogg.
“Doubtless; but can I risk the lives of fifty men to save three?”
“I don’t know whether you can, sir; but you ought to do so.”
“Nobody here,” returned the other, “has a right to teach me my duty.”
“Very well,” said Mr. Fogg, coldly. “I will go alone.”
“You, sir!” cried Fix, coming up; “you go alone in pursuit of the Indians?”
“Would you have me leave this poor fellow to perish—him to whom every one present owes his life? I shall go.”
“No, sir, you shall not go alone,” cried the captain, touched in spite of himself. “No! you are a brave man. Thirty volunteers!” he added, turning to the soldiers.
The whole company started forward at once. The captain had only to pick his men. Thirty were chosen, and an old sergeant placed at their head.
“Thanks, captain,” said Mr. Fogg.
“Will you let me go with you?” asked Fix.
“Do as you please, sir. But if you wish to do me a favour, you will remain with Aouda. In case anything should happen to me—”
A sudden pallor overspread the detective’s face. Separate himself from the man whom he had so persistently followed step by step! Leave him to wander about in this desert! Fix gazed attentively at Mr. Fogg, and, despite his suspicions and of the struggle which was going on within him, he lowered his eyes before that calm and frank look.
“I will stay,” said he.
A few moments after, Mr. Fogg pressed the young woman’s hand, and, having confided to her his precious carpet-bag, went off with the sergeant and his little squad. But, before going, he had said to the soldiers, “My friends, I will divide five thousand dollars among you, if we save the prisoners.”
It was then a little past noon.

The commanding officer of Fort Kearney was there. He had heard the news of the attack on the train, and had mustered one hundred men to defend the station against any Sioux attempt at revenge. "You, sir!" cried Fix, who was standing by.

"I must. I cannot abandon my servant."

"Oh, well," said the captain, "no one here has a right to teach me my duty. I will go. Thirty volunteers!" he added, turning to the soldiers.

"Will you let me go with you?" asked Fix.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
He had, indeed, made up his mind to accept the consequences of his wager, whatever they might be. The calmness with which he had acted throughout his journey did not desert him now, even in the face of apparent defeat. The clock in the great hall of the Reform Club was striking the hour; the members were assembled, some glancing at the timepiece, others at the door, as if expecting the arrival of the man who had so audaciously staked his fortune and reputation on the possibility of circumnavigating the globe in eighty days.

But Phileas Fogg did not appear. His absence was noted with a mixture of disappointment and satisfaction; disappointment by those who had believed in his success, satisfaction by those who had predicted his failure. The minutes passed, and the hands of the clock moved inexorably forward. At last, the hour was complete. The wager was lost.

Meanwhile, in his quiet house in Saville Row, Phileas Fogg sat in his accustomed chair, his face betraying no emotion. Passepartout, his faithful servant, hovered anxiously nearby, unable to comprehend the stoicism of his master. Aouda, the gentle and grateful woman whom Fogg had rescued from a terrible fate in India, watched him with concern and affection.

"Monsieur Fogg," Passepartout ventured, "is there nothing to be done?"

Fogg shook his head. "The time has passed, my friend. The wager is lost."

Aouda approached him, her eyes shining with unshed tears. "You have been so noble, so generous. You have risked everything for me, for a stranger. I cannot bear to see you unhappy."

Fogg looked at her, and for the first time, a flicker of emotion crossed his features. "Madam, you owe me nothing. It was my duty to help you."

"But I owe you everything," she insisted. "If only there were some way I could repay you."

Passepartout, unable to contain himself, burst out, "Monsieur, you are the best of men!"

Fogg rose and paced the room. The silence was heavy, broken only by the ticking of the clock. At last, he turned to Aouda. "Madam, would you do me the honor of becoming my wife?"

Aouda started, surprised by the suddenness of the proposal, but her answer was clear. "Yes, Mr. Fogg, with all my heart."

Passepartout, overjoyed, rushed out to find a clergyman. In his haste, he discovered, to his astonishment, that it was not Sunday, as he had believed, but Saturday. The realization struck him like a thunderbolt: they had gained a day by traveling eastward around the world. There was still time! Phileas Fogg could yet win his wager.

events.title: Aouda's Worry and Fix's Inner Turmoil
detailed_summary: Aouda waited by herself in a room, reflecting on Fogg's selfless generosity and calm bravery.
She recognized he had risked his fortune and now his life out of duty, without hesitation or outward display.
Fix experienced different emotions, struggling to hide his agitation.
He paced anxiously before regaining his composure.
He realized his mistake in allowing Fogg to leave alone, permitting the man he tracked globally to separate from him.
Fix reproached himself harshly for his lapse in judgment, feeling foolish.
He berated himself, convinced Fogg wouldn't return and questioning how he, holding an arrest warrant, had become so influenced by Fogg.
As time passed slowly, Fix felt lost.
He considered revealing everything to Aouda but anticipated her likely negative reaction.
He contemplated pursuing Fogg across the plains, noting that footprints were initially visible in the snow but would soon be erased by fresh snowfall.
Discouragement set in, and Fix felt an overwhelming urge to abandon his pursuit entirely.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Aouda retired to a waiting-room, and there she waited alone, thinking of the simple and noble generosity, the tranquil courage of Phileas Fogg.

events.text_segment:
Aouda retired to a waiting-room, and there she waited alone, thinking of the simple and noble generosity, the tranquil courage of Phileas Fogg. He had sacrificed his fortune, and was now risking his life, all without hesitation, from duty, in silence.
Fix did not have the same thoughts, and could scarcely conceal his agitation. He walked feverishly up and down the platform, but soon resumed his outward composure. He now saw the folly of which he had been guilty in letting Fogg go alone. What! This man, whom he had just followed around the world, was permitted now to separate himself from him! He began to accuse and abuse himself, and, as if he were director of police, administered to himself a sound lecture for his greenness.
“I have been an idiot!” he thought, “and this man will see it. He has gone, and won’t come back! But how is it that I, Fix, who have in my pocket a warrant for his arrest, have been so fascinated by him? Decidedly, I am nothing but an ass!”
So reasoned the detective, while the hours crept by all too slowly. He did not know what to do. Sometimes he was tempted to tell Aouda all; but he could not doubt how the young woman would receive his confidences. What course should he take? He thought of pursuing Fogg across the vast white plains; it did not seem impossible that he might overtake him. Footsteps were easily printed on the snow! But soon, under a new sheet, every imprint would be effaced.
Fix became discouraged. He felt a sort of insurmountable longing to abandon the game altogether. He could now leave Fort Kearney station, and pursue his journey homeward in peace.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Aouda retired to a waiting-room, and there she waited alone, thinking of the simple and noble generosity, the tranquil courage of Phileas Fogg. He had sacrificed his fortune, and now risked his life, all without hesitation, from duty, and without a single murmur. Aouda was keenly conscious of all that she owed him. So great, so generous was his conduct, that she could not keep back her tears.

As for Fix, he wandered to and fro in the station, and saw no means of leaving it. He was overwhelmed with disappointment, and rage against himself for having allowed Fogg to go. He had followed him around the world, only to let him escape at the last moment! He sat down on a bench, and beat his head with his fists. He accused himself of stupidity, and declared that he was unworthy to be a detective. He considered that he had been influenced by Fogg’s presence, and that he had allowed himself to be carried away by the man’s calmness and generosity. He was sure that Fogg would not return, and that he had lost his prey for ever.

Time passed slowly. Fix felt as if he were lost in a dream. He thought of telling Aouda everything, but he knew how she would receive his confidences. He thought of pursuing Fogg across the white plains, but the tracks of the sledge were already disappearing under the fresh falling snow. Discouraged, he was on the point of abandoning all hope, and of leaving the station and returning to England.

A large, shadowy form with a bright light appeared through the mist, looking fantastical.
No train was scheduled from the east, nor had the requested relief arrived; the next scheduled train wasn't due until the following day.

The engineer and stoker eventually regained consciousness.

He decided against continuing to Omaha, deeming it safer to return despite the risk of encountering Indians.

events.text_segment:
Towards two o’clock in the afternoon, while it was snowing hard, long whistles were heard approaching from the east. A great shadow, preceded by a wild light, slowly advanced, appearing still larger through the mist, which gave it a fantastic aspect. No train was expected from the east, neither had there been time for the succour asked for by telegraph to arrive; the train from Omaha to San Francisco was not due till the next day. The mystery was soon explained.
The locomotive, which was slowly approaching with deafening whistles, was that which, having been detached from the train, had continued its route with such terrific rapidity, carrying off the unconscious engineer and stoker. It had run several miles, when, the fire becoming low for want of fuel, the steam had slackened; and it had finally stopped an hour after, some twenty miles beyond Fort Kearney. Neither the engineer nor the stoker was dead, and, after remaining for some time in their swoon, had come to themselves. The train had then stopped. The engineer, when he found himself in the desert, and the locomotive without cars, understood what had happened. He could not imagine how the locomotive had become separated from the train; but he did not doubt that the train left behind was in distress.
He did not hesitate what to do. It would be prudent to continue on to Omaha, for it would be dangerous to return to the train, which the Indians might still be engaged in pillaging. Nevertheless, he began to rebuild the fire in the furnace; the pressure again mounted, and the locomotive returned, running backwards to Fort Kearney. This it was which was whistling in the mist.

Towards two o’clock in the afternoon, while it was snowing hard, long whistles were heard approaching from the east. No train was due from that direction, and the relief engine requested earlier had not yet arrived; the next scheduled express would not pass until the following day.

The mystery deepened as the engine drew nearer, its iron bulk looming fantastically in the wintry haze. Inside the cab, the engineer and stoker, their faces pale and drawn, exchanged bewildered glances. Realizing the train must have been left behind, the engineer surmised that some calamity had occurred, though he could not guess its nature. Weighing his options, he resolved not to press on to Omaha, but to risk the return journey, even with the threat of Indian attack. With grim determination, he rekindled the fire, coaxed the boiler back to life, and set the locomotive in reverse, retracing the iron rails through the snow-laden wilderness.

Now, as the engine’s whistle echoed across the frozen landscape, the men at Fort Kearney understood at last the source of the mysterious sound: the prodigal locomotive, come back from its wild flight, bearing its shaken crew and a tale of peril on the open plain.

Towards two o’clock in the afternoon, while it was snowing hard, long whistles were heard approaching from the east. Through the thick mist, a large, shadowy form with a bright headlight gradually became visible, advancing with a fantastic appearance. No train was expected from that direction, and the relief engine requested earlier had not yet arrived; the next regular train was not due until the following day.

The enigma was soon explained. The approaching locomotive was the very engine that had become detached from the train and had sped away, carrying the unconscious engineer and stoker. After running several miles, the engine had finally slowed and stopped, coming to a halt about twenty miles beyond Fort Kearney as the fire in the furnace died out. The engineer and stoker, having lain insensible for some time, at last recovered their senses. Finding themselves alone in the midst of the prairie with only the locomotive, the engineer could not understand how the separation from the train had occurred, but he suspected that some accident or trouble had befallen it.

Uncertain of the circumstances and aware of the dangers that might still be present, he hesitated to continue on to Omaha. Judging it safer to return, even at the risk of encountering Indians, he rebuilt the fire, raised steam, and set the locomotive in reverse, retracing the track towards Fort Kearney. The whistling that had been heard through the snow was thus explained: it was the returning engine, making its way back to the point where it had been separated from the train.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The travellers were glad to see the locomotive resume its place at the head of the train.

events.text_segment:
The travellers were glad to see the locomotive resume its place at the head of the train. They could now continue the journey so terribly interrupted.
Aouda, on seeing the locomotive come up, hurried out of the station, and asked the conductor, “Are you going to start?”
“At once, madam.”
“But the prisoners, our unfortunate fellow-travellers—”
“I cannot interrupt the trip,” replied the conductor. “We are already three hours behind time.”
“And when will another train pass here from San Francisco?”
“To-morrow evening, madam.”
“To-morrow evening! But then it will be too late! We must wait—”
“It is impossible,” responded the conductor. “If you wish to go, please get in.”
“I will not go,” said Aouda.
Fix had heard this conversation. A little while before, when there was no prospect of proceeding on the journey, he had made up his mind to leave Fort Kearney; but now that the train was there, ready to start, and he had only to take his seat in the car, an irresistible influence held him back. The station platform burned his feet, and he could not stir. The conflict in his mind again began; anger and failure stifled him. He wished to struggle on to the end.
Meanwhile the passengers and some of the wounded, among them Colonel Proctor, whose injuries were serious, had taken their places in the train. The buzzing of the over-heated boiler was heard, and the steam was escaping from the valves. The engineer whistled, the train started, and soon disappeared, mingling its white smoke with the eddies of the densely falling snow.
The detective had remained behind.

The travellers were glad to see the locomotive resume its place at the head of the train. They could now continue the journey so terribly interrupted. Aouda, with tears in her eyes, thanked the brave Americans who had rescued her companion. Fix shook hands with them, but could not restrain a tear. The conductor, who had been searching the train with anxiety, approached Aouda and said:

"Are you going to board, madam? The train is about to start."

"But the prisoners?" asked Aouda.

"We cannot wait any longer," replied the conductor. "We are already three hours behind time."

"When does the next train leave for San Francisco?" asked Aouda.

"To-morrow evening, at half-past six."

"But that will be too late! We must wait!"

"It is impossible. If you wish to go, please get in."

"I will not go," said Aouda.

Fix had heard this conversation. A conflict was going on in his mind. He had thought of leaving the train, but now that it was ready to start, he felt himself riveted to the spot. The struggle recommenced; anger and failure strove within him, but he could not abandon the matter thus. He would see it to the end.

The whistling of the engine and the noise of the steam announced that the train was about to start. The engineer whistled, and the train moved off, its smoke mingling with the falling snow. Fix did not get on the train, and remained at the station.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The travellers were glad to see the locomotive resume its place at the head of the train. The delay, though unavoidable, had made them anxious, for every minute was precious in their race against time. As the engine whistled and the cars began to move, a sense of relief passed through the party. Phileas Fogg, ever composed, merely glanced at his watch, calculating the lost minutes and adjusting his plans accordingly. Passepartout, more demonstrative, could not help but express his satisfaction aloud, exclaiming, "At last! We are off again!" Aouda, though silent, smiled gratefully, her confidence in her companions restored.

The train gathered speed, the rhythmic clatter of the wheels soothing the nerves of the passengers. The vast American landscape rolled by, a blur of prairies and distant mountains. Conversation resumed in the compartment, subdued at first, then growing more animated as the travellers recounted the events of the delay. Colonel Proctor, who had been a source of some tension, now seemed content to let the matter rest, and even offered a few words of apology for his earlier impatience.

As the sun dipped lower in the sky, casting long shadows across the plains, the train pressed on towards its next destination. Fogg, ever vigilant, reviewed the timetable and calculated their expected arrival. Though the delay had cost them precious time, he remained confident that, with luck and perseverance, they could still complete their journey within the allotted eighty days. The spirit of adventure, undiminished by setbacks, carried them forward into the gathering dusk.

events.title: Anxious Night Vigil at Fort Kearney
detailed_summary: Hours went by under dismal, very cold weather conditions.
Fix remained seated and motionless on a station bench, appearing almost asleep.
Aouda, braving the storm, repeatedly left the waiting-room to scan the snowy landscape from the platform's edge.
She strained to see through the mist and listen for any hopeful sound, but found nothing.
Each time, she returned inside, chilled, only to venture out again shortly after, always without success.
Evening arrived, but the rescue party led by Fogg had not returned.
Concerns grew about their whereabouts: Had they encountered the Sioux? Were they lost in the mist?
The fort's commander was worried but attempted to mask his anxiety.
As night deepened, the snowfall lessened, but the cold intensified dramatically.
An absolute silence settled over the plains, unbroken by wildlife.
Throughout the night, Aouda wandered near the plains, filled with dread and imagining countless dangers.
Her suffering during these long hours was immense.
Fix stayed in the same spot, awake but unresponsive.
When a man approached and spoke to him, Fix only shook his head.
The night continued in this state of anxious waiting.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Several hours passed.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Thus the night passed.

events.text_segment:
Several hours passed. The weather was dismal, and it was very cold. Fix sat motionless on a bench in the station; he might have been thought asleep. Aouda, despite the storm, kept coming out of the waiting-room, going to the end of the platform, and peering through the tempest of snow, as if to pierce the mist which narrowed the horizon around her, and to hear, if possible, some welcome sound. She heard and saw nothing. Then she would return, chilled through, to issue out again after the lapse of a few moments, but always in vain.
Evening came, and the little band had not returned. Where could they be? Had they found the Indians, and were they having a conflict with them, or were they still wandering amid the mist? The commander of the fort was anxious, though he tried to conceal his apprehensions. As night approached, the snow fell less plentifully, but it became intensely cold. Absolute silence rested on the plains. Neither flight of bird nor passing of beast troubled the perfect calm.
Throughout the night Aouda, full of sad forebodings, her heart stifled with anguish, wandered about on the verge of the plains. Her imagination carried her far off, and showed her innumerable dangers. What she suffered through the long hours it would be impossible to describe.
Fix remained stationary in the same place, but did not sleep. Once a man approached and spoke to him, and the detective merely replied by shaking his head.
Thus the night passed.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Several hours passed. The weather was very bad, and the snow, falling in large flakes, made the air thick and the ground white. The cold was intense, and the wind, which blew from the north, increased the discomfort of the waiting party. Fix sat motionless on a bench in the station, as if he were asleep. Aouda, despite the storm, left the waiting-room more than once, and, standing on the steps, tried to pierce the mist which hung over the plain; she listened, as if by instinct, for the sound of the returning party. She returned, chilled through, to the room, only to go out again after a few moments, but always in vain. Evening came, and neither Mr. Fogg nor his companions appeared. Where could they be? Had they been attacked by the Sioux, and, being unable to defend themselves, been carried off or slain? The commander of the fort was very uneasy, though he tried to conceal his anxiety. Night came; the snow ceased, but the cold increased. The hours passed slowly. The plain was lost in obscurity, and absolute silence reigned. Nothing was to be seen; nothing to be heard. Aouda, full of sad forebodings, wandered about the station, sometimes going out on the plain, shuddering at the thought of the dangers which Phileas Fogg and his companions might be encountering. Her suffering was dreadful. Fix, still motionless, did not speak. Once a man approached and addressed him, but he only shook his head and did not answer. Thus the night passed.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Several hours passed. The train sped on across the vast Indian plains, the rhythmic clatter of the wheels a steady accompaniment to the thoughts of the passengers. Phileas Fogg sat in his compartment, as composed as ever, his eyes occasionally glancing at his watch, ensuring that every minute was accounted for. Passepartout, meanwhile, could not help but gaze out the window, marveling at the unfamiliar landscape: the endless fields, the distant villages, the occasional herd of cattle crossing the tracks, causing the train to slow for a moment before resuming its relentless pace.

The heat of the day began to wane as the sun dipped lower in the sky, casting long shadows across the countryside. The train made brief stops at small stations, where vendors hurried alongside the carriages, offering fruit, tea, and curious trinkets to the travelers. Passepartout, ever curious, leaned out to purchase a cup of steaming chai, savoring the spicy aroma as he returned to his seat.

As the journey continued, the passengers settled into a quiet routine. Some dozed, lulled by the motion of the train, while others conversed in low tones, sharing stories of their own travels. Fogg remained aloof, his mind focused on the precise schedule he had so meticulously planned. Every so often, he would consult his itinerary, confirming that they were still on track to reach their next destination on time.

Outside, the landscape gradually changed, the lush greenery giving way to rocky outcrops and scattered trees. Night began to fall, and the lamps in the carriages were lit, casting a warm glow over the travelers as the train pressed on into the darkness, carrying Fogg and his companions ever closer to their goal.

events.title: Rescue Party Returns; Train Missed
detailed_summary: At sunrise, visibility improved, allowing objects up to two miles away to be seen.
Fogg's party had gone south, but the southern plains remained empty.
By seven o'clock, the captain, now genuinely alarmed, was unsure how to proceed.
He debated sending another rescue detachment, weighing the risk against the low chance of success.
Just as he decided and was about to order a reconnaissance mission by calling a lieutenant, gunshots were heard.
Soldiers rushed out, interpreting the shots as a possible signal.
Half a mile away, a small group was seen returning in formation.
Phileas Fogg led the group, followed closely by Passepartout and the two other travelers rescued from the Sioux.
The rescuers had engaged the Indians ten miles south of the fort.
Just before the soldiers arrived, Passepartout and his fellow captives had started fighting back; Passepartout had incapacitated three captors with his fists when Fogg and the soldiers intervened.
The returning party was met with joyful celebrations.
Fogg paid the promised reward to the soldiers.
Passepartout remarked to himself about the high cost he represented to his master.
Fix observed Fogg silently, his internal thoughts complex and hard to decipher.
Aouda, overwhelmed with emotion, took Fogg's hand and squeezed it, unable to speak.
Passepartout immediately looked for the train, expecting it to be ready for departure and hoping to make up lost time.
He cried out, asking for the train.
Fix informed him that the train had already left.
Phileas Fogg inquired about the next train.
He was told the next one wouldn't arrive until that evening.
Fogg reacted to this significant delay with his typical calm, acknowledging the fact quietly.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: At dawn, the half-extinguished disc of the sun rose above a misty horizon; but it was now possible to recognise objects two miles off.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Ah!” returned the impassible gentleman quietly.

events.text_segment:
At dawn, the half-extinguished disc of the sun rose above a misty horizon; but it was now possible to recognise objects two miles off. Phileas Fogg and the squad had gone southward; in the south all was still vacancy. It was then seven o’clock.
The captain, who was really alarmed, did not know what course to take.
Should he send another detachment to the rescue of the first? Should he sacrifice more men, with so few chances of saving those already sacrificed? His hesitation did not last long, however. Calling one of his lieutenants, he was on the point of ordering a reconnaissance, when gunshots were heard. Was it a signal? The soldiers rushed out of the fort, and half a mile off they perceived a little band returning in good order.
Mr. Fogg was marching at their head, and just behind him were Passepartout and the other two travellers, rescued from the Sioux.
They had met and fought the Indians ten miles south of Fort Kearney. Shortly before the detachment arrived, Passepartout and his companions had begun to struggle with their captors, three of whom the Frenchman had felled with his fists, when his master and the soldiers hastened up to their relief.
All were welcomed with joyful cries. Phileas Fogg distributed the reward he had promised to the soldiers, while Passepartout, not without reason, muttered to himself, “It must certainly be confessed that I cost my master dear!”
Fix, without saying a word, looked at Mr. Fogg, and it would have been difficult to analyse the thoughts which struggled within him. As for Aouda, she took her protector’s hand and pressed it in her own, too much moved to speak.
Meanwhile, Passepartout was looking about for the train; he thought he should find it there, ready to start for Omaha, and he hoped that the time lost might be regained.
“The train! the train!” cried he.
“Gone,” replied Fix.
“And when does the next train pass here?” said Phileas Fogg.
“Not till this evening.”
“Ah!” returned the impassible gentleman quietly.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: At dawn, the half-extinguished disc of the sun rose above a misty horizon; but it was now possible to recognise objects two miles off. Phileas Fogg and the party he had gone to rescue had disappeared to the south, but the vast plain remained empty. The captain, who was really alarmed, did not know what course to take. Should he send another detachment to the rescue? Should he sacrifice more men, with so little chance of saving those already sacrificed? His hesitation did not last long, however. Calling one of his lieutenants, he was on the point of ordering a reconnaissance, when gunshots were heard. Was it a signal? The soldiers rushed out of the fort, and half a mile off they perceived a little band returning in good order. Mr. Fogg was at their head, and behind him were Passepartout and the two travellers who had been rescued from the Sioux. They had met the Indians ten miles south of the fort. Passepartout and his companions had begun to struggle with their captors, and three of the latter had been felled by the sturdy Frenchman’s fists, when the detachment came up and rescued them. All were welcomed with joyous cries. Phileas Fogg distributed the reward he had promised to the soldiers, while Passepartout, though bruised and battered, could not help remarking that he had cost his master dear. Fix, without saying a word, looked at Mr. Fogg, and it would have been difficult to analyse the thoughts which struggled within him. As for Aouda, she took Mr. Fogg’s hand and pressed it in her own, too much moved to speak. Meanwhile, Passepartout was looking about for the train; he thought it ready to start, and hoped to save the lost time. “The train! the train!” cried he. “Gone,” replied Fix. “And when does the next train leave?” asked Phileas Fogg. “Not till this evening.” Fogg simply replied, “It is all right; we must wait,” and sat down quietly, with the air of a man who had done his duty.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The steamer was now drawing rapidly toward the port of Suez. The land was low and flat, and a few palm-trees, whose tops were visible above the mists, indicated the position of the town. At seven o’clock the Carnatic passed between the breakwaters and entered the harbour. The passengers hurried to the deck, and gazed eagerly at the shore, which they were to leave so soon. 

Phileas Fogg, who had not yet appeared, now came from his cabin, accompanied by Aouda, and followed by Passepartout, who was still pale, but had almost recovered from his illness. Mr. Fogg paid the steward the charges for the passage, and the three, after giving a parting glance to the vessel, went ashore. 

Aouda was dressed in European fashion, and the curious crowd that gathered on the quay could not guess her nationality. Passepartout, with his carpet-bag in hand, followed his master and mistress, and looked about him with wonder. The quay was crowded with natives and foreigners, and the noise and confusion were great. 

Phileas Fogg, after securing a carriage, directed the driver to take them to the railway station. There he learned that the train for Cairo would not leave for an hour. He ordered breakfast, and the little party sat down in a room of the station, and partook of the meal. 

During breakfast, Passepartout could not help but express his admiration for the promptness and regularity with which his master conducted their journey. Aouda, too, was grateful for the care and attention she received. 

At the appointed hour, the train started for Cairo, and the travellers, comfortably seated, looked out at the strange landscape. The journey across the desert was monotonous, but the novelty of the scene kept them interested. Camels and caravans could be seen in the distance, and the sun shone fiercely on the yellow sands. 

Thus, the journey continued, each hour bringing them nearer to their goal, and Phileas Fogg, calm and collected as ever, kept a careful eye on his watch, determined that nothing should delay their progress.

chapters.chapter_title: CHAPTER XXXI. IN WHICH FIX, THE DETECTIVE, CONSIDERABLY FURTHERS THE INTERESTS OF PHILEAS FOGG

events.title: Fix Proposes a Sledge Solution
detailed_summary: Phileas Fogg realizes he is significantly behind schedule, causing distress to Passepartout who feels responsible.
Detective Fix approaches Fogg, confirming the critical importance of reaching New York by the evening of the 11th for the Liverpool steamer.
Fix calculates Fogg is twenty hours late due to the Indian attack, leaving only eight hours to make up.
Fix suggests a novel method to regain the lost time: travel via a sail-powered sledge, an idea proposed to him by a local man.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Phileas Fogg found himself twenty hours behind time.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: It was the man who had spoken to Fix during the night, and whose offer he had refused.

events.text_segment:
Phileas Fogg found himself twenty hours behind time. Passepartout, the involuntary cause of this delay, was desperate. He had ruined his master!
At this moment the detective approached Mr. Fogg, and, looking him intently in the face, said:
“Seriously, sir, are you in great haste?”
“Quite seriously.”
“I have a purpose in asking,” resumed Fix. “Is it absolutely necessary that you should be in New York on the 11th, before nine o’clock in the evening, the time that the steamer leaves for Liverpool?”
“It is absolutely necessary.”
“And, if your journey had not been interrupted by these Indians, you would have reached New York on the morning of the 11th?”
“Yes; with eleven hours to spare before the steamer left.”
“Good! you are therefore twenty hours behind. Twelve from twenty leaves eight. You must regain eight hours. Do you wish to try to do so?”
“On foot?” asked Mr. Fogg.
“No; on a sledge,” replied Fix. “On a sledge with sails. A man has proposed such a method to me.”
It was the man who had spoken to Fix during the night, and whose offer he had refused.

Passepartout, his faithful servant, paced anxiously at his side, wringing his hands in silent remorse for the delays that had beset their journey—delays for which he could not help but feel responsible.

Detective Fix, ever the shadow in their company, approached with a measured step. "Mr. Fogg," he said, "it is imperative that we reach New York by the evening of the 11th. The Liverpool steamer will not wait."

Fogg nodded, his gaze unwavering. "We have lost twenty hours to the misfortune in India. Only eight remain to recover what is lost."

Fix, whose mind was as quick as his purpose was secret, leaned in. "There may yet be a way. A local man has proposed a sledge, fitted with sails, capable of traversing the frozen plains swifter than any train. With favorable winds, we might regain the time."

Passepartout’s eyes widened with hope, while Fogg, ever unflappable, simply replied, "Let us see this sledge at once."

**End of segment.**

Phileas Fogg found himself twenty hours behind time. Passepartout was desperate; Fix, calm but attentive, approached Mr. Fogg as they stood in the station.

“Mr. Fogg,” said Fix, “may I ask you a question?”

“Certainly,” replied Fogg.

“You must reach New York by the evening of the 11th, to catch the steamer for Liverpool, must you not?”

“I must,” answered Mr. Fogg, with his usual composure.

“You have lost twenty hours on the journey?”

“Yes; twenty hours, owing to the stoppage on the line.”

“And now you have only eight hours left to make up?”

“That is so,” said Fogg.

Fix paused, then continued, “A man I met here, a certain Mudge, has a sledge fitted with sails. He assures me it can cross the snowfields to Omaha faster than the train could have taken us. If the wind holds, we may yet reach New York in time.”

Passepartout looked at his master with renewed hope. Mr. Fogg, after a moment’s reflection, simply said, “Let us see this sledge.”

He reviewed his journey, recalling each leg of the trip: the delays in Suez, the storm in the Pacific, the mishap in India, and the unexpected detour through America. Each obstacle had seemed insurmountable, yet he had pressed on, driven by his wager and his unyielding sense of punctuality. Now, with only a few hours left, he believed all was lost. events.title: Inspecting and Hiring the Sail-Sledge
detailed_summary: After Fix indicates the man who proposed the sledge, Fogg approaches him.
Fogg and the American, Mudge, enter a nearby hut.
Inside, Fogg inspects the vehicle: a frame on sledge runners designed for multiple passengers, equipped with a tall mast, a large brigantine sail, a jib-sail, and a rudder.
These sledges are noted for rapid winter travel across frozen plains when trains are snowbound, often matching or exceeding express train speeds.
Fogg quickly makes a deal with Mudge.
Conditions are favorable: a fresh westerly wind and hardened snow.
Mudge is confident he can reach Omaha in hours, allowing Fogg to catch eastward trains.
Fogg decides to take this chance to potentially recover the lost time.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Phileas Fogg did not reply at once; but Fix, having pointed out the man, who was walking up and down in front of the station, Mr. Fogg went up to him.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: It was not impossible that the lost time might yet be recovered; and such an opportunity was not to be rejected.

events.text_segment:
Phileas Fogg did not reply at once; but Fix, having pointed out the man, who was walking up and down in front of the station, Mr. Fogg went up to him. An instant after, Mr. Fogg and the American, whose name was Mudge, entered a hut built just below the fort.
There Mr. Fogg examined a curious vehicle, a kind of frame on two long beams, a little raised in front like the runners of a sledge, and upon which there was room for five or six persons. A high mast was fixed on the frame, held firmly by metallic lashings, to which was attached a large brigantine sail. This mast held an iron stay upon which to hoist a jib-sail. Behind, a sort of rudder served to guide the vehicle. It was, in short, a sledge rigged like a sloop. During the winter, when the trains are blocked up by the snow, these sledges make extremely rapid journeys across the frozen plains from one station to another. Provided with more sails than a cutter, and with the wind behind them, they slip over the surface of the prairies with a speed equal if not superior to that of the express trains.
Mr. Fogg readily made a bargain with the owner of this land-craft. The wind was favourable, being fresh, and blowing from the west. The snow had hardened, and Mudge was very confident of being able to transport Mr. Fogg in a few hours to Omaha. Thence the trains eastward run frequently to Chicago and New York. It was not impossible that the lost time might yet be recovered; and such an opportunity was not to be rejected.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Phileas Fogg did not reply at once; but Fix, having pointed out the man, who was walking up and down in front of the station, Mr. Fogg went up to him. He was an American, named Mudge, and, according to Fix, was a great smuggler of contraband articles. He was, however, the only person at Fort Kearney who could undertake the journey. Fogg approached him, and, without wasting words, explained his need. 

"Are you the man who proposes to take me to Omaha?" he asked.

"Yes," replied Mudge; "are you ready to start?"

"As soon as possible."

"It's a risk, but I can do it. The wind is fresh, the snow is hard, and the sledge is ready."

Fogg and Mudge entered a hut near the station. There, Fogg examined the singular vehicle. It was a frame, mounted on two long, narrow runners, and fitted with a seat for several persons. A mast, twelve feet high, rose from the frame, to which was attached a large brigantine sail. In front, a smaller jib-sail was rigged, and behind, a rudder served to guide the sledge. This contrivance, used in winter for crossing the frozen plains, is propelled by the wind like a ship. When the trains are snowed up, these sledges make rapid journeys, sometimes even outstripping the express trains.

Mudge, who was a bold fellow, was confident that he could reach Omaha in a few hours, if the wind held. Fogg, seeing that the opportunity was favorable, quickly came to terms with him. The price was agreed upon, and, without further delay, preparations were made for departure. Fogg, Fix, and Passepartout took their places on the sledge, and, under the guidance of Mudge, set out at full speed across the snow-covered plain, trusting to the wind and the skill of their driver to recover the time they had lost.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
He approached the man with his usual composure, and, addressing him in a calm, measured tone, inquired, "Are you the guide who is to take me to Allahabad?" The man bowed affirmatively. "I am ready to start," said Mr. Fogg. "It is half-past eight," observed the guide. "We must lose no time." 

Mr. Fogg turned to his companions. "Let us go," he said. Passepartout, who had been anxiously watching the proceedings, hastened to follow his master, while Detective Fix, still keeping up the appearance of a casual acquaintance, fell in with the party. The guide led them to a small, open carriage drawn by two sturdy horses, which stood waiting near the station. Their luggage was quickly stowed away, and in a few moments they were rolling out of the town, leaving the bustling station and its crowds behind them.

The night was clear, and the air cool and refreshing after the heat of the day. The road lay through a country dotted with villages and groves of trees, the silence broken only by the rhythmic hoofbeats of the horses and the occasional cry of a night bird. Mr. Fogg sat quietly, his face betraying no emotion, while Passepartout gazed about him with curiosity and wonder. Fix, meanwhile, kept a watchful eye on his quarry, determined not to lose sight of him for an instant. Thus, the little party pressed on through the Indian night, each occupied with his own thoughts, as they journeyed towards Allahabad.

events.title: Aouda's Loyalty and Fix's Ambiguous Resolve
detailed_summary: Concerned about Aouda's comfort during the exposed sledge journey, Fogg suggests she remain at Fort Kearney with Passepartout, who could escort her to Europe later.
Aouda firmly refuses to be separated from Mr. Fogg.
Passepartout is pleased by her decision, as he doesn't want to leave his master alone with Fix.
The narrative notes the uncertainty of Fix's internal state: whether Fogg's return altered his suspicions or if he still saw Fogg as a cunning criminal nearing the end of his scheme.
Despite any potential shift in opinion, Fix remains committed to his duty and getting the group back to England swiftly.

events.text_segment:
Not wishing to expose Aouda to the discomforts of travelling in the open air, Mr. Fogg proposed to leave her with Passepartout at Fort Kearney, the servant taking upon himself to escort her to Europe by a better route and under more favourable conditions. But Aouda refused to separate from Mr. Fogg, and Passepartout was delighted with her decision; for nothing could induce him to leave his master while Fix was with him.
It would be difficult to guess the detective’s thoughts. Was this conviction shaken by Phileas Fogg’s return, or did he still regard him as an exceedingly shrewd rascal, who, his journey round the world completed, would think himself absolutely safe in England? Perhaps Fix’s opinion of Phileas Fogg was somewhat modified; but he was nevertheless resolved to do his duty, and to hasten the return of the whole party to England as much as possible.

The detective, however, was really inspired by the hope of returning to England with as little delay as possible, and of delivering his man to justice. events.title: The Sledge Journey Begins
detailed_summary: The sledge is prepared for departure at eight o'clock.
The passengers board, bundling themselves in warm travel cloaks.
The two large sails are hoisted.
Propelled by the wind, the sledge glides across the hardened snow at a remarkable forty miles per hour.
The distance to Omaha is about two hundred miles, potentially coverable in five hours if the wind persists.
Barring accidents, arrival in Omaha by one o'clock seems possible.
The narrative remarks on the extraordinary nature of the journey underway.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: At eight o’clock the sledge was ready to start.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: What a journey!

events.text_segment:
At eight o’clock the sledge was ready to start. The passengers took their places on it, and wrapped themselves up closely in their travelling-cloaks. The two great sails were hoisted, and under the pressure of the wind the sledge slid over the hardened snow with a velocity of forty miles an hour.
The distance between Fort Kearney and Omaha, as the birds fly, is at most two hundred miles. If the wind held good, the distance might be traversed in five hours; if no accident happened the sledge might reach Omaha by one o’clock.
What a journey!

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: At eight o’clock the sledge was ready to start. The passengers took their places on it, well wrapped up in furs and cloaks. The two great sails were hoisted, and under the pressure of the wind the vehicle slid over the hard snow with a speed of forty miles an hour. The distance between Fort Kearney and Omaha is at most two hundred miles; if the wind held good, the distance might be traversed in five hours. If no accident happened, the sledge might reach Omaha by one o’clock in the afternoon. What a journey! The travellers, seated side by side, could not speak to each other; the cold, increased by the rapidity at which they were going, cut their faces, and the wind made the sledge creak as if it were about to fly into pieces. The sledge, carried along by an irresistible force, flew over the vast white plain, as if it were being carried through the air.

events.title: High-Speed Sledding Across the Plains
detailed_summary: Bundled together, the travelers find conversation impossible due to the intense cold, which is amplified by their speed.
The sledge moves smoothly, resembling a boat gliding over water.
At times, strong gusts seem to lift the sledge slightly off the ground.
Mudge skillfully steers, maintaining a straight course and correcting any veering tendencies.
All available sails, including a jib and an additional top-mast jib, are deployed to maximize wind power.
The speed is estimated to be at least forty miles per hour.
Mudge expresses confidence in reaching their destination, provided the vehicle doesn't break.
Fogg has incentivized Mudge with a significant reward for timely arrival in Omaha.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The travellers, huddled close together, could not speak for the cold, intensified by the rapidity at which they were going.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Mr. Fogg had made it for Mudge’s interest to reach Omaha within the time agreed on, by the offer of a handsome reward.

events.text_segment:
The travellers, huddled close together, could not speak for the cold, intensified by the rapidity at which they were going. The sledge sped on as lightly as a boat over the waves. When the breeze came skimming the earth the sledge seemed to be lifted off the ground by its sails. Mudge, who was at the rudder, kept in a straight line, and by a turn of his hand checked the lurches which the vehicle had a tendency to make. All the sails were up, and the jib was so arranged as not to screen the brigantine. A top-mast was hoisted, and another jib, held out to the wind, added its force to the other sails. Although the speed could not be exactly estimated, the sledge could not be going at less than forty miles an hour.
“If nothing breaks,” said Mudge, “we shall get there!”
Mr. Fogg had made it for Mudge’s interest to reach Omaha within the time agreed on, by the offer of a handsome reward.

events.title: Prairie Crossing and Passengers' Reflections
detailed_summary: The sledge traverses a vast, flat prairie, described as resembling a frozen sea or lake.
It takes a direct route, shorter than the winding railway line that follows the Platte River.
Mudge isn't concerned about the river as it is frozen solid, presenting no obstacle.
The main risks are identified as potential damage to the sledge or a drop in the wind.
The wind remains strong, causing the mast's metal lashings to vibrate and create a musical sound.
Fogg remarks on the specific musical notes produced by the vibrating lashings, his only words during the trip.
Aouda remains well-protected from the wind within her furs.
Passepartout, face reddened by the cold, starts feeling optimistic about reaching New York in time.
He feels gratitude towards Fix for arranging the sledge but maintains his reserve due to suspicion.
Passepartout deeply reflects on Fogg's selfless act of rescuing him from the Sioux, acknowledging the risk Fogg took with his life and fortune.
While the passengers are lost in their thoughts, the sledge speeds through the deserted, snow-covered landscape.
They pass ghostly trees and encounter wildlife like birds and howling prairie wolves.
Passepartout prepares his revolver as the wolves approach, but the sledge outpaces them, avoiding danger.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The prairie, across which the sledge was moving in a straight line, was as flat as a sea.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Had an accident then happened to the sledge, the travellers, attacked by these beasts, would have been in the most terrible danger; but it held on its even course, soon gained on the wolves, and ere long left the howling band at a safe distance behind.

events.text_segment:
The prairie, across which the sledge was moving in a straight line, was as flat as a sea. It seemed like a vast frozen lake. The railroad which ran through this section ascended from the south-west to the north-west by Great Island, Columbus, an important Nebraska town, Schuyler, and Fremont, to Omaha. It followed throughout the right bank of the Platte River. The sledge, shortening this route, took a chord of the arc described by the railway. Mudge was not afraid of being stopped by the Platte River, because it was frozen. The road, then, was quite clear of obstacles, and Phileas Fogg had but two things to fear—an accident to the sledge, and a change or calm in the wind.
But the breeze, far from lessening its force, blew as if to bend the mast, which, however, the metallic lashings held firmly. These lashings, like the chords of a stringed instrument, resounded as if vibrated by a violin bow. The sledge slid along in the midst of a plaintively intense melody.
“Those chords give the fifth and the octave,” said Mr. Fogg.
These were the only words he uttered during the journey. Aouda, cosily packed in furs and cloaks, was sheltered as much as possible from the attacks of the freezing wind. As for Passepartout, his face was as red as the sun’s disc when it sets in the mist, and he laboriously inhaled the biting air. With his natural buoyancy of spirits, he began to hope again. They would reach New York on the evening, if not on the morning, of the 11th, and there were still some chances that it would be before the steamer sailed for Liverpool.
Passepartout even felt a strong desire to grasp his ally, Fix, by the hand. He remembered that it was the detective who procured the sledge, the only means of reaching Omaha in time; but, checked by some presentiment, he kept his usual reserve. One thing, however, Passepartout would never forget, and that was the sacrifice which Mr. Fogg had made, without hesitation, to rescue him from the Sioux. Mr. Fogg had risked his fortune and his life. No! His servant would never forget that!
While each of the party was absorbed in reflections so different, the sledge flew past over the vast carpet of snow. The creeks it passed over were not perceived. Fields and streams disappeared under the uniform whiteness. The plain was absolutely deserted. Between the Union Pacific road and the branch which unites Kearney with Saint Joseph it formed a great uninhabited island. Neither village, station, nor fort appeared. From time to time they sped by some phantom-like tree, whose white skeleton twisted and rattled in the wind. Sometimes flocks of wild birds rose, or bands of gaunt, famished, ferocious prairie-wolves ran howling after the sledge. Passepartout, revolver in hand, held himself ready to fire on those which came too near. Had an accident then happened to the sledge, the travellers, attacked by these beasts, would have been in the most terrible danger; but it held on its even course, soon gained on the wolves, and ere long left the howling band at a safe distance behind.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
The prairie, across which the sledge was moving in a straight line, was as flat as a sea. It seemed a boundless, frozen plain. The trail, which the sledge was following, was lost in the great white expanse. Not a tree, not a house broke the uniformity of the surface; only the long, black line of the railway, winding away to the south, disclosed the route of the trains. In the distance appeared a few moving black points, which, when nearer, were seen to be large, wild animals—wolves or coyotes—who, attracted by the sledge, pursued it with their long, loping gallop. Passepartout, revolver in hand, kept watch, ready to fire on the marauders if they came too near. But the sledge, impelled by the strong wind, flew on so rapidly that the animals were soon left far behind.

It would have been difficult to imagine a journey more monotonous or more silent. The travelers, wrapped in their furs, were almost invisible in the thick coverings. Only the metallic lashings of the mast, vibrating in the wind, gave forth a musical sound, to which Mr. Fogg called attention, remarking that it was the "A" of the scale. These were the only words he uttered during the journey. Aouda, carefully protected from the cold, looked at the strange landscape, and Passepartout, his face reddened by the sharp air, began to feel more hopeful. He even thanked Fix, who, though he had arranged the sledge, was still the object of his suspicion. Yet Passepartout could not help feeling grateful, and, above all, he reflected on the devotion of his master, who had risked life and fortune to save him from the Sioux. While these thoughts passed through his mind, the sledge sped swiftly over the frozen plain, passing ghostly trees and the occasional flight of birds, until the howling of the wolves was lost in the distance.
