LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
And now what course would Phileas Fogg adopt? It was difficult to imagine. Was the gentleman, who seemed to be so imperturbable, so calm in the face of adversity, about to give up the contest, to renounce the wager, and resign himself to defeat? Or would he, on the contrary, seek some new means of reaching his destination, some untried path to London, in the hope of still accomplishing his journey within the prescribed time?

Phileas Fogg, as always, betrayed no sign of agitation. He stood upon the deck of the Carnatic, his gaze fixed upon the horizon, as if calculating the distance yet to be traversed, the hours yet to be spent. Passepartout, his faithful servant, watched him anxiously, uncertain whether to speak or remain silent. The events of the past days had been a whirlwind: the delays in India, the rescue of Aouda, the pursuit by Detective Fix, and now the unexpected obstacles in Hong Kong. Yet through it all, Mr. Fogg had maintained his composure, his methodical approach to every difficulty.

After a few moments, Fogg turned to Passepartout. "We must not lose time," he said quietly. "The next steamer for Yokohama departs in a few hours. We shall take passage on her."

Passepartout, relieved to have a plan, hurried to make the necessary arrangements. Aouda, who had come to rely on Mr. Fogg's judgment, expressed her gratitude for his continued resolve. Detective Fix, ever watchful, followed their movements with keen interest, determined not to lose sight of his quarry.

The hours passed swiftly. The trio boarded the steamer, their hopes renewed. The sea was calm, the weather fair, and for a time it seemed as though fortune might once again favor the intrepid travelers. Yet, as they sailed eastward, new challenges arose. The ship encountered a violent storm, delaying their progress. Supplies ran low, and the crew grew anxious. Through it all, Phileas Fogg remained steadfast, his eyes ever on the prize.

At last, the coast of Japan appeared on the horizon. The travelers disembarked at Yokohama, weary but undaunted. Fogg wasted no time in seeking out the next means of conveyance. He learned that a steamer bound for San Francisco would depart in two days. Determined not to lose a moment, he set about securing passage, while Passepartout scoured the city for any news or assistance that might aid their journey.

In Yokohama, the travelers encountered a troupe of acrobats preparing for a performance. Passepartout, ever resourceful, joined their ranks in order to earn a little money and, by chance, encountered Fix, who had also arrived in Japan. The detective, still convinced of Fogg's guilt, continued his pursuit, though he could not help but admire the Englishman's tenacity.

Finally, the day of departure arrived. Fogg, Aouda, and Passepartout boarded the steamer for America, their spirits buoyed by the prospect of reaching the next stage of their journey. Though the obstacles had been many, and the dangers great, Phileas Fogg's resolve had never wavered. He would continue onward, ever confident that he would complete his journey around the world in eighty days.

events.title: Burning the Ship for Fuel
detailed_summary: Fogg explains his wager to Speedy: he must reach London by 8:45 PM on December 21st or lose £20,000.
He reminds Speedy that his refusal to go to Liverpool necessitated these actions.
Speedy retorts gleefully that Fogg's predicament earned him $40,000.
Speedy compliments Fogg, saying he has 'something of the Yankee' about him.
Fogg confirms his ownership of the vessel's wooden parts.
Fogg orders the crew to dismantle the interior fittings—seats, bunks, frames—to be used as fuel.
Dry wood is needed to maintain high steam pressure.
The poop deck, cabins, bunks, and spare deck structures are sacrificed on the first day.
On December 19th, the masts, rafts, and spars are burned.
The crew works energetically, feeding the fires.
Passepartout joins in the demolition efforts with great vigor.
A frenzied atmosphere of destruction takes hold as they dismantle the ship.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: You must know that I shall lose twenty thousand pounds, unless I arrive in London by a quarter before nine on the evening of the 21st of December.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: There was a perfect rage for demolition.

events.text_segment:
You must know that I shall lose twenty thousand pounds, unless I arrive in London by a quarter before nine on the evening of the 21st of December. I missed the steamer at New York, and as you refused to take me to Liverpool—”
“And I did well!” cried Andrew Speedy; “for I have gained at least forty thousand dollars by it!” He added, more sedately, “Do you know one thing, Captain—”
“Fogg.”
“Captain Fogg, you’ve got something of the Yankee about you.”
And, having paid his passenger what he considered a high compliment, he was going away, when Mr. Fogg said, “The vessel now belongs to me?”
“Certainly, from the keel to the truck of the masts—all the wood, that is.”
“Very well. Have the interior seats, bunks, and frames pulled down, and burn them.”
It was necessary to have dry wood to keep the steam up to the adequate pressure, and on that day the poop, cabins, bunks, and the spare deck were sacrificed. On the next day, the 19th of December, the masts, rafts, and spars were burned; the crew worked lustily, keeping up the fires. Passepartout hewed, cut, and sawed away with all his might. There was a perfect rage for demolition.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
You must know that I shall lose twenty thousand pounds, unless I arrive in London by a quarter before nine on the evening of the 21st of December. I missed the Carnatic at Hong Kong, and was forced to come on the General Grant, and now, as you refused to take me to Liverpool—'

'And you shall not get there!' replied Andrew Speedy, grinning with delight. 'You have made me lose forty thousand dollars, and I mean to make you lose your twenty thousand pounds!'

'Well, Captain,' said Phileas Fogg, 'if you will be so good as to let me have the use of your vessel—'

'No, sir!'

'But I have bought her.'

'You have bought my vessel?'

'Yes; at a price which you cannot refuse. I have the bill of sale here.'

Andrew Speedy was speechless. He looked at the document, then at Fogg, then at the crew, who were busily engaged in tearing up the deck and cabins. The interior fittings, the bunks, the frames, the seats, all were being carried to the furnace.

'You are not only a bold man, Mr. Fogg,' said Speedy at last, 'but you have something of the Yankee about you.'

'And now,' said Fogg, 'let us get on. The wood, the wood!'

The crew, encouraged by the reward offered by Mr. Fogg, worked energetically. The poop, cabins, bunks, and spare deck structures disappeared on the first day. On the 19th of December, the masts, rafts, and spars were burned. Passepartout, with a hatchet in his hand, cut, tore, and demolished with all his might. A sort of feverish excitement pervaded the ship. The crew, who were not sorry to be paid for this destruction, worked as if they were demolishing a house. The steam was kept up to the highest pressure, and the Henrietta sped onward as if she were a regular transatlantic steamer.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: This sum I have staked upon my word, and I am determined to win it. I must therefore devote myself, body and soul, to your service. I have a strict timetable to follow, and every minute lost may cost me dearly. You, Passepartout, must be ready at all times to obey my instructions without hesitation. Our journey will be long and arduous, and we shall encounter many obstacles along the way. But I have calculated every stage, and I am confident that, with punctuality and perseverance, we shall succeed. Remember, the fate of my wager depends on our promptness. We must not allow ourselves to be delayed by any unforeseen circumstances. I rely on your loyalty and resourcefulness, Passepartout. Together, we shall traverse continents and oceans, braving storms and perils, to reach London in time. Let us prepare at once, for every moment is precious. The world awaits us, and our adventure begins now. Let us depart without delay, for fortune favors the bold.

events.title: Reaching Queenstown and Devising a New Strategy
detailed_summary: By December 20th, the ship is reduced to little more than a flat hull as railings and most of the deck are burned.
They sight the Irish coast and Fastnet Light.
By 10 PM, they are passing Queenstown.
Fogg has only 24 hours left to reach London, the time needed just to get to Liverpool at full steam.
The fuel source (the ship itself) is nearly exhausted.
Captain Speedy expresses sympathy, noting their position opposite Queenstown suggests failure.
Fogg confirms the lights indicate Queenstown.
He inquires about entering the harbour.
Speedy states it will take three hours, possible only at high tide.
Fogg calmly pauses, formulating a final, inspired plan to overcome this setback.
Queenstown is identified as the port where transatlantic mails are offloaded.
These mails travel by express train to Dublin and then by fast boat to Liverpool, saving 12 hours compared to the ships.
Fogg intends to use this same mail route.
By taking this route, he aims to reach Liverpool by noon the next day, allowing enough time to travel to London before his deadline.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The railings, fittings, the greater part of the deck, and top sides disappeared on the 20th, and the “Henrietta” was now only a flat hulk.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Instead of arriving at Liverpool the next evening by the “Henrietta,” he would be there by noon, and would therefore have time to reach London before a quarter before nine in the evening.

events.text_segment:
The railings, fittings, the greater part of the deck, and top sides disappeared on the 20th, and the “Henrietta” was now only a flat hulk. But on this day they sighted the Irish coast and Fastnet Light. By ten in the evening they were passing Queenstown. Phileas Fogg had only twenty-four hours more in which to get to London; that length of time was necessary to reach Liverpool, with all steam on. And the steam was about to give out altogether!
“Sir,” said Captain Speedy, who was now deeply interested in Mr. Fogg’s project, “I really commiserate you. Everything is against you. We are only opposite Queenstown.”
“Ah,” said Mr. Fogg, “is that place where we see the lights Queenstown?”
“Yes.”
“Can we enter the harbour?”
“Not under three hours. Only at high tide.”
“Stay,” replied Mr. Fogg calmly, without betraying in his features that by a supreme inspiration he was about to attempt once more to conquer ill-fortune.
Queenstown is the Irish port at which the transatlantic steamers stop to put off the mails. These mails are carried to Dublin by express trains always held in readiness to start; from Dublin they are sent on to Liverpool by the most rapid boats, and thus gain twelve hours on the Atlantic steamers.
Phileas Fogg counted on gaining twelve hours in the same way. Instead of arriving at Liverpool the next evening by the “Henrietta,” he would be there by noon, and would therefore have time to reach London before a quarter before nine in the evening.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
The railings, fittings, the greater part of the deck, and top sides disappeared on the 20th, and the “Henrietta” was now only a flat hulk. At last they sighted the Irish coast and Fastnet Light. By ten in the evening they were passing Queenstown. Phileas Fogg had only twenty-four hours in which to reach London; and that was the time which was required to reach Liverpool, even if the sea should remain calm all the way. The steam was nearly exhausted, and the hull could not be burned. At this moment Captain Speedy came up to Mr. Fogg, and said, “Well, sir, we are opposite Queenstown.”

“Is that the place where we land the mails?” asked Mr. Fogg.

“Yes,” replied Speedy, “and the tide serves at twelve.”

“Where do the mails go?”

“To Dublin, by the most rapid express, and from there by the swiftest boats to Liverpool. They gain twelve hours by this route.”

“Will you take me on board?”

“Certainly, sir.”

Phileas Fogg calmly paid the captain what was due, and, as the Henrietta could go no farther, he had himself and his party landed at once. He was determined to catch the mail express at Queenstown, and thus gain the time lost. By this means he hoped to reach Liverpool by noon the next day, and London before the expiration of the period allotted for his journey round the world.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text:
The railings, fittings, the greater part of the deck, and top sides disappeared on the 20th, and the “Henrietta” was now only a flat hulk. However, on this day, they sighted the Irish coast and Fastnet Light. By ten o’clock in the evening they passed Queenstown. Phileas Fogg had only twenty-four hours in which to reach London; and that was the exact time required to reach Liverpool, even if the sea remained calm and the steam was kept up. The fuel was nearly exhausted. At this moment Captain Speedy approached Mr. Fogg, and said, with a heavy heart:

“Sir, we are opposite Queenstown.”

“Ah! We are opposite Queenstown?”

“Yes.”

“Can we enter the harbour?”

“Not yet; at high tide only, in three hours.”

“And what time is it now?”

“Ten o’clock.”

“We must wait?”

“Yes; the tide will not serve till one in the morning.”

Phileas Fogg did not reply. It was evident that he had been inspired by a sudden idea. The port of Queenstown was the regular port of call for the transatlantic mail steamers. The mails were landed there, and forwarded by express to Dublin, always ready to start; from Dublin they were carried by the swiftest boats to Liverpool, thus gaining twelve hours on the fastest steamers. This route Phileas Fogg resolved to take. By gaining Queenstown, he would be able to reach Liverpool by noon the next day, and London within the period prescribed by the wager.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The crew worked tirelessly, stripping away every available piece of wood that could be spared without compromising the vessel’s ability to stay afloat. The cabins were dismantled, their panels and doors fed to the insatiable furnace. Even the masts, save for the barest stumps needed for balance, were sacrificed to keep the engines running. The Henrietta, once a proud and sturdy ship, was now reduced to a mere skeleton, her appearance more that of a raft than a seaworthy craft. Yet, under the determined command of Captain Speedy and the relentless urgency of Phileas Fogg, she pressed on through the Atlantic waves.

The weather, fortunately, remained fair, and the sea calm, allowing the makeshift vessel to maintain her course. Passepartout, ever resourceful, assisted the crew in their labors, while Fix kept a wary eye on Fogg, still uncertain of his intentions. Aouda, though anxious, bore the ordeal with quiet fortitude, her faith in Fogg unwavering.

As the days passed, the fuel dwindled, and the Henrietta’s progress slowed. On the morning of the 21st, land was sighted at last—the coast of Ireland, faint on the horizon. A cheer rose from the exhausted crew. With the last scraps of wood burning in the furnace, the Henrietta limped into Queenstown harbor, her journey at an end. Fogg, undaunted, prepared to continue his race against time.

events.title: Arrival in Liverpool and Fogg's Arrest
detailed_summary: The Henrietta reaches Queenstown harbour at 1 AM during high tide.
Fogg warmly shakes hands with Captain Speedy, leaving him on the remains of the ship (still valuable).
Fogg's party (including Aouda and Passepartout) immediately goes ashore.
Fix considers arresting Fogg there but hesitates, experiencing internal conflict and doubt about Fogg's guilt.
Despite his uncertainty, Fix continues to follow Fogg.
The entire group boards the waiting train at 1:30 AM.
They reach Dublin by dawn.
Without delay, they board a fast steamer to Liverpool, which cuts directly through the waves.
Phileas Fogg steps onto the Liverpool quay at 11:40 AM on December 21st.
He is now only six hours away from London.
At this moment of near triumph, Fix approaches Fogg, places a hand on his shoulder, presents his warrant, and confirms his identity.
Fogg affirms he is Phileas Fogg.
Fix declares Fogg arrested in the Queen's name.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The “Henrietta” entered Queenstown Harbour at one o’clock in the morning, it then being high tide; and Phileas Fogg, after being grasped heartily by the hand by Captain Speedy, left that gentleman on the levelled hulk of his craft, which was still worth half what he had sold it for.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “I arrest you in the Queen’s name!”

events.text_segment:
The “Henrietta” entered Queenstown Harbour at one o’clock in the morning, it then being high tide; and Phileas Fogg, after being grasped heartily by the hand by Captain Speedy, left that gentleman on the levelled hulk of his craft, which was still worth half what he had sold it for.
The party went on shore at once. Fix was greatly tempted to arrest Mr. Fogg on the spot; but he did not. Why? What struggle was going on within him? Had he changed his mind about “his man”? Did he understand that he had made a grave mistake? He did not, however, abandon Mr. Fogg. They all got upon the train, which was just ready to start, at half-past one; at dawn of day they were in Dublin; and they lost no time in embarking on a steamer which, disdaining to rise upon the waves, invariably cut through them.
Phileas Fogg at last disembarked on the Liverpool quay, at twenty minutes before twelve, 21st December. He was only six hours distant from London.
But at this moment Fix came up, put his hand upon Mr. Fogg’s shoulder, and, showing his warrant, said, “You are really Phileas Fogg?”
“I am.”
“I arrest you in the Queen’s name!”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The “Henrietta” entered Queenstown Harbour at one o’clock in the morning, it then being high tide; and Phileas Fogg, after being grasped heartily by the hand by Captain Speedy, left that gentleman on the levelled hulk of his craft, which was still worth half what he had sold it for. The party immediately went on shore. Fix was not without his doubts as to the propriety of arresting Fogg at this point; he did not know whether the warrant had arrived, and besides, it was certain that Fogg would not escape him; for he was evidently making for London directly. Fix did not, therefore, arrest him at Queenstown; he resolved to follow him to Liverpool, and thence to London. The party took the train at one-thirty in the morning, and arrived at Dublin at daybreak. Fogg, after having seen that Aouda and Passepartout were comfortably seated, attended to himself the arrangements for the steamer which was to take them to Liverpool. At twenty minutes before noon, the steamer passed the mouth of the Mersey, and Phileas Fogg landed, at last, on the quay at Liverpool, December 21st, at eleven-forty A.M. He was only six hours distant from London. Fix now felt it his duty to arrest Mr. Fogg. He had followed him from country to country, and now that he was on English soil, the warrant was in his hands. He approached Mr. Fogg, and, as he was passing, quietly said, "Mr. Fogg, I arrest you in the Queen’s name!" Phileas Fogg, without betraying surprise, replied, "Are you really arresting me?" "Yes, in the Queen’s name," replied Fix. "I am Phileas Fogg," said that gentleman.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: Phileas Fogg, with Aouda and Passepartout, immediately landed. He hastened to the railway station, and found that a train for Dublin was about to start. Fogg, after securing places, was soon speeding across the green fields of Ireland. At Dublin, he crossed directly to the steamer bound for Liverpool, and, after a rapid passage, arrived in England. It was now the morning of the seventy-ninth day since his departure from London. Fogg, calm and collected, took a cab for the railway station, and, accompanied by his faithful companions, started for the metropolis. The journey was accomplished without accident, and at last, at twenty minutes before nine, the cab stopped before the door of the Reform Club. Fogg paid the driver, and entered the club with a firm step. His heart beat with emotion, but his face betrayed no sign. He had accomplished the journey around the world in eighty days.

chapters.chapter_title: CHAPTER XXXIV. IN WHICH PHILEAS FOGG AT LAST REACHES LONDON

events.title: Fogg Imprisoned; Passepartout's Guilt and Aouda's Distress
detailed_summary: Phileas Fogg found himself incarcerated in the Liverpool Custom House, scheduled for transfer to London.
Upon witnessing his master's arrest, Passepartout nearly attacked Fix but was stopped by police officers.
Aouda was utterly bewildered by the arrest, unable to grasp the reason behind it.
Passepartout explained to Aouda the accusation against Fogg – that he, a man of integrity and bravery, was arrested as a common thief.
The charge horrified Aouda, and realizing her helplessness to aid her protector, she wept profusely.
Fix maintained that arresting Fogg was his duty, irrespective of his guilt or innocence.
Passepartout was struck by the devastating realization that he was responsible for this misfortune.
He agonized over his decision to keep Fix's identity and mission secret from Fogg.

He reasoned that had Fogg been warned, he could have potentially proven his innocence to Fix, or at least prevented the detective from shadowing him at his own expense only to arrest him upon reaching England.
Consumed by guilt and regret, Passepartout wept uncontrollably and felt desperate.
Despite the cold weather, Aouda and Passepartout remained outside the Custom House, both determined to wait and see Fogg again.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Phileas Fogg was in prison.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Neither wished to leave the place; both were anxious to see Mr. Fogg again.

events.text_segment:
Phileas Fogg was in prison. He had been shut up in the Custom House, and he was to be transferred to London the next day.
Passepartout, when he saw his master arrested, would have fallen upon Fix had he not been held back by some policemen. Aouda was thunderstruck at the suddenness of an event which she could not understand. Passepartout explained to her how it was that the honest and courageous Fogg was arrested as a robber. The young woman’s heart revolted against so heinous a charge, and when she saw that she could attempt to do nothing to save her protector, she wept bitterly.
As for Fix, he had arrested Mr. Fogg because it was his duty, whether Mr. Fogg were guilty or not.
The thought then struck Passepartout, that he was the cause of this new misfortune! Had he not concealed Fix’s errand from his master? When Fix revealed his true character and purpose, why had he not told Mr. Fogg? If the latter had been warned, he would no doubt have given Fix proof of his innocence, and satisfied him of his mistake; at least, Fix would not have continued his journey at the expense and on the heels of his master, only to arrest him the moment he set foot on English soil. Passepartout wept till he was blind, and felt like blowing his brains out.
Aouda and he had remained, despite the cold, under the portico of the Custom House. Neither wished to leave the place; both were anxious to see Mr. Fogg again.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Phileas Fogg was in prison. He had been shut up in the Custom House, and he was to be transferred to London the next day. Passepartout, when he saw his master arrested, would have fallen upon Fix had not the policemen prevented him. Aouda was thunderstruck at the suddenness of an event which she could not understand. Passepartout explained to her how it was that the honest and courageous Fogg was arrested as a common malefactor. The young woman’s heart revolted against so heinous a charge, and when she saw that she could do nothing to save her protector, she wept bitterly.

As for Fix, he had arrested Mr. Fogg because it was his duty, whether Mr. Fogg were guilty or not. The thought that he might have been mistaken did not trouble him in the least.

Passepartout was overwhelmed with remorse. He blamed himself, with unceasing bitterness, for not having warned Mr. Fogg. He had had it in his power to apprise him of what was going on, and he had not done so. He might have told him about Fix’s errand, and Fogg would then, no doubt, have given him proofs of his innocence, and would have been able to prevent the detective from following him to the end of the world, only to arrest him, as he did, on English soil. Passepartout wept till he was blind, and felt like blowing his brains out.

Aouda and he passed the night outside the Custom House, in the bitter cold. They did not wish to leave the place; they wished to see Mr. Fogg once more.

Aouda and he passed the night outside the Custom House, in the bitter cold. They did not wish to leave the place; they wished to see Mr. Fogg once more.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Phileas Fogg was in prison. The iron bars of the cell cast long shadows across the cold stone floor, and the air was thick with the scent of damp and despair. Fogg sat on the narrow cot, his posture as upright and composed as ever, though his mind was a tumult of thoughts. He had come so far, traversed continents and oceans, braved storms and delays, all to be thwarted at the very last moment by an accusation he knew to be false.

Passepartout, his faithful servant, paced anxiously outside the cell, wringing his hands and muttering to himself. He could not forgive himself for not having realized sooner the true identity of Detective Fix, whose relentless pursuit had led to this predicament. Aouda, too, was distraught, her eyes red from weeping, her heart heavy with worry for the man who had saved her life and won her affection.

Inside the cell, Fogg remained calm. He knew that time was of the essence. Every minute spent behind bars was a minute lost in his race against the clock. Yet, he refused to give in to despair. He trusted in his friends, in Passepartout’s resourcefulness and Aouda’s devotion. He believed that the truth would come to light, and that justice would prevail.

As the hours ticked by, hope flickered in the darkness. Passepartout raced through the streets, determined to find a way to free his master. The fate of their journey—and perhaps of Fogg’s future—hung in the balance.

events.title: Fogg's Stoicism Under Pressure and the Stakes
detailed_summary: Fogg's predicament seemed catastrophic, occurring just as he neared the completion of his journey.
His arrest was described as fatal to his chances of winning the wager.
Having reached Liverpool at 11:40 AM on December 21st, he needed to be at the Reform Club by 8:45 PM, leaving just over nine hours for a six-hour train journey.
Inside the Custom House detention area, Fogg remained seated on a wooden bench, outwardly calm, still, and showing no signs of anger.
While not resigned, this final setback did not provoke any visible emotional reaction.
The narrative speculates whether he harbored a suppressed, intense rage waiting to erupt.
He sat calmly, his purpose unclear – was he still hopeful, still believing in success despite his imprisonment?
Fogg carefully placed his watch on a table, observing its hands move.
He remained silent, his expression notably fixed and severe.
His situation was framed starkly: innocence meant ruin, guilt meant capture.
The thought of escape might have crossed his mind, as he briefly paced the room.
However, the locked door and heavily barred window offered no obvious escape route.
He resumed his seat and retrieved his journal.
Under the entry for "21st December, Saturday, Liverpool," he added the details: "80th day, 11.40 a.m.," then continued to wait.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: That gentleman was really ruined, and that at the moment when he was about to attain his end.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: On the line where these words were written, “21st December, Saturday, Liverpool,” he added, “80th day, 11.40 a.m.,” and waited.

events.text_segment:
That gentleman was really ruined, and that at the moment when he was about to attain his end. This arrest was fatal. Having arrived at Liverpool at twenty minutes before twelve on the 21st of December, he had till a quarter before nine that evening to reach the Reform Club, that is, nine hours and a quarter; the journey from Liverpool to London was six hours.
If anyone, at this moment, had entered the Custom House, he would have found Mr. Fogg seated, motionless, calm, and without apparent anger, upon a wooden bench. He was not, it is true, resigned; but this last blow failed to force him into an outward betrayal of any emotion. Was he being devoured by one of those secret rages, all the more terrible because contained, and which only burst forth, with an irresistible force, at the last moment? No one could tell. There he sat, calmly waiting—for what? Did he still cherish hope? Did he still believe, now that the door of this prison was closed upon him, that he would succeed?
However that may have been, Mr. Fogg carefully put his watch upon the table, and observed its advancing hands. Not a word escaped his lips, but his look was singularly set and stern. The situation, in any event, was a terrible one, and might be thus stated: if Phileas Fogg was honest he was ruined; if he was a knave, he was caught.
Did escape occur to him? Did he examine to see if there were any practicable outlet from his prison? Did he think of escaping from it? Possibly; for once he walked slowly around the room. But the door was locked, and the window heavily barred with iron rods. He sat down again, and drew his journal from his pocket. On the line where these words were written, “21st December, Saturday, Liverpool,” he added, “80th day, 11.40 a.m.,” and waited.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
That gentleman was really ruined, and that at the moment when he was about to attain his end. This arrest was fatal. Having arrived at Liverpool at twenty minutes before twelve on the 21st of December, he had till a quarter before nine that evening to reach the Reform Club, that is, nine hours and a quarter; the journey from Liverpool to London was six hours.

Phileas Fogg sat motionless, alone, in a sort of waiting-room of the Custom-House. He did not speak to any one. His situation was a terrible one, and might well have made him angry. But he was calm, and if he suffered, he did not show it. He was not, it is true, resigned; but this last blow failed to force from him any sign of emotion.

Was he being devoured by one of those secret rages, all the more terrible because contained, and which only burst forth with an irresistible force at the last moment? No one could tell. There he sat, calm and motionless, watching the hands of his watch, the only evidence of his emotion being the more than usual firmness of his features.

Did he still cherish hope? Did he still believe, now that the door of this prison was closed upon him, that he would succeed? However that may have been, Fogg carefully put his watch upon the table, and observed its advancing hands. Not a word escaped his lips, but his look was singularly set and stern.

The situation was a terrible one, and for a man whose affairs were so precisely regulated, the least delay was ruin. Innocent, he was ruined; guilty, he was captured. Did escape cross his mind? Did he examine the walls of his prison? Did he try the door? There was evidently no escape. The window was heavily barred; the door was massive and double-locked.

After pacing the room for a moment, Fogg sat down again, and, drawing his journal from his pocket, wrote: "21st December, Saturday, Liverpool," and made a note of the time: "80th day, 11.40 a.m." Then he waited.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
He had succeeded in going round the world in eighty days, only to fail by a few hours; and now he was ruined, his fortune lost, his reputation gone, and all for nothing. The blow was terrible. Phileas Fogg, who had so coolly accepted the most trying situations, now felt his heart wrung. He was ruined, and by his own fault. He, a methodical man, had forgotten one detail—the most important of all! He had made a miscalculation of a day. His journey had been accomplished, but he had arrived in London seventy-nine days after his departure, instead of eighty; in other words, he had reached the city twenty-four hours in advance, but, by a fatal mistake, he had thought himself behindhand. This was the cause of his disaster.

It was truly a cruel blow. He had staked everything, and had lost. He sat motionless and silent in his room at Saville Row. Passepartout, crushed by grief, did not dare to speak to his master. Aouda, too, was silent, and looked at Mr. Fogg with an expression of the deepest sympathy. The house in Saville Row, which had been so lively with preparations for the journey, was now plunged in gloom. The servants moved about noiselessly, as if in the presence of a corpse. Mr. Fogg had no heart for anything. He remained in his room, not even caring to look at the newspapers, which were full of his exploit. He had failed, and that was all he could think of.

But in the midst of his despair, Aouda approached him gently, and, with a voice full of emotion, thanked him for all he had done for her. She told him that, whatever his fate, she would never forget his kindness and courage. Her words brought a faint gleam of hope to the heart of the ruined gentleman.

events.title: Unexpected Liberation and Fogg's Retaliation
detailed_summary: As the Custom House clock struck one, Fogg noticed his own watch indicated a time two hours later.
This discrepancy sparked a realization: if he could board an express train immediately, reaching London and the Reform Club by 8:45 PM was still possible, causing a slight furrow in his brow.
At 2:33 PM, a commotion erupted outside, involving raised voices identified as Passepartout's and Fix's.
A flicker of light appeared in Phileas Fogg's eyes.
The door burst open, revealing Passepartout, Aouda, and Fix rushing towards him.
Fix appeared disheveled and out of breath, struggling to speak.
He stammered an apology to Fogg, explaining the arrest was due to a mistaken identity, as the actual bank robber had been apprehended three days earlier.
Fix declared Fogg free.
Upon his release, Phileas Fogg walked directly to the detective.
He stared intently at Fix, then, in an uncharacteristically rapid movement, drew back his arms and punched Fix squarely, knocking him down with mechanical precision.
Passepartout expressed approval of Fogg's action, calling it a fine example of English boxing.
Fix lay on the floor without uttering a word, having received what he deserved.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The Custom House clock struck one.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He had only received his deserts.

events.text_segment:
The Custom House clock struck one. Mr. Fogg observed that his watch was two hours too fast.
Two hours! Admitting that he was at this moment taking an express train, he could reach London and the Reform Club by a quarter before nine, p.m. His forehead slightly wrinkled.
At thirty-three minutes past two he heard a singular noise outside, then a hasty opening of doors. Passepartout’s voice was audible, and immediately after that of Fix. Phileas Fogg’s eyes brightened for an instant.
The door swung open, and he saw Passepartout, Aouda, and Fix, who hurried towards him.
Fix was out of breath, and his hair was in disorder. He could not speak. “Sir,” he stammered, “sir—forgive me—most—unfortunate resemblance—robber arrested three days ago—you are free!”
Phileas Fogg was free! He walked to the detective, looked him steadily in the face, and with the only rapid motion he had ever made in his life, or which he ever would make, drew back his arms, and with the precision of a machine knocked Fix down.
“Well hit!” cried Passepartout, “Parbleu! that’s what you might call a good application of English fists!”
Fix, who found himself on the floor, did not utter a word. He had only received his deserts.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
The Custom House clock struck one. Phileas Fogg was in time. In fact, throughout the journey, he had always regulated his watch by the local time of each country he passed through; and as he was now in England, he naturally set his watch to London time. But his watch showed twenty minutes past two. This discrepancy between the time on his watch and the actual time struck him forcibly. He looked at the clock, then at his watch, and for the first time a suspicion of the truth flashed upon him.

"Why!" he exclaimed, "it's only one o'clock! I have still time to reach the Reform Club!"

He called for a cab. At that moment, a commotion was heard outside, and immediately after, Passepartout burst into the room, followed by Aouda and Fix. Fix was pale, breathless, and his hair was in disorder. He rushed up to Fogg, and in a voice choked with emotion, stammered:

"Sir—Mr. Fogg—I am—so sorry!—I was mistaken—a dreadful mistake—the real robber was arrested three days ago—you are free!"

Phileas Fogg, without saying a word, looked at Fix, and as if moved by a sudden impulse, raised his arms, and with mechanical precision, dealt the detective a blow that sent him sprawling to the floor.

"Well hit!" cried Passepartout. "Parbleu! that's what you might call a good English punch!"

Fix did not utter a word. He had received his deserts.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text:
The Custom House clock struck one. That was the exact hour at which Phileas Fogg had been absolutely due at the Reform Club. He had accomplished the journey round the world in eighty days! To do this he had employed every means of conveyance—steamers, railways, carriages, yachts, trading-vessels, sledges, elephants. The eccentric gentleman had throughout displayed all his marvellous qualities of coolness and exactitude. But at this moment, as he sat in the Custom House, he was still unaware of his success.

He looked at the clock, then at his watch, which showed two hours more than the Custom House clock. The difference between London time and that of the place he had just left had deceived him. He had gained, not lost, a day! If he could now take an express train, he might yet reach the Reform Club by a quarter before nine.

A slight furrow appeared on his brow. At two minutes thirty-three seconds past two, a great noise was heard in the street, with cries and vociferations, which passed through the Custom House. Phileas Fogg’s eyes shone for an instant. The door opened, and Passepartout, Aouda, and Fix rushed in. Fix was out of breath, and his hair was in disorder. He could not speak. "Sir," he stammered, "Mr. Fogg, I am sorry. I was mistaken—a dreadful mistake... the real robber was arrested three days ago. You are free!"

Phileas Fogg, without saying a word, looked at Fix, and, as if moved by a sudden impulse, drew back his arms, and with the precision of an automaton, knocked the detective down.

"Well hit!" cried Passepartout. "Parbleu! that’s what you might call a good English punch!"

Fix did not utter a word. He had received his deserts.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The Custom House clock struck one. Phileas Fogg, punctual as ever, stepped out of the cab and surveyed the bustling quay. The air was thick with the cries of porters and the clatter of luggage carts. Passepartout, his faithful servant, hurried behind, clutching their modest valises. Fogg’s calm demeanor betrayed no hint of the urgency that pressed upon them; every minute was precious, every delay a potential threat to their wager.

As they approached the ticket office, Fogg produced his passport and tickets with practiced efficiency. The clerk, accustomed to the flustered travelers of the hour, was momentarily taken aback by Fogg’s composure. Passepartout, meanwhile, gazed in awe at the great steamship moored nearby, its funnels belching clouds of smoke, ready to depart for the next leg of their journey.

With tickets in hand, they made their way up the gangplank. Fogg paused, glancing at his watch, and nodded in satisfaction. They were precisely on schedule. Passepartout, ever the optimist, whispered, “Monsieur, we shall win the bet yet!”

Fogg offered a rare, slight smile. The adventure was far from over, but for now, the clock’s chime marked another victory in their race against time. The journey continued, relentless and full of promise.

events.title: A Desperate Rush to London Ends in Failure
detailed_summary: Fogg, Aouda, and Passepartout promptly departed the Custom House, hailed a cab, and quickly arrived at the railway station.
Fogg inquired about the availability of an express train to London.
The time was 2:40 PM, but he learned the express had departed at 2:05 PM.
Without hesitation, Fogg requested a special train.
While suitable locomotives were available, railway regulations prevented the special train from leaving before 3:00 PM.
At 3:00 PM, Fogg, having motivated the engineer with the promise of a significant reward, finally set off towards London accompanied by Aouda and Passepartout.
The journey needed to be completed in five and a half hours, a feasible goal if the track remained clear.
However, the train encountered unavoidable delays en route.
When Fogg finally stepped onto the platform at the London terminus, clocks throughout the city were chiming 8:50 PM.
Having successfully traveled around the world, he had arrived five minutes past his deadline.
The bet was lost.

Mr. Fogg, Aouda, and Passepartout left the Custom House without delay, got into a cab, and in a few moments descended at the station.
Phileas Fogg asked if there was an express train about to leave for London. It was forty minutes past two. The express train had left thirty-five minutes before. Phileas Fogg then ordered a special train.
There were several rapid locomotives on hand; but the railway arrangements did not permit the special train to leave until three o’clock.
At that hour Phileas Fogg, having stimulated the engineer by the offer of a generous reward, at last set out towards London with Aouda and his faithful servant.
It was necessary to make the journey in five hours and a half; and this would have been easy on a clear road throughout. But there were forced delays, and when Mr. Fogg stepped from the train at the terminus, all the clocks in London were striking ten minutes before nine.
Having made the tour of the world, he was behind-hand five minutes. He had lost the wager!

chapters.chapter_title: CHAPTER XXXV. IN WHICH PHILEAS FOGG DOES NOT HAVE TO REPEAT HIS ORDERS TO PASSEPARTOUT TWICE

events.title: Fogg's Unseen Return and Calm Acceptance of Ruin
detailed_summary: Phileas Fogg returned to his London home without attracting notice, his house remaining shut as if empty.
After arriving at the station, Fogg instructed Passepartout to buy supplies before proceeding quietly home.
He confronted his financial ruin with characteristic calmness, despite the devastating blow dealt by the detective's actions.
His journey, marked by overcoming obstacles and performing acts of kindness, ended in failure just short of the goal due to an unexpected event.
Very little money remained from his travel funds; his primary fortune, £20,000 at Barings, was owed to his Reform Club associates due to the lost wager.
The immense cost of the journey meant winning wouldn't have brought significant wealth, aligning with his character of betting for honor rather than profit.
The lost wager resulted in his complete financial ruin.
Despite the catastrophe, Fogg had already determined his future actions.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The dwellers in Saville Row would have been surprised the next day, if they had been told that Phileas Fogg had returned home.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Mr. Fogg’s course, however, was fully decided upon; he knew what remained for him to do.

events.text_segment:
The dwellers in Saville Row would have been surprised the next day, if they had been told that Phileas Fogg had returned home. His doors and windows were still closed, no appearance of change was visible.
After leaving the station, Mr. Fogg gave Passepartout instructions to purchase some provisions, and quietly went to his domicile.
He bore his misfortune with his habitual tranquillity. Ruined! And by the blundering of the detective! After having steadily traversed that long journey, overcome a hundred obstacles, braved many dangers, and still found time to do some good on his way, to fail near the goal by a sudden event which he could not have foreseen, and against which he was unarmed; it was terrible! But a few pounds were left of the large sum he had carried with him. There only remained of his fortune the twenty thousand pounds deposited at Barings, and this amount he owed to his friends of the Reform Club. So great had been the expense of his tour that, even had he won, it would not have enriched him; and it is probable that he had not sought to enrich himself, being a man who rather laid wagers for honour’s sake than for the stake proposed. But this wager totally ruined him.
Mr. Fogg’s course, however, was fully decided upon; he knew what remained for him to do.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The dwellers in Saville Row would have been surprised the next day, if they had been told that Phileas Fogg had returned home. His doors and windows were still closed, no appearance of change was visible. After leaving the station, Mr. Fogg had directed Passepartout to purchase some provisions, and quietly returned to his house. He bore his misfortune with his habitual composure, but the blow was a crushing one. He had failed! He, a man of such punctuality and exactness, had been stopped on the very threshold of success by an unforeseen event. The cost of his journey, the sacrifices he had made, the obstacles he had overcome, all had been in vain. The few guineas that remained of his travelling fund were all that was left to him; his twenty thousand pounds, deposited at Baring Brothers, were due to his colleagues of the Reform Club. Even had he won, the sum would not have enriched him, and it was in honour, not in gain, that he had staked his fortune. Now, he was ruined, and he accepted his fate with that calmness which never deserted him. Already he had determined what he would do.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_0.text: The dwellers in Saville Row would have been surprised the next day, if they had been told that Phileas Fogg had returned home. His doors and windows were still closed, no appearance of change was visible. After leaving the station, Mr. Fogg had directed Passepartout to purchase some provisions, and quietly returned to his house. He bore his misfortune with his habitual composure, but the blow was a crushing one. He had failed! He, a man of such punctuality and exactness, had been stopped on the very threshold of success by an unforeseen event. The cost of his journey, the sacrifices he had made, the obstacles he had overcome, all had been in vain. The few guineas that remained of his travelling fund were all that was left to him; his twenty thousand pounds, deposited at Baring Brothers, were due to his colleagues of the Reform Club. Even had he won, the sum would not have enriched him, and it was in honour, not in gain, that he had staked his fortune. Now, he was ruined, and he accepted his fate with that calmness which never deserted him. Already he had determined what he would do.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: The quiet, methodical gentleman, whose habits were as regular as the ticking of a clock, had vanished so suddenly that his absence was still the subject of much speculation among his neighbours. Yet, on that particular morning, the familiar figure of Mr. Fogg might have been seen ascending the steps of his residence, his composure undisturbed, his attire immaculate, as though he had merely taken a brief stroll rather than circumnavigated the globe. Passepartout, his faithful servant, followed closely behind, bearing the marks of fatigue and adventure, but with a look of satisfaction upon his face. The house itself, which had seemed almost deserted during their absence, now stirred with renewed life as Mrs. Aouda, the gracious lady who had accompanied them on their journey, entered with a gentle smile. The neighbours, peering discreetly from behind their curtains, exchanged incredulous glances, unable to reconcile the return of Mr. Fogg with the wild rumours that had circulated in his absence. Inside, the familiar ticking of the great clock in the hall resumed its steady rhythm, as if to welcome its master home. Phileas Fogg, unruffled as ever, took his place in his favourite armchair, and with a slight nod to Passepartout, signalled that all was as it should be once more.

events.title: Household Anxiety and Passepartout's Vigil
detailed_summary: A room was prepared for Aouda, who felt deep sorrow over Fogg's situation.
Aouda perceived from Fogg's few words that he was contemplating a significant, perhaps drastic, plan.
Passepartout, aware of the potential for desperate acts like suicide among determined Englishmen, began to watch his master closely but discreetly.
The servant went to his own room and finally turned off the gas jet that had burned continuously for eighty days.
He discovered a gas bill in the mail, reinforcing his decision to end the costly expense he felt responsible for.
The night passed uneasily; Fogg retired, but his sleep was uncertain.
Aouda remained awake throughout the night.
Passepartout maintained a loyal vigil outside Fogg's room.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: A room in the house in Saville Row was set apart for Aouda, who was overwhelmed with grief at her protector’s misfortune.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Passepartout watched all night, like a faithful dog, at his master’s door.

events.text_segment:
A room in the house in Saville Row was set apart for Aouda, who was overwhelmed with grief at her protector’s misfortune. From the words which Mr. Fogg dropped, she saw that he was meditating some serious project.
Knowing that Englishmen governed by a fixed idea sometimes resort to the desperate expedient of suicide, Passepartout kept a narrow watch upon his master, though he carefully concealed the appearance of so doing.
First of all, the worthy fellow had gone up to his room, and had extinguished the gas burner, which had been burning for eighty days. He had found in the letter-box a bill from the gas company, and he thought it more than time to put a stop to this expense, which he had been doomed to bear.
The night passed. Mr. Fogg went to bed, but did he sleep? Aouda did not once close her eyes. Passepartout watched all night, like a faithful dog, at his master’s door.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: She had been separated from the man to whom she owed so much, and whose fate was now so uncertain. Passepartout did his best to comfort her, but his own heart was heavy. He could not forgive himself for the fatal error which had brought about this disaster. He recounted to Aouda all that had happened, and she listened with deep emotion. The hours passed slowly. Every sound in the house made them start; they expected at every moment to see Mr. Fogg enter, but he did not appear. It was only too evident that he was still detained. Aouda’s anxiety increased as the day wore on. She could not rest; she paced the room, her hands clasped, her eyes filled with tears. Passepartout watched her in silence, sharing her sorrow and remorse.

events.title: Passepartout's Attempted Confession and Fogg's Stoicism
detailed_summary: In the morning, Fogg summoned Passepartout with instructions for breakfast for Aouda and himself.
Fogg indicated he would be busy settling his affairs all day and requested Aouda excuse his absence from meals.
He expressed his intention to speak with Aouda briefly in the evening.
Passepartout, receiving the orders, felt compelled to obey despite his emotional turmoil.
Observing his master's unwavering composure, Passepartout struggled to leave his side.
His heart was heavy with remorse, blaming himself more intensely than ever for the failure of the journey.
He agonized over not warning Fogg about Detective Fix's intentions, believing this omission led directly to the disastrous delay.
Overcome with emotion, Passepartout burst out, asking why Fogg didn't blame him for the failure.
Fogg responded with complete calm, stating he blamed no one, and instructed Passepartout to leave.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Mr. Fogg called him in the morning, and told him to get Aouda’s breakfast, and a cup of tea and a chop for himself.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Go!”

events.text_segment:
Mr. Fogg called him in the morning, and told him to get Aouda’s breakfast, and a cup of tea and a chop for himself. He desired Aouda to excuse him from breakfast and dinner, as his time would be absorbed all day in putting his affairs to rights. In the evening he would ask permission to have a few moment’s conversation with the young lady.
Passepartout, having received his orders, had nothing to do but obey them. He looked at his imperturbable master, and could scarcely bring his mind to leave him. His heart was full, and his conscience tortured by remorse; for he accused himself more bitterly than ever of being the cause of the irretrievable disaster. Yes! if he had warned Mr. Fogg, and had betrayed Fix’s projects to him, his master would certainly not have given the detective passage to Liverpool, and then—
Passepartout could hold in no longer.
“My master! Mr. Fogg!” he cried, “why do you not curse me? It was my fault that—”
“I blame no one,” returned Phileas Fogg, with perfect calmness. “Go!”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Mr. Fogg called him in the morning, and told him to get Aouda’s breakfast, and a cup of tea and a chop for himself. He told him also to let Aouda know that he would like to see her, and that he would be engaged all day in settling his affairs, and begged her to excuse him at table. Passepartout listened to his master without a word, and went out. He was so much overwhelmed with grief, and felt so much remorse for his own conduct, that he could not help bursting into tears. He blamed himself more than ever for the fatal delay which had cost his master the victory. He accused himself, not only of having been the cause of the misfortune, but of not having warned Mr. Fogg in time of the projects of Fix. He had not dared to do so! He was the most miserable of men. Mr. Fogg, however, did not reproach him; and, on leaving the room, Passepartout could not help but go back to his master, and, in a choking voice, ask:

"Monsieur! why do you not blame me? It was my fault that—"

"No, my friend," replied Mr. Fogg, in his usual quiet tone, "you could not foresee what has happened. Leave me, and do not think of it any more."

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: Passepartout obeyed with his usual promptness, though he was still somewhat bewildered by the rapid succession of events that had so recently upended his quiet life. He prepared the breakfast with care, making sure that Aouda would have everything she needed to feel comfortable in the unfamiliar surroundings. The tea was brewed to perfection, and the chop was cooked just as Passepartout liked it, though he found his appetite somewhat diminished by the excitement of their journey. As he set the tray before Aouda, she thanked him with a gentle smile, her gratitude evident in her eyes. Passepartout bowed respectfully, then withdrew to enjoy his own modest meal. Meanwhile, Mr. Fogg sat by the window, consulting his watch and the railway timetable, his calm demeanor unchanged. The morning light filtered softly into the room, promising another day of adventure as the little party prepared to continue their remarkable journey around the world.

events.title: Shared Grief and Fogg's Seclusion
detailed_summary: Passepartout relayed Fogg's message to Aouda.
He confessed his feeling of powerlessness to influence Fogg but suggested Aouda might have some sway.
Aouda doubted her ability to influence the self-contained Fogg, questioning if he ever recognized her deep gratitude or emotions.
She urged Passepartout that Fogg shouldn't be left alone and inquired about the evening meeting, assuming Fogg meant to discuss arrangements for her future in England.
Aouda grew thoughtful, contemplating the situation.
The Saville Row house remained quiet throughout Sunday, resembling an empty dwelling.
Fogg broke his long-standing routine by not leaving for the Reform Club at 11:30 AM.
He saw no reason to go, as his friends would no longer expect him, having missed the deadline the previous evening and lost the wager.
Visiting his bankers was unnecessary; his opponents held his cheque and could claim the £20,000 directly.
Fogg stayed home, sequestered in his room, organizing his affairs.
Passepartout restlessly moved about the house, the hours dragging.
He anxiously listened and peered through his master's keyhole, fearing a terrible event.
His thoughts turned to Fix, but without anger, acknowledging Fix had merely done his duty based on a misunderstanding, unlike Passepartout's own perceived folly.
This self-blame tormented him ceaselessly.
Feeling unable to bear his misery alone, he joined Aouda in her room, sitting silently in a corner, observing her sadly.
Aouda remained lost in thought.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Passepartout left the room, and went to find Aouda, to whom he delivered his master’s message.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Aouda was still pensive.

events.text_segment:
Passepartout left the room, and went to find Aouda, to whom he delivered his master’s message.
“Madam,” he added, “I can do nothing myself—nothing! I have no influence over my master; but you, perhaps—”
“What influence could I have?” replied Aouda. “Mr. Fogg is influenced by no one. Has he ever understood that my gratitude to him is overflowing? Has he ever read my heart? My friend, he must not be left alone an instant! You say he is going to speak with me this evening?”
“Yes, madam; probably to arrange for your protection and comfort in England.”
“We shall see,” replied Aouda, becoming suddenly pensive.
Throughout this day (Sunday) the house in Saville Row was as if uninhabited, and Phileas Fogg, for the first time since he had lived in that house, did not set out for his club when Westminster clock struck half-past eleven.
Why should he present himself at the Reform? His friends no longer expected him there. As Phileas Fogg had not appeared in the saloon on the evening before (Saturday, the 21st of December, at a quarter before nine), he had lost his wager. It was not even necessary that he should go to his bankers for the twenty thousand pounds; for his antagonists already had his cheque in their hands, and they had only to fill it out and send it to the Barings to have the amount transferred to their credit.
Mr. Fogg, therefore, had no reason for going out, and so he remained at home. He shut himself up in his room, and busied himself putting his affairs in order. Passepartout continually ascended and descended the stairs. The hours were long for him. He listened at his master’s door, and looked through the keyhole, as if he had a perfect right so to do, and as if he feared that something terrible might happen at any moment. Sometimes he thought of Fix, but no longer in anger. Fix, like all the world, had been mistaken in Phileas Fogg, and had only done his duty in tracking and arresting him; while he, Passepartout. . . . This thought haunted him, and he never ceased cursing his miserable folly.
Finding himself too wretched to remain alone, he knocked at Aouda’s door, went into her room, seated himself, without speaking, in a corner, and looked ruefully at the young woman. Aouda was still pensive.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Passepartout left the room, and went to find Aouda, to whom he delivered his master's message. 

Madame," he added, "I can do nothing. I have no influence over my master; but you, perhaps—"

"What influence could I have?" replied Aouda. "Mr. Fogg is always so kind, so noble! But he is so inflexible! Do you think he is giving up this contest? Do you think he will let himself be discouraged by a single failure? No! He will not. He will do what he deems his duty. But what will become of me?"

"We must not leave him alone for an instant," said Passepartout. "If anything should happen to him—"

Aouda shuddered at the thought. Throughout this day, Sunday, the house in Saville Row was as if uninhabited, and the silence within was only broken at times by the dull sound of footsteps crossing the floor. Fogg did not leave his room; he did not go, as was his custom, at half-past eleven to the Reform Club. Why should he? His friends no longer expected him, since he had not appeared the evening before as the winner of the wager. He had no reason to visit his bankers, for his adversaries held his cheque for twenty thousand pounds, which they could cash at their pleasure. Fogg had nothing to do but remain at home, and arrange his affairs.

Passepartout wandered about the house like a lost soul, and found himself continually drawn to his master's door. He listened, even peeped through the keyhole, and imagined that he could see Fogg, seated motionless, his face betraying no emotion. What a terrible thing it would be if Fogg were to commit some desperate act! The thought haunted Passepartout, and he reproached himself bitterly for his own stupidity, which had been the cause of all this misfortune. He thought of Fix, but did not blame him; he was only doing his duty, while he, Passepartout, had been the real culprit.

He could not bear his misery alone, and so he went to Aouda, who sat in her room, thoughtful and silent. Passepartout sat down in a corner, without speaking, and looked at her with an air of deep sadness. Aouda was absorbed in her own reflections.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Aouda received Passepartout’s message with a mixture of relief and concern. She had been anxiously awaiting news from Mr. Fogg, her mind troubled by the events that had so rapidly unfolded since their arrival in Liverpool. The prospect of Fogg’s arrest had weighed heavily upon her, and Passepartout’s presence brought a glimmer of hope. 

“Is there any news?” she asked, her voice trembling slightly.

Passepartout, ever loyal and eager to reassure, replied, “Monsieur Fogg is calm, madame. He asks that you do not worry. He will do all in his power to clear himself.”

Aouda nodded, her eyes shining with gratitude. “Thank you, Passepartout. I know he is innocent. We must have faith.”

The faithful servant bowed and withdrew, leaving Aouda to her thoughts. She paced the small sitting room, her mind racing with memories of the journey—the perils they had faced, the kindness and courage Mr. Fogg had shown, and the growing affection she felt for the reserved Englishman. She could not bear the thought of his suffering for a crime he had not committed.

Meanwhile, Passepartout hurried back to the police station, determined to do whatever he could to aid his master. He wracked his brain for any detail that might help prove Fogg’s innocence. The hours passed slowly, each minute seeming an eternity.

At last, the door opened, and Fix entered, his face grave. Passepartout confronted him at once. “Monsieur Fix, you must help us! You know Monsieur Fogg is not the robber. You have followed us all this way—you must know!”

Fix hesitated, the weight of his error pressing upon him. “I… I was only doing my duty,” he stammered. “But now, I see I was mistaken. I will do what I can.”

Together, they set out to gather evidence and appeal to the authorities. Aouda, learning of their efforts, insisted on joining them. Her presence lent strength to their cause, and her earnest pleas moved even the most skeptical officials.

As the day wore on, hope began to flicker anew. The truth, it seemed, could not remain hidden forever. And through it all, Passepartout remained steadfast, determined to see his master vindicated and their journey’s purpose fulfilled.

events.title: Fogg Reveals His Ruin to Aouda
detailed_summary: Around 7:30 PM, Fogg requested to see Aouda and was soon alone with her.
He sat opposite her, displaying no outward emotion, appearing exactly the same calm and impassive man as before his journey.
After a period of silence, he addressed Aouda, asking her forgiveness for bringing her to England under false pretenses.
Aouda attempted to speak, but Fogg asked to continue.
He explained that when he rescued her, he was wealthy and intended to use part of his fortune to ensure her a comfortable and independent life.
He stated plainly that he was now financially ruined.
Aouda acknowledged she knew of his ruin and asked his forgiveness in return, suggesting her presence might have caused delays contributing to his failure.
Fogg countered that leaving her in India was impossible and her safety required bringing her far away from her persecutors.
Aouda observed that Fogg felt obligated not only to save her life but also to secure her future well-being.
Fogg confirmed this but noted circumstances prevented it, offering her the small amount of money he had left.
Aouda inquired about his own future.
Fogg coldly replied that he personally needed nothing.
When asked how he faced his impending fate, he answered simply that he faced it as he always did.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: About half-past seven in the evening Mr. Fogg sent to know if Aouda would receive him, and in a few moments he found himself alone with her.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “As I am in the habit of doing.”

events.text_segment:
About half-past seven in the evening Mr. Fogg sent to know if Aouda would receive him, and in a few moments he found himself alone with her.
Phileas Fogg took a chair, and sat down near the fireplace, opposite Aouda. No emotion was visible on his face. Fogg returned was exactly the Fogg who had gone away; there was the same calm, the same impassibility.
He sat several minutes without speaking; then, bending his eyes on Aouda, “Madam,” said he, “will you pardon me for bringing you to England?”
“I, Mr. Fogg!” replied Aouda, checking the pulsations of her heart.
“Please let me finish,” returned Mr. Fogg. “When I decided to bring you far away from the country which was so unsafe for you, I was rich, and counted on putting a portion of my fortune at your disposal; then your existence would have been free and happy. But now I am ruined.”
“I know it, Mr. Fogg,” replied Aouda; “and I ask you in my turn, will you forgive me for having followed you, and—who knows?—for having, perhaps, delayed you, and thus contributed to your ruin?”
“Madam, you could not remain in India, and your safety could only be assured by bringing you to such a distance that your persecutors could not take you.”
“So, Mr. Fogg,” resumed Aouda, “not content with rescuing me from a terrible death, you thought yourself bound to secure my comfort in a foreign land?”
“Yes, madam; but circumstances have been against me. Still, I beg to place the little I have left at your service.”
“But what will become of you, Mr. Fogg?”
“As for me, madam,” replied the gentleman, coldly, “I have need of nothing.”
“But how do you look upon the fate, sir, which awaits you?”
“As I am in the habit of doing.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
He took a chair opposite to her, and remained silent for a moment. Then, suddenly, "Aouda," said he, "forgive me for bringing you to England. I have been ruined—utterly ruined by the folly of this journey. I can no longer devote to you the portion of my fortune I intended. I am but a poor man. I must ask you, therefore, to pardon me for having led you, unconsciously, into a position so distressing."

"Mr. Fogg," replied Aouda, rising and seizing his hand, "do not speak thus! You, who have saved me, owe me nothing! Surely, if there is any blame, it is mine. Perhaps, if I had not been with you, you would have succeeded."

"No, Aouda, you are not to blame. It was impossible to leave you in the country from which you had fled. You could not have remained in India, and your safety could only be assured by removing you so far that your persecutors could not reach you. If I have been able to do this, I am happy."

"But the future—" said the young woman, in a faltering voice.

"I do not know what it will bring, Aouda. It rests with Providence. But I wish you to be happy. I have little money left, but all that I possess is at your service."

"Mr. Fogg," replied Aouda, gently, "what will become of you?"

"As for me, madam," replied the gentleman, coldly, "I need nothing."

"But how do you look upon the fate which awaits you?"

"As I ought to look at it."

"Whatever it may be," resumed Aouda, "your friends—"

"I have no friends, Aouda," said Fogg, in a tone which betrayed a slight emotion. "I wish to ask you a question."

"What is it?"

Aouda looked at him attentively. The suspense, in which the poor woman had been left, was becoming intolerable.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Phileas Fogg took a seat near the young woman. Aouda looked at him with an expression of deep gratitude. For some moments neither spoke; Fogg, usually so calm and self-possessed, seemed to hesitate, as if seeking the right words. At last he said, in a low voice, "Aouda, I must leave you. I have done all I could for you. I have nothing left to do but to set you free."

Aouda looked at him in surprise. "Leave me, Mr. Fogg? Why do you say that?"

"Because I have failed," he replied. "I have lost my wager, and I am ruined."

Aouda's eyes filled with tears. "Ruined! And because of me?"

"No, not because of you," said Fogg gently. "I have always acted according to my conscience. I have tried to do my duty. But now, I must think of your future. I cannot offer you the life you deserve."

Aouda was silent for a moment, then she said, "Mr. Fogg, do you not see that I owe you everything? My life, my happiness, my hope? If you leave me, I shall be alone in the world."

Fogg looked at her, his composure shaken. "Aouda, I am not worthy of you. I am a ruined man."

Aouda rose and approached him. "You are the noblest of men. If you will not remain with me as my protector, then let me remain with you as your wife."

Phileas Fogg started. He looked at Aouda, and for the first time, his face betrayed emotion. "Aouda," he murmured, "do you truly wish this?"

"Yes," she replied simply.

events.title: Aouda's Proposal and Fogg's Declaration of Love
detailed_summary: Aouda suggested Fogg's friends could help prevent him from facing poverty.
Fogg stated he had no friends.
She then mentioned relatives.
Fogg replied he no longer had any.
Aouda expressed pity for his solitude, remarking that shared sorrow can be easier to bear.
Fogg acknowledged the saying.
Standing and taking his hand, Aouda asked if he desired both a relative and a friend, offering herself as his wife.
Fogg rose, showing uncharacteristic emotion with a light in his eyes and trembling lips.
Aouda observed his reaction, her own gaze conveying sincerity, strength, and devotion.
Her willingness to sacrifice everything for him initially surprised Fogg, then deeply moved him.
He briefly closed his eyes, seemingly overwhelmed.
Upon opening them, he declared simply and profoundly, "I love you!"
He affirmed his love was sacred and complete, dedicating himself entirely to her.
Aouda cried out, clutching his hand to her chest in joy and emotion.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “At least,” said Aouda, “want should not overtake a man like you.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Ah!” cried Aouda, pressing his hand to her heart.

events.text_segment:
“At least,” said Aouda, “want should not overtake a man like you. Your friends—”
“I have no friends, madam.”
“Your relatives—”
“I have no longer any relatives.”
“I pity you, then, Mr. Fogg, for solitude is a sad thing, with no heart to which to confide your griefs. They say, though, that misery itself, shared by two sympathetic souls, may be borne with patience.”
“They say so, madam.”
“Mr. Fogg,” said Aouda, rising and seizing his hand, “do you wish at once a kinswoman and friend? Will you have me for your wife?”
Mr. Fogg, at this, rose in his turn. There was an unwonted light in his eyes, and a slight trembling of his lips. Aouda looked into his face. The sincerity, rectitude, firmness, and sweetness of this soft glance of a noble woman, who could dare all to save him to whom she owed all, at first astonished, then penetrated him. He shut his eyes for an instant, as if to avoid her look. When he opened them again, “I love you!” he said, simply. “Yes, by all that is holiest, I love you, and I am entirely yours!”
“Ah!” cried Aouda, pressing his hand to her heart.

Phileas Fogg, as calm and composed as ever, looked at Aouda with his usual quiet dignity. "Madam," he replied, "I have done only what I considered my duty. Aouda, moved by his stoicism, could not help but feel a deep admiration for the man who had risked so much for her sake. "But you have friends, Mr. Fogg," she insisted gently. "You have me."

Thus, in the quiet of the evening, the three companions found solace in each other's presence, determined to face whatever trials lay ahead with courage and hope.

events.title: Joyful Acceptance and Immediate Wedding Plans
detailed_summary: Passepartout was called and entered the room promptly.
He saw Fogg still holding Aouda's hand and instantly grasped the situation.
His face lit up with immense joy, compared to the brightness of a tropical sun.
Fogg inquired if it was too late that evening to contact Reverend Samuel Wilson of Marylebone parish.
Passepartout beamed, assuring him it was never too late.
The time was noted as five minutes past eight.
Fogg proposed the wedding take place the next day, Monday.
He confirmed this with Aouda, who readily agreed.
Passepartout departed immediately, rushing to make the wedding arrangements with great speed and enthusiasm.

events.text_segment:
Passepartout was summoned and appeared immediately. Mr. Fogg still held Aouda’s hand in his own; Passepartout understood, and his big, round face became as radiant as the tropical sun at its zenith.
Mr. Fogg asked him if it was not too late to notify the Reverend Samuel Wilson, of Marylebone parish, that evening.
Passepartout smiled his most genial smile, and said, “Never too late.”
It was five minutes past eight.
“Will it be for to-morrow, Monday?”
“For to-morrow, Monday,” said Mr. Fogg, turning to Aouda.
“Yes; for to-morrow, Monday,” she replied.
Passepartout hurried off as fast as his legs could carry him.

chapters.chapter_title: CHAPTER XXXVI. IN WHICH PHILEAS FOGG’S NAME IS ONCE MORE AT A PREMIUM ON ’CHANGE

events.title: Shift in Public Opinion and Renewed Interest in Fogg's Wager
detailed_summary: Public perception of Phileas Fogg dramatically changed upon the news that the actual bank thief, James Strand, was apprehended in Edinburgh.
Previously viewed as a fugitive, Fogg was now recognized as an honorable gentleman undertaking a remarkable, precise journey.
Newspapers revisited the wager, reigniting interest among bettors both for and against Fogg.
Trading of "Phileas Fogg bonds" resumed, and new bets were placed, significantly increasing Fogg's standing in financial circles.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: It is time to relate what a change took place in English public opinion when it transpired that the real bankrobber, a certain James Strand, had been arrested, on the 17th day of December, at Edinburgh.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Phileas Fogg’s name was once more at a premium on ’Change.

events.text_segment:
It is time to relate what a change took place in English public opinion when it transpired that the real bankrobber, a certain James Strand, had been arrested, on the 17th day of December, at Edinburgh. Three days before, Phileas Fogg had been a criminal, who was being desperately followed up by the police; now he was an honourable gentleman, mathematically pursuing his eccentric journey round the world.
The papers resumed their discussion about the wager; all those who had laid bets, for or against him, revived their interest, as if by magic; the “Phileas Fogg bonds” again became negotiable, and many new wagers were made. Phileas Fogg’s name was once more at a premium on ’Change.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: It is time to relate what a change took place in English public opinion when it transpired that the real bankrobber, a certain James Strand, had been arrested, on the 17th day of December, at Edinburgh. Then the papers with one consent fell to praising Phileas Fogg’s conduct. His photograph was reprinted, his biography was published, and everything that could be done to honour him was done. The members of the Reform Club were delighted to find that the wager was still in question, and that Fogg’s journey round the world was not a mere wild, eccentric idea, but a serious and practical thing. The bets, which had been suspended, were now resumed with fresh vigour. Bonds were issued, and made their appearance on ’Change. Phileas Fogg’s name was once more at a premium on the market. The five clubs which had set up Fogg’s antagonists, gave up their opposition, and the odds in his favour were largely increased. The excitement was intense.
